reviews.review_text: This game is like that one day when you were sick, so you didn't go to school and your favorite cartoon series was on a 24h marathon, and it was snowing, and it was actually two weeks till christmas, and you were getting your dream Lego set, and you were cuddled in bed, and there was pie, and you just played video games all day and oh my god im crying  Play this game. NOW.

Good game. Kicked me right in the feels with its amazing storytelling. Undertale has it all: memorable characters, an amazing soundtrack, well timed jokes and puns, and more. This game plays with alot of RPG elements and thats what makes it unique. Its nice to see something this clever. UT is a piece of art.      My only problem : bad fandom.  (I'm talking about the bad side of the fandom. Stay away from the bad side to protect your eyes) This review will get downvoted because I said that.

You should totally play this if you enjoy; -Earthbound/Mother/similar genre of old school RPG's -Amazing soundtracks - >internet references -Severe emotional trauma -Crippling paranoia about everything you've done and will potentially do in your miserable span of existence  TL;DR made me an emotional sobbing mess, so all in all 10 outta 10 would delete my biological save file and experience this ♥♥♥♥ all over again.

Pros:  - Amazing music.  - Amazing characters.  - You don't have to kill anyone.  - All problems can be solves without violence.  - Goat mom is so nice.  - You can date a skeleton.  - You can be friendzoned by said skeleton.  - Dogs.  - You can fight a fish woman and then hang out with her later and become friends.  - You help said fish woman and an anime loving lizard dinosaur thing discover their true feelings and get together.  - You can pet the dogs.  - Puns.  - You get to be on TV with a hot robot dude.  - Puzzles  - Quotable and memorable dialogue.  - Pretend date the scientist lizard.  - Mew Mew Kissy Cutie 1 is better than Mew Mew Kissy Cutie 2.  - You can throw a stick and the dogs will catch it.  Cons:  - This game is fictional.

At first when I saw this game I didn't think much of it. All I knew about the game was that there were two cool looking skeletons named Sans and Papyrus. Other than that I thought nothing else of this game. Infact I thought this game was lame in all honesty. So, one day I decided to purchase the game. I thought it was going to be a waste of money. Little did I know this game was going to be the most heart wrenching, intense, emotional game I will ever play in my life. The characters in this game are memberable and relatable. Theres always excitment everywhere you turn. I've been so attached to the characters in this game. When they gave me the option to kill I could never bring myself to it. Even after beating this game I can't bring myself to hurting the characters. WHICH IS SO STRANGE BECAUSE THEY ARE VIDEO GAME CHARACTERS. This just goes to show that this game will make you attach yourself to the characters you interact with. And the underlying theme of this game is incredibly strong. I don't want to reveal it in this review you're just going to have to beat the game and find out for yourself. This game is incredibly powerful and it's totally worth the price. You will be entertained for hours and your heart will be torn into bits and pieces (trust me, my heart was crying so much) If you are still reading this I thank you for your time. Toby Fox and his team did an amazing job on this video game. I've never been happier with a game such as this one. Lastly, Don't judge a book by its cover, as cliche as this sounds, thats what I did and I could've missed out on a great game. That is all I have to say. Have an amazing day:)

It's like when we discovered Cave Story.  But even better.
It's a great game. Go buy it and play it.  If I type anymore it will spoil the experience. The game was spoiled for me, and I do not want others to have the adventure ruined like I did.
If you kill things you, are going to cry. If you kill everything, you are going to cry.  If you spare everything, you are going to cry.   If you play this game, you will cry.

Well. This game honestly took me by surprise.  When I first saw this game, I didn't really think much of it, just another generic 8-bit RPG filled with memes, so I didn't really ever consider playing it. Then, a friend of mine gifted me it, and I didn't want to be rude and put it off, so I thought 'hey why not give it a shot?'  And so I did. Frankly I was surprised at the bullethell aspect of dodging enemy attacks in an RPG game, and I don't really mind bullet hell so I welcomed it. Boss battles are also quite unique as well. They each have their own gimmick that you have to do, IF you want to befriend them. (tip: if you want to, there is always a way to spare absolutely every enemy you encounter in the game, no matter what. You sort of have to do that on your first playthrough if you want to see the True Ending). In terms of attacks, they each put in their own unique twists in an attempt to hinder you. Frankly I really liked how all the bosses mixed it up in terms of attacks and gimmicks. Enemies are pretty interesting too  In terms of story, how should I put this? It takes a while to find its own voice, and the story seemed generic with a mild humourous twist at first. But then I got to the final few parts of the game, and the story REALLY picked up from there. VERY rarely have I ever played a game where I managed to legit feel something for the story and it's characters, and Undertale's finale did exactly just that.  NPC's are also pretty unique. A lot of them I found pretty funny, although some of the attempted humour may not appeal to some people, as they may think it tried too hard. Nevertheless, almost all the NPCs are likeable and have clear distinct personalities.  The soundtrack. The soundtrack is, quite frankly, one of the best aspects of this game. I have not found one track in here that I dislike. Just about every single one I've heard, I've loved. The best ones are the boss themes, a lot of them are a mix between retro and modern. Toby pulled off this combination in an absolutely excellent way, putting this game's soundtrack in my list of the best soundtracks I have ever heard in any videogame  Overall, would I reccomend it? It depends. If you don't mind bullet hell and retro style graphics, then this is definitely the game for you. If you don't like either as much, then I'm not sure if you will enjoy this game, but I still advise to try it out for the story/characters. This is definitely one of the better games I played this year, and I can't wait to see what'll happen if I do different things during different runs.  10/10

Undertale is an RPG game that takes many cliché elements in RPG games and creates it into this new type of game in which, just as the description mentions, you do not have to harm a single soul.   PROS: + Unique type of gameplay + Battles are unlike anything seen before + Surprising elements (planned crashes, (non-harmful) game file issues, etc.) + Many different characteristic entities, all with a very unique behavior + Intriguing artwork + Multiple 'routes' and endings + Great amount of soundtracks + Trading cards with valuable crafting rewards  CONS: - It's not really clear in some battles what you're supposed to do - The protagonist character is rather bland and randomly constructed. It doesn't feel satisfying to be the 'normal guy' in what is best described as a world filled with a colorful mismash of vivid characters - A lot of the game and its areas and transitions make little to no sense - Not exactly story-driven, despite the title being UnderTALE. Rather a loose collection of character dialogues, jokes and interactions that eventually bring you to the end - The further you come in the game, the more it devolves into endless dialogues that really make you want to skip them (for example: the part where Alphys just keeps texting you over and over annoyed me greatly) - You don't do much else than walking around, interacting with characters and having battles  Undertale is a pretty pioneering game when it comes to what we have seen in RPG games already. However, it's not exactly a game for everyone. If the humor didn't catch you, like it didn't with me, chances are you didn't enjoy the game altogether. Despite my generous rating for this game, because I feel that this game is certainly different than your average RPG, I did not enjoy this game a lot because the charm of it simply failed to capture me. Obviously it did click with other people. Even then, I still fail to understand how this game was dominating the gaming market for several months, and seemingly still raging on as I edit this review I typed months ago when the game's afterglow should've ended already.  My rating: 8/10 (read on for more information about this rating. Any more comments about this will get removed)  Edit: I usually don't break character in my reviews, but I want to share a bit of the bad experiences I had with both the game  and  the mentality of the fanbase.  I copied and pasted my review back after a mass fanboy downvoting parade flew over it. It's not really fair to sketch my review off as 'not helpful,' because I give both pros and cons and explain why I don't recommend it. I'm not saying the game is bad or shouldn't be played, but it's not my cup of tea either. I could also just write an awful joke or reference from the game here, like a lot of people do because the crowd deems it 'hilarious,' but that isn't helping anyone, but instead deprives people from helpful reviews that  do  help them getting an insight of what the game is like.  This game enforces some kind of idea that if you don't like the game, you will be found and treated like a heretic and your choice on videogames is suddenly bad. I mean look at the helpful/not helpful ratio of the negative reviews, while most 'singular-line reviews' in the positive section have a 90+ percentage of being 'helpful' (read: completely useless).  I've seen some well-constructed 'not recommended' reviews way better than mine being downvoted beyond belief. This kind of inability to witness people disliking something you love arose in some of my (former) friends and makes me feel like this game is mainly played by teenagers or people who find the hype of randomness and memes hilarious and can't at all take any negativity over it.  Seriously, I have been told these exact words by someone I used to refer to as friend: 'I know what's good for you better than you know yourself.'  Of course, if you don't see yourself in this, you shouldn't feel guilty. I'm not implying that you shouldn't downvote reviews that aren't going further than a few sentences, nor that you shouldn't voice your opinion over it, but instead encourage you to rate and argumentate fairly and considerate. Feel free to downvote mine too if it didn't give you insight or a different perspective. This is all besides the point of this review, but I'd like to have this addressed nevertheless. This seems to play a role in many reviews ever since Steam was invented, and it's a shame.
Amazing characters, awesome music, high replay value and a deep story. 10/10 No but really, it's amazing.

When the credits ended, I stared at the screen for the longest time. I stared so long a dog appeared and just stood under the title. You know, that cute fluffy white one? Then I stared even longer. The dog fell asleep. I managed to keep up my staring for a decent ten minutes after that but nothing else happened. I begrudgingly closed the window. I never played a videogame before that reminded me of how it's better to love and forgive than it is to hate and murder. That's the stuff they teach you kindergarten, but mostly because they don't want all of you arguing over the only box of crayons or the last gummy bear in the jar. This game means so much more. I'm an adult now and I've been struggling with a lot of the themes presented within this work. It was so relevant and so beautifully articulated, I didn't have the heart to do what many of peers are pushing me to do: a Genocide Run. I guess I'm not the hard-hearted person I once thought. I can't even bring myself to kill fictional characters (although I did accidentally kill Toriel on my first try and ended up resetting right away. I felt horrible!), much less hate them. I look at my current life now. There's only one person I truly despise, but this game has shifted my perspective. The anger has turned to pity. This game is the best therapy I've ever had (not that I've been to actual therapy). It's true when they say love when you can. Because we all have such a short time here, whether it's up on the surface or down below. Everyone deserves love and mercy. Sorry for getting so sappy. *cough*

If you have come here for a review of this game then you have come to the wrong place, but if you are looking for a recipe for butterscotch cinnamon pie then your in the right place.  Making the Pie Shell  You will need:  1 1/3 cup flour 1/4 teaspoon salt 1/3 cup sugar 1/2 cup butter (cups of butter, not buttercups) 1 egg yolk 1 tablespoon water 1/4 teaspoon vanilla extract Instructions:  Combine flour, salt, and sugar. Cut in butter, and mix until the consistency is like coarse sand. Mix in egg yolk. Add water and vanilla, and mix until the dough comes together. Form into a thick, flat cylinder. Wrap in plastic and refrigerate (about 30 minutes). Butter a pie tin, and roll out dough to fit in the pan. Crimp edges and prick the bottom all around with a fork. Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (204 degrees C). Gently tuck parchment paper or aluminum foil on top of the dough, and pour about a cup of dried beans or pie weights on top. Bake until golden brown (about 20 minutes). Remove pie weights and let cool, then brush the bottom with milk. Completing the Butterscotch Cinnamon Pie  You will need:  1/4 cup butter 2 cups whole milk 1 cup heavy cream 1/2 + 1/4 cup brown sugar 2 tablespoons water 9 egg yolks 3 tablespoons corn starch 2 teaspoons cinnamon 1 baked pie shell Whip cream Instructions:  Brown the butter in a small sauce pan (heat until bubbles stop and there is a nutty aroma). Heat milk and heavy cream on medium until the edges form bubbles. Heat 1/2 cup brown sugar with water on medium until the bubbles become slow and big. Reduce heat to low. Slowly whisk in brown butter, and then the milk/cream mixture. If there are any caramel lumps, raise heat until they are dissolved. In a bowl, combine remaining brown sugar with yolks, corn starch, and cinnamon. While whisking, stir in half the stove mixture into the bowl (this will prevent the corn starch from lumping). Pour everything back into the pot and raise heat to medium, stirring constantly so the eggs do not scramble. Stir until mixture considerably thickens, and adheres well on the back of your spoon. Whisk to ensure homogeneity, then pour into pie shell. (You may have a little extra left over.) Bake until mixture has set (about 25 minutes, then turn off the oven and leave inside for 20 minutes more). Let cool in the refrigerater (about 1 hour). Serve with whip cream (and enjoy the feeling of your HP being fully restored!).

Edited after true eding ***  In a nutshell, Undertale is one of those games I went in, trying my best to be cynical and proffesional about it and ended up devouring me. Incredibly good and enjoyable despite frustrations  +Absolutely creative. The game seems to never run out of ideas. +Extremely stupid(ly good) writing. Its simple enough for anyone to enjoy but mature when it has to be +Choices matter! Holy ♥♥♥♥, finally! +Lore is deep and well crafted. +Characters have a personality! Havent seen that in a while , I missed games with charisma +Unique fight system that encourages you to think instead of just attacking. Each fight is a puzzle +The themes and overall message changes on your actions, making each player feel specialy involved +Despite bosses are somewhat harsh, you pretty much are deeply invested into winning. That is hard to achive, and Undertale manages to suck you in for that. + The unique fight system ( attack or pacify) adds a layer of possibility for those who want a challange of emotion  +The true ending is , by no doubts, one of the best ive seen  +/- Might be that im a guy who studied humor for years as a cartoonist, but the comedy in Undertale is allright, but falls into a childish category. Puns galore, slapstick and some rather weak lines. There so bad they're good - that kind of mediocre. Maybe thats the point. Still made me chuckle in joy, but I can see many disliking it -/+ THE BOSSES. Holy moly they are a challanging in a bad way. (as stated before, it can be dimished by the investment in the story, but beating them the first time is a grindfest of trial and error) -/+ The unique fight system ( attack or pacify) is flawed, as it can make you waste time doing an action for no results , spending long periods in unnessesary long encounters.  -The fanbase. No, seriously. Avoid Tumblr like the plauge. It can deeply harm your vision of the game . ♥♥♥♥ing hell, avoid TUMBLR because its Damn Tumblr!  9 outta 10. You have to give this game the chance if story-choice driven game are your thing.

I decided to go back and give this game a more serious review, because it really deserves it.  I ended up getting this game in November (around Thanksgiving) of last year, and ever since I've still enjoyed it to this day. Undertale is a game that revolves around a 'choice' system, and the choices you make end up varying the game's ending. As you might have heard, there's 3 main endings - a neutral run, a pacifist run and a genocide run. It follows a sort of puzzle RPG styles while also having a bullet hell style mechanic for combat, which I ended up enjoying. Figuring out how to spare certain characters was a good part of the game for me, and it was pretty interesting. Of course, the plot is incredibly well-written. At the surface, it isn't anything too special, but going deep into it (especially when you do the Pacifist/Genocide runs), there's a lot of twists and turns throughout the game that I won't spoil to keep it's integrity. With the different runs and endings of the game combined with the fun puzzle RPG/bullet hell gameplay, I was able to go back to this game plenty of times since getting it, and to be quite frank I don't regret it. While there are games I still enjoy going back to and playing, this is probably the first that's ever had a real impact on me and given me something to follow.  Sure, the fanbase can be pretty trashy and the game's pretty much everywhere at this point, but if you don't let that spoil the experience for you, then I can easily recommend picking this one up. It's an easy 10/10 from me, with the only real complaint I have being the visuals.  P.S. Alphys is love, Alphys is life.
Game gave me a fear of plants.   + All the hype is justified, amazing story, compelling characters and the game offers a great emotional rollercoaster that makes you laugh, nerd out and well.. sad.

*edit in December 2015* I originally reviewed this game in September, when it had freshly launched and I had just played it. It was a quick, silly, premature review, but it got the point across well enough, so I'm keeping it there; but I wanted to update this a bit to more fully reflect what this game means to me.  This is not just your average flash-in-the-pan popular-for-a-month 'quirky indie game', like some people seem to be assuming. This is not a game that just affected everyone for a moment but will be forgotten tomorrow. Two and a half months later and it's still just as profoundly stuck with everyone I know who's played it, in most cases even moreso than before, as things have settled and we've really had time to think about the game and what makes it so great.  Undertale quite simply has more heart put into it than any game I can think of. Every inch of the game is saturated with so many secrets, easter eggs, wonderful little touches, and signs of the love and care put into the whole package. Every single character, especially the major ones, are so well-designed... the dialogue is so on-point at all times, with immeasurable mountains of optional dialogue you'd have to play through the game dozens of times to see all of... the graphics a simple but charming, and the music is unforgettable. Most of all, though, the game makes you feel emotions. Strongly. I mean running the whole gamut of them, too, even if you just go down one story route. Everything is just so well-done, and even moreso in retrospect after you play the game, look back weeks or months later and realize just how phenomenal it all really was.  Toby is modest to a fault about all this, and some fans are indeed perhaps a bit  overly  enthusiastic -- but there is a reason this game has gotten as much attention as it has. There is a reason it's become so beloved.  Succinctly put, it's my favorite game of all time now. I say this in confidence after months of letting everything sink in; it has officially dethroned Chrono Trigger, after 20 years, as my very favorite video game. So... yeah.  (original review below this line) ----  I wanted to wait until I finished it to review this game, but I honestly can't.  No, really. I rarely feel like playing any game for more than a couple hours at a time anymore; I always have things on my mind, other things I think of that I should or could be doing -- even the absolute best games, even ones I consider favorites, can't keep me hooked and unwilling to move from my seat like this one already has, from the very beginning. Every single save point I thought, 'Maybe I'll take a break now... nahh, just a bit more....' and was glad I stayed. It starts out strange but intriguing, and just gets better and better and better. I don't even care if the rest of the game ended up being trash, I'd still recommend it as the first few hours are absolutely more than worth the miniscule asking price.   It's unlike anything else. It's just too good. Buy it.  *edit after finishing it, via the true good ending* BUY IT.  BUY IT. AND A COPY FOR EVERYONE YOU KNOW.

* Start the game, Name the child after Yourself, Explore Everything, then do what You Wish.  * Play alone, and don't play around people who played Undertale before you if it's possible.  * No matter what,  do not  watch/read about the story or gameplay until you complete the game at least once, (You'll be thankful for it later.)  * Don't worry about what your doing, even if they know.  * Once you complete Undertale,  then  we can talk about the game in detail, and I can explain why I took more then one thousand, one hundred, and sixteen hours of thinking about writing about a game I played a year ago before writing these points down.  *  Have fun and stay determined.

GREAT game, beetween this game and LISA you can see how great an indie game can be if people put effort and heart into it, also the fanbase is huge and incredible, now, lets talk about the game a bit... the story... IS AWESOME, that being said, you can accidentaly play a playthrough were the plot wont be that good (the 'bad' ending) in wich there is not that much story and what is there is mostly for people that are replaying the game, so be sure to play the game several times i am currently during my 5th playthrough and i plan on playing again after i finish it, the gameplay, at a first glance it might look like your typical earthbound like rpg and it kind of is... but with some twist, the battles are done by timing your attack, the best you time is the more damage you do... now the enemy attacs are really interesting, they present itself like it would be on a shoot' em up or a bullet hell kind of game (like touhou games) and it is quite unique and quite challenging some times, thats not all of it there are some enemies that will change this patern again and again during the development of the game, so you wont get bored of it... but there is also another twist on the gameplay you dont need to fight, as the game proudly tells you on the store, you dont have to destroy anyone and i mean ANYONE it doesnt matter how much it looks like you have there is allways a peacfull way out and there is where most of the charm of the games shine, i will expand more on this later, now the music and sound design it is also great you every song is carefully crafted and it fits perectly to whats happening on the game, the sound effects are also good and quite charming (the sound of despair coming out from a broken bike is an example). Now graphics... having in mind that this is a game with 8 bits-like graphics i can say that there are also great, each sprite is well designed and have ton of details, and if not, the minimlistic style fits perfectly what is hapening, now one of the best things if not the best about this game are the characters, every single one is awesome, and loveable and unique and i mean everyone even the most unrelevant characters are charming... you have to make sure to check them and to talk to them and to do everything you can, i cant pick a favorite character i just cant, i love every single one of them. and also i said that the game shines when you choose the peacefull way out and this is because of the characters, when you forgive every single one you are basically making them realice what they are doing or you help them know themselves better, and you are rewarded with really interesting dialogues.   Toby Fox, thanks, i love you and i love undertale  i hardly can say anything bad about the game to be honest... it has a GREAT sense of humor, the story is great, it has a HUGE replayabilty, the characters are lovable, the gameplay is great, the graphics and the sound/music is great too, i have to think hardly about something bad about the game but if i have to say one 'bad' thing about the game is that you can not erase what you do most of the times what i mean by that is that if you kill someone and then repent and load a previous save or restart the game, the game remembers, no matter if you didnt save the game (almost) allways remember, the only thing you can do to really restart the game is by erasing the steam folders that have the data of the game.  i also want to highlight that the game is FULL of secrets, some of wich i am sure are still to be uncover but rest asure the greatly active fanbase will found them all someday i am sure ;)   my score i think is an obvious 10/10 (during my first playthrough i said my score was 9-9.7 but after playing it again i have to give it a perfect score kudos toby fox and thanks for so much)

English ------------ Deutsch  hOI!!!!!! welcom to... my review! Do you wanna have a bad time? ♥Yes - Buy this game. ♥No - Buy this game. bOI!!!!!! Definitely worth checking out, reminds me of 'Earthbound' from the 90s, if you liked it, you'll enjoy Undertale too, it's without a doubt one of the greatest games I have ever played. Undertale has been gaining quite a bit of popularity as of late, and for good reason; IT'S GODLIKE. Allow me to give you a quick rundown of why this is.  As far as the gameplay goes, Undertale is a retro style, Earthbound-ish RPG with some bullet-hell thrown in. It's pretty delicious. But where the game really goes BEAST MODE, is in it's dialogue, humor, Characters, and story.  This all gets even JUICIER when they throw in some cause-and-effect decision making into the mix. Depending on the choices you make throughout the game, even small ones like choosing to either kill a random monster or spare its life, will affect the game in some way. This leads to bunch of different endings and changes to the story that you can witness, and it also leads to a ton of replayability.   Sounds pretty sick, huh? Well, you're dang right.  The soundtrack, especially the boss themes, is comparable to a 5 star steak sauce marinade, which is to say, it is quite good. Speaking of boss fights, Undertale has some of the SICKEST ones i've seen in some time. Many of them put unique twists on the combat style and they are DANG GOOD.  When all is said and done, this game reminds me a lot of that Horse Egg Casserole I ate last week: It looks a little weird at first, but once you get a taste, it gives you a warm satisfying joy in your belly that sticks around for days to come. This is surely a slam dunk worth experiencing.  If Undertale was an earthquake, it would have a magnitude rating in the 7.1-7.9 range, 'Major earthquake. Serious damage.' Thank you for reading this review.
An extremely enjoyable game, certain parts you have to admit you wouldn't like that much. But other than that this game is easily a 10/10 for being such a great game!

There is more heart, ingenuity, love, and DETERMINATION in this one game then there are in most series.  I haven't felt this way about a game in a long time. My favorite 2 RPGs of all time are Earthbound and Mother 3, but Undertale is so much more than that. If you consider yourself and RPG gamer and you have not played Undertale, you should be simply ashamed of yourself.  It is truly something special.

Don't let the graphical style fool you, this game was a labor of love.  Things react to your actual actions as a player, not just dialogue prompts... the NPCs will react in different ways based on seemingly minor things you may or may not have done. There's alternate dialogue everywhere, multiple endings, so many things to find... there's little secrets and hints, and it takes at least two playthroughs to put the important bits together. Little hints and facts you may have picked up from just reading a bookshelf can come back and hit you hard when you learn more about what's going on, for example.  The battles are really interesting as well. There's generally multiple ways to end a conflict, and the dodging mechanics when you're being attacked vary a lot throughout the game and major fights tend to introduce new twists. The fights have a lot of work put into them, much more so than I imagined from seeing the simple Dragon Quest-style view. Everything from the enemy reactions to the sprite changes and animations must have taken a lot of time for each monster, much more work than you usually see anymore.  The game's not very long, you can 'beat it' once in a day if you push... but I think it's well worth getting 'cause there's so much in it to explore when you replay it (to try to avoid spoilers). And yes, all the crying. Like at least 7.46 cryings, assuming correction on the standard deviation of the bawl-o-meter.

I do not know if it simply the hype around this game or what, but it has to be said that out of any game I've played in recent memory this has to be the most enjoyable even if it were to boil down to simply the characters alone. Going in depth on the significance this game holds for me can only go on and on. The story is simple yet complex when you look at how the mechanics relate to the game, there's an underlying message that evokes strong feelings for the player once they realize the nature of their actions and how those actions persist throughout games in this industry without much thought given to them.  Further more the music score in this game has to be my favorite ever conceived. GOTY 2016

Undertale - The friendly RPG where nobody has to die I never heard of this game before until it release on Steam around September 2015 and it seemed to be very popular for some reason. I thought what's the big deal about this game? It look just like an RPG game like EarthBound or Mother 3. So I went to the  Undertale website  [undertale.com]  and try demo. The first minute on demo was really impressive and after I finished the demo I went back to Steam and buy full game and soundtrack bundle instantly, I didn't buy games on steam for full price for long time but I really want to support the developer.  The very first game that make me feel bad for trying to kill monsters Undertale is a truly one of the most heartwarming and very charming story-driven games that I've ever played so far. I was playing normally by killing everything I encounter because that is just how an RPG games played right? but until I fought the first boss    Yes, it's Toriel everyone's beloved goat mom    and suddenly I just realized that I don't want to kill her but I accidentally kill her while trying to lower her hp but she will die if you attack when her hp is less than 1/4 of her full hp and that was the first emotional train that hit me straight into my face when I hear her last word. Well I have not feel so strong of an emotion toward game since the ending of Okami    Amaterasu and Issun farewell scene    anyway I reset that playthrough and start my new playthrough again and surprisingly, some of the characters know I regret my decision and decide to start new playthrough that mean every decisions you made in this game will be save in somewhere in game files and will affect the game unless you wipe your data on your computer.   The gameplay First, it might look like normal RPG game but when you play you will find some humor of this game like you cannot actually sell your items to shopkeepers like in RPG because they don't want to spent money for items that they're never use but there still only one shop that still want to buy your items because they want them and they have a very deep history   'hOI! welcom to da TEM SHOP'   or YES! You can literally date a skeleton! And maybe some events you may think the game crash but actually the game close itself to make it look like game crash. but the most outstandingly design gameplay that very unique is a battle system it still be turn base battle but instead of you and your enemies switch turn attacking each other the game will refer you as a heart that can move around and you control it to dodge enemies attack like a bullet hell game for avoid getting hit and when your turn to act you can choose to attack and kill them or chose 'not' to attack instead if you feel bad for hurting them. This game have main 3 playthroughs, so as I mentioned earlier you can finish the game by killing everything or only kill someone who annoying you or even kill no one at all these playthrough you choose will lead you to different endings.   Story This is the selling point of the Undertale and the reason that I buy this game I really love Undertale's story such an amazing story that filled with good humor, morality and emotional feeling. Sometime they have some silly thing to laugh about or sometime will be moment that my eye cover in tears from very emotional story that make me try not to miss any content in Undertale not just dialogue but everything I suggest when you playing you should inspect everything in the game even it were pile of garbage maybe you might found   an astronaut food  . It really fun to discover secrets in Undertale. As I said some characters know about SAVE system that mean they will know what happened in last playthrough so dialogue will change when you talk to them that make Undertale different form other RPG in Skyrim you can save and killing people just for fun then load save again like nothing happen but in Undertale if you did that some characters will still remember so be caution if you playing on no killing playthrough.   Conclusion If you are not into story rich game don't play it, if you are concern about 'bullet hell dodging thing' because you are not good at it but still want to play the game for story then go and get the game it is not that hard and they have some armor   Temy Armor   to help you progress the game. This game is true morality story you will get what you really deserve at the ending of your playthrough that you choose. The soundtracks are very good too, they really affect the game so for the best experience you should not mute the game I have some moment that shed a few tears from my eye because soundtrack is so good and it fits very well with current story. 10/10 one of best games of all time for me.
Skyrim with morality or Pokemon without animal abuse.

I cannot recommend this game enough. I got it on a whim because a friend posted a really weird picture of a character (later discovered to be Burgerpants) and went 'lol wtf'. So, being curious, I googled.   Honestly? The game didn't look like anything I'd be interested in. I'm not a huge bullet hell fan. But the artwork was so quirky, and the trailer cracked me up a little, so I figured 'why not'?  BEST. MONEY. SPENT.   This game is AMAZING. Fantastic. I cannot lavish it with enough praise. The music, the characters, the twisting storyline - it's all there, and it's all endearing, heartwrenching, memorable. Your actions DO make a difference in the grand scheme of things, and there's all kinds of small hidden bits and pieces you can discover on multiple playthroughs. Characters you think 'oh god, this is going to be obnoxious' you wind up loving, and growing attached to. Theme songs you can't stop playing after you turn off the game.  This game, out of all the ones I've played this year - and that's a lot - has stuck with me vastly. And that's saying something. It seems so simple, and it's just NOT. I can only hope you have the same experience I did, and enjoy it. It's an experience, yo.

This is one of the best games of 2015.   It's not because of the gameplay or the graphics, as they're quite simple yet efficient, or the amazing chiptune music it has, but it's because of the novelty and the experience it offers. The story is superb and the characters are captivating.  There are few games that can mess with your emotions like this one. It's full of memorable moments. Not killing the enemies is much more fun than I thought it could be.  The only bad thing I can say about this game is the fandom (or, to be fair, just a part of it). Sometimes there will be something super clever and unusual that will blow the mind of a lot of people, and some of them can't handle it. It's the kind of the problem that 'My Little Pony: Friendship is Magic', a girls cartoon whose creators decided to put real content instead of the usual bimbo drivel, has. The fans mean well, but if some of them bothers you, just ignore and take the game for what it is.  It's not an expensive game and despite only having up to 30 hours content it's worth the price. And even though the soundtrack is the same price of the game, it might be worth it too.
I won't spoil anything if you just play the game.

Expect to play this all the way through more than twice if you want the full experience; but don't expect it to be the same game on each run.  Proud to have backed this game.

If you're late to the Undertale party like I was, you may only know of this game for some awkward moments, witty one-liners, or even a few memes. Rest assured, they're all here, but there is much more below the surface.  What truly set Undertale apart for me was the overwhelming amount of love and care poured into it. Don't let the graphic style fool you; this game more than makes up for it with its memorable and relatable characters, incredibly catchy soundtrack, consistently unique battles, and an attention to detail that would make any fan of the Mother series proud.  On top of all this, the most engaging aspect of Undertale is the fact that there are always multiple solutions to any problem or opponent you face. The decision is yours to make as a player, and you only have yourself to praise/blame for the results of your actions. This game's unique take on the traditional/expected RPG was wonderfully refreshing.  My only piece of advice if you are considering this game for purchase is to avoid spoilers at all costs. Undertale is a game that is best experienced for yourself!
If you like good writing, good music, good dogs, or having your heart torn to pieces, then I would highly recommend this game.

Undertale is magnificent gift, it is hands down my favorite game of 2015 and Honestly probably my favorite of all time, this is one of the greatest experiences I've had in a very long time. Toby put a lot of love and care into this game and it really shows, I have never been so invested in a story and it's characters in my entire life. Undertale is definitely a game I'm going to continue coming back to every now and then just to revisit all the characters and places I love.  Narratively this game is a paragon of interactive story telling. Every choice you make weighs on your conscious because every connection you make with the characters feels organic. Every character and their dialogue are all so charming it's hard to dislike any of them, even the background and non story important folk have a lot of character to them, the art style while simple is appealing and fit the world nicely. Don't get me started on the sick jams the music is perfectly composed, every part of the soundtrack fits the moment flawlessly really helping bring out the emotion in the scene. I could listen to the OST all day and have and continue to listen to this magnificent soundtrack for years to come.  An RPG where playstyle actually changes the way the story shapes up, depending on whether you go down a pacifist, nuetral or genocidal path, characters, dialogue and places change A LOT, allowing for several playthroughs if so desired. Befriend even your enemies by choosing to just show a little mercy or murder everything if you so desire these options take you on completely different stories. Toby thought of every contingency when it comes to decision making, almost everything has some sort of different dialogue depending on what you do, or don't do.  I wanted to add on some things since I didn't talk about game mechanics: •One warning I would give is that this is NOT a traditional RPG, that term is kind of just sprinkled ontop of the game, the defensive combat mechanic during the entire game is an AVOIDANCE / BULLET HELL type of mechanic and is always in use, so if you're not fond of that type of gameplay or just not very good at it you're better off watching a playthrough. •Linear, if you have a problem with games being linear than yeah that's a thing I guess? I don't count linear as a negative if it's done right. •Some jokes/gags do run on a bit, some characters can be a bit two dimensional with their personality (on a surface level, there's more to them if you play down certain paths), I felt it was written well and honestly I liked them through out the entire game. •Playing the game completely blind is honestly the best way to play the game, not knowing the characters and locations makes everything so much better. •This game isn't for emotionally detached edgelords either, it's a touchy feelsy type of story.    TL;DR: I legitimately have nothing negative to say about Undertale, I have never been so enchanted and enamored by ANYTHING in a very long time. I think about this game every single day, I listen to the music every day, I've lost sleep over how much I love this game and I want to cry. 11/10 Would true reset my mind to experience it all again.  Gonna go lay down while I continue to experience an existential crisis.  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 2016 notes  After playing this game a year later, on the anniversary of its release date, I can honestly say I still feel the same way about it. It's still a really, really good game with fun characters and dialogue, amazing music and a nice story with interesting game mechanics. It's a shame this game gets such a bad reputation because of a lot of rabid fans and its popularity on the internet. Allowing otheres to ruin something beautiful for you is a real shame.   I feel bad for those that didn't get to experience pure, unspoiled, completely blind not knowing any of the characters or music. That experience was so amazing, seeing and learning everything the first time without prior knowledge was well... Magical. Going in knowing nothing was honestly life changing for me, never being able to experience that again is heart wrenching, I truly wish I could.  Even now the game still brings out beautiful emotions other games and media fail to bring out and just makes me really think and want to be a better person. Thank you for everything Toby Fox, you've really inspired me to be more DETERMINED, I can't wait to see what you do next friend!

Undertale is a remarkable game that never disappoints. In addition to its engaging and entertaining take on the worn-out turn-based RPG system, it boasts a wonderful soundtrack, a lovable cast, and laughs and surprises around every corner. It's very rare that a game evokes as much reaction and emotion in me as much as Undertale does, and it does both humor and drama fantastically.  I firmly believe that everyone should at the very least give Undertale a try. It is truly an experience all its own.

After playing through the game a fourth time, and watching my good friend PKG play through the pacifist route, I have decided to change my review from a 9/10 to a 9.5/10. Pretty insignificant change, but this game deserves it. If you'd like to view my old review, I'll be keeping the old one available for your reading pleasure.  Original review published Jan 23 2016:  Undertale is a fantastic, thought provoking, hilarious, depressing, and overall insanely enjoyable game. The music is outstanding (but people need to chill with the whole 'undertale has the best music of all time' thing, it doesn't). It's something you will invest your emotions into, and it knows that. This game will break you. It certainly broke me, I almost felt what humans call 'feelings.' Weird, right? I played this game like a traditional RPG and 2 hours later I felt like a giant piece of ♥♥♥♥. Choices matter. A lot. Everything you do has an impact on the final outcome of the game, and it makes it all the more worth it.   I'm going to give this game the highest rating out of any game I'd played that came out in 2015. I'd almost give this game the highest rating that I've ever given a game. It's fantastic enough to earn a 10/10, but I'm giving it a 9/10. Now that's not bad at all. I've only given one game a 10/10 rating EVER. 9/10 is ♥♥♥♥ing generous coming from someone like me who hates video games. It's my second favorite game to have come out in 2015, ironically sitting behind Killing Floor 2.   So why did I give it a 9/10 I don't hear you ask? Well, the internet has ♥♥♥♥ing RUINED this game. On the game front it has very few, if any flaws AT ALL. It's damned near perfect, However the fanbase and what the internet has made it out to be is just too ♥♥♥♥ing awful to ignore. The Undertale fanbase is so ♥♥♥♥ing awful, that I'd say it's significantly worse than FNAF and Minecraft. The best way I could describe the fanbase is Five Night's at Freddy's fanbase, only 1 year older, and much less mature. It makes sense, trust me. The fans are rabid as ♥♥♥♥, and it turned me off of the game almost entirely. I made a negative comment on an Undertale video that had nothing to do with the game, but a song in the game, and I got a DEATH THREAT because of it. (I'm not kidding,  gyazo.com/feb1e8214b52b33115fa5a271eb41df7  <- screenshot). Memes aren't funny, especially stupid ♥♥♥♥ing video game memes. Also, something being random doesn't make it funny. It's ♥♥♥♥ing stupid when people say the humor is good for being 'random.' And when the internet finally realizes that, the fanbase will be slightly less cancerous than Furious Pete's crotch.   That's really all I can say about the game without spoiling it. And believe me, you don't want this game spoiled for you. I'm glad I bought and played through it before having the game spoiled for me, because this was a truly fantastic experience filled with lovable characters, an outstanding story, a great soundtrack, and one of best senses of humor in a game EVER. Undertale is absolutely 100% worth the money, and I'd recommend it not only to people who like RPG/Bullethell games, but to anybody who likes video games. This is by far one of the best (if not the best) indie games ever made, and it currently sits pretty comfortably at the 12th slot on my personal favorite videogames list.  My name is Storm, and you've just had the pleasure of reading this review.

I've never been one to go out of my way and recommend a game, and even if I did, the chances of it being an RPG are rather slim. That being said, this game has swooped in and earned its spot as my favorite game ever, which is saying something considering I could never quite pick any single title to say its my absolute favorite.  The 'combat' system never gets boring, though if you suck at dodging bullets (like me), it can get a bit tiresome when confronting bosses. The graphic style is pretty cute, what with animated little sprites and what not. The soundtrack is simply DIVINE. Dialogue is funny and quirky, just like the characters you'll run into on your journey.  Its, and I don't say this lightly, probably the best game you'll see in a while.  A warning, should you decide to try this game: It will tug on your heart strings (unless you truly are a monster). I've never had a game have me tear up so much.

Honestly, after beating the game for 7 hours to have the 'happy ending', I cried 3 times because the story is just amazing. It is stunning and incredible. I've never expected to end this way. It started off with some stupid and dumb puzzles. But after that, it drove the player deeper and deeper as the story takes its place and time and affected the players an unprecedented way. That is the factor that makes Undertale a masterpiece. I played a lot of RPGs and this one really makes me turn around and give me an unique story with beautiful gameplay.   *THE SYSTEM OF UNDERTALE Now, when I first saw Flowey ( dat son of a ♥♥♥♥♥ ) almost killed me, all I think is that this game is stupid because all I have to do is move my heart ( i mean my soul ) around like a little ♥♥♥♥♥. However, after sinking my teeth into the game, I realized it's a lot more and its brilliance lies on its simplicity. Undertale expected me to have played RPGs before and played with those conventions in unexpected ways and that clever manipulation of gameplay mechanics adds weight to a story that couldn’t have been told in any other way or medium. That's what I need from RPG games. Make something new! At first, I thought I got that dodging combat mechanics, but after a while, the gameplay started pushing me and players to a limit with these storytelling from characters to characters as the story builds up. Every monsters in the game has its own unique way to deal with, you can fight them or spare them if you want the true pacifist ending, of course. For me, I wanted the true pacifist ending so therefore, I have to flirt, hug, and pet in order not to kill them so that I can spare them. That's it a cool idea. Not only that, the way that I interact with them feels like we were treating each other from I to I. There are tons of jokes relating to anime and even snail jokes that really know how to set up a crowd. Undertale really knows how to predict the players and that's it a factor that I like about Undertale.  * THE WAY MONSTERS WORK The way Undertale builds up the story is hilarious and touching. A lot of hidden messages are putted through out the game. Each of them knows how tell a story about humanity and morality. For example, when I was listening to echo flowers in a hallway that recorded a conversation between two people, I was impressed by it. It was about a monster whose greatest wish was to escape this underground lair to see the view, don't want to share it because she(he) afraid that her( his ) friend might laugh at her ( him ). However, after telling the truth, the friend laughed anyway and it was funny until it said: ' Sorry, it’s just funny… That’s my wish too. '. And from that I was silenced for how honestly these characters were written. Witnessing the depth of monsters's dreams about freedom really a strength of Undertale. Giving the players the exploration of humanity and morality. Talking to them and discovering about them is amazing. I was amazed for how well-developed these characters were written. It just makes me cry because I have to fight them which I don't.   *THE MOST AND OBVIOUS REASON WHY UNDERTALE IS A MASTERPIECE: DETERMINATIONNNNNNNNNNNNNN Of course, games like super meat boy, hotlline miami, dark souls really make us have to say ' wtf ???' and rage quit. Not only that, but they also do something that makes you angrier is showing a text that say ' YOU DIED' which is pretty annoying, right ??? Now, as for Undertale, 'Stay determined' will be the phrase that I will remember for the rest of my life. In Undertale, there are lots of times that I keep dying over and over. Not only that, you can't sell things ( maybe that is the first time we seen in RPG gam, right??? Or maybe dark souls, perhaps ???? ) to the merchants. However, after putting up with it, I have experieced a meaningful story, so many things that I want to explore in Undertale and I don't want to give up. WHY?? DETERMINATION !! I was really entranced by the way characters worked. Some people said this game looks like sh*t. For me, even though the art not that impressive, it is still an amazing game.  * VERDICT I really don't know how to describe this game. I really am. But I can only call it by one word only ' MASTERPIECE '. It really has its own dynamic way to tell a story with great comprehension about RPG players's mindset. I gotta admit that this game will be the game that I will never forget. And because of this game, I AM NOW FILLED WITH DETERMINATION !! 10/10 Would recommend anyone buying it. It's a masterpiece

Even if you think 10 dollars is a bit too expensive for a 6 hour long game - but you will quickly find it is your choice for it to not be the case -   Even if you've been spoiled a part of the game when it blew up the Internet by surprise - I did too, but I still managed to discover things in my playthrough -   Even if you don't like sudden blows of popularity by some indie games that end up becoming passing trends, kind of like Slender of FNAF back in the day - however this game is well above those two, and that could be justified only by the lack of cheap jumpscares -   Even if you're tired of hearing your friends begging you to try it - saying it's the best game ever, or, maybe more realistically, the best game of 2015 -   Even if you can't stand all the memes this game has created - or if you think they will die as quickly as they were shaped -   Even if you think that a game messing up with the player or breaking the fourth wall is nothing new - though with this one, it's on another new level -   Even if you're fed up with indie games with 8-bit graphics - this one has some 16-bit sprites, that's already a plus if you're all about graphics -   Even if you heard songs from the OST a thousand times already - and you only heard the more popular ones, as the entire OST is a gem -   Even if you think that the idea of choices in a video game has no effect on you anymore - though here, it's really your choices that determine if you want to have a good time with this game... or not -   Even if you suppose that the concept of becoming friends with everyone is naive and pointless - that's still, paradoxically, the most fun you will have in the game -   Even if you prefer cats to dogs - and maybe this game will change your mind on that point -  You should, in my opinion, at least try Undertale, or its demo. It's a game that goes far beyond your expectations, and an experience that you will have a hard time to forget.

First of all, I am not a fan of RPGs myself but I do have my own exceptions. Undertale just entered in this list in the past night, as I am writting this review.  In this game, you play in the skin of a human girl that has fell into the depths of a mountain, where there is a world with monsters sealed away from the surface for many years due to a war where humans ended victorious. In order to the monsters be able to return back to the surface, they need a last human soul out of 7... and that's you. What are you going to do? Will you fight back and destroy them?... Or will you spare them with hopes they won't harm you and understand that humans aren't necessairly murderers? Well, you will be pleased to know that you can actually decide which destiny you want in this game: you can optate to kill every monster you find, you can kill ones and give mercy to others and you can give mercy to everyone. And every little action you do in the game has got consequences in the story. This is the only RPG I know where you can win without killing opponents and that was one of the main reasons I got interested in trying out this game. I went for a Pacifist Route as I really did not want to finish the life of the creatures and let survivors thinking that every human is equal and I can guarantee that your actions are rewarded in surprising ways! You also end up getting attached to the most important characters of the game as each has got a different personality and are really memorable!  Now, I will talk about the game by parts and tell what I think about each:  Story - The essence of Undertale's story is simple as I explained above but it is impressive the level of depth it has got as I can really tell that these indie developers have put a lot of thought in it not just by having experienced the game but also by informing myself on the internet about the other kind of consequences it can bring depending of other types of actions you do. There are really many different versions of the story. There's drama but there is also a lot of humour, dark humour and references to japanese culture and I promise that this game will steal you smiles and laughters!  Graphics - Other thing that pleases me in Undertale is the retro aesthetic it has got but this is just a matter of personal taste. They are pleasant and detailed. It interestingly changes to a more minimalist graphism once you enter in a battle. There's a detail that I won't develop a lot as it involves spoilers but there is a point where I really believe you will feel disturbed by the type of visual a certain monster adquires for being distinctively 'out of place'.  Gameplay - In third person it works like a normal RPG: you wander around to explore the environments and you interact with characters to obtain informations. Ocasionally, you will be dragged to battle with a random monster. Fortunately, the encounters are not annoying as they do not appear a lot of times. In battle, you have four options: to fight (a graph appears and a vertical bar passes through it. The more centered the bar is by the moment you press your key, more damage you inflict), to act (this functionality is really interesting as the secondary options that appear really depend of the monster you find, and even in here the creators used a lot of humour!), to use items (like in normal RPGs, items can be used to heal HP or to increase stats) and to give mercy (monsters will be spared from harm but it won't work unless you performed necessary actions in the Act command although this rule only applies to the majority of the monsters). The way battles work has got an original mechanism as I never saw something similar before: your soul is represented with a red heart and inside a limited area you can move it to dodge yourself from enemy attacks that vary a lot. There are occasions where you have your soul limited to specific movements too or that you are exposed to special enemy attacks that force you to either freeze yourself or to move yourself to ensure you don't get harmed. You really need to have dexterity in your fingers as some enemies attacks (especially bosses) can be really difficult to dodge. A note I would like to make is that in case you want to spare every monster, is the fact that every monster you find has got a different way to be 'defeated' and they are not only creative but will also surprise you and make you laugh a lot!  Controls - I don't have got a single complaint in these: they are simple and very sharp. If you are enoughly familiar with playing with a keyboard you won't have any issues.  Sound and music - Just like the graphics, these are retro-like. The sounds are varied and simple. While there is not a lot of different musical tracks in the game I found them pleasant.  Difficulty level - The level of difficulty is progressive and is challenging but not to the point of frustration.  Longevity and replay value - I finished the game in approximately 10 hours but the time of conclusion might vary depending of the player skills and the destiny you choose. It is relatively short, but the fact that your actions change the whole story course gives you extra reasons to consider returning to the game and play it again.   I am really happy that a game like this appeared in an industry overflooded with games with the same selling formulas and same conception formulas. It brought a completely new way to play an RPG and hooks you to the end. I do think the industry needs more games like this as with the technology evolution many game makers seem to forget what's most important in the conception of a videogame: its essence, its soul.   Undertale is a hidden indie gem that deserves recognization. I really can't find any complaint for it as I never found any annoyances in it nor even glitches. And this game can be yours for only 9,99€, a real bargain. Please buy it, it is worth every cent. And spread the word: Determination.

This is is a role-playing game in a truer sense than most other RPGs. Every fight you have has an impact on the story, and changes how the characters in it regard you. It is not a harsh emotional roller-coaster, but unless you're very jaded it will pull at your heart-strings many times!  It is not a terribly difficult game. If you've played a Tohoe shooter, R-Type, or Gradius, then the combat system will not be hard to grasp.  This game allows you to have the most bitter, and most sweet endings. And it will judge you for it, but it is all to tell a very well written intimate story.  If you give it the 4-9 hours it needs to tell that story, your money will be well spent!  Just remember, there's always another option.
If you don't buy this game and experience it at least once in your lifetime...  You're going to have a bad time.

Undertale should be gone into blind, don't look up too much on it. If you haven't played it yet, I would recommend not reading this review or any.  Anyway, Undertale is a very unique game that pulls off uniqueness in a way that isn't just simply overloading the game with non sensical ideas like many indie games that have the same aspiration. It deconstructs RPG formula, & video game formulas in general, while providing a core gameplay component of a hybrid turn based rpg where you try to dodge enemy attacks in a way similar to top down shooters. The game has you questioning video game morality, one way in which by 'humanising' the monsters, & also presenting plenty of humourous writing & a bizarre, humourous world. Undertale also notably has one of the best soundtracks in gaming.  Undertale is not without its flaws though. Obviously, I like the game, love it in fact, but boy is it flawed. The first huge flaw i'll mention in Undertale is the way the game progressed, which is pretty bad thanks to the mix of uber linearity & monopacing. There are many linear JRPG games but Undertale sadly felt linear to the point of being on rails too much of the time. Things to discover off the story path that have gameplay value can be counted with one hand & bits of text & such with no value can be counted with 2. Undertale also felt like it was going 60bpm throughout, imagine a car on cruise control. Only towards the end & in a few boss fights does this rule change. Consequentially you never get to get acquainted with any particular area & immersing yourself in the events taking place in them, the people, etc..., something that all of the greatest RPG games had.  The other major flaw is the structural use & also gross overuse of misdirection humour that the game is practically built upon. It looses it's effect quite quickly due to this, & can be related to the monopacing. Misdirection jokes eventually become things that are tied to the game formula that you would come to expect at regular intervals.  Undertale is far from perfect, & judged purely through an objective lens & quantifiable measurements, it would only be decent at best, but Undertale is an art piece that manages to challenge the foundations of game design. The overall plot is very clever even though the actual script is not the best, the game does some of the best 4th wall related stuff I've seen at the end, & of course, boasts an amazing soundtrack. Not unlike Postal 2, Undertale is important to gaming as an artistic medium despite not being the best it can be as a game, & through a subjective lens, my thoughts on the game would be a solid 8/10. One of the best in 2015 (if not the best).  I focused this review on bad things because a lot of the good is too hard to put into words or impossible to say without spoiling the experience, but I highly recommend giving Undertale a shot.

I do not have it in me to do it. Not after the amazing experience this game has given me.  Everyone should play this game. If you can't afford it, it should be at the top of your birthday wishlist, because the experiences this adventure can and will share with you are well worth the price of admission. There is something here for anyone and everyone. My biggest regret having finished this game is that I don't have to play it anymore, bar a full reset, which I'm not sure if I can do.  Oh, and the OST is great. 10/10

These feelings! What do I do with them?  I can remember the first RPGs I played being Final Fantasy VIII (don't judge). It was different and brought me into the RPG genre. But now I can't go back to it anymore because I believed I fell out of love with this whole genre. The turn based systems bored me to tears, the real time systems became mindless killing just so I could progress the story without having to be stuck on a boss because I didn't grind enough to a certain level. And though I would never admit it out loud there was a part of me that would always questioned my actions in said video game. Subconsciously I could feel myself having this conversation with myself.  'Why are we killing this random solider?'  To which I would reply 'Because they are in my way. ' 'We don't have to kill them.' 'Oh yes we do.' 'Why?' 'Because I won't get any exp and then I'll die to a boss and I won't be able to progress in the game.' -hits the runaway command- 'See why can't you do that more often?' 'I only did that because they were stronger than me and would kill me in one hit! -sigh- Time to go grind...'  When I play an RPG I want to play it for the story. I want to roll around in the lore, really get a good feel for the time, place, and setting in which the game takes place. Some games do this some better than others but for the most part I start to lose intrest the moment the game slaps me with a 'You must be this high a level in order to progress' Now the game won't actually say that but it will be hinted at the moment you come to a boss and die over and over again. I thought I was done with RPGs for good.  THIS THIS GAME CAME ALONG AND TURNED MY WORLD UPSIDE-DOWN  Or rather turned what I thought of a RPG could be upside down...what a pleasant surprise. 'The rpg where nobody has to die, eh?' I thought. I was a bit skeptical and didn't jump into the game right away. Until a Let's player I watch frequently decided to give it a go. I watch the first part of the game, which I heard was basically the tutorial section and was hooked.   HOW DID THE DANG TUTORIAL SECTION MAKE ME CRY?!   It was the tutorial section for Pete's sake the part of just about any RPG that you just want to skip over to get to the good part but that was the trick of this particular game. I CAN'T FIND A BAD PART. There was no time when I just wanted to skip, no part where I was bored. I had to get this game myself and I have no regrets.    Ten minutes into the game I was already invested and the more I played the deeper I feel in love with this game. Every monster is memorable, every character is unique and loveable. I never got board with battles since most of the time I was trying to figure out their problems while dodging their different attack patterns. And even if you chose to attack its never the: push-a-button-and-wait method that I was used to from most RPGs.   Now its really tough to talk about this game without spoiling something so I'll do my best. The multiple endings and hidden secrets add enough to the re-playability but this meta game play feature it also has makes the game makes you wonder just how deep does this rabbit hole go...and the only way to find out is to play it yourself! You will not regret it no matter what your play style is.

Hit all the right notes. All of the humor, charm, and character of the various Mario RPG games and then some. The bullet hell twist on the encounters keeps the gameplay fresh and fun, not to mention the twists and turns that itself takes with a ton of the bosses. The story and writing is also is very self-aware in more ways than one, and in a good way. The 'quirkiness' of certain moments kind of rubbed me the wrong way at first, but in the end I liked a lot of the characters, and loved a good few more. Won me right over. You'll laugh, you'll probably cry, and be intrigued and unsettled by its darker elements. It's got a ton of heart. A lot like Earthbound, like everyone knows, but very much its own thing.  Unless, you'd like to play the game the other way.  Because, as it might be obvious, there is an other way to play this game.  One I've not had the guts to do.  And if that interests you, well...  Just stay determined.  Because you might have a bad time.

Do you wanna have a bad time?  No? Then buy this game...   If you know nothing about this game and have somehow managed to avoid any spoilers, congrats! You have avoided most of the internet by some dubious means. I recommend you buy this game without knowing anything about it. It makes the game much more enjoyable. Immerse yourself and have fun.     If you know about this game and still haven't spent the measly $10 to experience such a wonderful work of art, then just read the tons of positive reviews on Metacritic or watch the first episode of someone's playthrough (I recommend Dodger, a.k.a 'Press Heart to  Continue' on Youtube. 1st episode doesnn't contain any spoilers you should worry about). I promise, you will not be disappointed with your purchase.  Also, this game easily features my favorite OST of all time. Toby Fox put the icing on the cake with his fantastic music.  Pros +Story driven by characters actions in a logical manner. +Lovable characters that really help flesh out the atmosphere +Soundtrack on its own is nothing short of remarkable. Seriously, I can't get enough of the OST! +The games atmosphere adapts to the player's actions in such a striking manner. You'll see ;)  +Witty fighting mechanics make the game difficult when it needs to be.   Cons -'People' rule 34 this. It's disgusting, so just be careful when Googling this game.

This might be the best game i have ever played.  It has an amazing story, filled with characters that will make you care more than you'd think. The story will probably leave you in (deep) thought for a week or two after. You might even realise a thing or two about real life afterwards (i have heard about people who did). I have to admit that the story even made me tear up... no game has ever done that before!  The characters have great personalities. They feel like real people/friends.   What you do with this amazing story and these great characters is up to you. You can choose to kill them all, or go out of your way to not hurt them. But your choices matter in this game, and you cant change them. Starting a new game won't change it. You will have to play all the way through with your choices. I did not want to hurt anyone, but i accidentally did anyway. I felt horrible and the game did not want me to forget what i did. You can do the genocide route, the pacifist route or both, but i have not and will never take the genocide route.   The soundtrack will not disappoint. It is so good that i bought it the day after i finished the game.   There is much more to say about this game, but this review would just turn long and boring if i continued.  I cannot recommend this game enough. You will be missing out on a great experience i you dont play this game.  Be good, and stay determined!

One of the most important morality narratives in games since Bioshock or Spec Ops: The Line, Undertale is the rare breed of game that makes you question why you kill in videogames. It's also charming and fundamentally optimistic, challenging you to be a good person and empathize with your enemy.   The combat system is a frantic, ever-mutating bullet hell that's constantly redefining it's own rules and flipping the script to keep you guessing how to play it. Every enemy is a puzzle to figure out how to make friends and 'win'. You'll cheer up ghosts that fight you with their tears, and sinister turnips that want you to eat your veggies. It's weird, disarming, and puts a smile on the face of a cynic and softens a hardened heart.  Adding to the feelings-fest is an expansive soundtrack that keeps you tapping your foot or wiping tears from your eyes at many of the games critical moments. Honestly, the soundtrack is an achievement in itself. It's filled with distinctive leitmotifs that are tied to characters and themes, with familiar motifs weaving in and out at just the right time. It's beautifully rendered, and part of the reason I bought the game at full price (which I never do).  All in all, if you want to meet some fun characters who you'll slowly grow to love, and reconsider violence in videogames, Undertale is a must-buy.  Cons: the walk speed is very slow, some of the jokes can be grating, and the enviroment art is basic and/or ugly.
Really recommned this game for anyone out there that is lookin for a positive experience.

It is so sad, and so happy. It is silly, and scary. Even the villian isn't even that bad once you get to know him ;)  Undertale. A game from start, to finish. A game of Life, and Death. A game of Sadness, and Happiness. A game of LOVE, and love.  It's been great, UNDERTALE. It really was. Goodnight.
