Occasionally in this world, one will stumble across a story; a tale so wonderfully perfect, so amazingly beautiful, so remarkably incredible, that touches the soul. A tale so powerfully moving, that it can reach out and touch one's very being. In the scheme of things, the touch is small, the contact brief. The same cannot be said of the impact the contact has. Stories like that stay with one, they become a part of them. A piece of the soul will always and forever hold that beauty, that wonder, that the tale imparted upon it.  Ladies and gentlemen, Undertale is this sort of story.

It took me far too long to finally play this game. I just saw so much hype it was bit too much for me. However, I was still interested, and still wanted to play it. A kind soul gave it to me as a gift, and so I decided to finally play it.  It all seemd rather childish at first, a childrens story... but i was hooked even before he title shoed up. in part because of a choice I made, and i felt the game pretty much said 'welp. this is your life now!'  Lets go over a few points.  1.) Graphics If you want the latest and greatest graphics, then this simply isn't your kind of game. With the exception of a few key points in the game, this is largely a pixel-game. Pixel graphics galore. Something I love, bcause games like this usually focus on character development. This game did nt disapoint in that respect.  2.) Characters Every character, including the random-encounter enemies, seems to have a story behind them. Sure, some are silly, others are more serious, but they are all made with care, by someone that loves his craft. The main characters are particularly interesting. All of them seem well-rounded in their own ways. I believe they all try to get you to learn to love them too. In my opinion, they succeed in this front.  3.) Story Its pretty hard to explain what's so amazing about this game's story without spoilers, so instead, I'll justouch on what drew me in:  One of my most favorite genres in the world is comedy. This game is comedy gold. Puns, groaner jokes, and a few characters themselves just the most hillarious ever, i almost never stopped laughing. There were times where the comedy was kind of over-the top, and sometimes bland, but it always fit with the characters and story. The comedy itself is why I so highly reccomend it.  It's more than simply comical, however. you'll laugh, youll feel fear, you'll feel bewildered, you'll think everything is messing up... but stay determined, dont give up, and you will perservere. Never before had I played a game that questions what undertale questions. I can see in it elements from how Homestuck works, and it truely works here.  4.) Sounds Although I can't say the sounds are unique, I can say the way sounds are used in this game is very well put together. Characters all have their own voice, and they are different enough that you can tell who is speaking solely through the sound that comes on for every character in the text. Sound is used very well throughout the entire game.  5.) Music For being a pixel game, the music is very well thought out, and very well put in. Especially in one part with a certain ghost. It may not be as iconic as pokemon, or as famous as okami, but I feel thats a part of how its used in the game. In various places, there is a  lack  of music, all to invoke a sense of ambience. There was never a time I felt the music was out of place.  6.) Puzzles None of the puzzles were extremely difficult, and the easiest ones are actually solved for you. A few of them  seem  to be really really hard, but if you stay determined, you'll be fine. I can't say too much here without spoiling, but I can say there is usually more than one way to solve every puzzle. That fact, plus how they are solved, is another reason I adore this game.  7.) Overall As a whole, Undertale has proven to be one of the best games in its genre of pixel games. This is doubly true if you liked games such as Earthbound, and Cave Story, though neither of those games captures the essence of why Undertale is so good. If you can look past the fact its a pixel-game, and just start listening to the story, then I'm ertain you will enjoy it just as much as I do. Its a very well-made game, that knows when to take itself seriously, and when not to. All annoyances in the game seem to be put there on purpose, and all the easy portions were, too.  Undertale is not impossibly hard (though parts will seem such), and not terribly easy (though, again, parts will seem such). With technically three main endings, there is replaybility, which gets even better with the fact even though you start over...   the characters remember you, vaugely (and sometimes 100%), from your previous runthrough  . Just remember to stay determined, and nothing will be able to stop you :)  Full disclosure: I recieved this product as a gift from a friend. I'm so glad they gave it to me, and I'm so glad I decided to play it. Its an amazing game that I will likely buy for someone else, just so I can support the delveloper. <3

True Pacifist here.  Loved the game. The writing went above and beyond expectation, the musical variety and intensity was excellent. Gameplay was...well, it's an RPG, but the ACT system is quite creative, and the player has to piece things together to achieve their goals. That being said, the best part about this game is the ending, especially for pacifists. The last -- what, eight hours? Masterfully crafted, and absolutely something you should play through for yourself. Toby did good work.  Most of the game: 8/10, enjoyable and unique but not my favorite game ever  Papyrus: 10/10, bones untrousled  Mettaton: 10/10, fabulous fight  Everything past Mettaton: 12/10 hold on to your hopes and dreams  Surpasses AAA titles in thought-provocation and emotional draw, made mostly by 1 dude, it's ten dollars. Worth the money.

I thought I had 2015 pegged...  I mean, Metal Gear Solid 5: The Phantom Pain comes out. Boom, Game of the Year. Easy. Then this ♥♥♥♥ing game shows up. At first, I was skeptical. 'This game? There's no way this could be GotY material.' I was wrong. I was so wrong. I have never been more wrong in my entire life. This game is just amazing. If I had to pick a game to be described as perfect it would be this one.  The art style might be a bit quirky but it's a good quirky and I wouldn't change it for the world. The music is sublime and I'm listening to it as I type this up because I can't get enough of it. However I think the games real forte lies in its gameplay and its story. Gameplay-wise, the pacifistic rpg battle system is damn near the most refreshing twist I've seen in a videogame of late. You can play it straight and slaughter everything but you can, and probably should, win by not fighting. The humor in this game is incredible as well. There's a joke to be found around every corner. But don't think this game is all fun and laughs. The humor juxtaposes a dark and sophisticated story. within minutes of starting this game you'll find yourself staring hard choices in the eye. Undertale's use of characterization is some of the best I've ever seen. Everything practically drips with character, from plot important npcs down to the very enemies you fight.  If I had to make a complaint... If you tied me down and put a gun to my head and said I had to find something bad to say about Undertale I'd say that it's too short. But it isn't. When I finally beat it I didn't want more because I was unsatisfied, rather I wanted more because it was such a good experience. This game is going to be one of those games that I'll never forget. I'll remember it from start to finish because every moment was enjoyable. Every second was well spent.  So do I recommend this game? Yes. I recommend Undertale. I recommend it wholeheartedly.

I'm Jake. I'm here to tell you a story.   I've played, watched, and suffered through many RPGs in my life. I've laughed, cried, rage, and trashed games in despair. I've lost thousands upon thousands of hours of my life to these games.  This game beats them all, without contest or equal. As blasphemous as it may sound, Earthbound was literally NEVER this good. This is perfection.  Other games rely too heavily on quirky contemporary humor, or weird (read:poorly localized) senses of taste, making it nearly impossible to enjoy them to their fullest. I don't know if it was just my lucky day to perfectly resonate with an indie game, or if this really is the most moving game of all time.  I could talk about how immersive and beautiful the game's world is, how every situation (even the noclip!) has secrets and dialogue options. Nothing is left unfinished or unaccounted for. I could go on about how every single NPC is awarded multiple new lines of dialogue for every major story development, and how every enemy encounter is also an NPC, and you can talk to all of them! I could tell you how you will come to love every single one of the quirky, cuddly, sometimes mystifying main characters with all your heart, despite only spending a few minutes with each. I could also tell you how this game is a complete deconstruction of all RPGs, ringing with a novel and weighty sentiment of player choice being the deciding factor of roleplay in a single-player RPG. I could tell you how the entire story shapes around your actions!  But, I think that discussion should be saved for the annals of eternity, where it belongs.  Now, I've played Mother 3. My tear ducts are well oiled. This is definitely the game for you if you enjoyed or are a fan of the Mother series. I think you'll love this game even if you aren't. It's just that good.  In one final note, I also used to swear on the Pokemon Mystery Dungeon games from the mid-oughts. Anyone remember those? They each made me cry with their lovable characters, simple pixel-art expressions, great music, and situations of outright despair. I loved those games.   After having played through Undertale all the way to the True Pacifist Ending, I can safely say. Undertale beats those games with a rubber hose!  10/10. Would become the freaking monster butterscotch Pope again.  Butterscotch Pope would be a really good name for a rock band.

This game is ingenious. This won't be any in depth review telling you about the pros and cons, but it will tell you that this game will impact your life and perspective on... A lot of things. As someone who normally doesn't feel much for characters in fictional stories, there were times where I actually felt quite a bit for these characters. The amount of fourth wall breaking and the tone of the game can do anything from making you happy, sad, and even making you feel like a horrible person. The game will remember everything and anything. It will make you laugh. It will make you cry. There is almost no question about whether or not you will enjoy this game. Do you like RPGs? Do you like laughing? Do you like unique characters? Do you like intruiging stories that draw you in? Do you like dogs? If you said yes to one of those, you'll like this game. If you said no to all of them, you'll probably still enjoy it. This is in fact my new all time favorite game. You want to play it blind, trust me. I don't suggest watching ANYTHING about this game, just play it, love it, and you'll have no regrets.

The gameplay is the most unique in any game, combined with a story and complex characters that react to your actions... Just the first 10 minutes totally and hopelessly sold me to the game.  Let me reiterate, the gameplay is unique, but it's also familiar RPG old-school style. If you pay attention to the story, and you should, you'll reap rewards in game but also in life. It breaks so many conventions that RPGs have a death grip on that I'm not sure if I should be so surprised at it becoming a cult-hit.  Back to the unique gameplay: You can kill the enemies, or you can try to get them to give up. If a monster is obsessed with washing, ask it to wash you. Then you can just show mercy and you 'win' the fight. The story is extensive and I've missed a lot despite looking for as much as I could manage I can take other paths to learn more. Thankfully after the end you can still wander around and for reasons I won't spoil.. there are so many choices.. and each are tracked. The game might even remember despite starting a new game.  Don't assume anything. Take it at face value. Pay attention. This game has managed a perfect balance of horror-scary and comedy, and whatever mixture in between. The intro to the game, pay attention, and you'll have a good time.  Don't pay attention?  YOU'LL HAVE A BAD TIME... [in game joke but helpful to remember if you ever read it in game.]  I'm gonna go out on a limb here and say this is the best RPG I've ever played. If not within this style of jRPG/Early cRPGs. Definitely Top 5 RPGs of all kinds on my list.  Finally, no spoiling here, but this game will MIND♥♥♥♥ YOU at least somepoint.  Don't assume anything!!!! This game is really unique.. the most unique in any game, combined with a story and complex characters that react to your actions... Just the first 10 minutes totally and hopelessly sold me to the game.  Back to the unique gameplay: You can kill the enemies, or you can try to get them to give up. If a monster is obsessed with flexing, flex too and have a flexing contest ; ) . Then you can you 'win' the fight without killing. The story is extensive and I've missed a lot despite looking for as much as I could manage I can take other paths to learn more. Thankfully after the end you can still wander around and for reasons I won't spoil.. there are so many choices.. and each are tracked. The game might even remember despite starting a new game. = To start simply 523/437, will get around to reviewing the game more than two sentences. For now I'll just say it's the greatest old-school cRPG/jRPG I've ever playing.

This game is easily, hands down, the best game I've ever played. Now, if you want to know everyone else's reasons for loving this game, go ahead and scroll down. I challenge you to find a -single- bad review for this game. Why? Because this has everything you could ask for.  The story of this game is remarkably compelling- it merits replay after replay.. Not in spite of the fact that you know the story, but BECAUSE you know the story! It's like a book. The more you re-read, the more you understand, the more secrets you unlock, the more you enjoy it and feel for the characters.  And that's what you do in this game- you feel for the characters. They're not static like in most other RPGs you find- Somehow, they seem more relatable, more alive, more -human- than most humans in other games. Where most games, you have one well-developed character, in this game, you have.... Well, I'm not going to spoil it.   I would go on and on and on, and I easily could... But I will have MERCY and SPARE you the massive review. Suffice it to say this:  While most game dev -teams- struggle to make a compelling game, somehow Tobyfox managed to make a game that eclipses all of them, practically by himself. So put that in your spaghetti. If you need some salt for it, just lean over the plate. The tears this game's storyline will give you will be salt enough.   Ten out of Ten stars. I would give it more, but that's mathematically impossible. Oh well, giving it the highest score of any review I've ever made, and am likely to ever make, is fair enough....
Human!! Please enjoy this spaghetti.

Undertale is an RPG where you play as a human named Frisk who falls into a vast cavern and must survive. I recommend purchasing this game and adding it to your charade of games. Here's why  The Characters: 9/10  Undertale has AMAZING characters. Whether if they're a short skeleton who likes puns or a talking flower who wants your soul, Toby never messed it up! This is because Toby probably has previous programming experience such as creating the Earthbound Halloween Hack which features Megalovania, a song that has been the most notorious in the soundtrack. Technically these characters are some you will never forget whether it's someone great and bumbling like Papyrus or someone mysterious and unsettling like Gaster. You will never forget them! Only one problem, SOME can be forgotten. These are mainly the BG characters so It doesn't affect the rating that much.  The Story: 9/10  Okay. This game got much more creative with the RPG element besides just earning experience, gaining inventory and journeying. This game decides to undertake in going a different route besides just travelling all the way just to stop some baddie and then celebrate about it. Many games like the Paper Mario franchise and the Final Fantasty franchise are responsible for this gaming sin. Instead of doing that you're a child stranded in a vast, immense cavern and must reach the end and leave. But there is a final boss, It even recycles the plot from Super Paper Mario where you defeat the main villain but one of the side villains kill the main one and turn into a monstrosity, Oops, spoilers.  The level design: 10/10  Toby's time working on this game was well worth it! All of them are beautiful in their own way and kept my eyes fixated on my screen. None of these were terrible in any way. The one that was most beautiful were the Ruins. The most nostalgic stage of the entire 6 hour playthrough of fun you'll have.  BONUS: About the developer himself His name is Toby Fox. His experience with other things and the music he's worked on led his success to Undertale, he's made multiple references to webcomics like Homestuck and Cucumber Quest in this game and even one of the soundtracks is inspired by both of them. This is the factor to Toby's success and why Undertale was such a big hit.  Conclusion: 10/10  Okay. Toby your work is absolutely outstanding. I love your game development skills and how hilarious you made all the characters seem, especially Papyrus, he made me chuckle everytime he was on the screen. From the ruins all the way to the end this game was the paramount reason I started RPG development.  Welp tl;dr here.   Ten out of Ten! Have a nice day you review critics, and you too Toby Fox. ~Noisemaster's Reviews

If you ever find yourself arguing with someone that doesn't think that video games are an artistic medium, this should be your go-to example.  It isn't just that the game has more care, skill, and thought put into it than any other you're likely to play this year. It isn't just that it's superbly written, or that it's self-aware enough to be both hilarious and downright terrifying, sometimes at the same time. It isn't even all of the subtle details and variations that make the prospect of multiple playthroughs something to look forward to, instead of a chore.  It's that the entire time your playing, regardless of HOW you play, Toby Fox is presenting an experience that manages to feel tailor-made for YOU; the game is astoundingly good at predicting what the player will try, and the experience of seeing how the game reacts - as a singular entity, not just as something presenting you with the next challenge - is something that no other medium can offer in quite the same way.  I'm not writing this review to convince people to buy it; I'm writing this review because this is a game that well and truly deserves to be celebrated.
Will anyone read my review? Probably not.  Still, It would be a sin to just leave this game un-recommended.

AMAZING.  This game. is AMAZING. BUY THIS GAME. It's soundtrack is amazing, the story is great, the gameplay is very diverse and unique (befriending or killing different characters changes the outcome of the story).  Buy this game. NOW.

I introduced this game to a friend as 'one of the best games I've ever played' and I've been thinking about that a lot, as if to justify my own choice of words towards myself. It feels weird to me to put this game in the same category as, say, Ocarina of Time, which I played with my brother when I was like 11 years old and took us weeks to finish. It just doesn't really compare.   I could say a lot of things here about the soundtrack (which is fantastic), the gameplay (robust, unique and with a perfect difficulty curve), the writing and the characters (brimming with charm, humor, personality and depth) and the huge amount of love and attention to detail that was so obviously put into this. But the bottom line is really that, despite the fact that I love games as a medium and I've played plenty of titles that I enjoyed, I didn't think I'd get to feel this way about a game again as an adult.

If you have $10 to spare, you definitely need to buy this game. If it goes on sale, you shouldn't have an excuse NOT to buy it.

This game is absolutely astounding. Some people may write this game off because of the graphics and its rather lackluster first glance appeal, but that would be a dire mistake. This game truely sets itself apart from other games by having unique entities, like the bullet hell system in combat and the fact that every single encounter, battle, etc counts. Every battle has a meaning, an affect on the game world. The game dramatically changes according to whether you go on an outright slaughter, attempt to save everyone or even something inbetween. This is one of the few games where your choices matter 100% and dramatically affect the outcome of the game and your progress along the way. In addition to the stellar gameplay, the soundtrack is masterfully crafted and adds a lot of deph and emotion to the already deep story rich gameplay. I could probably sit here and go on on about how amazing this game is, so I'll simply say that you will not regret buying this game. Priced at $10 its a steal compared to the pricing of so many other games. I guarantee that this will be one of the games that you have no problem playing again and again to see the different endings. This game truely delivers beyond its scope and has very strong emotional development.

To all those people out there that played through part of Undertale and gave up, this is a review for you.  When I first played through the game I killed Undyne and quit. I thought the game was extremely boring, repetitive and I hated all the characters.   Then my friend forced my to play through to the end of the game and I recieved the Neutral ending, I thought it was very cool, but the one fight wasn't worth my time. I still disliked the game and I continued along with my life thinking it was overhyped to the extreme, but the game refused (heh) and one night my friend and I were in a Skype call and he forced me to play through the game again. This time on Pacifist. OH. MY. GOD. I loved it. Not killing the characters made me love them, the dates, the hangouts, the spagetti, I finally loved the game. I nearly cried during the ending and now everytime I hear the song played during the end (Hopes and Dreams, or His Theme) I tear up a little.  The game is nothing to write home about if you don't go through Pacifist or Genocide, mainly the first one. The game isn't one that you enjoy from start to finish, it's one that you push through at first and gradually love, and that battle makes the ending a thousand times more rewarding than if it was just given to you about characters you all love.  My thoughts before Pacifist - 6/10 MY thoughts after Pacifist - 9.9/10 (I had a bad time at one of the endings)  If you gave up before finishing, do yourself a favor and push through it to get the endings, because it's so worth it.

THIS IS THE BEST RPG I'VE EVER PLAYED. I HAVE BEATEN THE GAME MORE THAN 10 TIMES AND HAVE NO INTENTION TO COUNT NOW.  I got 4 different endings(now 5, view the updates at the bottom of my review)-- normal(killed Toriel, Papyrus, and Asgore), normal(Spared Asgore but he killed himself in order to give me his soul and let me escape the underworld), true pacifist, and genocide(+ soulless pacifist, view the updates at the bottom of my review). Gosh the true pacifist ending is really touching. It has surely made thousands of people cry(I'm not one of them lol. I wouldn't tell you that I cried for at least 10 times even if I did).  The only part that is not good enough to me is the FREAKING Sans fight. You will get to the Sans fight if you play a genocide run. IT LITERALLY TOOK ME A MONTH TO BEAT HIM. SANS IS TOO FREAKING STRONG. On a second thought, maybe the producer of the game attempted to make the player feel the weakest in the genocide route. Sans was made to be a god intentionally.  And I have to brag about it: HELL YEAH I BEAT SANS! HELL YEAH.  In comparison with Life is Strange, I'd say this game is much better. No offense to those Life is Strange fans, cuz I'm one of them too. However, choices don't matter in Life is Strange as much as they do in Undertale.  (Life is Strange Spoilers warning) For those who've beaten Life is Strange, you must all know that no matter what choices you made in the previous episodes, there would only be two endings for you to choose. And they are both bad endings. Undertale, on the other hand, has multiple endings depending on the choices you've made. AND THERE IS A REALLY HAPPY ENDING.  Plus, if Chara is a girl, can I be her boyfriend? (Just a tip: DON'T PLAY THE GENOCIDE ROUTE IF YOU'RE NEW TO THIS GAME. YOU WILL REGRET IT.)  Updates: I just got my fifth ending which is the soulless pacifist ending. That jumpscare was epic. Again, Reminder: Don't play the genocide run at first. It messes up everything

Probably in my top 5 favorite games because of just how brilliant the game is. It reminds me of the amazing old games I'd play, such as Chrono Trigger, Metroid Fusion, Final Fantasy, and all those amazing games.  Undertale is an amazing game that EVERYONE should play. Its worth far above its $10 price tag. Its worth WAY more than many huge production games that I've played.  The story is so personal and brilliant, and you really feel like you are the character that you are playing as. Toby did a perfect job of that.  Now let me go cry in a corner.  ________________________________________________________________  Review after pacifist ending:  This game has transcended the fourth wall and space and time and feels and my mind more than any other game has that I have ever played or any movie that I have ever watched (Yes, even Bioshock Infinite, Madoka Magica, and Inception). It has the most mind blowing ending of any game that I have ever played ever. It brings you into a new level of contemplation of life and video games and stories in general that I have never reached before.  And my gosh that OST. My GOSH that OST.     I'm just not sure if I even have the guts to do a genocide run now ;--;     ________________________________________________________________  Review after genocide ending:     Just kill me now

A lot of it personally for me probably stems from the fact that the protagonist is refered to as 'they' by everybody and that you can hang out and make friends with all the silly monsters no matter what the differences. Undertale has been the most refreshing thing I've played this year and I just want to share this joy with as many people as possible. It's understandable that it might not be for everybody because some people are put off by 4th wall breaking and a lot of meta jokes (Which this game does a lot, like woah. Oh, and puns. Yep.) but for some (like me) that's the biggest treat a game can give. Do yourself a favour and experience Undertale.

After finishing Undertale completely I knew I had to write a review about it. I have never written a review (with effort) before but I’m going to try to describe the game for you as objectively as possible. There will be some subjective parts but it should be obvious when I talk about my personal opinion.    What is Undertale?   Undertale is an indie RPG made by toby fox and released on 15 September 2015. It started its life as a kickstarter project on 13 June 2013. Toby fox asked for only 5000$ to make the project reality yet he received 10 times that amount. The main mechanic of this RPG is that you don’t have to kill anyone, but you can if you wish.   Community   I want to start off with the community because it seems that this is the main reason why people are discouraged from this game. Lots of people call the Undertale fandom toxic and although it’s not the best community I’ve ever seen it’s by no means as bad as people say it is. Yes, there are a lot of memes and ♥♥♥♥-posts and sometimes Undertale is being mentioned for no reason but there are also some amazing people who try to expand the story after the game ends or create amazing fan art. What I think the main reason is that the Undertale community is treated as toxic is because most people don’t realise that if someone didn’t play the game yet that they won’t understand the jokes that are being told. I can clearly see why this would be annoying but saying the community is toxic because they make references to certain moments in the game that you just don’t know about (yet) is idiotic.  At the end of the day though you shouldn’t even consider the community as a reason for not liking / not playing the game. Especially considering this is a single player game, you won’t have any interaction with the community within the game itself.   Story   This is the main selling point for Undertale. It’s story. Here is a brief part of it to get you started: ‘Long ago, two races ruled over Earth: humans and monsters. One day, war broke out between the two races. After a long battle, the humans were victorious. They sealed the monsters underground, under Mt. Ebott, with a magic spell. After many years legends say that those who climb the mountain never return. You, the player, climb the mountain and you fall in a pit where you end up in “The underground” the place where the monsters were sealed away. Your objective? To find a way back to the surface.’  The story is perfectly designed to make any interaction the player may take feel important. Even when in battle it always feels like you are progressing the story instead of you just getting interrupted to fight someone. The characters have their own personalities and this even includes some of the random NPC’s and normal enemies. All of the characters are really likable, even if you may find some annoying at first. Some of the characters their backstories are really deep and some characters don’t even show any of their backstory making them very mysterious.  Throughout your adventure you will be faced with certain choices, the biggest and most obvious one being that you can either kill or spare your enemies. This is a very important aspect of this game. When you kill someone they are actually dead. You may have certain species of monsters that keep on reappearing but the monster that you previously killed isn’t coming back.  Almost all of the decisions you can possibly make will change the story. There are three major endings to this game: Neutral, Pacifist and Genocide. All of these endings will explain different parts of the story.   When you try to immerse yourself into the story you will be blown away by it, multiple times. I have cried when playing this game and there is no shame to it. The story is just that good. I would love to tell you at which points this happens but obvious spoiler warning. You will just have to trust me on this one.    Gameplay   When it comes to gameplay you have two major situations. In-battle and out-battle.  Out-battle you will run around trying to solve various puzzles to progress, interact with characters to further the story, try to find new items and better equipment. Pretty standard RPG stuff. The puzzles are fun. Although they’re neither easy nor difficult they are still interesting to do.  In-battle you have two ways of defeating your enemies, by killing them or by sparing them. When it comes to sparing the enemies, fights will become puzzles themselves. You will have to perform different kind of acts in order to make the enemy not wanting to fight you any longer. You will have to understand what every enemy expects out of you in order to make them merciful. Don’t worry you don’t have to search up what kind of hidden numbers of characteristics each enemy has. It all becomes obvious during the fighting itself.  If you wish to slaughter your enemies then you can do that however admittedly this is a pretty weak part of this game. Unlike other RPG where you have many different attacks and spells all with their unique stats and effects. In Undertale, you only have one way of inflicting damage. The amount of damage that you deal is based on your timing in pressing a button but other than that, actually hurting the enemy doesn’t really change that much. (You do get different timing patterns with different weapons but overall it will be very similar)  There is something really interesting though about this game and I wish that a lot more RPG’s would use a mechanic like this. In a traditional RPG, when it is your enemies turn you simply have to take the damage and hope it doesn’t kill you. In Undertale, if an enemy attacks you, you will have to dodge the attacks yourself in order to survive. You will be a small heart that you can move around to avoid the projectiles that the enemy shoots at you. It’s basically a bullet-hell. The game will start off easy on you but the dodging can become really difficult later on in the game. The great part about this is that you can improve your own skills when fighting the enemy instead of mindless grinding to boost your characters stats.    Music   If you don’t like chiptune then you probably won’t like the songs ON THEIR OWN. You see we are talking about a game with a retro style so the chiptune fits in. However more importantly is that the songs always seem to match the situations in the game perfectly. Yea I know that that is what video game music has to do but I have never seen so perfectly done as in Undertale. When it comes to the soundtrack that you can buy separately I’ll admit that it is a bit overprized.   Summary    Undertale has become my favourite single player game of all time and for good reasons. The fighting elements are interesting and skillful and the story will make you curious and wanting to get more. The game is also decently large with an average of 21 hours of gameplay to beat all three major endings. With it only costing 10 euros I don’t see a reason not to buy it. Even now that it's has become a year old it's still a great story to be part off. If you still aren’t sure about purchasing this game then you can still try out the demo. You can download the demo on the  official Undertale website  [undertale.com] .   Recommendations for playing   The best way to play this game is to be as blind as possible. The story is the most important aspect of this game and even in the early beginnings the game will start to give you important story elements. Also actually try to immerse yourself into the game. The character you are controlling shouldn’t be played like you would with, let’s say, Mario. In Mario games you pretend to be Mario and save the princess but in Undertale you are playing as yourself. The game heavily depends on your own decisions.

I've always been a sucker for cute indie games, but Undertale was honestly one of the most heartwarming and genuine games I've played in a long time. Reminiscent of the games I loved from my childhood with its fun, original and engaging gameplay, as well as some great ways of guiding you through decision making. Undertale is perhaps one of the best games to come out of 2015 in my opinion. On a scale from one to ten (one being worst game ever, ten being best game ever), I’d give it a 7/10 (great game, really enjoyed it).  My personal pros and cons (and neutral opinions): + Great story + Wonderful soundtrack + Characters are well designed + Unique and fun combat system + Very well priced ~ Multiple endings ~ Easy puzzles - Unimpressive graphics - Short - Getting the “best” ending requires specific conditions, making it difficult to get during a blind run  (It's worth noting that the fanbase can be pretty... irritating at times. Not the game's fault by any means.)

This game is flawed.  The pacing is inconsistent, there are sometimes bugs, the availability of shortcuts when backtracking isn't plentiful when it needs to be, and there are many times where the game fails to fulfill its promise of crafting a story around your choices.  But...  BUT...  This game is  charming.  Side characters and plot-important NPCs alike have life and charm unlike any other, and the dialogue should at least be able to coax a smile out of even those who are jaded when it comes to net-era-savvy humor.  As if that wasn't enough, the music is excellent and complements the gameplay and cutscenes perfectly. The gameplay varies it up quite a lot once you leave the first area, so 'navigate menus and dodge the monochrome bullets' is not the most you can expect out of this game. Not by far.  If you're concerned that this game is trying to shove a message down your throat, make you feel bad for daring to kill an enemy in a video game, it's not. NPCs will tell you where you can shove various things and you'll have a bad time, but the game never tells you you should feel ashamed of yourself.  In fact, you'll make friends that know exactly how you feel.

The reasonable answer to 'Should I buy this game' is  YES! Buy it now!  Of course, most people will want to know a little before handing over money, so...  Here's a review to try and get you to buy this.  It's really quite difficult to summarize this game into a couple of points. From the comedy, to the story-driven characters, to the game-changing choices you can make, to the FANTASTIC music, it all meshes together to create one of the most fun, intense and emotional RPGs ever. The hype can seem discouraging, but I was not hyped about this game until after I played it. I know it's a gamble when somebody tells you to go into a game and pay money all whilst knowing absolutely nothing about the game in question, but take that chance with Undertale. If you just invest a bit of time into it, you will almost certainly be very satsified.  Well, I suppose you should know just one thing before going in: killing is entirely optional. This is a very integral part of the game, so keep it in mind.  This game will take you all the way from tears to blind rage and back again. This game isn't worth its asking price. I would pay twice, or even three times as much for this game. This is  not  a game to pass up, just because it seems overhyped or the visuals seem terrible. I myself watched a video of this game beforehand and thought it was boring. Boy, was I wrong.  So do yourself a favour and pick up this game because you will almost certainly love it, even if you dislike RPGs or turn-based strategy games. If nothing else convinces you, this game can practically run on a toaster, making it the perfect game for a long road trip, or if you're looking for fun on a budget.

*** NO SPOILERS ***  I don't usually write reviews for any games, but for this one I have no choice.  The main reason I bought this game was because I saw some clips of it and thought it would be hilarious. I thought it would make me laugh. I did not expect it to make me feel.  The self-awareness of this game is absolutely astonishing. When you save, the game knows. When you start a new save, the game knows. The developer even rewards you for editing the games files (the 'FUN' value) by rewarding you with extra content, and it all fits into the lore. The games lore is one of the most consistent lores I have ever seen with laws that extend to every single small segment of the game.  Another great thing about this game is that every single step counts. Absolutely every single one. Even those small random fights you encounter throughout the game. Every single one of them will impact the entirety of the game.  The emotions this game makes me feel are indescribable. The last game that made me feel like this was Metal Gear Solid 3. Every single thing you do not only in your current run but in your previous run WILL come back to haunt you. Every decision you make. Every piece of dialogue you read. It will all build up and you will truly be judged as a human being.  I'm the type of player that really enjoys getting to the cream of the crop. When playing games I often won't do things like sidequests just because I want to get through the main and most polished content just so that I can get on to the next game. I beat this game several times, doing all of the main endings not once, but twice. I beat this game 6 times. That should be saying a lot coming from me.  BUY THIS GAME. It will make you a better person.

[Mostly spoiler free review] (I'm too lazy to proof read so expect weird formatting and typos)  I hated it when I first played it, couldn't stand the skelebros so I barely played it, but I was determined to finish it at least once because I didn't want to be rude to my friend who gifted the game to me.  But with time the game started to grow on me, I got emotionally invested in the characters and started liking them (and paying for their college education) and after finishing the game I was greatly upset at the ending I got and was determined to get the best possible ending.  So I sat down and played through the entire game again in a single 7 hour sitting, doing every single side quest and character story I could find. I finished that 2 days ago and I'm still processsing it; the story is increadible and well written, the endings are (unlike a lot of story games) satisfying, the characters are, somehow, the most real I've ever seen and I (who normaly is stone cold in games) got extremely attached to a lot of them (I will never accidentaly kill you again, I swear ;~;) The graphics aren't anything special but they still manage to create the characters in a way I didn't think 8/16/whatever bit could accomplish (I normally despise retro stuff) and the game's combat mechanic is unique and fun (except for that one boss, ♥♥♥♥ that one boss) and doesn't get old for a long time.  Overall, it's easily one of the best games I've ever played and I was a fool for doubting it, and I will give it a solid 9,5/10. I recommend it to everyone.

I'm not really too hip to notice the 'trends of today', so I didn't join in on the hype train for this game. A nice friend told me to play this game because it's really good. How or why is it good? She didn't say. Just told me to play the game blindly, so I did.   Undertale is a bullet hell type RPG, wich is pretty fun and unique. The gist of this game is that you can complete the game without harming a single 'enemy'. Emphasis on enemy. EVERYTHING you encounter in the game during a FIGHT you can befriend in a spcific way while dodging their attacks. So in a sophisticated, philosophical, complex, [big word], way you can be passive.  But I'm used to my RPGs having violence, loot, gold, and EXP, some of you might think. Yea you can still kill LV up and get gold like any RPG. But if you're not a sociopath who can't feel guilt and enjoy harming others, you're going to have a bad time. This game can get you emotionally and you might even feel bad by wacking a frog with a stick. I mean c'mon why would you do that? The frog doesn't know any better, give it a break, or flirt with it even.  You can be violent or get through the game without harming a soul. Wich ever path you choose will change the story. Speaking about story changing, certain characters in the game will rememeber your actions like in those Telltale pointy clicky games. Some characters even go as far as to break the fourth wall. Even when you revert back from a SAVE, they might remember something you did.  But yea, the games pretty good. Spent 10 hours or so on [one?] run to get the true ending. A dollar worth an hour for a total of 10 hours of gameplay (or more). Undertale is really a game you want to experience rather than watch some Youtuber play it for you.   Judgement Pros: -Amazing music -Nice interactive gameplay (rather than taking turns slapping each other) -Unique world full of adventure -Can flirt with goat mom -Being friendly can win you the game -Snail racing -Be on television -Save the world -Make a snowman very happy  Cons: -Heavy feels -Can't actually hook up with cool skeleton -Feels are too strong -Brace for crying -Evil flowers   I give this game a rating of:  Asriel did nothing wrong/10

It's highly unlikely that anyone's going to find this review buried beneath the thousands of other reviews, but I feel like I'm personally obliged to leave a review for this game. It's left a... considerable impact on me.   This is mostly a response to the negative reviews of this game, as I struggle to understand how people could dislike the game.   Undertale does indeed have some flaws. It's designed for a very specific demographic, and many have complained that the fandom is absolutely abysmal. And... that's kind of true, but it's true of any popular game. This game does indeed pander towards the 'Tumblr' demographic, and, well, I'm in that demographic, so maybe I have a biased opinion. I feel as though the community is a contributing factor that leads to this game's dislike by those that have never played it: because people constantly pester those who have not played it to play it, and fail to understand how someone could not like it, and I somewhat fall into this category. It's annoying when people constantly pester other people to do things, and I know I've probably ruined the experience of the game to a few people just by my massive obsession, and feel that I really need to apologize for it. I feel like this fandom will give the game a horrible reputation, and violate Toby's wishes of this game's discussion never becoming a 'garbage cesspool.' But still, however the fandom may ruin the public perception of the game, the game itself is still good. I got the game before it blew up, I just saw it on steam, and bought it without really knowing what it was, and I adored it.   Some people complain about the graphics, something that has never mattered to me. I appreciate the minimalism. And I don't think I'm really driven by nostalgia, per say. I didn't play Earthbound until two years ago, and I thought it was alright. For me, Undertale was much better, much better than probably any other game I'd ever played, although it's really hard to compare Undertale to other games, because it's so unique. The story... didn't really make me that emotional. It's not like I cried, or anything. But I still believe that it was expertly crafted, and that the game was put together with so much care, and wit, a kind that you could never really find in any other game.  I laughed constantly throughout this game. This game had my kind of humor, and I guess some people have different senses of humor, so maybe it won't appeal to them. But it was perfect for me, and there was not a single character I disliked, at all. It was the perfect mix of humor and plot. The pacing kind of felt a bit iffy the first time I played through the game, though, so there's a slight criticism. But still, playing it a second time, and seeing all the slight foreshadowing, and how everything tied together, I guess I changed my mind. I loved the plot, and I loved the humor. It's a bit confusing at points, but it can come together. I do think part of the true final boss was a bit corny and generic, and I was slightly disappointed by it, but that doesn't really matter.   This game kept throwing all sorts of unexpected things at me, and I loved every second of playing it. I never lost interest, I was constantly engaged. I'm the sort of person that plays video games mostly for the stories. My favorite part of any RPG is talking to NPCs. Dialogue is the primary focus of this game. It's understandable why I liked it. This game wasn't necessarily difficult, though some of the boss fights were a bit challenging, but that isn't the point. The gameplay isn't the focus of the game - it's merely using the medium of gameplay to tell a story, and it does it quite well. It uses game mechanics as metaphor, and I thought it accomplished this excellently.  I found the beginning of the game to be the least engaging part, and while I still absolutely adored it in every way, and thought it was perfect, it wasn't the best the game has to offer. So, I guess some people who only played the game for around an hour didn't really experience what made me love this game.   I've played the game around 4 times. I'm obsessed. I originally wrote this review, and then planned to stop thinking about it, but boy, was I wrong. I've watched 4 of my friends play this entire game, all the way through. I run the wiki for this game. It occupies my thoughts, honestly, 20% of the time. I can't stop thinking about it. I kind of wish it was longer, but I couldn't see any way to extend it. The game is already so interconnected, that I really don't want it to ever be patched, (except for bug fixes), and I never want to see a sequel or anything. Because this game is perfection, and I doubt any other game could really replicate the quality of this game.   For me, it was the perfect game. For most people that buy it, it'll be a pretty good game. For a few, it might be a waste of money. The only scenario where I would recommend not buying the game is if you are really, really bad at bullhell, in which case I'd just recommend watching a Let's Play of the game instead. Although, I really do believe that this game is an experience that you can enjoy to the fullest extent if you play it yourself.   If you've somehow traversed all of these reviews, and are actually reading all this, just buy the gosh darn game already. It's clear that you're interested. Give it a shot. You'll probably love it.

Undertale is a beautifully crafted game with intense gameplay, inspiring music, and clever humor. This text-based game is filled with decisions, which will all result with different endings. The diverse characters and items add to your journey, but the humor sets Undertale apart from other games. About 50% of all NPC's dialogue includes some kind of pun and/or joke. Many Easter Eggs are hidden through-out the world. By far, the funniest characters are Temmies.  In this game, players are able to 'personalize' who their character becomes. Players can choose how violent they act to how much they explore the land.   Undertale is very similar to the Nintendo 64 game, Paper Mario. They are both played the same way- turn-based fights and a branching story line, however Undertale outranks all other games of this type. Even though much shorter in gameplay, Undertale can be enjoyed multiple times because of choice making.   Overall Rating for Undertale- 9/10

This game seems small, it looks to be something that can't compare to more complex games. But, this game and it's story, it's ability to draw you in and invest in it is astounding. This game is one of the best I have exerienced in my life.  This game has done what many games don't deliver, especially in recent years.  This game made me FEEL  This game made me happy, it made me cry, it made me devistated It made me love, it made me feel attachment.  Please play this, it will be something you will carry on your mind for a long time after you experience it.

I have no words that can describe this game without spoiling anything. To me, the best way to play it is to jump in blindly, not knowing what's to come or what your adventure will bring. Take my word and play this game to the very end. You will not regret it.

This is a deceptively fantastic RPG/Bullet Hell game. It pays homage to many classic RPGs with nods in character, situation and music and yet it manages to have it's own unique story and charm. I'll be honest: some of the bullet hell elements are quite challenging. This game also almost demands more than a single play-through in order to really get to the meat of the story. And holy cow does this deceptively simple story get deep when you go through the game more than once.  The music gets stuck in your head. Fair warning.
I was VERY hesitant about buying this game, despite the overwhelmingly positive reviews. So glad I did. One of the most enjoyable games I've played in a long time.

Before I didn't want to start this game, one night I did that for fun...  I played over 16h... After 8 i completed first run... Then i decided to do pacifist run, because I killed 2 of the characters and felt bad...   It was best decision in my entire gaming life...  One of the best games I've EVER PLAYED!  If you really want to feel that game, do full pacifist mode without killing anyone as second run!  That game is something more than just game.  YOU NEED TO FEEL IT BRO!  2354/10

This game is a slight mix of touhou-esque bullet hell which it does quite well with the slight art style of earth bound, and so many feels that it makes your heart feel like someone squeezed lemons on it.  The game is charming to the stupidest degree quite literally and was a beautiful adventure that you could experience a number of different ways, the characters make the game immensely fun to play in a variety of different ways just to experience how they'd react, the interaction of the battles with those characters also made the game a delight to play from the beginning to my end with all the cheesy lines, jokes and just straight up fun dialogue, and that's the best part, I've only played it through twice.  There's two thing's I'll say to end this, go in blind if you can, buy this game and enjoy it without seeing any form of spoilers, not that you won't enjoy it any less, but the value is found in every interaction you have in the way you decide to interact with the character. And go in with Determination. Would recommend everytime.

This game, from the characters, to the music, is about FEELINGS, every piece of music made me feel something, ad always matched the settings i was in. The soundtrack is way better than expected, i listen to it by itself quite often. The characters are well written and all have personality. I have not played a game that did so much with so little in ages. The game is short (the true pacifist run took me 14 hours, cause i did everything i could think of) and a no mercy run would take, 5-6 hours. I HIGHLY recommend that any new plays start with the pacifist route to get the most story. This game has something for just about everyone, give it a shot. And buy the soundtrack, you wont regret it.

This game is so cool! its so funny how when i first played it i just played it like any normal rpg. However, later in the game... nope! not telling you anything! thats for you to find out. in all, its a game worth its price, so go ahead and buy it already!

I love games. I have loved games as long as I rember. I have greatly loved many different games, for many different reasons.   And yet I have never loved any game enough to write a review for it.    Edit: Okay, I guess I lied, but I don't really count the '11/10 would break legs again' review for Day Z as a heartfelt 'Love This Game'   Then, on a random, impulse driven purchase after a tough day at work, I bought Undertale.  I can't even put into words just why Undertale is so great, but the fact that this game is compelling me to try and do so anyway should speak for itself.  I felt a lot of things playing Undertale: curiosity, shock, joy, fear, anger, sorrow, disbelief, regret. But most of all, I felt  Determination . And I'm not just being cheesy, I'm not just playing off of the importance of 'determination' in the storyline. I really, truly, felt determined to play, to win, and in many cases, to go back and right the mistakes I had made before.  The game, the story, is incredibly compelling. Well worth the $10 I dropped for it. Heck, it'd be worth $20 or even $30, and I am usually pretty stingy with my cash.  So, Two Thumbs up, 10/10 would not destroy anyone again, now I'm off to go see what that news article about Undertale merchandise was saying...
Best game this year.  Buy it.
If you liked Earthbound or Mother 3, you'll probably like this. Good soundtrack, too.

Toby, do you need a hug? I have never experienced any story, video game or otherwise, with so much feeling and such rich ideas, This is a game unlike any other that you really have to play to understand. There were points in this game where I was crying and laughing at the same time. This game will become a milestone in video game history. Toby please continue to do what you do because this is the kind of game people need to play.

JESUS. ♥♥♥♥ING. CHRIST. I have no words to describe this game. The characters, the music, the storyline, EVERYTHING is incredible. I have only done the Pacifist and Neutral route and I am amazed by this game. I really don't want to do the Genocide route, but I will go through it to experience to whole game. This game is totally worth buying.
This game is one of my favorite games of all time the visuals, dialogue, music, and don't even get me started on the story. Literally 10/10

It's been a long time since a game has made me feel the way Undertale has.  Amazing story, amazing writing, amazing gameplay.  What are you still doing looking at this? If you haven't already go buy and play this game.

Please buy this game. You are doing yourself a disservice by not playing this game.  Pros:  - Great writing - Great Characters - Fantastic Music - Nice Retro Graphics - Spaghetti (no, really) - Seriously I'm not writing all the pros there are too many  Cons:  - First area can be kind of annoying, but it lasts like 20 minutes so whatever - Movement speed is a little slow, making backtracking somewhat annoying  10/10 buy this game.
Undertale is one of the best games released this year and one of my personal all time favorites.

It is a geart game, I loved everything about it. I have only done one playthough and the final encouter hit me like a brick. I had been avoiding killing anyone the whole game and the thing that they tell you just seriously messed me up. I am scared to do a genocide run...I really am scared tbh. I love the characters and I will feel like Garbage for killing them as I have emotionally invested in the game.
THIS GAME IS SO FRUSTRATING BUT I CAN'T STOP PLAYING. The identity struggle of Bob is too real. Can't handle.
The game's pretty good and all... Just stay away from the fanbase.  Very vocal and cringeworthy.

Everything you already heard about this game is true. It might be blasphemy, but this game easily beats Earthbound and the Mother series in all the staples those games have in regards to RPGs. The music is amazing, the battling system is unique and a nice change of pace, and the humor could not stop tickling my funnny bone.  This game is a MUST PLAY.

Well, this review is long overdue but I guess better late than never, right? Spoilers (of course :/)         *Loads game *Sees flower and wonders why a friend gave such a childish game *Shocked when flower attempts to murder him *After accidentally killing Toriel and resetting, the flower points out what I did, and continues to break the fourth wall *Goes through a game unlike no other *Cried at the end of a pacifist run *Was too weak (of mind) to do a genocide past snowdin *Attempted pacifist many times to save Asriel *Realizing he can't be saved, does the one thing the game asks after a pacifist run 10/10 would do again

Obviously inspried by Earthbound and Yume Nikki. Which is good because those games are really good. Has a good meaning and a very reactive world. Overall I'd probably say that Undertale manages to get up to the level of it's inspiration. And it doesn't just ♥♥♥♥ing copy them.

Sans: 'Hey kid wanna buy a hot-dig?' Me:'Uhhhhh sure' *You got a Hot-Cat' Temmie: ' I gotta go to colleg.' Me: 'Uhhh ok'   GREAT GAME you can take 4 paths pacifast/genocide/True pacifast/Nuetral Well buy the game already...

Outstanding must play game. This game will make you really mad but you wont be able to stop playing because the story is just too interesting. Every little detail impacts you and you will have to play through more than once to experience the amazing story. Get this game.
I've never been so afraid of a flower before this game.
game of the year
Honestly one of the best games I've ever played. The soundtrack is amazing to listen to in the car as well!

--spoiler free--  To Preface this, i am not even a RPG fan, but all the praise this game gets got my attention so i decided to give it a try.  This is one of the most amazing single player story i've ever played through. The story telling is extremely well done, not revealing everything but letting us put the pieces together as some almost hidden characters and pieces of the lore are revealed.  The Soundtracks is out of this world, i was blown away by it, catchy when needed (mettaton and spider dancer) and haunting when exploring some secret areas related to a specific ending.  I honestly couldn't find a flaw in the soundtrack.  The boss battles are fun, a bit hard for some but that can be explained by how inexperienced i am in such games.   Overall amazing game, the only con i could find is for how little you are prepared for the trip to feeladelphia, but hey that's for the best i guess.
Honestly one of the best games I've ever played. The soundtrack is amazing to listen to in the car as well!

This game is...  There's no words to say how wonderful this game is. You have to buy it. You have to play it. And try to not harm anyone. Be good, child. Buy it, play it, win it.   I can't count on my hands how many times I cried...

This is one of my favourite games of all time, it's amazing, funny, challenging and you easily fall in love with every character. Stop reading the reviews and just give it a chance if youre skeptical! ;w;

this game is masterpiece.

I'm completely stunned by this game. Before playing this I believed this would be a good game just by the vast amount of positive feedback, but I honestly didn't know the full extent of this game's amazingness. No other game has managed to make me care for it so much to the point I so emotionally wrecked the first week after finishing it. Only some movies and books have gotten me to that point, but a game never has. All I'm able to say now is that if you are having doubts about getting this game, don't listen to them! It took me a while to play this game, over a year after it came out. For the longest time, I had to hear about it among my friends or see jokes and references about it throughout the internet. Constantly, I hear how good it is, but at the same time because of how popular it got, the fandom has gotten a lot of hate. Because of how much people like this game, some people are turned away from it before giving it a chance, or simply because it was hyped up too much for them to find satisfaction.  The concept is fresh, allowing you to choose between fighting monsters and growing stronger or trying to please them and spare them from a fight, which in return doesn't make you any stronger. You must do something different for each creature to earn its trust and avoid a fight. The creatures themselves are fun to see and can be pretty creative. Some are pretty basic but others have humorous designs or personalities, like a small volcano creature that attacks stronger when you encourage it because it thinks it's helping. When you are sparing an enemy, you usually have to pick between a few different options to act on. While it's interesting learning each creature and what you need to do to earn its trust, it's never really challenging and doesn't really make you think outside the box much. Most of the time you'll either be doing a trial and error of the different actions or just stalling until a fight ends. If you choose to ignore the pacifist option and simply attack the enemies, it's a pretty basic time-based system requiring less thought than the alternative.  The game has different routes based on how you go about the spare or kill option. There are three main routes, the pacifist route, in which you kill no one at all and befriend all of the key characters, the genocide route, where you kill EVERY enemy and fightable character, and the neutral route, which is pretty much everything in-between and also mandatory to complete first for story purposes. There's a lack of variety between the routes and the philosophy is pretty black and white, either being kind to everyone or going on a murderous rampage. If you try to mix it up and kill one or two creatures on a regular run or spare a few on a genocide run it just results in the basic neutral ending. It would be interesting if there was more variety based on who you choose to kill and who you don't, like affecting the story or who you fight next or maybe grant you access to exclusive items or places, but all it does is intervene in the objective of either sparing or killing everything and give you some different dialouge at the end. However because it is a unique concept I don't blame Toby Fox for not adding too much depth and complexity into it and focusing more on the story and the idea of an RPG where no one has to die. It's the first of its kind so there's room for a lot more implementation of the concept.  The routes themselves don't change that much. the neutral and pacifist routes are pretty identical up until the end besides some minor dialogue changes. The genocide route is pretty much designed to not be fun, as you skip a lot of story bits and kill the main cast. The main attraction of the genocide route is the fights, which are the most challenging of the game. The fights are enjoyable and beating them is satisfactory, but there are very few actual bosses in the genocide route, which takes away the main entertainment one would look forward to. But hey, it was intended not to be fun, so it works I guess.  The combat in general is really fun. It's pretty much a bullet hell where you avoid the attacks from the enemy before you make your move. While typical enemies aren't all that special, I had a lot of fun with the boss battles. The boss battles like to change up the mechanics and have a unique twist to make the fight more engaging and entertaining. Though they aren't that difficult and just require learning their attacks to avoid them successfully. The music is also great. There's not just one or two great tracks, pretty much all of the bosses have amazing themes and they suit the battles well and add to the atmosphere.  The game looks okay. I'm not really a fan of Frisk's design but it's alright. I like the designs of the main cast, all of which are memorable characters, as you may guess by how popular they've become over the internet. The locations are kinda dull, probably the weakest part of the game. There isn't much to explore and the puzzles never require much effort.   The humor and characters are pretty divisive among the people I've met. I liked it, I thought the characters were fun and I thought the game was pretty funny. I can understand why one wouldn't but I thought it was enjoyable and never felt too overbearing. It really depends on if it's your cup of tea or not. I think a lot of the hate for the humor comes from the fandom, who make a small gag from the game into a huge meme you see over and over again. The whole bad puns doggo anime stuff I kept hearing about weren't as obnoxious as I thought they would be and were pretty small parts of the overall humor you find in the game.  As for the story itself, it was really good. It wasn't mind-blowing, but it was very entertaining and the whole climax was great. You can probably guess what the main message at the end of the game is going to be, but that didn't make it any less enjoyable for me. The theme is kinda obvious but the execution is very well done and the whole presentation is great. It's something you have to experience for yourself and it ties the game together very nicely, so I wouldn't just watch a video of the end or something, because you should be engaged throughout the game in order to fully enjoy it. It's also interesting learning about the lore of certain characters and how it develops across the different routes. Even though the ending of the genocide route was creepypasta fuel I thought it fit in nicely and the mood was genuine.  I usually don't mind fandoms because I think every franchise has its fair share of obnoxious fans but it got to a point with this game where it hindered my experience. I know it's easy to get swept up in the hype of a game but they ruined a lot of things. There were several moments in the game that were supposed to be big surprises and cool twists that were just outright spoiled for me. Mainly it was the final bosses, who were still fun to fight, but it took away a lot of impact already knowing they were coming. One major spoiler is simply the existence of a character which is ruined just by people having profile pictures of them. And it's not like I was looking at gameplay videos or looking up information of the game, all of these things were ruined for me just by virtue of being in groups with people who played the game. Just hearing about the game so much revealed a lot of key moments from the game that I wish I could have experienced blind. I guess it's my fault for not playing a game immediately when it comes out.  Overall, I thought the game was really good. It wasn't perfect, and the popularity was definitely overblown, but I thought it was a very enjoyable experience. The game isn't for everyone, and I can see why some people wouldn't like it. It has flaws like any other game, but I think the pros outweigh the cons. It has a nice cast of memorable characters with an intriguing concept, great music, and a lovable feel. I know the fandom can be annoying, but I encourage you to give it a chance and go into it with an open mind. It was an enjoyable experience that I'll play again for sure. Just don't expect this game to be the greatest thing ever, but also don't try to force yourself to hate it because everyone else loves it. Sure there are a lot of things that could have been better, but it's a fun experience nonetheless.

This is a game like no other. Where else can you lie back and trip the light fantastic with a ghost, go on a (platonic) date with a skeleton, or call a goat 'Mom' and almost mean it?   Everything you encounter is inventive, interesting, hilarious, and sometimes even heartbreaking. It has the greatest storytelling in almost any game I've ever played, and you can't help but fall in love with the complex characters who surprise you at every turn. As a grown man, it's difficult for me to admit it, but I sobbed at my keyboard towards the end due to how well it draws you into its emotional gravity.  I cannot possibly say enough good things about it. Buy this game immediately. Ignore all spoilers and/or advice, and just play it.

Man where to start with this? I'll skip all the things you probably already know, like how you don't have to kill any monsters if you puzzle out how to placate them.   So, Undertale is a quirky little puzzle RPG and one of the most emotional journeys I've ever had with a game. Determination, Hope, Joy, Fear, Sadness, Surrender, Despair, Rage. I felt it all. I wish I could say it was amazing the whole way through but there was one section that felt like a bit of a slog and I had to take a break. So I completed it in what, 4 days instead of 3? I'm not sure I'm done with it just yet seeing as there's apparently more to the story in other paths, but I have reached an ending I'm truly satisfied with.  It was well worth pushing through that one section to see everything unfold, and right now I've been starting at THE END for the whole time I've been writing this, mostly because the music is so good, but also to see if anything happened. You never know if there's going to be something more with this game. Almost everything is able to be interacted with and worth the interaction.  I kickstarted this game and I am very glad to have supported this game's creation more than anything else I've backed. I can practically guarantee you'll be glad you chose to purchase it as well.  Oh, one last thing before I go. Just remember that despite everything, it's still you.

Undertale might be one of the most memorable experiences I've had in years. If you're on the fence, play the demo and ask yourself if you want more.  The only real issue I had is that there are a few segments that aren't exactly color blind friendly. Thankfully, they can be brute forced without  too  much difficulty.

This game....I just don't know what to say about it that hasn't already been said 50 times over in other reviews. This game is usually compared to Earthbound and/or Mother 3, both in incredible use of humour and abrupt tearjerker moments   and nightmarish final bosses that give you nightmares.    What does this game have to offer, exactly?    Memorable characters    Incredible soundtrack    Easy to learn but hard to master 'avoiding damage' system    Excellent taste in humour    Good replayability    Multiple endings   so you can either slaughter everyone or be a true pacifist      The store page already mentions it but there's dogs    You pet the dogs    Bosses usually have their own special gimmick that is easy to quickly understand    I'm out of bullet points   I've never actually written a serious review for something before, but this game is worth your time and money. If it's ever on sale, buy it for yourself and buy another copy for a good friend. This game could easily entertain you where a game worth sextuple (aka x6) it's price won't.

I tried to avoid hype for this game, and with good reason. Don't get me wrong this game is fun and quirky, but is not the second coming of christ as many people claim.  With that being said, Undertale is a charming game with a nice bullet hell combat system and characters that are deeply varied and fleshed out. Getting multiple endings means decent replay value, amd the boss fights are varied and interesting  My two complaints are A). the game automatically assumes killing people makes you a terrible person. Truly an amazing game, amazing is just one of the many complimentary words I can use to describe this game. At first glance this game does not look to appealing. I was really on the edge if I should get it or not, but after reading some of the insane amount of positive reviews and considering the game was on sale, I got it. Let me tell you, I didnt regret it! Undertale has all you could ask for in a game. An amazing story, clean humour, adventure, a unique combat system, a nice soundtrack. The list just keeps on going! Undertale allows you to carve your own path in the story, either be passive to everyone you meet, or brutally beat them to a bloody pulp (I think you know which one I chose). Anyway, there are several endings to the game that you can get (One being absurdly weird and disturbing) that all depend on your actions throughout the game. And the combat system? Man, do I love the combat system! Its a unique twist of the pokemon combat system, but instead of just being attacked back and losing damage instantaneously, its actually almost like a minigame everytime your enemies (or friends) fight back, making it so that you can actually not get injured or get injured less by pure skill. It truly does give the game a twist when fighting enemies. Overall, this game is a prime example of a beautiful game sent from the heavens above. Sure I may only have 6 hours in the game as of writing this review, but trust me, I will be playing this game again just to see what the other endings have to offer! What are you waiting for? You could have already bought the game by now instead of reading this silly review! I'd hope you know by now how amazing this game is. Words cannot describe its true beauty, just play it already!

Undertale is quite the piece of art. Its an RPG/bullet hell/test of morality. Its got a level of self-awareness that is never seen except in comedic context. I highly recommend this game. Its short, but sweet. It has plenty of replayability, too.

I got this game as a gift from a friend, I love said friend more now.  This game had a serious impact on me, it's the first game I've ever played that made me feel and think a lot for a couple of days after I finished it, much like certain books and movies have done in the past.  It may not be the most visually amazing game out there, but the heart of each character, the challenging but varied and fun combat, the incredibly catchy music and the absolutetly staggering amount of different ways the game changes depending on how you play it, really makes it stand apart from other RPGs.  I wouldn't listen to all the hype and praise though, go in with a neutral mindset and give it a good chance, stay DETERMINED and it won't disappoint you.
Knowing that good video games can still be made fills me with determination.

Oh man, how do i begin with this review...  First of all, this game overstepped all of my expectations in just the very begining, this game is one of a kind, filled with awesome things that a lot of games nowadays forget to do or they just dont care about it anymore.  The story is the strongest part of this game and it is really well written and exectued, is a rollercoaster full of emotions, from the start to the conclusion the choices you do are going to be affected in the story, if you want to just play it without caring anything but kill people you are missing the whole point of the game, the little details this game has are unbelievable good, the cast of characters are funny, good and memorabe, the fights with bosses are great and the way they interact with is very unique. You can be a saint with everybody and get an ending, or be the devil formed in a little kid with a stripped shirt and kill everything that moves and get that good ol' EXP quicker.  The soundtrack is INSANELY good, it's the second strongest part of the game, it carries the game the same way the story does, it fits perfectly with the 8-bit style, the soundtrack is so good that even after you close the game you will still hear it in your head that you will probably go to youtube and listen it for hours while thinking how good the songs are.  I think in the future it will be one of those games for referece that will be remembered as one of the bests.  Long story short, go buy this game, you willl not regret it, it's one of the best 8 bucks (10$ without discount) that i've ever spent in steam.  Buy this game or die, or rather, play it then die.   My final rate is 89 billions/10, thanks for reading.

Absolutely wonderful. The first JRPG in a long time that has moved me to tears. From quirky characters, Wario Ware-like gameplay mechanics and great humour to a story that manages to be intriguing, well written, and surprisingly touching, Undertale hits all the right spots right from the start.
