Play this game. I don't care, just play it. Your friends calling you to hang out? You don't need friends. You need to use the money to buy food? You don't need food.   Oh and don't look the internet for anything about this. Thank me later.

A lovely adventure through an imaginary underground world infested with scary monsters, such as skeletons, tsundere planes or vegetables.   Entertaining sense of the creator's humour will accompany you through your journey as you meet various likable characters on your way back home, both enemies and (hopefully) friends. The game's preferred way of battling aggressors is trying to find a peaceful resolution which will convince the monster to stop fighting and the available options are unique per all monster types. For example, if you fight a sexy looking monster who can't stop admiring itself in the mirror, perhaps it'd like to hear about its nice hair? If you're not interested in becoming friends with anyone, you're also more than free to kill them, though that might have its consequences. Undertale features few endings based on the player's actions through the game and all of that is sweetened by the game's catchy soundtrack.  Definite 'must play' for people interested in story focused games.

A wonderful meta criticism of RPGs in general complete with a very creative world, fun characters, and some of the craziest breaking of the fourth wall to come by video games in a while. This game allows you to be an angel of hope or an angel of death. Actions have consequences, and this game never lets you forget that! Play wisely and you'll have a wonderful and touching experience from beginning to end.   Initially the hype around this game deterred me, but I couldn't have been more wrong about how good it could be. It has its flaws here and there, most often the backtracking, but it's nothing major and the puzzles aren't horrifically hard. The music is also fabulous. A lot of love went into this game!

I don't ususally find myself enjoying RPGs too often. But this game...  I love this game. Every action (or inaction) has consequence. Every character has... character. I doubt I've felt such a range of emotion from playing a game as I have this one, from laughter, to near crying, from pride, to compassion... You can tell that Toby has put a ton of thought and feeling into this game, in every interaction, in every single savepoint, in every single choice...  If you're reading this, I feel it's a good idea to pick up this game. Even if you're not, still go for it. You won't regret it.
I can't stop crying ;_; 'True Pacifist Route' totally broke my heart <3 Best game ever!

Make moral choices that effect the story while simultaneously listening to one of the best soundtracks of all time.
This is honestlythe best game I have ever played...no seriously... I thought Gmod was good XD (Gmod is good but this is much better!)

Undertale presents itself as traditional a 2-D RPG as it can get with turn based combat mechanics, a host variety of environments to explore and interact with, and an elaborate if not abstract cast of characters. The world in itself is actually beneath the world above because you're not just anywhere, you're many ways down under where many monsters will greet you.  However, at the surface, Undertale is a deceptive title with many elements that can be both endearing and perhaps even thought provoking. If your heart can survive the journey, you will further come to appreciate the quirks and good times that are buried in the game.  Combat mechanics often involve a bullet hell variety timing and precision with that very element being upped and turned on it's head just when you think you've learned to master it. The same can be said for the main cast of characters who can prove just as unpredictable and in an odd sense, human at their best comical standards and at worst dramatic moments.  The main element that shines in Undertale is the pacing and flowing of the story, and it's not just patience that players are rewarded for but their ability to not be violent. For those who have played it, they understand this. Combat can be achieved without combat at all and while arguably a bit more tedious, the results are as entertaining as they are heart warming. Undertale at it's peak will lavish players with genuine moments many developers and various teams strive to produce but all too often fail to achieve. On the same hand it will relentlessly punish players for cruelty and violence. A mirroring affect that not only denies the ultimate conclusion, but also does not relinquish after the game's credits have rolled.  Undertale proves in an age of more accessible and easily digestible plots coupled with bite sized gameplay, that with the right words and clever enough world, a game can hold onto you even more once it's concluded. If there is any one game on your list of ' I have too many -insert game service- games that I haven't played already so I won't buy this! ' this one should certainly not be on it.

Buy this game if you want to experience these things below. -8 bit graphics -Getting real life lessons -Cool soundtracks (and spooky ones) -Met a weaboo scientist -Sending a cat that types like a 5-year old kid to college -Multiple endings (pacifist, neutral, genocide) -Approaching a plane that is a bit tsundere  -Befriend with two skeletons  -Flip the switch -Stack 30 hotdogs on your head  Undertale will fill yourself with DETERMINATION. and feels. so much feels if you choose to pursue the good ending.  10/10 will pet 8-bit dogs again

It's kind of hard to say much about Undertale without spoiling it, but this game has quickly become a part of my heart and SOUL, and is extremely important to me. So I feel a huge need to recommend it to others.  To put it simply, Undertale is a game about a human that falls into an underground world of monsters. The game is made by Toby Fox, who you may know as a popular composer, notable for working on Homestuck, with pixel art by Temmie Chang. The battle system is unique in that NO ONE HAS TO DIE; every battle gives you the option of FIGHTng the traditional way, or ACTing; non-violently negotiating with the enemy to convince them not to fight anymore. The way you choose to address battles with this system has a permanent effect on the rest of the game. The other unique aspect of the battle system is the bullet hell style system to avoid damage, which is truly unique for an RPG. You can make friends, enemies, and many other things along the way. And, well, that's really all I can say about the story without spoiling too much. Oh, also it takes inspiration from another great game; earthbound. But at the same time manages to be its own thing. The humor, music, writing, and presentation are all top notch, and by the end you'll care so much about everyone in the game, and will possibly change the way you think about the world within a game forever.  In short, please pick up Undertale. It's so amazing, Toby Fox deserves money and, well, frankly, it's only 10 bucks. What have you got to lose?  * Reading this review... It fills you with determination.
I've never played a game that makes me feel so ♥♥♥♥♥♥ for accidently killing a character and then resetting the game.
This game filled me with determination.

11/10 - IGN This game made me poop my pants when i played it, Undertale is a Story-Rich JRPG inspired by other great games like Earthbound, i must say this but i havent seen a better game in my current life.

Buy it. No, stop reading this review. Go out and buy this game. There's no excuse as to why anyone shouldn't purchase this masterpiece of a game. It's only $9.99 on the Steam Store but offers one of the best story-driven games i've played in 2015. You see, it's not an ordinary game... everything you do MATTERS in this game. I dare say, it rivals choice making games like Mass Effect, Telltale Games, and so on.  Characters are incredibly likable, the puzzles are interesting without being cringe worthy to solve, enemies and bosses don't have to be slain (in fact, you can totally spare everyone and try obtaining the True Pacifist Ending like I did). The lore is really something you don't want to skip, the plot twists are pretty wicked, the boss fights are awesome, and nothing rubbed me off the wrong way.  If you're engaged, you'll most likely get emotional. There's bits in the game that don't make sense at first until you've completed it or done certain 'requirements' to find out the truth. God I love this game. It's extremely rare to get such a golden example when it's only $9.99 when i've played games that failed miserably while being sold for $59.99 ... yea. Greatest aspect is the fact your choices matter. Hey you want to reload and change something? Oh the game won't forget what you did during your previous save. Even if you quit and try making up, the game isn't going to forget. Think carefully about everything you do, for even the most useless / simple item could be significant later on. Everything matters, and I love how the game doesn't disappoint in reminding me of that.  Also the first game that asked of me to NOT restart (aka going into NG+) because story reasons. Yeah that took me by surprise but I loved it. In fact, I loved every moment I spent playing this game. It's funny, addicting to play through even if you die a few times ... you'll grow attached to the characters (especially Toriel) along with being sucker punched. It has dark themes, don't take this lightly as some happy-go-lucky game because it's not. But who's to say it has to remain dark? You choose however you want to handle the adventure, as a pacifist or murderer.   10 / 10 game, is now on my top ten favorite games OF ALL TIME. Please, support the game and buy it. I promise you, it's worth every cent when playing this well crafted game that I won't be forgetting anytime soon, or ever really.
A really touching story made me cry like a ♥♥♥♥♥ the music is really good the characters in this game are really well done  a must have game for my opinion

This game...this game touchs my very soul. Its music is powerful, its message is strong. Its cast of characters is amazing. I will forever carry this game and its music with me, where-ever I go. Its part of who I am, what I believe. Its part of my soul, my heart, and my mind. There is so much I wish I could say, but the words just...don't exist for me to convey how I feel. So many strong emotions swell within me. This game may have went silent, but it won't ever die.  Toby, if you are reading this...I would like to thank you for creating this game. There is much I wish to say to you, but I can't find the words for it. What you've made here...its just...perfect in my eyes. The music is so wonderful, the characters...I love it all. I want to thank you ever so greatly Toby. You're game helped me become a better being. You helped me see the errors of my ways, and I thank you for that. I thank you for this game, for its message...for everything.  To end this all...I just want to say this, one final time. Undertale is an amazing game. I loved playing it. I will never do a genocide run. I just don't have the heart or soul to do so. I can't bring myself to harm any of the characters in this game, nor can I see poor Asriel be killed off. I can't bring myself to do it, and I never attemped to do so. I love this game, and I will carry its message with me forever. Through this life, and whatever comes after this.  No matter how old I get, how old this game gets, I will always, always...keep its message known, its story and music heard. I will never drift away from it. This game shall always stay with me, no matter how old I do get. I will treasure it, and love it, as I do now. I don't care, if I will be hated for loving this game, long after its been released, I don't care if I'm made fun of, for my love of it. Because in the end, this game is still with me. I, love this game so very, very much.  Stay DETERMINED....and Goodnight.

Before you do anything else, do not research any more about this game after reading this review. Undertale is a game best played when playing as blind as possible. What can I say about this game? Undertale, a retro style RPG, is a wonderful game to play and has a well thoughtout story and concept, and offers a refreshing taste for those who want to play something different.  It's HIGHLY recommended to best play this game without knowing anything about it to begin with. So for your sake, I won't go into depth about the story.  The only thing I'd like to point out is if you're a person who has a bitter taste for memes in a game, let it be known that this game does have a few of those within the game as you go through the game. They aren't part of the story, but are there for ♥♥♥♥ and giggles if you wanna look at it that way (unless you're bitter and don't like that). And this game is also a bullet-hell type of game, so be prepared on exhaling out of your nose or mouth loudly (or screaming at your monitor, whichever is your perference of becoming angry).  The soundtrack for the game is also well made and woven perfectly into the gameplay. You might find yourself sometimes pausing in areas to listen and appreciate the music.  Undertale is worth playing. For 10 bucks, it sure is as hell fun. 10/10

Imagine all the bad tropes in indie games done right, and you have Undertale. I wrote this game off for being just another shilled out indie game, and I couldn't have been more wrong. This is everything you heard about it, and more. Even if you don't like RPGs, you owe it to yourself to try it out. Amazing soundtrack, great writing oozing with atmosphere.   A game where your choices, even the smallest of things, matter a lot. The game can be funny, heart wrenching, or pure nightmare fuel, all depending on how you play it.

First off, the combat system is very interesting and fun to play. Definitely inspired by bullet hell shooter-based games (Touhou, a notable example). Attack patterns and enemies are also varied. Little-to-no grinding, which is a fresh breath of air apart from traditional RPG and RPG-like games. You can negotiate and escape during a battle without unnecessary fighting, heck, you can even beat the game without killing a single soul.  Graphics does perfectly match those old RPGs from the 90s, but still needs some improvements. There are a few sections in the game that are just so empty and bland. Nevertheless, the developer did a very good job of recreating the retro feel.  Excellent writing filled with interesting characters, humor and twists. Very well designed endings, your choices really do matter. Also the breaking-the-fourth-wall sequences are done well and really help with the immersion.  Flowey/10
in the 10 hours i've played this i've had a much more fulfilling experience than the 2 and a half weeks i spent on the phantom pain  also i dated a skeleton, 10/10

Imagine all the bad tropes in indie games done right, and you have Undertale. I wrote this game off for being just another shilled out indie game, and I couldn't have been more wrong. This is everything you heard about it, and more. Even if you don't like RPGs, you owe it to yourself to try it out. Amazing soundtrack, great writing oozing with atmosphere.   A game where your choices, even the smallest of things, matter a lot. The game can be funny, heart wrenching, or pure nightmare fuel, all depending on how you play it.

Woah! :O  I've never had ANYTHING touch my feelings in such a deep way before as Undertale! It's crazy! And even half a week after finishing it I just can't think of anything else. My productivity went down, yet I feel like it was totally worth it. A huge inspiration! And those jokes are hilarious! xD  The world is very well written. Everything works together well, and even very early things have some meaning late in the game. Everything has a meaning! Even if they seem to be some flavour dialogue.    Though, personally, I'm not much a fan of the bullet hell fighting. But of course, the game needed some more gameplay elements, and this was the best way to add something while making it varied and unique for every monster. It never really got frustrating though!   One thing I'm even less a fan about is the whole meta stuff. About saving, loading, and resets being actual game components and seen by some characters. Especially in the endboss fights where   your file gets 'erased' and brought back.   It feels like it makes the actual story, about the war, the barrier, and you trying to just get home, feel so small and insignificant, as you're fighting for   reality itself, and not just to free the monsters, or just to get back home.     Especially odd as even after you fight the endboss, the barrier breaks, and everything is as if the entire timeline never was in danger.   I would really prefer if it was just its own little contained world, with a legend, and a hero.  But yeah, I imagine, since the game is largely about defying common tropes, the meta things were planned even before you came up with the story  Even thought it's a large part of my review, it did not make the game worse for me. It's more of a personal preference. Undertale still is my absolute favourite top game!    The writing reminded me a little to Psychnonauts, as many scenes are done in a humorous cartoon like fashion.  Many things that most game developers largely ignore have been added in. Many small things that work wonders together, giving the game a much more lively feel. Like the different facial expressions of the characters. And the 'cutscenes' like when   you were dating with Papyrus or cooking with Undyne,   or even when toriel angrily stared at that Froggit attacking you xD It seems to be so much additional work, but it made the whole game so much more fun and emotional! And the fight with Toriel, how she tried to stay determined, and slowly lost her steam, and eventually stopped attacking completely :C  I wish you could stay a little longer with her in the ruins in the beginning. To get a bit more familiar with her,...  ...and to make leaving her even worse D:   The music is perfect and conveys the feelings very well! The writing is perfect and conveys the feelings very well aswell! And the character sprites and animations are perfect and convey the feelings very well aswell aswell! :P  The tiles of the game map seem a little simple though. But I guess it's more of a style than just simple art. As things like the shop windows, or the core are in marvellous pixel art!   One of the many best things about the game is the ending. I only played one run in pacifist, but it was amazing!   I'm really really really really glad that the ending truly is happy. No sudden 'artsy' bittersweet ending, or a complete open ending. It really is a full, satisfying ending. You can see how the characters are doing afterwards, and even how you finally get to stay with Toriel x3    I really hope there will be a sequel or something similar set in this universe, even if it's not in the same genre as this game. But the worldbuilding and writing is just so grand. It could even be smallish slice of life things. Doesn't need any big adventures!   ]: )

Every so often, something comes along that is more than just a book, a movie, or a game. It's something special. It goes beyond the medium to create characters, situations, a world and an experience that you never forget as long as you live.  Undertale is side-splittingly funny, it's enormously charming, and its gameplay is unique and exciting, but all of these things will be forgotten in time. The characters, the world, the events that took place; these will not. A true artist puts a piece of his or her SOUL into anything they create, and I imagine there is a very large piece of the developer's SOUL inside of Undertale. By the end I felt affection for these characters. The prospect of something bad happening to them made me feel real, genuine emotion. They absolutely came alive in my mind, and these little fragments of the creator's SOUL push this well beyond a game.  That doesn't tell you anything about the plot, or the gameplay, or the style. It doesn't matter. If you're the kind of person who is looking for an experience, who wants to laugh and cry and be moved by a game instead of just stabbing the enemies until your LV goes up, this is for you.
Now that it's over... there's an Undertale shaped hole in my Undertale shaped heart.

An excellent game and likely now one of my top favorites. This is what happens when Earthbound/Mother 3 has a kid with the RPG Maker adventure RPG, Yume Nikki-- and I feel that after experiencing the game, it truly is my most apt comparison.  For a bit of backround, I tend to be very bad about completing games that I have, especially on PC. But Undertale is a game that kept my interest, and while it took me multiple play sessions to get through even one of the routes (Pacifist, I cannot handle Genocide yet), it was a well-worth experience that I wish I could experience again with a mind clear of expectations.  The writing is great, being consistently not only humorous, but also emotional. Toby Fox shines well with his music, and some of the tracks, especially during the end points of the game, need to be heard at least once-- preferrably while you're playing the game yourself. The characters of Undertale are all varied and endearing; even the store keepers are great to talk to. And some points are even kinda scary, but it's a good level of it that helps keep your attention.  The gameplay is absolutely unique, taking cues from bullet curtain games (Touhou) for the main point of your defenses. Attacking in itself is very unique as well, giving you a bar in which you need to press your execute button to hit the middle, or close to the middle, repeatedly. But there's the added twist that you can, definitely, get through the game without killing any monsters-- and in fact, it's vital for your run to do so, depending on what you're aiming for. To avoid killing, you can do Shin Megami Tensei-style options of trying to appeal to the monster to get them to stand down, at which then you can give them mercy and spare them. You can even choose to attack, but then not actually attack, which counts as a move in itself, which can help your way towards sparing. You won't gain EXP through this-- and the game 's Pacifist route is built in such a way that it's much more skill based due to the unique way of defending, so you won't need to level up-- but you will gain Gold in which you can buy healing items and armor with.  You come to care about the characters in the game. You become invested in seeing things through to the end. You truly want to see things reach a happy conclusion. Through a unique usage of automatic saves that happen in the backround, your actions will change your experiences-- and these are experiences that will stay consistent, even if you reload without saving. I don't think I'll ever see a game again that uses such a mechanic to this extent, and it is excellent as a story-building tool.  Really, I can't recommend this game enough. You might mess up at first. You might miss things you should do, at first. But experiencing this game is highly worth it, especially for the $10 entry price (though I wouldn't be against recommending buying the bundle with the OST for $8 more.)

A brick is building material used to make walls, pavements and other elements in masonry construction. Traditionally, the term brick referred to unit composed of clay, but it is now used to denote any rectangular units laid in mortar. A brick can be composed of clay-bearing soil, sand and lime, or concrete materials. Bricks are produced in numerous classes, types, materials, and sizes which vary with region and time period, and are produced in bulk quantities. Two basic categories of bricks are fired and non-fired bricks.  Block is a similar term referring to a rectangular building unit composed of similar materials, but is usually larger than a brick. Lightweight bricks (also called 'lightweight blocks') are made from expanded clay aggregate.  Fired bricks are one of the longest-lasting and strongest building materials, sometimes referred to as artificial stone, and have been used since circa 5000 BC. Air-dried bricks, also known as mudbricks, have a history older than fired bricks, and have an additional ingredient of a mechanical binder such as straw.  Bricks are laid in courses and numerous patterns known as bonds, collectively known as brickwork, and may be laid in various kinds of mortar to hold the bricks together to make a durable structure.

Undertale is a game that at this point doesn't need any introduction, it's gained a huge amount of attention, especially considering the game came out of pretty much nowhere and got little attention before the game launched. The game has gained a large and dedicated fandom that some would argue has gotten out of control.  But enough about that, lets talk about the game itself.  Positives -Excellent OST full of memorable tunes -A cast of well written, genuinely interesting and entertaining characters -Great story that's heavily affected by player choice -Good morality system -A few quite fun, if simple puzzles -Some quite nice spritework -A simple but still quite exciting battle system -some pretty crazy 4th wall breaking ♥♥♥♥ near the end. Negatives -Game can be a bit too heavy handed with the message at points -some of the spritework (especially the battle sprites) can be a bit bland and could use some more detail, and those battle sprites should be in colour.  All in all a excellently crafted game that I think everyone who calls themselves a gamer should at least try  9.5/10

As an avid old school RPG fan from the 90s, I picked up Undertale based on the hype alone. I wasn't quite sure what to expect, but I was hoping for a pleasant surprise.   Well, I was surprised all right. Let's start with you actually DO in this game, since nobody that reviews this seems to actually tell you anything about the gameplay.  This is at its core a very bare bones RPG. There are no skill trees, no special attacks, and no other stats other than attack, health, and defense. You have only person in your party - yourself - and you fight random monsters like any classic RPG. You have only 2 choices when you have a random encounter: Fight, or persuade. Fight is exactly that, direct damage against the monster's HP. The persuade option, or 'Act' let's you pick a dialogue option to talk the monster down. Pick the right one (or enough right ones in succession) and the monster stands down and you spare its life.  Combat is incredibly superficial. Worse, you will NEVER gain levels if you choose to spare all the monsters you face. Your only progression will be gaining new equipment, of which there is only 2 slots, and they are just stat upgrades generally.  Outside of combat is an extremely linear RPG experience. You go from environment to environment, encountering NPCs, small shops, and learn a bit about the lore behind the world. There's little exploration to do and little reward for doing it outside of the many jokes you might discover. There are a few puzzles, but most of them are incredibly simple and more designed to poke fun at puzzles found in most other classic RPGs.   There are some gimmicks the game utilizes. Each time a monster attacks you, instead of dealing simple damage, it opens a small bullet-hell mini game: Dodge all the projectiles and you take no damage from the monster. This is truly the only challenging part of the game. It tests your 1942 skills more than your RPG talents.There's also some very clever manipulation of your Save File that works really well when it's actually exploited, which is too rare. While the game has multiple endings it certainly doesn't warrant multiple play throughs.  Obviously the heaps of praise this game gets can't be justified on its game play. So does the overall presentation thrust it into greatness? Not really. Almost everything you encounter in this game is a joke or a long running gag - all monsters, their attacks, most NPC dialogue, and most search queries in the environment. Few of these elicit more than a chuckle, despite the constant absurdist quality of it all. The graphics are certainly not pretty as you'll note from the screen shots. Battles are almost complete black and white.  The game has almost no options. You can go fullscreen or what looks like 640x420. You can set some controller buttons. And that's it. There are no sound options so get ready to reach for that volume knob when you boot this sucker up.   It does have one thing going for - awesome 8-bit music. There are some seriously memorable tracks here (my shortlist of favorites: Metal Crusher, Song That Might Play When You Fight Sans, Dummy, Spider Dance, Megalovania, Bonetrousle). And there are a couple moments of sheer brilliance. The game is at its best when it plays off of RPG tropes and breaks the 4th wall. But there's not enough to justify how long it'll take you to get to those moments. I can't recommend it as a whole package.
Undertale is incredibly fresh, and incredibly nostalgic. It's hilarious, beautiful, and surprising. I'm so glad I've finally found a game like Undertale.

I normally don't go out of my way to review games, but this one was special. Like most people I played the demo way before the full game. The demo was so emotional, so I figured nothing could top that high standard. Boy was I wrong! I played a pacifist, and they throw some last minute feels at you before the final boss battles that actually managed to make me cry a little.  If you couldn't tell by now, the story was my favorite part about this game- not to say that I don't love everything else about it. The pixelized art is beautiful, the game mechanics are fun (not to mention an incredibly unique mix of touhou shooter and rpg battle that I'd love to see in more games in the future), your choices COMPLETELY matter (no, not just for endings- the entire game changes based on how violent you are), and while the music is subtle most of the time, when a boss battle or an emotional scene happens it makes things intense very quickly! If there were any complaints, it would be that the puzzles are very easy- but personally I liked that because then I could get to the story and character bits faster! *-*  This game is easily worth $10, and if you want to support it further the soundtrack isn't expensive! Personally I find it to be worth way more than $10, and I hope this game reaches consoles and handhelds in the next year.   ***** Possible Spoiler*****   If you want the best ending, never stop being a pacificist and be friends with every monster you can! (After playing the whole game through I don't know if I can handle murdering everyone... might have to just youtube it instead. Trust me, you get REALLY attached to a lot of the characters in this game!)

This is my first ever review but I just had to write about the game. I do not want to spoil anything but despite being funded on a low budget this game is better than ANY AAA game I've played so far. It made me laugh and smile so many times. I also cried a few times... It's quite the emotional roller coaster and I'm surprised I got such an enjoyable game for only 10$. The soundtrack is also amazing and I may possibly just throw another 10$ for it

Undertale is perhaps one of the most important narrative-based games ever made. Not only is it an amazingly charing RPG with interesting core game mechanics, but the things it does with the video game medium and the things it says about it help to understand and advance the ways that a game can tell a story.  With its mini-bullet hell-styled combat and the ability to interact with and spare enemies, Undertale uses every aspect of its battle system to flesh out its creatures, its world and your place in it. And that's just the tip of the 'burg. With multiple endings, so many great lines of writing behind every object and character, and an approachable 5-10 hour length, reaplaying the game is a rewarding experience. Also, the soundtrack is amazing. And, yes, you can date a skeleton.  So, yeah, Undertale should be a required play for anyone with interest in video games as an art form, specifically developers. Specificlaly because you can date a skeleton.

Out of any game I've played, this is the only one that I've completed 100%  It's hard to give away too much without spoiling some parts of the game, but the brilliant storytelling, fun combat mechanics, and unparalleled character development land this as my favorite game of all time.   I implore you to try this game for yourself. I am not a huge fan of JRPGs, but this game stole my heart.

There are very few games I can genuinely say I have felt a real connection toward its characters. In fact I can only say that's happened to me with only two or three characters. Characters like Chloe from Life is Strange, or Lee from TTG's The Walking Dead Season 1. However, I have to admit, never once have I ever felt that these characters have felt more like a genuine family member to me then any of the characters here in Undertale. Rather it's Toriel as my mother, or Asriel as my little brother, Sans as my cool uncle, or Papyrus as my UNcool uncle who's so uncool that he's actually super cool. I love these characters, I want them to succeed, I don't just feel bad for them, or sympathize with them, I feel happy when they are happy as well, and when they are sad, so am I. This became most apparent when I had fought Asriel at the end of the True Pasficet ending, as I SAVED him, and as began to scream and cry, begging for me to stop and let him win, I started to cry with him. After the fight, and it asked me if would forgive him, or not I did so without second thought. Then when the game asked me to comfort him, again I lost it, I wept several manly tears (okay maybe not very manly). Never before have I felt so attached to any characters in any work of fiction. I have never felt that I could relate, so closely then I have with this game. Toby Fox, if you actually read these (which is unlikely) Then I want to thank you personally, from the bottom of my heart, for making characters that I have come to love, so much.
10 out of 10 would recommend on IGN.

This game has changed my opinion for indie games, FOREVER. This game makes you feel like a giddy child recieving ice cream and your dad returning from the army after you just lost the tournament match in your favorite sport.  Amazing game. 10.1/10.

This game holds a mirror up to you and you are given the reality that reflects your actions. Goes from being sentimental and emotional to terrifying and hilarious all within minutes of each other. Most genuine and well thought out game I've played in years.

To be honest, I thought I wouldnt even like this game when I first looked at it, the visuals were kinda....meh. But, when a friend gifted it to me and I finally played it, I instantly loved Undertale as I realised that the visuals were probably the only flaw in the game.  Your actions dictate the story, and your choices actually do matter, as characters interact with you differently depending on what you've done. All this is complimented with a unique bullet-hell combat system, great characters, an amazing OST, and a great dark story.  When I'm convinced to replay a game just a few days after I finished it, I must've really liked it. But being convinced to replay it for the third time? That's all I got to say.  Go play it. Sure, its a polarizing game, if you don't like it, well meh, its okay, you move on and forget about it. Its only $10 after all. But if you like it? You'll really like it, and that $10 would've been put to good use.

EDIT: As of November 8, after 3 weeks of on-and-off play, I finally beat Undertale--twice. One for the neutral ending, the other for the true one. Still my favorite game of the year.    EDIT TWO I MISSED THE ♥♥♥♥ING ASRIEL EASTER EGG, BRB, INITIATING TRUE RESET!!    Man, this game.  I've had the various endings, characters and most events spoiled for me forwards, backwards, and sideways; and I'm not even halfway through my first playthrough yet (it's pacifism, don't worry). Even with that being said, I'm still going to finish the game, because  I love Undertale so damn much .  Given that you play the game as the pacifist, Undertale provides an absolutely fantastic experience choc-full of memorable characters who will undoubtedly drive you into maximum overfeels. I guarantee you at least one event that'll make you laugh..and cry. The latter has many more than the former. Every time you run into an encounter, random or otherwise, the game turns into a mix of an RPG & bullet hell that is always refreshing.   Be warned that malicious actions have consequences; the game WILL remember if you kill somebody, even if it's an insignificant minor enemy, and will bar you from the true ending. Should you be really curious to see what happens if you kill things, watch Youtube videos on it.  I recommend this game to anyone who liked the Mother (Earthbound) series. Undertale is actually quite inspired by it, IIRC. It's hands down one of the best games I've played this year. Hell, it's my favorite game of the year. No, wait, not even that--it's my most favorite game  ever .  11/10, would play through again. And again. And  again .

I can count on one hand number of times a form of media has had such an impact on me that I've spent a whole day in a post-completion stupor, thinking about the experience I'd just had, the journey I'd just been on, the feelings I'd felt. Shockwaves of emotion emanate from the memory of the story, just as powerful as they were when originally felt. Lessons are learnt, hours are spent looking up fanart, theories, experiences from other players - anything to keep the journey alive.  Undertale was an experience I'll never forget, ranking amongst games, films, novels and series that have stayed with me for years. I can say without a shadow of a doubt that no game has made me connect with its characters on as strong a level as Undertale did, and they lack three dimensions and voice-acted speech. I genuinely laughed out loud at several parts of the game, bawled like a child at others, and loved every second of it.  If you do pick up Undertale (which I cannot recommend enough that you do), do yourself a favour and really  get  into it. If you do, you'll find a game that will reciprocate the action, only it'll be there to stay.

Oh boy, how do I begin describing this game? It is very hard to do so without spoiling, and if it is spoiled, then a great part of the experience will be ruined. But here I go.  Undertale at first glance might look like a simple looking JRPG, with some new twists added to the typical JRPG formula. You can either kill or spare your enemies, and who and how much you kill affects the outcome of the game. Instead of directly receiving attacks from enemies that lower your HP, defending works as some sort of mini bullet hell, and each boss adds its own little twists into it. It is rather fun, although the random encounters don't offer too much by themselves. Gameplay wise, it is fun and enjoyable, and can provide a great challenge if you so desire.  But really, it is a whole lot more than that. Undertale reminds us of how powerful storytelling can be in a videogame, in a way only videogames are able to achieve and no other medium can ever dream of. It is truly a great experience, and a real ♥♥♥♥ing ride all the way through. Gameplay and Story tie together very damn well, and your actions for once, have real importance.  And did I mention the soundtrack? Holy damn, it's ♥♥♥♥ing god tier and one of my favorite soundtracks ever. Really great stuff.  So my verdict? Go buy it now. Seriously. It's a really fantastic game.

Undertale.... a game that i had never given much credit. When i first looked at it; the graphics seemed bad, monsters seemed stupid, and the story didnt seem appealing. But i started seeing people talk more and more about this game... i had to give it a try, and to my surpise was one of the best games i've played in a long time. That said the worst thing about Undertale is its hard to decribe because your experience is different depending on how you play...    I have completed the Neutral and True pacifist routes so my experience/ review may be different then someone who:   *played the Genocide route  *Only played Neutral route  *Did not play through the entire game (Which is kind of a given)  -----  Undertale is a game where your choices matter.... that said there is really only 2 major choices that really effect the game. Kill all the monsters or don't. There is a 3rd ending but it requires you to complete the 'Neutral route' first. Anyway, even though the choice seems small it changes the way certain characters act, which ones you meet, which ones you wont, and how future run thoughs are played.   Neutral:   For me i found this route like every other rpg out there. Bond with certain characters, boss battles, dying to monsters a lot, and exploring a world of the creaters imagination. But the game has many things that set it apart from other rpgs. The jokes are perfect, interesting ways to fight creatures, amazing character development, and sometimes 'pee your pants creepy' moments. This route (when you dont kill any of the main characters or any monsters at all) really makes you fall in love with the friends you make on your journey. The ending to this route is creepy and funny all at the same time and makes you want to replay the game to get another ending and actually beat the game (this routes ending makes you feel that there is stuff undone).  True Pacifist:   The ending to any RPG that makes you get close to your friends within the game. Though it still stands apart from other rpgs with its humor, story, and surpising experiences. When beaten the game will make you feel as if you cant reset it thanks to a character asking you not to 'reset the time line' and make you feel as if you are playing god.   Genocide:   The route you take if you kill every monster. Although i haven't played this route for myself i have seen/watched/ and talked about this route with others. This route makes this friendly RPG turn into a horror game all of its own. The main characters that were your friends in the other two routes become your enemies and the way they talk and act are different. Sometimes when you check places red text will apear telling/ asking strange things like 'where are the knives' or 'its me, (fallen human's name)'. Though this route is much different and some what terrifying the mystery and strory development are great.   ----  Undertale is a beautiful, beautiful game and i suggest this game to anyone willing to sit down and play it. It really surpised me and i can say personally that its an experience worth while... the best way to describe it is to say...its a friendly rpg where NOBODY has to DIE....

Undertale is a game that is hard to explain with words. It has singlehandedly made me laugh, feel more emotion, and feel more excitement than any game I have ever played before it. Easily my favorite game of 2015 and perhaps my favorite game of all time. For 10 bucks, you could buy 2 foot long subs filled with regret. Or you could buy this... this masterpiece.

[No spoiler review!]  This game is polished.  Cutting through the sea of early access games with hollow content that never seems to fully flesh out, and the rocky AAA titles that chopped swathes of content in order to meet deadlines, this game's attention to detail, well thought-out plot, and self-aware style shine through like a veritable diamond in the rough. On more than one occasion I found myself thinking that the author has really thought of everything for this game.  This game is a puzzle RPG.  Puzzles abound on the overworld. Combats can be resolved in more than one way. Creativity, clever solutions, or 'thinking outside the box' are all generally rewarded. Enemy attacks are predictable and reasonably avoided. That said, this is, at least mechanically, an easy game. If you expect your technical skills to be challenged, you will be disappointed, except perhaps for a few boss fights. Equipment and items are available should you find yourself struggling, or could instead be forgone altogether to increase the difficulty.  This is an emotional game.  As an RPG, reading (and understanding) the on-screen text is important. If you find yourself often skipping through text in games, or have difficulty immersing yourself in a game, you will be disappointed in this game. If instead, you find yourself often wondering how other characters might react to a given plot event, you'll often be pleasantly rewarded. Difficult choices are available to you throughout the game and are reasonably presented. Conversely, the game's humor keeps the energy high at all the right times.   If you buy this game, expect to put 10-15 hours into a single playthrough, depending on your skill level and reading speed. It is well worth the $10 this game cost at the time of review.

Undertale is not a game, it is an experience.  Do you like RPGs?  Buy this game.  Do you like games with a sense of humor?  Buy this game.  Do you like stories with characters that are so well-crafted you are convinced they are real?  Buy this game.  Do you want something to play after getting burnout from other games?  Buy this game.  Do you like games that are different when you re-play them in a different way?  Buy this game.  Do you like games that are so clever, they can successfully go meta?  Buy this game.  Do you have free time?  Buy this game.  Do you want to join a fun, loving community?  Buy this game.  Do you want to understand what the hype is about?  Buy this game.  Do you want to see why it got voted Best Game of All Time on GameFAQs?  Buy this game.   There  ARE  no downsides. Buy the game, or your life will not be complete.

So I don't really post reviews for games...        But this is not a game.   This is an   EXPERIENCE   that made me feel a range of powerful emotions where other games could only make me feel a certain way for a set ammount of time and would let that feeling fade away.  Undertale felt polished and ready and full of tiny details that could make someone's day better.  In fact, all of the choices felt like tiny details. If you don't know, in Undertale you have the option to not kill anyone at all but you are always given the choice to do so and that makes you wonder 'What would happen if I kill this person right now?' and if you did, it would change how the story plays out, but not the story itself.      I have only ever done a pacifist run (the story for not killing anyone) but I've seen that a genocide run completely changes the feel of the of the game and even   slightly   changes the ending of a pacifist run. (I don't have the heart to go and kill every one ;-; )   However, as all good suprises: The less said the better.  But this is the best game that I have played in years.           (I just realised that Undertale is almost the exact opposite of Hotline Miami)

Do yourself a favour and buy Undertale.  This game has quickly become one of my all-time favourites - the music is gorgeous, the story is great, the combat is fun (think Earthbound meets WarioWare), and the characters are each so unique and well-developed that you can't help but fall in love with them. What's not to like??  And the best part? Your choices matter. Seriously. A lot of recent games don't handle morality-based stuff well, but Undertale knocks it out of the park. There's something about this game that lingers in the back of your mind even a few days after its over, and that's how you know you've come across a story that's really special.   TL;DR: 10/10 would cry over skeletons again

The concept of the game is very interesting, the Genocide, Pacifist and Neutral routes make the gameplay very interesting and ensure if you want to play the game you won’t have to play through the same story line. I personally enjoyed the Pacifist route the best, doing what is needed to start and maintain the Genocide route is heart-breaking to do as all the characters are very lovable and the consequences for your actions make the player feel bad for choosing Genocide. So overall the game is very well made for just been made by mainly one person and the storyline it great and the characters are very well designed.  -SPOLERS-  I have to say my favourite part of the game was in the Pacifist route meeting Papyrus and going through his puzzles, his reaction to seeing you for the first time is funny and seeing him trying so hard to capture you is moving to watch as he really wants to become a part of the royal guard.   My favourite character has to be Sans, he is very amusing when he makes puns and is overall a lovable character. He is also very mysterious because he appears to ‘teleport’ places, for example when you head towards the mysterious door Sans seems to teleport after he goes out of the view of the screen and when Sans walks away and appears in the completely opposite place to where he was originally heading.   Overall I would recommend this game because of its detailed and deep story line, lovable and interesting characters and good soundtrack that just about always fits with the events and locations.

Well, coming from an Earthbound fan (and one who's been waiting for the Mother 4 release for over 2-3 years now), this game came as quite a surprise gem. I never knew of the past Kickstarter campaign it came from, and upon the release, I had no initial draw toward the bits and pieces I had seen of it.  That is, until a friend of mine gifted this bundle of entertainment to me.   Though I immediately saw the draws between this and the Mother Franchise, I couldn't help but love it. Music, Character Development, Story, and hell, even the unique encounter system was humorous the whole way through.  Though it probably sounds like ignorant gushing over a game, this was legitimately one of the most surprisingly touching games I've seen over the past year, and I'm sure glad to see many more open to this quirky style. :D  Since its indie fame has jumped forth (leaping, more like it), my only hope is that unlike other quickly hyped indie games that are released nowadays (looking at you, FNAF) that the community around it, doesn't over-saturate what makes this game unique to anyone that has given it a quick look.  Don't spoil this game for yourself, it would really be a waste.   For all of you reading that are waiting for Mother 4, this will not be a disappointment. :)

It is 3AM as of writing this review.  This game has fantastic humor which frankly trumps almost every game I've seen in the past decade. It has characterisation that far outstrips most other RPGs you can pick up today, and the story holds more suprises and genuine twists than I can even remember.  But remember one thing, this game is lighthearted, funny, both heartwarming and heartbreaking, has so much attention to detail and funny, genuine well written character interaction that it's hard not to get attached to the characters. At the same time, the game can really pull off some very dark moments, the soundtrack has amazing range and the art just works.  Oh, and as a closing statement?  You know when you think the game's over? Hah, don't worry, you'll figure it out.

I went into this game not quite sure I was getting to, but I ended up getting a lot out of it.  It's a unique game where it actually feels like it does what it claims to do: that your choices actually determines how the game plays out—characters will act differently whether you're being a friendly pacifist, or a kill 'em all murderer. The world can feel alive, or it can feel like you're the only person alive.  While the combat may not be everyone's up of tea, I enjoyed it greatly. Figuring out how the normal monsters ticked were easy enough after awhile, but it's the bosses where the mixed combat of puzzle and bullet hell shooter really shine. Each of the bosses has a unique take on it, and it was an element I enjoyed greatly.  The biggest strength though, is its writing and its characters. The characters are well-designed and well-written—sticking with you long after you finish the game. You'll start to care for them over the course of the game if you choose to befriend them, and they just might shatter your heart should you decide kill them instead. But even then, some of them show the strength of their character in the face of adversity—either by still believing in you and giving you the benefit of the doubt, or by giving it their all to keep the rest of the world safe.  And on the story, the game does a fantastic job of balance with its thematic elements. On the surface, it seems like a very simple, lighthearted game with its many jokes and snappy writing. But its lightheartedness only serves to really drive home the darker elements hidden beneath the surface. It's a game that'll make you laugh, make you cry, make you scared, and make you smile all at once.  The other strength is its soundtrack. It is absolutely worth the bundle, but even if you don't get when you buy the game, it's worth the $10. Many of the game's battle themes are extremely catchy and pleasant to listen to, but even some of the overworld themes will find a way to get stuck in your head.  I will say that for those that get major anxiety from unsettling/creepy imagery, then it might be a little difficult for you to get into it. Near the end of the game if you go the   neutral   route, then it can get extremely rough for about thirty minutes or so with the final boss. Just throwing that up there as a warning.  One last note, you real need to get the true end of the game. It'll take more than one playthrough to do it, but I promise you the payoff is worthwhile.

My analasys of this awesome game: The soundtrack is awesome, and really compliments the sometimes stupid and otherwise awesome moments in the game. The graphics are 8-bit retro, i know. But even though they might look a bit odd at first glance i think it was a good choice to focus more on the gameplay and story aspect of this game. The story is absolutely amazing, this is one of the most captivating and beautiful stories to come out of the games i've played. The gameplay is really interesting as it (without spoiling anything) allows you to become one with the character, and makes every encounter different. The mechanics, now this might not make a lot of sence if you haven't completed the game already, but the game actually keeps track of your deaths and choices throughout the game, which at the end comes to a conclusion based on a lot of different variables. This makes it so that you can actually have three different playthroughs and get to different endings because of your choices. The ending is awesome, the gameplay is ridiculous and it changes very fast from making you laugh to making you cry. I would probably rate this game 9.8/10 the only reason as to why it wouldn't get a 10/10 would be because the game made me love the characters so much that i still can't get myself to do the genecide route.

But otherwise if you have never heard of this (somehow) or are looking for a unique gameplay experience in an RPG this is a great pick up.

Undertale is one of those games that you see a lot of online and don't really know much about until you look into it a bit more, but when you do look into it you're hooked. The game has amazing characters (not just main characters - the entire supporting cast are just as great) that you truly do care for as well as having different features and areas that can be achieved and unlocked through playing the game in different ways. I would recommend that for your first playthrough you avoid any spoilers if possible and just go through it without knowing what lies ahead. By this point you'll probably be in love with the game and want to play it again, which is great news because there's three different endings to the game! To top it all off, the game has an amazing soundtrack that you'll have stuck in your head for days, but because it's that good you won't mind at all.  I really do recommend that you go into the main part of the game with very little information about what's to come, however if you do want to see what the game has to offer then I recommend checking out the first episode of the Steam Train playthrough on YouTube (spoilers are kept to a minimum but it provides enough footage to see what the game has to offer). If you like what you see there then buy the game and play it before you watch any more footage from it as there's so many things that you should experience for yourself the first time that you see them, especially when you reach the point where the different endings come into play!

This game was a creative joy road down Feels Alley with a few stops at WTF town, Mind Blown Lane, and Comedy Street. Toby Fox and co. made a brilliant game. Fallout 4 be damned, once I fired this up I couldn't stop till I was done.  What I liked about it (aside from the obvious heaps of creativity lovingly dumped all over every aspect of the game) was the way it turned the whole RPG system on it's head with the ACT system and then how it had a consistent story with foreshadowing, hints, and teasers that tied everything in. It also addresses the player being able to Save and reload saves by working this into the game in a fascinating, and at one point terrifying, way.  I'd recommend this game to everyone. It is a must play and should be Game of the Year for 2015.

By this time, you have probably heard something about Undertale, due to the massive hype train about it. Whether it is showing up in image macros, youtube videos, or various in-jokes, it is clearly a massive internet sensation. I will do my best to try to cut through the hype and get to the core of the matter.  Undertale is an RPG based on games from the 16-bit era (SNES/Genesis) with elements of bullet dodging games. The mechanics are fairly straightforward - walk around and interact with characters, occasionally getting into turn-based combat. The combat interface features option for attacking the monsters, which uses a timing minigame, running, and using items. The innovation comes in the ability to perform a variety of actions toward monsters. Choosing certain actions will convince the monster that you are friendly, and can end an encounter without you or the monster dieing. This awards you with gold, but does not award XP. When it is the monster's turn, there is a brief dodging minigame. This gets tougher as the game progresses, but the game is not a bullet hell. I've been okay even on my low LV run, despite being pretty bad at bullet dodging.  The graphics of Undertale are mostly 16-bit sprites, and pretty well done. The game looks well put together, but don't 3D graphics or photo realistic designs.   The musical score for this game is one of the best I have heard in an indie game. It's a nice blend of 16-bit retro tunes and a wide variety of musical styles ranging from symphonic to jazz to rock to polka. Sound effects are otherwise fairly basic. Each character has a particular sound effect for their voice, making it possible to recognize them, but there is almost no voice work in the game.  Undertale's hype is built almost entirely on its story. It has a large number of ending variations. Every boss you kill or spare changes the outcome of the game. It is indeed possible to live up to the game's tagline of being the RPG where no one has to die, and that is a very satisfying if challenging outcome. You can also kill every single monster in the game, which is challenging for its own reasons. The game has a message to it, but it is not preachy or really self-righteous about it. The game just treats monsters in random encounters like characters as opposed to being just a source of XP. It also takes into account game mechanics in the story - saving and loading is something that happens in the world of the game.  Characters in Undertale are highly memorable. Toriel and Flowey (both of who show up in the first few moments of the game and are on the cover art) are both very interesting characters with a solid amount of backstory available to explore. Writing is clear and easy to read, and the game's humor is pretty impressive. I have written this with the intent of not spoiling the game, and it is best experienced unspoiled. (I read spoilers beforehand and wish I hadn't)  If this sounds at all interesting to you, I recommend buying Undertale. It is well worth $10 US, the soundtrack is great, and when it is on sale it's a steal.

Undertale is not a game for everyone. Some will call it the best game ever made and rave fanatically about it, others will find it to be a good game. Still more will find that not much in the game speaks to them, and many will even seek to silence the fanatics and tarnish the games reputation wherever they can. For a moment however, let's forget about the polarising fanbase, all the hype, all the arguments.  I won't tell you that Undertale will be the best game you've ever played. I won't tell you that Undertale will change your life. I wont' tell you that you will hate Undertale. I won't tell you that Undertale is overrated. I won't tell you how you have to feel about Undertale. In fact,  I won't even tell you that you HAVE to play Undertale.  Instead I'll tell you what Undertale means to me.  To me, Undertale is a fantastic and unique gaming experiance. It is a lesson for me about simple game design and story telling. I love the music and the characters and their stories tug at my heart strings. It's a trip down memory lane and brimming with personal nostalgia thats very close to my heart. The story and gameplay seem unique and new for me, somthing farmiliar and yet different. The battles annoyed me a little after a while and some monsters seemed to easy for me. The boss battles on the other hand excited me and I was always salivating for the next one. I adore pixle art but the graphics were too simpllistic for me. They did however manage to grow on me over time. The story brought me to tears on more than one occasion. In the end I was filled full to the brim with determination and felt a real connection with the game and it's characters, one I have not felt for quite a long time.  I loved Undertale.  I will tell you, if you think the trailer or demo look interesting, that you SHOULD play Undertale. Then once you've made up your mind, good or bad, you can come back and tell everyone what Undertale means to you.

This game is a little overhyped by its fans, and while I do like Undertale, it does have its flaws and is not as good as the hype would suggest.  Here's how it is. The graphics are sub-par, just barely a cut above an average gamemaker game, although they are a little bit better during battles. The gameplay is unique, but still feels barebones. The game's 'mercy' mechanic is neat but doesn't really change that the gameplay is still very simple.  The only place where this game really shines is in the writing. The characters are charming and witty and the story has all kinds of twists and turns. It may remind you of your favorite cartoons from when you were a kid. If there is a reason to buy Undertale, it is the writing. Everything else in the game is just a vessel for conveying the story, and it shows.

Pros: + Demands to be loved and adored, and succeeds at it. Game is very cute and has an insane amount of charm. You will laugh, smile, and be decently close to tears. + Characters are all somehow so easy to get attached to. They're goofy and not really written in a 'epic novel' way, but they are very easy to like. + Gameplay is simple to grasp but can be difficult when it needs to be. Some fights will give you some minor trouble in the 'clean' run, whereas the 'genocide' run is notoriously more difficult. It's very reminiscient of games like Earthbound (which is where some inspiration is drawn from, so good for that). + Story is very intriguing and sad, and offers a lot of alternate endings depending on your choices (the absolute good ending, the neutral endings (loads of these), and the genocide endings). All have different meanings to take away from the game. + Addicting soundtrack. + Memes.  Cons: - Despite the good value for the price, it is short. I would have gladly paid 50$ for 5x the amount of things to explore if the experience was just like that. Granted, there are multiple endings to explore and replaying the game changes things around!  - While the ending felt very resolved and I loved it, I wish there was more to do with a certain character we encounter at the end. I also wish there was more interaction with many of the main characters. - Hard mode needs to be fully done! With maybe more story to be had if you redo the pacifist run in hard mode.  Overall:  Great value for the price, and a game that deserves the hype it gets (at least, on tumblr). I'd recommend it for anyone craving a well-crafted, thoughtful, classicaI gaming experience. I also really hope the creator does more with the universe, and tries for bigger projects. I'd love to pay for more.

When looking upon the RPG genre, many games can be looked upon and most are great in story and content. However, the need to 'Level up' and 'gain exp' has always been questionable to me because it seems kind of disturbing in the long run. 'Kill this thing and level up then go kill another and level up,' the system is good, don't get me wrong, but it seems unnecessary at times. This game beautifully questions this system while also having the same content of a RPG. While also abiding to this way of gameplay, it also adds in cooky characters that make you laugh, smile, and even in other playthroughs cry. All in all, the game is a masterpiece, although the fandom is crazy, and I highly suggest it for anyone with time to spare.  Oh, and I NEED TO WEAR FOUR PAIRS OF HOT PANTS!

If you want to know what I like about this game, read basically any other positive review, because they're all correct. Undertale is a very good game. Contender for game of the year, strong contender for indie game of the year. However, just like everything else in the world, it isn't flawless. These problems are all pretty minor in the grand scheme of things, but they should nevertheless be mentioned for the sake of completeness. Like I said, if you want to read what's good about it, there are literally thousands of other positive reviews you can read that'll mirror my views. I'm going to focus on the problems. (No spoilers)     High difficulty spikes for some boss battles.  Some fights are drastically more difficult than the preceeding area, to an often jarring degree. Make no mistake - even though it may not look like it, the game actually provides gameplay challenges. If you want to recommend Undertale to someone who doesn't usually play video games, keep this in mind.     Unpolished from a technical standpoint.  You can't enter the option's menu after loading your save - which you wouldn't want to do anyway, because there's literally nothing aside from 'Joystick Config'. Volume options, keyboard controls and resolution options are nowhere to be found. When playing in fullscreen (toggled by F4), there's some sort of invisible diagonal line that offsets the screen by about one pixel - it's not noticeable unless you sit close to your monitor, but it's there. Furthermore, the game crashes when you try to quit from fullscreen. Obviously it doesn't matter if you wanted to close the program anyway, but it's still mildly annoying. Finally, it runs at 30 FPS, which is honestly works perfectly fine, but the bullet hell sections would still benefit from a higher framerate.     Technically, there is player choice, but most people will have a nearly identical first playthrough anyway.  This is my most abstract criticism, because not only is it necessarily a bad thing, it's not even the game's fault. Let's face it, why  wouldn't  you do a pacifist playthrough your first time around? Undertale advertises its ability to negotiate yourself out of combat as a unique feature - and it is... which is why almost everyone's first playthrough is going to look almost the same. When given a choice between 'do what you do in every other video game ever' and 'do something new', it's not really much of a choice. If being merciful was a more common feature in games, you'd have more people doing a 50/50 playthrough or 'kill everyone' playthrough. But as it stands, since the words 'Killing is unnecessary' are the game's main selling point, it's clear that the vast majority of people will want to take that as far as possible.     EDIT: I don't like something about one of the endings,  I'm not going to go into details in order to avoid spoilers, I just wanted to point out that there is something I see as a blemish in the narrative. Most people don't seem to share my opinion though, so whatever.   If for some reason you think I hate the game, let me quote myself. ' Contender for game of the year, strong contender for indie game of the year. ' I'm just pointing out these flaws, because I haven't really seen anyone else do it. If you want to know why it's a good game, read literally any other review, or - better yet - play the game for yourself. The less you know going in, the better.

Want to cook ramen in the middle of a fight? Use the flavor packet. Want to make friends with a flower?...  ...perhaps not.  Seriously though. If you've already watched someone play this game on YouTube, you've runined it for yourself. If you're in doubt of getting this game, buy it before it's spoiled for you. I've enjoyed nearly every element to this game.

I really do feel like I'll come off as a broken record if I add my voice to the ten-thousand-something reviews here already, so I'll try to keep it short and sweet.  The storyline, if you ask me and plenty of other people, is well done. The characters are very memorable, have some interesting and  (At least somewhat)  unique personalities. Undertale was the first time in, well, ever that I found myself delighted when I saw Papyrus and Comic Sans in use. It was interesting to see how simple text, with barely any voices at all, can convey so much emotion. There were times that the game had me laughing quite a bit. And admitingly, on the other hand, Undertale was the first time that a videogame had me close to tears with emotion; but to be honest, I don't think that's a bad thing – it just shows how powerful of a game it can be.  The soundtrack worked perfectly with the game, as well. Helped to make the game much better, in my opinion. It's understandable if pixel art isn't your thing, but Undertale seems to pull it off well. It really does feel like some honest effort was put into making it look great.  Throughout playing the game, I have been desperately searching for flaws that the game may have. The puzzels are a bit of a challenge on the first try, but not too hard. They'll have you confused for maybe a minute, but they're by all means do-able. Whether this is a good thing or a bad thing is debatable. There's also the community. It shines in some spots, but in others, it's ... questionable. Personally though, I don't tend to keep a community in mind for rating a game; most of the time, how the community/fandom acts is not the direct result of creator intervention.  Games like Undertale are hard to come by.  REALLY  hard. It's rare that you find games such as this that shine, stand out from the rest, and are nearly perfect. The only flaws I find in Undertale are ones that, if you ask me, have little to no effect in the end.  Undertale is a full on 10/10. It's only like, ten bucks man. You're only doing yourself a favor by buying it.

[Characters] Characters are easy to understand and can fit into basic descriptions Frisk - The deaf kid who is always nice Chara - The girl who never blinks and has a bloody knife Toriel - The old woman who always is nice to children Flowey - Similar to Chara but does blink and has no knife I think you get it. [Story] Very simple Once upon a time,two races lived over the earth Wazowskies(Monsters) and Doras (Humans) Then there was a war and this guy used a spell and was like YOU SHALL NOT PASSSSSSSS Monsters want revenge against humans blah blah blah [Overall Gameplay] With four buttons FIGHT ACT ITEM MERCY it is similar to most RPG games but instead is more of FIGHT SPECIAL ITEM FLEE,making Undertale's system a bit different. Most people know that ACTING leads to MERCY. Now UNDERTALE is one of the few RPG games where you don't have to kill. Other RPG games that don't involve killing are 1. From Gamejolt and only involve exploring 2. Some idiot's work into trying to be better than this game. Or 3. Simply unexplainable. I actually hate people who hate people that hate this game (Bububleh that's alot of hate and people) since they are 1. Children under the age of 13 2. A mega-fan of Undertale or 3. Spoiler-free, humor-lite, non-ironic, vague-heavy review.  So, I played the game, as I assume most other people played the game (the first time, anyway), and it was a decent, quirky jRPG with some likable NPCs and a cool battle system. The end. And I beat the game (the first time) in the way I assume most people would beat it (the first time). And as I proceeded towards that first ending, it left me a bit underwhelmed. What had I missed that that made everyone swoon over this game? The stern advice of my friends filled me with determination to re-play the game... differently.  I replayed the game a second time, to get a different ending. And oh wow. The mind-blowing twists in plot, the depth added to those likable NPCs, the --actual-- nature of the plot. Just damn.   20/10. Not only must you play it, you must play it twice. Thrice, really.

In all my 10 or so years of being a gamer, nothing has ever stood out like Undertale. This masterpiece of a video game is unique to everything I've played, I've played on many different platforms through the my life on things like lesser known platforms such as VSmile, ION (don't remember what what was) and more known platforms such as the GameBoy Advance, DS, Nintendo Entertainment System, Super Nintendo Entertainment System, Nintendo 64, Wii, Atari 2600, Texas Instruments 99 4/A, PlayStation 1 and 2, Xbox 360, Xbox One, Arcade Machines and PC. Yet throughout all of the games I played on all of those platforms, none of them I repeat NONE OF THEM! Have ever been as close as Undertale. This game is more than just a work of art. It's the masterpiece that has and always survives the test of time. The primitive pixel graphics seems to add to the charm the game possesses. Undertale is the Mona Lisa of the entire Steam Library. It has memorable characters, a deep storyline and an amazing soundtrack. This is a work of art unlike any other. I HIGHLY recommend Undertale to everyone on Steam.

Undertale is a total waste of five hours...     of crying helplessly in the corner after you've beaten it.  Seriously, no game has ever challenged me, excited me, or entertained me as much as this game. tobyfox is a brilliant mastermind that breaks the mold of RPGs and the constant cut/paste behavior of game developers and storytelling, what this game is here is a testament to what video games should be.  if you haven't played it yet this is a spoiler free area. so enjoy this review. DO NOT RESEARCH THIS GAME ONLINE. DO NOT LET THIS GAME BE SPOILED FOR YOU. YOU NEED TO BE A DECENT HUMAN BEING AND SIMPLY PLAY THIS GAME. this game has a long, long list of nuances and decisions only you can make, so make them wisely and without spoiling the story for yourself, promise you you'll love it.  down to the technical, this game is an RPG, puzzle game, bullet hell, with fantastic storywriting and lots of hidden extras that plague you on your first through one hundreth runthrough. this game was the most FRUSTRATINGLY DIFFICULT game ive dealt with in a long time that didn't make me feel like hurling the keyboard at a wall. you WANT to finish this game and get to the end, to see it through in the marvelous way its written and designed.  down to the asthetical, great music, great art, great scenes (this is all 8 bit mind you) but its all so brilliantly drawn and meticulously crafted to bring you in deeper to the story. please whatever you do just enjoy this game. dont fly through it.  if there was anything higher than 10 it would be this game. EA, Activision, Bioware, Ubisoft, Bethesda, you ALL need to be looking at this game. for real. I don't know what to do with my life now that i've finished this game.
