I'll separate this by categories, Gameplay, Graphics, Story, Music. and Final Thoughts Gameplay - 8   It's good and its solid. Nothing super crazy. The gameplay does not make you want to come back to it more so than the story and adventure you go through. Although still a unique well thought of mechanic and it was executed nicely.  Graphics - 8  I feel this is the highest I can rate it since it is very old school looking and not the most impressive for old school looking games but the art direction is superb despite the old look. It looks more so 8 bit than 16 bit and even over that looks more like an old DOS-pc game over a console game. I can't just give a 9-10 here but the more you play it you realize just how creative they were. A nice thing they do is make it gradually more pretty as you play through it. It starts off very bleak and slowly becomes more pretty as it plays out. They use design to amplify the mood of story brilliantly.  Story - 9.5-10 This game is very surprising here. What starts very simple gradually like the graphics reveals it capable of more and more. You begin to think they can only tell the story in one direction and feels like its very simple and linear. Then it throw some REALLY crazy ♥♥♥♥ to throw you off. There is shockers, there is twists, and there is moments I really gasped like watching GOT. Also worth mentioning is the humor of this game. It's absolutely hilarious. One of the funniest games I ever played. But over its humor is it's emotion you really care for these characters in the end and most of them are very love-able. And the gameplay ties into the story perfectly. How you play the game is the message of the game.    This story IS TOP NOTCH.    Music - 10  I am so capable of writing a thousand page essay here so I'll keep this short. The sound track is up there with the works of Nobuo Uematsu and Yasunori Mitsuda. I know that's a bold claim but that is how well this music is sticking in my head. I can only compare it to the work of these guys because they are the only ones I think that it would be fair to compare Toby Fox with and that is 'The Best'.   Except neither of them wrote the game as well.  Overall thoughts  Game of the Year doesn't do this title justice. Because games I love this much haven't come out in close to 20 years now.    I know many people think that child hood impressions of games are grossly exaggerated and never on the level they are said to be because the age the material was absorbed. Even I thought maybe I was guilty of this.  Only until you play something that feels just as good. Playing Undertale proved to me that this is not the case. All the bits of wonder I received playing games like Chrono Trigger and Final Fantasy VII, in my younger years came alive in me while playing Undertale. That sense of childhood wonder was burning bright as ever. It proved to me that a game can STILL be as amazing as those titles if done correctly and because of that I'm filled with new optimism for gaming in the future.  Toby Fox's Determination has filled me with Inspiration.

Undertale, one of the most interesting and creative games I have played over the years. The story is not boring, and is always top-notch to my liking... you should like it too! It's not a grind fest, just to get from one place to another, and you are in action for most of the time.... unless you're doing puzzles. The characters are very easy to get attached to (I really reccomend doing the true pacifist run first for the best experience) The boss fights can be challenging (especially in genocide) but GOSH DARN is it so rewarding to mercy them..... or to brutally murder them. The scenery really does make it up for the graphics, and the sprites look well made!  Over all, I think Toby Fox spent his $50,000 well into this amazing game! It's well worth it to get it for £6.99/$10.00 (Btw, this is my first review, so don't worry if you don't agree.... thanks for reading ^^)

This is, hands down, one of my top five favorite games ever. The bullet hell battle system was so much more fun than regular back and forth attacks of traditional RPGs, the dialogue was funny and cute, the characters made me feel more for them than any hundred hour RPG has ever done.  Your actions affect the world, and killing people has a real effect to the game, giving it definite replayability. Though I don't think I can ever bring myself to reset the happy ending and I definitely can't bring myself to do a genocide. The music is great, too. And the visuals are surprisingly detailed for a sprite-based game. All-in-all, this game was an experience and I'll be sad not having anymore. I now have a Papyrus-shaped hole in my Papyrus-shaped heart,

There's no denying this game's popularity and critical acclaim. Regardless if you like or dislike this game, there's enjoyment to it. There's characters that are fun and entertaining and memorable. There's the eargasming soundtrack (seriously, there's not a single song in this game that isn't sweet to the ears). There's the '1984'-esque amount of meaning and analysis to be found. There's the twists you don't see coming. There's the RIDUCLOUS amount of effort put in.  And probably the most important, there's the everchanging tone and mood. This game can be sappy, scary, funny, dramatic, heartwarming, heartbreaking, and so much more.  You're gonna like something about this game. If not, you're gonna like a LOT about this game.  For $10, you'll probably just throw an extra $8 in for the soundtrack, 'cause Toby deserves it.

The book that I chose for my Summer Reading Essay is The Extraordinary Education of Nicholas Benedict, which is the final book in The Mysterious Benedict Society Series. The Extraordinary Education of Nicholas Benedict is about Nicholas Benedict who is an orphan with narcolepsy going to a new orphanage and trying to find a hidden treasure that he finds out about early in the book. Nicholas is not able to look for the treasure in the morning so he finds a way to get out of his room at night, which is locked at night because he has horrible nightmares and would scare the other children, by getting a wax mold of a skeleton key that the orphanage operator has. Nicholas also meets a friend whose name is John. Nicholas loves to read and while he is reading a book about astronomy, he comes across a note that says “Consult the Butler” and the book that was next to the book he was reading was written by Brian T. Butler, and inside the book are receipts to very expensive telescopes, which Nicholas thinks is the treasure. Nicholas is also very smart and realizes that the telescopes must have been placed in an observatory, and he sneaks outside during one of the nights and finds an overgrown pathway that he follows up a hill to the observatory. Nicholas goes inside to find the treasure but when he checks inside the observatory there’s a spot for a massive telescope but the telescope had been removed by someone. After Nicholas leaves the Observatory and is going to go back to the orphanage disappointed, he sees another overgrown pathway that after following it leads to a farm. Nicholas leaves and the next day he gets his friend John to sneak out and they go to the observatory together after Nicholas shows John the hidden passage, and they follow it to the farm. Once they get there they see a girl sitting on the edge of the cliff. Nicholas and John panic and try to get the girls attention, but she can’t hear them. After a while she realizes that she is being watched and turns around and looks frightened, and almost backs off of the cliff, Nicholas and John leave so that the girl is frightened and accidently falls off the cliff. The next day John and Nicholas go back to the observatory and think where the treasure would be in the observatory when Nicholas here’s someone in the forest coming to the observatory (which they started calling the Giant’s Head). At first Nicholas thinks it Mr. Collum, the orphanage director, but when they look to the door they see that it is the girl who was sitting on the cliff. Nicholas and John scream, and Nicholas faints. The next day the girl comes to the observatory and Nicholas starts talking to her in sign language. John asks how Nicholas knew how she was deaf and Nicholas explains how he realized that it took her a while to realize people were behind her when she was on the cliff, and when she scared them in the Giant’s Head and she didn’t flinch when they screamed. Nicholas and John talk to the girl all night and she explains that her name is Violet and that lives on the farm next to the cliff. A few days later- WAIT THIS IS UNDERTALE!!! ALL THAT TYPING FOR NOTHING!!!

For a game that's intentionally for a younger audience, I found this very fun and sometimes surprisingly challenging. This probably shouldn't come as a surprise though since it takes much of it's gameplay influence from the Bullet Hell genre. You could say this game has popularized the genre since Bullet Hell I consider to be a pretty niche genre.  The highlight of the game for me was the Mettaton segment, I found that entire area very fun.  This game offers a fun unique story, great gameplay, and the fact that it is replayable is an understatement.   I was impressed with how well your actions take real effective concequences in this game, something done so well I think Bethesda should really be envious.   When I first started this game, I was frustrated by how the game encouraged the pacifist approach, feeling that it was the game that would not let me play it. But as I got further into the game, I realized that the real heart of the gameplay is the passive approach. Figuring out characters holds a lot more depth than just mindlessly attacking them, and that's the beauty of this game! It truly is.   Unfortunately, I feel this game lacks in proper level design. Your sent on a linear quest through a shallow (but beautiful) world experiencing jokes disguised as puzzles. One of this game's biggest flaws is how it sometimes tries too hard to be funny that it kind of dominates the experience overall.  Either way, this was a great experience and I'm glad to have beaten this. One of these days I'm certain to try the other two routes this game offers if anything just to experience the extra bosses and content.  This game deserves a sequel, but I'd say it would probably be difficult to make story wise. But who knows what the creator might come up with. He's certainly very creative.

(Ok I'm changing this review for the better. Don't be fooled by my hours because I have over 17 hours offline.)    After not having internet for a week I decided to go back to Undertale because I was bored. This was the best decision I've made this summer. Undertale is one of my new favourite games because of it's humour, art style, and storyline.    If you're the kind of guy (or girl) who likes dumb AND witty humour everything in this game will make you smile. There are jokes where it flat out tells you what's funny and then there are jokes that you have to really look closely at to understand. There are even jokes stretched out across different story branches but I won't spoil them for you!   The art style is kind of hard to pin point exactly, some scenes remind me of an old DOS game but others are just plain SNES or NES style pixel art. It's a really pleasing game to look at. From the detailed battle sprites to the scenery and landscapes nothing goes un-noticed, for the exception of small items in the world like in the Junkyard. Never the less it's all well done, big or small.    Next up I'm going to talk about the storylines, there are 3 main plot lines in Undertale. The most popular being the Pacifist Route in which you spare every creature you encounter, I did this route first and you should too as it really ties together the story in a feel good way. Next is the Genocide Route where you do the exact opposite of the Pacifist Route, KILL EVERYTHING. When I say everything I mean EVERYTHING, every single damn monster you encounter? Kill it. This route isn't for the faint of heart and if you've grown attached to the characters in the story, well then prepare your ♥♥♥♥ for a bumpy un-lubed anal ♥♥♥♥ of emotions and feelings. Also the Genocide Route has the hardest boss fights ever so ♥♥♥♥ that. Last but not least is the Neutral Route. In this route you can really do whatever you want, there aren't a lot of rules. Want to kill a particular character you don't like? Go ahead, you're not evil but you aren't great either. Mercy and Fight can be used equally in this route and will give you an appropriate ending depending on who you have killed/spared and who you haven't. For any new players the Neutral Ending will be the first ending you get in Undertale on your first playthrough no matter what, doesn't matter if you kill everything or spare everything you're going to get a neutral ending.    Obviously the story is the biggest part to this game as evident by my significantly larger paragraph than the others I wrote. But that's just because there's more to talk about and more to describe in that catagory. This game is really well done and is obvious why it gained such a cult following so fast.   (TL;DR The art is good. The humour is good. The story is good. Go play it. Also it has a good soundtrack. Again go play it.)

After having played the demo back when it was just a kickstarter, I thought I fully knew what I was in store for when the game eventually came out.  Boy, was I wrong.   -This game had me laughing, crying, and engaged far more than any game I've played in the longest time.  -The game seems amazingly self-aware, yet stuck in it's own world all at the same time.  -The characters are rich, lovable, and extremely memorable.  -It's unique battle system is well designed and doesn't leave players looking for the 'Passive' route feeling left out. And the dev even made sure that if you're stuck on some boss fight or another that you don't have to sit through the same dialogue for each character. It'll just jump you right back into it.  -The ability to play through the game completely passively is a nice addition to an RPG, and allowed for great new ways to deal with encounters and bosses.  -The soundtrack seems to be perfectly attuned to each little instance you're in, helping the encounters and situations be all the more memorable and engaging.   I could continue listing the things I personally loved about this game, but the short of it is; it's worth the price. If you find yourself purchasing this game (as I hope you do), just remember to be good, child. And stay determined throughout.

I actually got this game because I had heard some of the soundtrack being played at a friend's place. This soundtrack is very well done and notoriously catchy at times - I'm very partial to 'Mad Dummy'.  As for the game itself, as others have mentioned, if you haven't played this game and know little to nothing about it, just pick it up and play it. Reading walkthroughs or reviews will very likely ruin a good portion of the story for you and that would be a waste. Most of the characters are at the very least unique or funny and at most relatable or sympathetic, and the story paces itself well - you get pieces of the story through character interaction.  The game is an RPG/dungeon crawler with slight puzzle elements, and the interesting bit is that you do not have to kill anyone, but you can if you want; it's your choice. Gameplay is similar to olderThere is a slight learning curve to gameplay, but almost anyone can pick it up and understand what needs to be done. It is fairly linear, but I believe this was intentionally done as to keep the overall story unknown until the climax.  The art style is reminiscent of older RPGs utilizing sprite art and basic color pallette and really pulls at the nostalgia strings. It also lends to the humor and drama of the characters and story without overwhelming you with stylistic tropes.  Overall, I loved this game, and the soundtrack is a great addition to those that enjoy chiptunes/8-bit style music.

My first introduction was via my friend who happened to be stuck on the final boss in a non-pacifist run, and had me and two other friends try to beat it for her. Suffice it to say, I saw hell and was unsure if I wanted to visit everything that came before. I'm incredibly glad I did. As you play, the backstory is slowly fleshed out, and you meet many....interesting characters along the way to say the least. Each has their own personality and redeeming qualities when you get to know them. Even in a world where everyone wants you dead, you can still make friends apparently. You also have the choice to go the opposite route, and cut a bloody path through the underground if you so wish. How you play is entirely up to you, but remember that even the smallest action can have echoes later on. From a technical stand point, the game is what it appears on the surface for the most part: an 8bit adventure with chiptune music. There's a distinct lack of glitches that is a breath of fresh air with the state of many games at launch these days. There are some various interesting choices in the technical realm used later on if your run is more neutral to genocidal. It had me somewhat confused at first, but it definitely made the experience with that final boss something to remember. No spoilers, but yes, it is supposed to do that, and you are supposed to reload it at times. It's not your computer. Overall, I really enjoyed my first run through of this game and look forward to a few more playthroughs in the future. Undertale is a charming 8bit adventure with a wonderful soundtrack that you will have stuck in your head long after you close the game. I highly recommend it to anyone who may be on the fence about it or anyone who wants a different sort of diversion in their gaming experience. Also, you can date a skeleton, and I did it because I could. I have no other explanation for doing that.
What started out as a little time sink into an indy RPG turned into the biggest emotional investment I've ever seen with a game. This game made me cry a ton. A skele-ton.

Undertale is as close to perfect as a game can get.  It's exactly as long as it needs to be, with no filler or padding - the 12 hours it took me to beat it were some of the most engaging and moving 12 hours of my life. Not since Lunar Silver Star Story Complete - a game I played nearly two decades ago - has a game captured and immersed me to this degree.  This game brought me to tears several times, just from how moving it is, so be prepared and have some tissues nearby.  Finally, I  highly  recommend playing through it as a complete pacifist the first time through. You don't have to kill a single person in order to progress; even when times are tough and are looking hopeless, remember that there's ALWAYS a merciful option.

I've never done a review for anything beyond 'good ♥♥♥♥ that's some good ♥♥♥♥' so here it goes: An incredibly fun bullet-hell/warioware/RPG game where you use diplomacy to win fights (or just beat the enemy up, that works too). The game has stunning writing: humor that left me in stitches more often than not, and more than one moment that made me start choking on my own tears. The gameplay (bullet hell/warioware minigames to dodge attacks, arguing to convince enemies to back down) is absolutely top notch, and the music has been stuck in my head ever since I saw the first trailer. 10/10 gave me a permanent fear of flowers.
Good game. You can date cute skeletons. You can pet dogs. And you can save everyone.

Fun combat mechanics. You can save the life of every character, but that doesn't make it just a talking game. You still can enjoy the bullet dodging as you duck spear thrusts to unleash your tactical hugs. Of course, you can also kill everybody. The different playstyles of the game are so vastly different in every way that it's almost like 2 different games. Lots of detail in the world building! The developer seems to have thought of everything, as many strange actions you can take actually get a reaction from NPCs.   If you do both major routes, it's about a 10 hour game, and well worth $1 an hour IMO

Well, this is interesting. I don't really write reviews but after finishing this game, kind of had to say my piece. so uhr, here it is.  Undertale was a game that captivated me until the very end, and what a game it was. This game shows that no matter what you think the limits of a game are, a game can always excel beyond what people expect. This is truly one of the best games I've played all year.   I cannot say how without spoiling it.  Now, I only did the pacifist route because I could never bring myself to hurt any of these characters after playing the game once, but the game concluded in such a satisfying manner...I honestly can't remember the last time I felt like this.  All I'm going to say to you, the viewer is: buy this game. Play this game. Do not stop until you have finished. This is some of the best Game of the Year material I've seen in a long time.

I have owned games on steam since 2005 and never felt the need to leave a review until Undertale.  I initially thought this game was massively overhyped, but this game does not conclude until you see the credit roll correctly (expect more than one play through).  Huge payoff, lives up to expectations and blows them out of the water. I did not expect to laugh, cry, or fear given the graphical limitations, but unless your soul has been taken by a monster, you will experience them all.  Buy the game (and play it until you know when it's done). You will definitely be satisfied.

Undertale is a short, but fun RPG with it's combat based heavily on a bullet hell, You might have already guessed but it's strong point lies on it's story and smart writing.  You either love or hate the game, it is very hard to revieuw but if you like to have a good story with one of the best soundtracks you can wish for then Undertale is the story you want.

I have to admit, I went into this game skeptical. I love the story that the RPG usually holds, yet I despise both RPG styled fights and bullet hell; both of which are key elements in this game. However, my skepticism was thrown out the window by the time I got past the first boss. The quick time events in battle kept me paying attention. The 'attacks' were driven by observation. I felt my progression with every enemy I spared. A sense of accomplishment trailed me while playing this game. The gameplay was excellent, in addition to the story, characters, setting, lore, humor, and the SOUNDTRACK. When playing, you really feel the determination mentioned with each save point. But as fun as this game is, it does delve into a rather horrific storyline. I wouldn't recommened it for the meek. I'm about to face the final boss, who I've seen online, and I think that's where it starts dissolving from clever humor into disturbing horror. The game also has some parts where the fourth wall is broken; not as a joke, but as the in-game characters questioning their exsistence and remembering past save files even if you hit reset. I just wanted to warn anybody getting the game, as I didn't have that warning myself, and it really freaked me out. So if you like an engaging, detailing game with unique characters, humor, and gameplay, Undertale is probably what you're looking for. Stay determined!

Its been a very long time since I played a game that I felt was made to be enjoyed and not just bought and played. I feel like Undertale is not only a work of art, its a labor of love.   Its a finely crafted experience that will resonate with you in one way or another.   You will laugh, you very well may cry and you will be filled with determination.  You will not regret your purchase.   I have faith in games again.   Thank you, Toby Fox.
Even as a cat person I admit that the dogs in this game were very cute. Would recommend.
Whether if you're a fan of making people happy and being friends with them, or killing anyone in your path and watching their friends and family suffer, this game is for you.

Just got through this game at last, and I'm honestly at a loss for words to sum up how positively I feel about this game. Like the sum feeling of every good experience I've had with games in my life.  The writing is funny - genuinely funny, the humor got me from beginning to end - and heartwarming and heartwrenching in equal measure at points. You WILL develop a fondness for every character, even ones you wouldn't expect to ever care about. You may think you have the nature of the story all figured out only to be thrown for loop after loop on this emotional rollercoaster, yet the reveals never feel manipulative or ham-fisted. I definitely cried some real tears on a few occasions. Just, a good and pure-hearted game.  The gameplay is extremely creative rewarding, and challenging without being outright impossible, even to someone with little to no experience with shmups, and the minor puzzle aspect to figuring out how to SPARE enemies was definitely something I enjoyed. And finally, the game looks and sounds incredible. While this game has multiple endings and several ways to play, for a great deal of replayability, here's a statement that'll only make sense to people who've beat the game; I'm satisfied to have beaten this game once, and never fire it up again. It was a wonderful experience and they've earned keeping their happy ending.
This convinced me to never play again after the true ending.

This game is meditation on killing in video games. It is an artfully imagined, and skillfully executed piece, similar in those ways to Earthbound. There is a lot going on, and there is an sinister idyllism pervading the experience. It is written with a talent for comedy, and an understanding of video game tropes and symbols. Just get it, and play it, and appreciate the gift you've been given by having experienced this tale.

There are dogs to pet, wonderful characters to become friends with (you wouldn't do anything else, would you?), and a great story that you can play again and again. Please play this game if you haven't. It's definitely worth the money and the time you play it. (Just don't be mean to your friends, that's just rude!)

Undertale is one of those rare games that has a unique charm about it. The unique gameplay, dynamic characters, interesting environments, and the amazing music that goes along with it makes the story very interesting. It is certainly a great enough game to keep an RPG fan interested.  If you're a fan of games like Earthbound, Undertale is definitely a game worth checking out. The type of humor is both reminiscient of Earthbound and completely unique. It stands on its own.  In this game you do not have to kill anything. Most battles can be fought using the 'Act' command while others take some thinking about how to approach it based on checking out the opponent and reading the clues in between turns.  Check it out. You really won't regret it. Unless you dislike dogs.
Goatmom is GOAT (Goat Of All Time)

Undertale...oh Undertale...  As you probably know from the store page, Undertale is an RPG where nobody has to get hurt. While this does hold true, there is so much more that makes this game a must-play for absolutely everyone. Yes, that means you, too.   The visuals, the combat, the music, the characters, the writing, the  consequences for your actions ... All of them are amazingly crafted and fine-tuned to be the most satisfying, most hilarious, most heartwarming, and most heart breaking  game I have ever played. The funny thing is, though...   I will probably never play it again.   Why? It's not because I already finished it and have seen everything. Trust me, I really, really, REALLY want to experience the magic of this game again. But...  You know what? I'll let you find out why on your own, it would be better that way. Buy this game, it's only $10 USD (or your regional equivalent). Considering how much love and care was put into the design of this game, that's a bargain. Play it. See it to the end.   The TRUE end  . You will not be dissapointed.   ...Oh, and for those of you who want to go through the game and  kill everyone  in the process... ... ...   D O Y O U W A N N A H A V E A B A D T I M E ?

I've spent practically 45 hours on a game that'll take you about 6-7 hours to clear the first time through. That, already, should give you a good idea of my thoughts on this game. Undertale is simply an absolutely fantastic game that I feel should be in every gamer's library.  Yes, it's on the short side, but that's honestly a good thing with this game. There are so many secrets to look for between the 3 routes (Pacifist, Neutral, and Genocide [also known as a No Mercy run]), some of which are exclusive to certain routes, that it would be annoying if the game was too much longer than it already is. Seriously, it's honestly one of my favorite parts of this game, some of these secrets are just astounding.  Perhaps my favorite thing about this game is not the charming characters, the humorous dialogue, the memorable boss battles, the amazing soundtrack, no... It's probably how the game makes you feel bad about killing monsters. Remaining as spoiler free as I can, when monsters get low on health, they lose the will to battle you, and they'll hope that you'll give them mercy. After all, they don't wanna die. Heck, if you keep killing them, the encounter rate will actually go down, to symbolize their fear of you.  Killing bosses (and certain, non boss enemies) has a more noticeable effect on things, since they'll no longer be in the game. You won't be able to participate in certain side quests, you'll miss out on humorous dialogue, and, worse of all, you'll be locked out of the Pacifist ending.  BUT, having said all of that, doing a Genocide run of Undertale is honestly something that I recommend everyone do. It'll break your heart, killing all of your friends, and you'll most certainly have a bad time, but it's also absolutely astounding what changes when you do a Genocide run, and will give you a whole other level of appreciation for this game.  But even if you don't do a Genocide run, just the Pacifist and Neutral routes already do such a great job at providing an amazing gaming experience that just those two routes alone are definitely worth $10. As I said, they provide an absolutely amazing experience that everyone should most definitely take part in. Screenshots don't do this game justice, you have to play it before passing judgment.
I can't give a full review without spoiling things, but let me just say; if there is an emotion, Undertale can make you feel it.

If you're a fan of Earthbound, Paper Mario, bullet hell games, LISA, or SMT, you owe it to yourself to play this game. Purely in terms of what it sets out to do, it succeeds in every possible way. By this point, this review is more for posterity's sake and because a game like this deserves praise even if the praise ends up just being a droplet in a sea of HOLY ♥♥♥♥ GO BUY.  If you enjoy games like Earthbound in terms of aesthetics and heartwarming experiences, while seeking a RPG that keeps you engrossed in the battle as opposed to mashing the 'Fight' command, this should be a 'must have' on your wish list.  Do you already have the game? Buy it for a friend! Share the love!  Though, try to stay away from the super obnoxious fans when you play the game - their love can get a bit messy and interfere with your enjoyment.  My only complaints: - the random encounters could stand to have more variety - after you've fought an enemy say about three times, there's really nothing different. Then again, running away is pretty easy too. - There are odd 'lulls' in activity and greatness in this game. But when it picks up again, it usually makes up for the lull. These mostly occur in the middle of the game.  Who this is not for: If you play games just to seek a challenge or competition and really don't care much for story or immersive experiences, this game may not live up to the hype.

Alright, First I want to say that this review is not going to have spoilers so your are safe to read this and I hope I persuade you to buy this amazing game.   So a couple weeks ago I went over to a friends house and he was playing a 8-bit stylish game that looked like ♥♥♥♥, He told me that it was called 'Undertale' and I was like 'well ♥♥♥♥♥♥ indie games amirite' but no... I was very wrong. I did some research that literally said stop researching and play it for yourself. I bought the game and booted it up it took a while on my ♥♥♥♥♥♥ laptop but once I saw the screen I was like 'dafaq.. no full screen?' (f4 to fullscreen btw) Now this game is very nostalgic and will take you back to Earthbound and Persona as they feel alike but Undertale is such a unique and refining experience to be had... and it's all in the comfort of your own home. I have literally speed ran this game twice in 8 hours and I can't say I found many secrets but jesus... some of these nods to other series had my cracking up and some had me crying. I was very satisfied with my experience no matter how long it was and I will keep replaying it until I find every secret and every ending... This game is a personal experience and every person will experience it a different way and this is why I beg you to give this game a try, You will not be disappointed  EDIT: I have now went down all paths and my opinion on this game stands, the tiniest details will change depending what you do, so make sure you check every nook and crany

This game teached me three things:   - Bad jokes and good hearts can make your day - You will make it to the stars if you stay determined - Tears are salty  Buy it. It's not a game, it's an experience. I don't want to be hipster-looking, but it shows that passion and imagination is way better than money and a good IGN rating.  Oh and, two things if you play this game:  Always choose 'act' and avoid all the spoilers.

Really the one huge flaw with Undertale is that knowing things about Undertale before you play it will possibly affect your experience negativly. So really you shouldn't be reading this right now. All i can say is that if you like rpgs... or now that i think about it, if you like games in general you will like this or atleast get something positive out of it.

Pros: - The soundtrack is notably one of the best things within the game, featuring a wide variant of interesting music that fits flawlessly with the tone of this game. - The settings although short are very impressive and differentiating from each other. -The characters are extremely vivid, and in the pacifist run they will make you make you care for them -The story itself is very deep, putting you on a winding path between a whimsical and sorrowful adventure, and even eery at times.(Especially in either true pacifist or genocide) The majority of AAA titles don't even come close to this excellence. -The game creatively extends such systems created by the Shin Megami Tensei series, to the point where nearly every enemy can contact you in a different way. -The True Pacifist Run will leave you very satisfied with completing the game, and even make you ponder most of it's life lessons it teaches you in the game -The game creates a very unique world compared to other RPGs, similar to a fashion the wonderful Earthbound/Mother games have created  Cons: -The RPG mechanics besides the pacifist mechanic leaves you with a shallow experience in fights, with only basic mechanics being in there otherwise. -While all the characters are vivid, quite a few are static in terms of a developing personality(Although there are quite a few outliers of this though) -Another problem with the game is that quite few of the characters have little to no flaws, making them at points very unrealistic (Although, you'll notice in the game a correlation with the developed and flawed characters) -The Genocide Run is where the majority of these flaws are brought out. Also within this run, you'll find that the fun aspects of the game are mostly gone and the difficulty spikes greatly between two bosses. Despite this though, I suggest after completing your pacifist run that you play or watch someone do this run.  General: This game isn't as godly as some fans will say, but more or less of a 'polished gem'. I myself feel that this game is a close masterpiece that should be cherished in the gaming industry, but not to the point that some fans make. This game masterfully creates it's tone, and provides very satisfying content for the $10 it costs. The audience that will enjoy this game will not be the general one, but if you have a piqued interest in the game, try out the demo and if you need a further look JUST watch the beginning of Snowdin. This will give you a good enough analysis if you'll like the game or not, and if you are still interested STOP WATCHING and play it quickly.  My Rating: 9/10 (Masterful, but with some present flaws) Realistic Rating: 8.25/10 (Great, but with quite a few noticeable flaws present in parts of the game)
Despite everything, it's still you.

I was really sceptical when I first saw this game. It had weird visuals and the only art I thought was good was some of the terrain/background. After buying it for my friend since they wanted it, they shared their library with me so I could try it out. My mind about the game has change a little bit. The visuals still look weird, poorly done and a little out of place. The music however is the best part of this game. That would make sense since the developer makes music and is known for that.  The story can be cliché and can try too hard at some points, but the multiple endings and clever design of the many paths you can take can make up for it. Little details and dialogue change depending on your previous playthrough. It's a nice touch and that would have taken a long time to code. The game can force you to like it's characters for their constant humor and annoyance. It works on alot of people, but I mostly just skipped alot of the dialogue because I wanted to just move on.  The gameplay isn't unique within itself, but it has never been done in an RPG before. People compare it to 'Gunhell' and it's fun to try and dodge the projectiles to avoid taking damage. The heart you control can also change colour which changes the whole mechanic which is a good thing.  The concept of 'not killing enemies' isn't entirely new. (Earthbound had your enemies turn to normal, become tame etc. You never killed anyone.) But what hasn't been done was that this was one of the main factors of the game.  This game can appeal to alot of people with it's story and simple easy-to-learn gameplay, but it just didn't do it for me. Mostly because of the art and story. It was a fun and short experience and people say it has good replayability but I don't think I'll play it again.  Overall, play it if you wish.  7/10

I'm usually not a huge fan of indie games because most of it is genuinely terrible. There's some saying... 'most of anything will be ♥♥♥♥', and it's true; but Undertale falls into the minority - the good games! The game itself isn't very long, but as for the impression it made on me, I can honestly say that it's something that will stick with me for a while. First of all, the cast is great! There's no one I'd call generic, even the enemies are unique and I do mean, unique... Secondly, the music's on point; I love emotionally charged songs so it's nice to know there's a lot of it. Lastly, the gameplay is something I've never seen before in an RPG: bullet hell-esque dodging and sparing your enemies? I gotta say, the feeling of imminent death and dopamine skyrocketing was something I hadn't experienced in a really long time, I seriously felt like I lost a few years of my life due to a certain... encounter. Anyways, overall, I'd say the game design is very strong which is pretty hard to find nowadays!

Note that I haven't even started to plumb the depths of this game but I feel compelled to leave a review anyway.  This game had so much buzz online that I was immediately resistant to trying it, out of a weird defiance, so when I did start playing this game, it was with preconceived expectations that I wouldn't like it and that it would not live up to the hype.  I was wrong.  This game slowly and completely immersed me in its little world. The music is simple yet brilliant. The characters are vividly imagined and their dialouge is cleverly written.  You aren't told too many rules explicitly, you learn how to play as you go along. When you equip different weapons, for example, you don't realize how to fight with them until you get into your next encounter. I found this interesting and engaging, and for that reason, it made me want to try out a variety of weapons rather than sticking with the first thing I equipped.   As for the story itself - you make many choices as you go along, and they do impact how the plot develops. You feel the consequences of some choices you make, and you sometimes feel like you are the villain in the game after all. The monsters become more human by the minute, and you feel like your 'human' character is not much different from them.  I will not lie, I felt increasing regret for killing a specific character in a boss fight. As I kept playing and learned that there are various ways to lead encounters so that you can Spare monsters (and as such, don't have to kill them), I ended up resetting the game so I could start all over again and spare that character.   Normally, video games have bosses that you are supposed to defeat and they are set up so that they are clearly a villain and obstacle that you, as the hero, need to get rid of. In this game, the 'boss fights' are monsters just doing their jobs, leading their lives, and often times have nobler motivations than you as the main character.   This leads to surprising levels of introspection and thoughtfulness, and at least for me, formed a desire to replay the game from the start to try to do things differently a second time around.

my review on under tale: it is a fantastic game with amazing humour, i was basically laughing the whole time, but even with a sense of humour the game had a sense of seriousness AND SO MANY FEELS the story was absolutely amazing, no matter which ending you did it was all fantastic, and the Easter eggs as well are quite interesting, and you would think with a game like this the gameplay must be bad right? Nope, the gameplay is fantastic with the fight scenes either being heart wrenching or very funny and some of the later boss battles… especially sans they are so hard, but they don’t make rage quit at all, it was still fun even when hitting triple digits of death, it’s a game where it doesn’t have stupidly hard difficulty (like I wanna be the guy) but it’s not too easy either! The game does hold your hand (literally toriel does) at the start but that’s just the tutoriel after that it really doesn’t, it’s a game where if you die it is your fault, it doesn’t lag, it’s not randomized, it is all your fault, you did it wrong but it’s still fun even if you die thousands of times, and the music! The music is also amazing, the person who composed the music knows what he is doing, it’s not just a generic dull boring music it’s an exciting, fun, nice music and it is just really the great! The only cons are that the puzzles aren’t the best; they are a bit generic, but still… kind of fun, so in conclusion undertale is a fantastic game with fantastic humour great characters , an amazing story with amazing music but mediocre puzzles 9.9/10

Undertale is a game which shows perfectly how to tell a story through the video game medium.  Books - Tell. Movies - Show don't tell. Games - Play don't show.  First of all, this game is not what it seems. Do you think it's more of a turn-based RPG? It really isn't, I'd say the gameplay is closer to a bullet hell game (dodge bullets or die). And then enjoying interesting characters and the world developing around you.   Second of all, the characters. If you're anything like me you're a jaded ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who can watch human execution videos mostly unphased. So the fact that this game made me upset for my wreckless killing of seemingly minor character is impressive. They (Toby Fox) didn't need a triple AAA budget, realisitc graphics, or previously established characters to make you feel the characters are real.   Lastly, The world feels alive, and every little choice you make effects the world, giving you an amazing sense of agency. Undertale does choice-based story gaming far better than any scam Telltale Game. There are multiple endings and a number of different interactions to have with characters based on earlier decisions.   If you truly want to enjoy Undertale, don't be a murderer. And if you try and reset....   The game knows, they always know    *Also the game gets pretty weeabooish towards the end, but that depends on your decisions.

An easy 9/10.

|-Spoiler Free Review-|  Undertale. A game so hyped up on certain corners of the internet you need to have your eyes closed to miss it. Luckily, I got to play it having only a few minor elements spoiled. A fresh run for all intents and purposes, which is the most recommended way to go in to it. After playing it myself, I also give that advice.   Many reviewers have differing opinions of what constitutes spoilers, so even spoiler free reviews may ruin small bits of the game. Tread carefully when reading other people's opinions on the game. I'll do my best not to include anything specific here.  On to the game:   Undertale is a 8 to 9 hour 8-bit story-driven rpg where your decisions in the story affect how the entire game plays out. Each decision you make changes how the other characters respond to your presence. This mechanic makes combat more meaningful in a genre where most fights are treated only as a means to grow stronger.   |-The Battle System-|   The battle system in Undertale is most similar to the Earthbound series. All the fighting takes place in turn-based combat from the perspective of the player character.  There are two twists to the formula.  1.) Enemy attacks are a form of top-down arcade shooter. Your ability to survive depends on how well you can dodge their unique patterns.  2.) Arguably the most important aspect of the game: You can attempt to spare every enemy you encounter.  Killing the monsters is usually quicker and easier than sparing them. On top of that, sparing monsters does not award the player with experience. With this in mind, the player needs to decide whether or not it is worth the trouble to leave each hostile enemy they meet alive.   |-The Story-|   The biggest reason most people try Undertale. Someone recommends the game and, more than likely, it is the first thing they'll talk about when trying to convince you.  Bottom line?  It's good. Not great, but good. It has a couple interesting twists here and there, but for the most part it follows a predictable path. Now that isn't necessarily a bad thing, but don't go in expecting a new classic of storytelling. If I get specific on the why it'll tread into spoiler territory, so let's move on to what I believe is the strongest part of the game.   |-The Characters-|   Undertale has a boatload of funny and endearing characters. Even the random battle enemies have unique personalities and interactions. Outside of the various areas you visit, they help to fill in the world and make it believable. In many rpgs random npcs mostly just have throwaway lines that don't have any impact on you at all. In Undertale they almost always have another joke to tell, or something that adds a little more to the overall story. It's definitely something I wish more games would do.  That's without starting on the main cast. In order to avoid spoilers I will say that for as much care and effort that went into the random npcs, much more was put into the named characters you encounter. Every one feels like they are necessary to the story, and none of them feel like they were tacked on just for the sake of it. Some of their interactions, on the other hand...   |-The Writing-|   For the most part, Undertale is well written. I wouldn't say it's a pinnacle of writing, but it does its job. It is servicable throughout, and there are only one or two times where it takes you out of the experience. Usually, this happens when the game is attempting to convey sadness, desperation, or sentimentality. It goes from heartfelt to hokey real quick. Some of those moments are well done, however.  The jokes are Undertale's strength. There are so many so frequently that I wonder if they started out with the idea that they were going to make a game with a ton of puns and awkward humor, and then try to fill in a story around the jokes. Most are well done but, as to be expected with so many attempts, some fall flat.   |-The Music-|   The music is great. If the characters are the strongest part of the game, the music is a close second. Like the characters, each piece of music makes each different area, situation, and boss fight feel all the more unique. From the monsters to the places they accompany. The retro-style of the music goes hand-in-hand with the visual style to create a cohesive world.   |-Overall-|   I played Undertale having only heard that it was good, and I tried it with relatively neutral expectations. In the time since, I have seen many people laud it as the game of the year (or all time, even). With that in mind, is Undertale as good as many people claim it to be?  In my opinion: No.  Undertale is good. It is worth playing. It is of a quality I wish every indie game would be. But it's not perfect, and its flaws were apparent to me as I played through it.  For many people, Undertale is the first game that they've played of this quality. The first game that gave them meaningful impact for the decisions they made. For them, it is the game of the year, maybe even the best game they've ever come across. It is none of these things for me, but that is not something I can hold against them.  All in all, Undertale is a game I am glad I played, regardless of its shortcomings.   8/10

The game is good, and that's it. With a price like $10 it's hard to pass up. The game isn't without it's issues though. A few things to note are that some of the RPG elements are dumbed down, some paths through the game are less satisfying than others, and while it has some great characters, a central plotline is sort of nonexistent. On the positive side, I personally found the gameplay interesting, and the overall presentation a delight to experience. If anyone is on the fence about getting this game, I will say this. There is a demo of the game that can be downloaded on its website. What the demo does is showcase the opening moments of the game. If you feel that after the demo the game is lacking, all I will say is the the game gradually evolves as it goes on. However the basis of the game can be found in the demo. I was personally hooked by the demo, and found the rest of the game to exceed my expectations. Though, that is the key word with this game, expectations. What I would recommend is to play the game with no expectations at all, and if you're on the fence on spending your precious ten dollars on this game, then play the demo to make sure it's for you. With all the praise it has been getting, Undertale is at least worth checking out.

A genuine game where you can either destroy your 'enemies' or spare them. More than perfect for casual players.  For those who are into casual genre games; Undertale, with all it's hype, is a must-try game for any person who has played countless old RPG and JRPG games, especially the MOTHER series. It follows a way that takes away the time you would spend on 'experience grinding', gets rid of it, and allows you to prevail without harming anyone--making bonds along the way.  Don't let the hype get to you. Since no game can be deemed the greatest, just relax and immerse yourself in the game. It's better if you experience the game with no expectations. Just play along the story, do what you feel is right, and let 'DETERMINATION' take you on train of emotions.  Quirky, at times humourus, at times emotional; the game forms a connection between you and all of it's characters.   UNDERTALE, is a game that you will smile upon in the future when you look back to it.

[SUPER SUBJECTIVE, PERSONAL REVIEW ALERT] I know people are looking for objective reasons to why games are good or not, and i couldn't fulfill that need, thus, this banner.  It's really hard to find the right words to describe this game. A big part of why this is my favorite game now, is personal. I always liked retro games, partly because i didn't have a choice. I didn't and don't have the best pc available... Far from it in fact, most of my computers couldn't even run the newest games on the lowest settings. But besides personal biases, this game is masterfully crafted, and the attention to detail is truly astonishing. The story is a great meta-commentary on RPGs and gaming in general, messing with the players head in a number of ways. But it doesn't devolve into a joke and memfest of 4th wall breaking, the game has it's humor, wich i again found really good, and laughed my ♥♥♥ off multiple times, but it got a broad range of emotions out of me, from tear-shattering laughter, to the edge of crying. It builds a cast ofreally strong and interesting, diverse characters, who you (or at least i) couldn't help, but get closely attached. And don't even get me started on the soundtrack... I listen to it on a daily baisis for almost 2 weeks now. You may have noticed, that i haven't touched on the story. That's because (as many have stated before me) saying even a word about the story. would spoil part of the experience, you have to experience it yourself. I don't know how did i avoid being spoiled, or even hearing about the game for months after release, but even if you are spoiled, it's worth it for the ride. This review turned out much more personal, than i originally wanted it to be, but i couldn't stop myself, this game touched me like no game has ever have. After each playtrough i looked at a completely different perspective at the characters, and the world. There are no more words for my amazement for Toby Fox's masterpiece, just these words: Please, do yourself a favor, and play this game.

I have a lot of mixed emotions about a story like Undertale.  I feel that it is in for the best interest of everyone to read this to play the game to know what I mean when I say it recaptures a kind of magic that can only be felt very scarcely. For some people, like myself, it's that haunting, beautiful wonder of gravity in a game where you decide the world and its' fate through patient battles of decision.  I have played a lot of JRPGs and western games and everything under the sun and I will admit something to you dear reader, this game did for me what Earthbound didn't. That must seem so strange, but we must come to understand something you and I; Earthbound and Undertale are not the same game.  They are similar. They are beautiful and they carry a small piece of history with them. Undertale will carry history, I think as the second coming of what we can hope for in games. With more and more titles like Earthbound & LISA starting to pop up, it feels like a great digital thaw might be cracking where we can see the gooey heart in a world of generic brown landscapes, open sand boxes that go nowhere, characters that you could or couldn't really care about & mindlessly doing something for as little as an ever-increasing Score. I like this feeling. I like the sincerity of it.  But I warn you of this, reader, DO not do it. And I'm sure you know what I'm talking about if you've played the game but if you don't? Do not go the other way. You will be warned, you will be bothered and maybe you'll care. Maybe you'll care. But the reality is, is that Undertale, is a world unto itself much like all other stories. I can't stop you, the only person that can Stop You, is Yourself. A part of me wants to explain how much I wish for you to understand the... Innocence of a world like this. But if you chose not, you'll come to, not necessarily a mind blowing revelation, but one of some profound impact.   You'll definitely be in for a less than pleasurable experience. Some might call it a bad time, I call it an option for development.  I played the game to the fullest capacity and went straight pacifist, I'm not a monster in the land of Monsters. But maybe you are, maybe you desire the taste for blood in the water like an 8 bit shark, in an ever-shrinking pool of soft-hearted chum. In which case, by all means. Enjoy. But remember, the leftovers are far less than satisfying.  With all that out of the way, let's talk about the game itself then.  Music? Music is great for the kind of game it is. It's upbeat, powerful and I remember humming Undyne's theme the most to myself. I haven't doen that since Digimon World on the Playstation 1. The music is really good and it feels authentic to both the atmosphere and story. Including the Tem Village.  10/10, no faults to be found.  The Story? The Story is You, are a child who has fallen into the depths of an ancient mountain said to house the monsters that once lost the war a great long time ago. You are now exploring their world, a visitor unrecognized by many because the monsters have all mostly forgotten what humans actually look like. I will not spoil anything for you under any circumstance, but I'd advise Caution in everything you do. Also, peace is, with 100% certainty, a valid choice.  8/10, I'd like to have seen just a bit more of the human world and what it was like but we'll get to see more in the future, hopefully.  Gameplay? The Gameplay in Undertale is that you are presented with a semi-linear JRPG style navigation with a menu that allows you to FIGHT, ACT, use an ITEM and to have MERCY for your foes or yourself. Using a proper combination of items given a certain number of fights, you can actually make boss fights much easier. You can choose to fight and fight and fight your way through, seeking to return to the warmth of the surface, or you can try and talk to anyone willing to do so. And those that aren't as willing to do so. 10/10, can't find any faults in it. Does the job adequately.  Pro Tip: You can't sell anything until you get to Tem Village, and certain items cannot be bought or found again. Be smart.  Characters? Ah, what would a story be without its cast and let me assure you that while the Monsters found in Undertale are seemingly simple, they do in fact have things they care about. You don't need to remember every bit of dialogue for the characters to have impact, but you will understand that feeling of being a friendly stranger in a strange land. It really isn't any stranger from my world or yours, so just act like Yourself.   Length? The game can be beaten I believe at just about 4 hours, maybe less considering I've seen someone run and win in under 2 hours (but not watched the video). I gave it the fullest look through and even on occasion just turn it on for ambient noise. But make sure that if you run a Pacifist run to go Back to the Flowers at the start, and to reload a save after talking Sans in that one room, towards the end. He'll do something, if you did it right.  Length? 9/10, I'd like to have seen more honestly. I would like for there to have been more and seen more but that's more my expectations than Toby or anyone else's.   Replayability? Yes. There are a number of endings and some interesting things happen if you decide you can't handle the cold. It explores choices well and honestly, I'd give this game to my kid for a lesson on things like morality.   Price? Ten dollars is a good price for a gem you can pick off the shelf and say 'wow it left an impact'.   Overall Opinion? On a scoring grade I'm giving it a Perfect 10. Really. I have minor nitpicks with it, but the reality is, those are my feelings for more. To see more, to feel more of this world. It's beautiful and charming and really I wouldn't change it for anything in the world unless it was for the better. There are mysteries hidden within and questions unanswered and I won't spoil those for you to discover. If you want more information, you can find it yourself. But if you really want to dig into a comfy, classical RPG with solid fun at the core, you can bet I'd recommend Undertale to people of all ages.  Nyeh heh heh.

This game is pretty great. Aside from all the humor (that the other reviews absolutely rave about), it has interesting and unique mechanics and is pretty original as far as misc. aspects go.   Excellent soundtrack as well (what else can one expect from Toby Fox). It fits the game and characters well, and sets the mood for itself.   The characters are well-written and convincing, and are overall very fun to interact with as each shows a different face to any given situation (PRO TIP: Call Papyrus in every possible room).  And the decision-making is excellent, too. It's well-crafted decision making that subtly lies within the process of gameplay. Instead of presenting you with '[CHOICE]', it lets you decide what to do almost fluidly, sublty affecting the outcome until you can reach a polar opposite ending.  I reccomend this game on a personal level.

Undertale isn't Amazing nor is it Horrible. I personally loved the game but I am a avid JRPG player.  The flaws of the Game: Sprite character art - Papyrus and Asriel look terrible. Only main story - There are no side quests. The combat isn't that hard - If you're used to Bullet Hell games like; 'The Tohou Project' the combat isn't very difficult. Maps are plain - The maps are cliche like snow levels or fire levels and the maps don't have anything that seperates them from other indie rpgs. 8-bit desgin - I understand with GameMaker Studio you can only make bit games but it couldn't of been 16-bit instead?  The postives of the game (Short ver.): The combat is original - No not killing enemys is nothing new (Look at Shin Megami Tensei) but the Bullet Hell mixed with turnbased combat is great! It's not even stuck to bullet hell for example the fight with Muffet or Papyrus. The music - Toby Fox's work on the webcomic 'Homestuck' was amazing and now an game OST? Yes please! Characters - I liked all the main characters but their personallities weren't that amazing, but they were all very likable. Story - SPOILER FREE: The twist with one of the characters you meet at the begining turned the game around for me which almost never happens with me, I even got pretty emotional with the pacifict ending. Dialouge - The jokes are mostly funny and the characters feel unakwared and very natural. Moral System - I don't hate this games moral system. Thats a Achivement. Mutiple endings - You get exactly what you deserve even after the Genocide ending you're punished when you reset the game.   Worst of all of the game: The fanbase  I'm not the greatest reviewer but this is definetly worth the £7 or $10. -- Cemlar
one of my favorite games ever

If you're a fan of Earthbound or Mother 3, you will almost certainly enjoy this game. It's got lots of humor, puzzles and moments that tug at your heart strings. The battle system is kinda weird for an RPG, turning into a bullet hell game, and it may remind you of Touhou. It's unique because there actually are consequences for killing mons without thinking anything of it, and the game remembers that you did that in a previous run. If you're starting a genocide run (or if you kill any of the bosses on the neutral route), it will make you feel like a horrible person. You'd be surprised how a game manages to make you feel bad for killing something you know is just pixels. The soundtrack is awesome enough to justify being a paid item on Steam and supporting the creator. My favorites are The Core, Death by Glamour, Another Medium, Megalovania, and Asgore. Spear of Justice is an honorable mention. Start to finish, it feels kinda short, especially if you do 2 or more playthroughs in a short span of time, which I would not recommend.

This game is amazing! An experience unlike any other game I have played. There is quite a lot to say about this game, but I'll keep this short.  At first glance this game might not seem that interesting, but you would probably be wrong.  Everything is just so well done in this, the characters are memorable in their own way. Even the random encounters will stay in your mind after playing this!  Fighting is basically turn-based combat, but each turn you have a minigame kind of thing where you'll have to dodge/repel your opponent's attacks. Combat system is a bit hard to explain, but it's really something unique.  Soundtrack in this game is one of the best one I've heard. The music varies from time to time, whether it's something happy while having a friendly conversation with someone or a menacing one when you are having an intense boss battle, it's awesome either way.  Also there is one thing that makes this game stand out of the others in my opinion, that being that you don't have to kill a single enemy in this game    or you can kill everyone   .  Undertale has been far more entertaining than most AAA titles for me. I'll hope that you will try this game out!

An indie RPG game with 'classic' graphics. It takes influence from the cult-classic game, Earthbound, which means it has a lot of humour to offer and many dark themes to find. The action-timings for when you're attacking changes depending on what weapon you have equipped, so the game is not feel as repitetive as most RPGs are. The soundtrack is amazing and fits the mood to the area and/or events that are happening while you progress through the game.  From what I've seen from other reviews, Undertale is not the first of it's kind nor is it the best example of it's kind. But I, as a new player through this kind of game, have been blown away and look forward to the universe of games that Undertale's formula has followed. If you have been overhyped for this game, it will most likely let you down. I entered with the right amount of hype and have thoroughly enjoyed what the game has offered me.
Clever, fun, and full of heart. The type of game that uses weirdness, humour and innocence to teach you something about how you approach games and maybe a little bit about yourself.

This game is really great! The story is gripping, the characters are filled with life! There are multiple endings and your actions actually mean a lot in the story. The deeper you go, the better the story gets.  Pros: 1. Power story: It is interesting and definitely makes a moral stand on  2. Hilarious: This is probably the best game I've encountered in a long time. 3. Once you stop, you cannot quit: I had said to myself that I would finish a game I was playing before I had started. I decided to just start the game, see the initial story, but then I found myself getting deeper into it. 4. The story is simple: The story isn't very complex. *Spoilers from the beginning of the game* You are a human who falls into a monster world and you are trying to escape */end spoilers* 5. Gameplay is amazing and entertaining: In this game, you don't have to kill anything. That's right. The big monster in the corner, you can sing to and make them sing along. The boss? Oh, yeah, you can make him your friend. Everything in this game is so dynamic, you can choose whether you will fight a monster or not 6. The music: The music is really great! Very good soundtrack!  Cons 1. The story is short compared to other RPGs: Don't expect a full scale story such as Fire Emblem or Tales of blah. The game is short, but makes up for it in replayability. There are multiple endings, multiple things you can do in the game, etc.  That's all the cons I can think of.   So, I would give this a good 9/10, just because I wish the story was longer. Everything else is flawless. The game is phenomenal!

[No Spoiler Review] On the surface, it's an RPG game with puzzle elements with a pixel art style going on. But in reality, this game hits home the moment you boot up the game. It will stay that way even to the end.  If you're inspired with games where you can carve your own path and grew up with games like Mother, this is more than enough to jump into the game and enjoy it. This is one of those games where it is designed well by narrative and player interpretation. Depending on the choices you make, as a matter of fact. It can make some parts easier, and later parts harder. Vice versa.  The atmosphere and the characters in it despite the direction they took with the pixel style are all rememberable. Just about every NPC in that game will have something to say, and it does change over time. So the exploration and curiosity is always beaming at every corner. This game's quirky, will go to great lengths to make all kinds of jokes. Both literal and sometimes clever, pun-ny ones at that.  The sound track? Now that really hits home as it takes inspiration from Mother/Earthbound, and takes notes from various SNES sound tracks and making it catchy enough to hum to a few battle tunes. Pretty addicting right there.  Now, for an RPG game, I know some of you want those hours you want to sink into. But this game does not care about a long, mediocre experience. With around 12~ hours or so of the time that I spent with, that entire time was spent with quality. No filler. No additives. No preservatives.   This will be one of those games you really want to go in blind. Don't look anything up. Play the way you want and see where the game will take you. You may be surprised and end up coming back for more.
This game made me cry, the best $10 i ever spent, best soundtrack and emotional characters

Oh man this game, why did I refund it? This game has one of the most messed up/amazing storyline and the gameplay is the most unique in any rpg i've probably ever seen. This game can be played in three main ways: Pacifist, Neutral, and Genocide. During Pacifist you spare everything. In my opinion this is where the game excels in story. In this way you get to hear tons of backstory about characters. Next is neutral, in this way you kill some characters and spare others. This is the part of the game where the story is getting a little bit weird in the sense of the story starts getting messed up. Then there is genocide. This is by far the hardest way to play the game in terms of the sotryline is just plain creepy, as an example the music is deeper and slowed down in most zones of the game. Also the gameplay is extremely frusrating because this mode has the hardest bosses in the game. A unique part of this game though is that even when you restart the game or uninstall and reinstall the game, all characters will remember your previous runs of the game. The soundtrack is probably one of the best there is out of every game i have ever heard.  I say this game + the soundtrack is worth $60 even though it is only roughly $20. You will get so much enjoyment out of this game and i give this game a 9.5/10.  If you like rpg games with an amazing yet messed up story line, this game is definetely for you.

So this is probably the best game to ever happen in recent memory.  It takes everything that makes video games art and tosses it all together into one big feels trip. It's one of few games that can tell a story just with music (Dark Souls comes to mind as being very good at that). It can tell a story with just one little line of dialogue.  You don't even need to think that hard about what the game is trying to tell you, because it's very up front about it. But if you take the time to think, and look into details a little more, there's a lot more very moving stuff to be found.  And I don't just mean in the game itself. This is a game that breaks down everything you know about video games, and it's already one of the best ever just because of that.  This is probably the best game to have been released in 2015, no contest.  The only game that could possibly ever match this one for its artistry is Dark Souls. Needless to say, this does not have the Dark Souls learning curve, so if you're trying to buy something moving and a Souls game is too hard for you, grab this.   Hell, if you're looking for something to get emotionally invested in, get this no matter what.

Perhaps one of the most well written games I've ever played, coupled with very solid gameplay mechanics, choices that matter a whole lot, lots of secrets and humour. And dogs.  There isn't really anything this game doesn't hit head on. It might seem like a simple RPG at first, with an interesting mechanic for actual battles, but it gets so complex with every enemy having unique and interesting attacks, and bosses having mechanics that change how you have to play the battles out for even more fun battles. And then the whole concept of sparing functions like a puzzle on its own - figuring out what each action does and how you'll get the monster to stop fighting. Sometimes you have to resort to options you wouldn't think would be necessary, but you don't have to kill a single monster in the game.  The writing is impeccable. It's full of ridiculous, silly humour that doesn't work through references, pop culture (for most part) or easy jokes (...also for most part), and is still hilarous and fun. Then we get into the serious stuff. It's pretty much how Earthbound and the MOTHER games run it: lots of really silly jokes that make the game seem lighthearted and not too serious, but then throws a bunch of heavy, serious and well connected plot at you to make you cry your ♥♥♥ off. And it also works in Undertale. The true ending torn me to pieces, happy yet sad pieces.  The characters are perhaps one of the best things about the writing. They're all so full of life and personality, and you get to see many of them evolve quite a lot, not to say find out more and more about them as you go on. Most of it is completely optional, if you don't care about them too much. But I can certainly say I've never loved a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ skeleton named after a font, nor a fish with a temper, so much before.  The artstyle is very solid. Simplistic, but cute and can still be somewhat disturbing... and very creepy... at times. There wasn't a single character/monster design that I didn't like, and the best part was the freedom they took with the whole idea of 'monster' - Literally anything can be a monster. Some of the stuff you see is plain ridiculous, yet lovely anyway. It's the weirdest thing to say that you can date a skeleton, pretend to be a gelatin, pet buff dogs, have a flexing contest against a horse and fight a very terrifying... flower... all in one game.  And then the music. Just, just buy it. It's ♥♥♥♥ing incredible. All of it. I stopped so many times in certain areas and battles just to enjoy the music for a little longer, something most games don't really get me to do. Even as much as I absolutely adored the game, I don't even know what was more worth it - the experience of everything this game is or the music alone. They were both as powerful and amazing as one another.  All in all? Not just a RPG game. A ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ experience of laughter, joy, challenge and bittersweet tears. One of the best games I've played in my life, perhaps the most memorable one. It's a game I would recommend to absolutely everyone, not just RPG lovers, not just bullet hell lovers, not just good story lovers. This is the kind of game that anyone would be able to enjoy immensely and finish it with a sad smile on their faces, wanting more. I already know that's how I will be, even though I have plenty more to do here.
My child, this game is just amazing and humerus! Do not think your taste is too refined for this game! So don't be a bonehead and get it today! I do hope you won't have a bad time, be good, alright?

Honestly, Undertale deserves all of the praise that it received. Amazing and memorable characters, excellent choice driven story, and truthfully one of the most phenomenal soundtracks I've heard out a video game to date are just a few out of the many aspects of the game that deserve praise. However, Undertale has... fallen from grace a little bit, to say the least. This is just my opinion, but I believe that the fanbase overhyped the game to the point of ruining it, very similar to the of Five Nights At Freddy's (which I never really liked in the first place to be honest). Don't get me wrong, this game has a very high replayability factor, its interesting bullet-hell combat system was fresh, and the story and character development, including the inclusion of LGBT characters in the form of Undyne and Alphys, were more than selling points for me, but the severe overhyping of the game kinda ruined the experience. Also the ridiculous amount of porn that exists if you look up Undertale on google. Overall, I give this game 10/10, but just know that this masterpiece is a shadow of its former self because of the extremism of the fans.

For anyone who has read negative reviews for this game blaming the fan base for the game being bad, don't let them dictate whether you buy this game or not. The dialogue is charming, the humour is surprisingly good and the gameplay is much like old turn-based game, with a few new mechanics to make every battle seem fresh. The battle system itself is fresh, as you can negotiate your way out of fights.  In short, don't let the reviews of this game blaming the fan base for why the game is bad and read some of the reviews that have substance and explain what features the game has.

A few days before I bought this game, I attempted to kill myself. I was going to jump off a building but in the end, obviously, I couldn't do it. I felt so alone and awful, even with help from my therapist. Then I bought this game, out of curiosity and I was just blown away by it. It...it may sound strange to some but when I played Undertale, it was like I was able to make my own decisions and I finally had friends that loved and cared about me. All the choices I made in my first playthrough were pacifist and...and it felt like someone out there was truly proud of me. It's really silly, I know, but as I was leading closer and closer to the end and hearing how proud my new monster buddies were of me, I just broke down. I forgot it was a game in those few hours. I forgot it was fiction as I was captivated by this beautiful story and amazing music. When I got my neutral ending, and Sans told me to take care of myself, because someone really cares about me, it was in that moment, where I was finally proud of myself for not killing myself. Again it's probably very juvinile but the feeling of having someone genuinly proud of you(no matter if they were fictional or not) when you're at your lowest, dragging yourself around just to make it through the day, well it means a lot to me.  This game actually made me feel something, which is very rare in a video game for me. I mean, yeah, I've done other rpgs but never have I felt this strongly about a game before. I advise everyone to play this game.

Play it by yourself, with very little info about it and this game will quickly become one of the most interesting experiencies you will ever have.
