You're not joining a phenomenon nor checking what everyone's talking about to give the 'final and most important opinion about this game ever'. No, dude, you're playing a piece of art. Enjoy it. Anyway, with that out of the way: Undertale's story and characters are the most important aspects. If you enjoy a good story (and a good laugh!) you should play this game. You will not regret it.

Let me start by saying this won't be a traditional game review. I'm not going to go into specifics about how the game looks, plays, and things of that caliber; alternatively, I'd like to take a moment to talk about something that many people seem to have a difficult time understanding: Happiness.  This is a concept that's easily comprehended by even the children in their youngest years of living, but later into things I've noticed that its true nature starts to get hazy. People start to question the very validity of the happiness that kids experience, and perhaps it is true that what some kids have isn't particularly real happiness, but if Undertale, Spirited Away, stories from across human history and even more than that has taught me, it's that children may understand happiness better than any of us. The young are filled with a desire to live and see what everything has to offer... an affirmative determination to learn more, laugh more, live more, and even love more. Maybe it is innocence that's the deciding factor, and maybe we do leave that behind at a certain age, but love, happiness, and peace ARE stronger than just simple innocence. In my eighteen years of living, I've yet to gain any EXP or LOVE (which only people who've played to the near end of the game will get), but I've never had any real reason to even try to. And as much as I wish I could say we were all playing the same game... the truth is we aren't; we play by the same set of rules to be certain, but some variables change them and us in the process. Some individuals lose the path to happiness. They do things that in their minds they see as logical decisions.   Killing people, killing ANYONE, including yourself, is never a logical answer, nor even a right answer; please take that to heart.  If you can't find your happiness... talk to someone. Talk to anyone willing to listen. I guarantee there's someone out there who will listen. It's all so intensely daunting... but one thing I can tell you is all of this... all of this is a project. It's a continued piece of effort that we throw ourselves into daily or bi-daily. It's incredibly difficult to find happiness in a short amount of time; it's so difficult it can't be measured by clear way of passing; however, it isn't impossible.  To find it though, you just have to keep going.  I can't tell anything about this game that you can't already see from the trailer, the internet, or everything that's already been said about it, but I can say this: If you'd like a pleasant experience, one that may teach you a thing or two about the inherent nature of happiness and love, than I'd say that you should try it out. You might very well enjoy it.  Have faith in others.  Have confidence in yourself.  Stay determined.  ~Anti

Here are some sentences that I can use to describe Undertale as a game.  -It has a vivid, inspiring, and emotional story, set in an expansive and elaborate world with a deep and dark past.  So much thought was put into this game and the lore is as mysterious and intricate as, say, the FNAF series.  -It contains a wholesome and diverse cast of characters that are lovable down to even the most minor of 'monsters'.  All of the characters have complex and amusing relationships, and even regular enemies and npc's are engaging.  -It utilises excellent pacing of comedy, heartbreak, triumph, discovery, etc. to always keep the player freshly invested.  There are plently of surprises around each corner that take the player by surprise in a literal sense and emotionally.  -It must have what I view as the best (retro) soundtrack of any media I've ever heard personally.  There is no need tab out or be bored. After beating the game, I've listened to the soundtrack many times just to jam.  -The gameplay is surprisingly fun, challenging, and entertaining, with a very fair and responsive difficulty curve.  One could describe it as something like a bullet hell game with puzzles and utter nonsense (amazing story) on the side.  It can be enjoyed heavily on a basic level of comedy and gameplay, and it has a high level of replayability.  -This game shatters all expectations and cannot be confined to any genre.  All that I can say is that it is its own very unique experience, with a feel and style akin to something like Earthbound.  -Undertale has forever changed the way that I look at video games and the way I look at life.  The story is presented in such a way that it leaves a lasting impact on you, especially since it is greatly influenced by the player.  -This all being said, a player will have to play through the game for a bit before they become comfortable enough for the game to start throwing curveballs at them; until then, it will appear like a 'standard rpg,' but be patient. Give it a chance, and you will throoughly enjoy your time spent in the underground. I HIGHLY recommend this to any person with any inkling of an interest to try out this new weird indie title. You can go far with this game; it will be the best $10 you ever spent. :)
One of the best and most clver RPG's I've seen in years. It's best to go into this knowing no expectitations, but it trumped any of mine.      This game is best enjoyed with a plate of spaghetti.

The story itself is rather goofy and also bleak at times, showing how life underground is basically a claustrophobic hell that the monsters have to endure. The score is amazing and really sets the atmosphere when playing the game. Other than that, Undertale has been a fantastic game to play. It’s a delightful little game, well programmed, beautiful musical score, unforgettable characters, and quite inspiring in my opinion. Although it's a quick one, you’ll have a great time.

I'm not sure what to say that hasn't already been said about this game, but I'll try  Undertale, defies all typical conventions of an RPG game, and I mean that in a good way. For those who get enamored by this game, it will make you laugh, cry, get mad, and all other torrents of emotions. It will break you. It is very meta too, which honestly surprises me the amount of content an depth a game like this has. For those who love gaming an RPG's this is a game that is worth trying at least once. I feel like you will fall for nearly all the characters, and genuinely do not want to harm them or kill them, as is one of the themes of this game. The story and characters and humor this game has is so unique, as well as the designs of monsters, that it amazes me one person made this game. I tip my hat to Toby Fox in that regard for this game which is more like an experience, and I don't say that lightly. If this game is not for you, then I totally understand and respect that as well. Even little things like the fact that you can't sell stuff to most shopkeepers in this game or the importance of items amazes me in this game, details like that, let alone all the 4th wall stuff. It never gets tedious or grindy and the bullet hell part of the game feels genuinely fun as well as the whole sparing an acting concept. There is just so much to this it blows the mind. I'm glad I decided to play this and would probably do it again, and would recommend it to anyone even slightly intrigued and interested by it, I'm sure you'd find something you'd like, as cute and charming as this game is. Alot of heart was definitely put into Undertale (pun intended).

Anything you thought was impossible, this game does it. When you think you know the mechanics of the fight box, it gets completely flipped on its head. I actually got a DRM free copy of this game prior to deciding that the dev deserved my support too.  Holy mother of dog though, this game has changed me, and I'm not sure I can ever go back. This game made me cry; this game made me legitimately laugh out loud alone in my room; this game made me filled with the most intense anger and /need/ to beat the final boss I have ever felt; this game made me feel guilty for every other game I've ever played, but most importantly....  This game made me a plate of sphagetti.  I highly recommend that you take the tagline 'A game where nobody has to die' seriously. There is only a single person in the entire game you even need to hit FIGHT for, and that's only because it's the only button you can even hit at the time. You will not regret it.  The story in this game is brilliant, and introduces a whole host of characters whom I cannot forget even if I tried, and despite my every attempt, I now find myself comparing every other game against. The music is a even mix between several genres, and flows and fits perfectly, and is worth every extra cent. The graphics are retro, but don't think that they're subpar in any way, and in fact I think any higher resolution would make the game lose its impact in a later section.  I have tried and tried to find a flaw in this game, if only for the sake of making it less perfect when I compare my future games to it. I have failed to find anything wrong except that Hard mode is not completed yet, and one aspect of the ending left me with a bittersweet taste in my mouth days later when I thought about it. (Though it's fitting, all things considered about the character it happened to.)  I could say 10/10, but that would only cheapen my rating. This game is perfect in every way, and it will leave part of your soul permanantly affected, and you may never see the rest of the world the same way again.  TL;DR it's so good I paid money for it after I got a copy for free, and now every other game seems duller by comparison.

*My review of Undertale , a great game with Earthbound-y roots*  Some light #spoilers  (you've been warned).  No plot details though.  Sooooo, I guess I did a successful run of Undertale.   tl;dr It was pretty good!   It was very cute, and endearing. I wouldn't go as far as saying it's an instant classic. It borrows heavily... ahem.... was inspired very much by... Well, let's just say it straight up pulled multiple things from Earthbound. Considering it's roots and who made it, that aspect is very much intentional. So, I can see why people who are absolutely bonkers about it might be affected by the redirected nostalgia of EB/Mother.  That isn't to say this is a bad or poorly made game. The graphical appearance belies a very well-crafted, intricate, attention to detail story with characters you actually care about (or eventually grow to care about). And your decisions actually matter to a granular degree! which is not often seen in those AAA higher budget 'choose your own adventure' type games. I'm very, very impressed with the amount of effort the writers went into crafting a story that actually encourages you to talk to everyone and not have it get boring. There were several jokes and one-liners... and well, things that happen that genuinely elicited a real response (for me, it was mostly smiling and laughter). And for the most part, what is said is contextual and reflective of other things mentioned in the story. It's the subtle callbacks. They're not overbearing, and it's really quite clever when you're paying attention.  The music was also surprisingly great. I guess the guy who programmed the game is a musician by education/trade? It had me humming along. The guy uses the same 3-4 leitmotifs I noticed throughout the game, but his effective use of several different genres and understanding of different styles of music really show that he gets music, and gets how to make it thematically relevant. The throwbacks, graphical references and directly ripped SOUNDFOUNTS from other video games were a nice and appreciated touch. Slight spoilers, but we have homages to several game franchises including (but not limited to) Earthbound (duh), Final Fantasy, and even Dynamite Headdy.  There were plenty of opportunities to subvert your expectations as well. I think it's nice and not frustrating when done well, and he did it well. I will say, I just about fell asleep in the first 45 minutes or so of the game, but once I got past the 'tutorials,' I found the game much more engrossing. The battle system is a great thing. Subverts your typical understanding of video games in the same vein and genre, while introducing a whole lot of custom 'scenarios' based on who and what you're fighting. I won't spoil anything major, but basically (apart from random battles from time to time), there are no two encounters that are the same.  The game is rather meticulously scripted. I won't say it feels linear, but it pretty much is. What matters here is more the choices you make. That's where majority of the 'exploration' comes from. Otherwise, the narrative is very much set in stone, like a well worn novel. The game does play with the concept of reality, time travel, and outside dimensions a bit, but the game will basically take a scripted path from start to finish. And that's okay! Because the attention spent to the details is second to none. I honestly think the narrow scope of the narrative serves to encourage multiple playthroughs, and doesn't waste the players time. There are lots of little secrets you can find and experience if you go a little out of your way to find them. That's part of what makes the game so engrossing. I go here, search that, what will I find? What goofy thing is there next to discover? The linearity of the narrative makes finding these kinds of things a little easier and thus you enjoy them more. So, in addition to being a good story, it's just a very well made, and well-paced game.   If I had to nitpick about anything, it'd just be that the art style/design in some of the characters is inconsistent. It comes across as a mish-mash sometimes. Some characters are well designed, but some look like they were scribbled onto a piece of paper with a ballpoint pen. Maybe chalk it up to a smaller budget, or a small team of people with different art styles, but I did notice it. It didn't really affect my ability to appreciate the game at all though. It's just something to note.  That said, character face sprites while talking were very expressive. One could tell a bunch of effort was put it into designing and key-framing them. It's probably important to have expressive and emotive faces next to the text bubbles because you spend half your time in the game reading dialogue. As a result the character sprites themselves don't nearly get the same amount of animation love... but to be frank, you hardly notice it because you're too busy laughing at a bad pun or enjoying an intense battle.  I did two endings (out of a possible three from what I understand?). I will be planning to do the third later tonight maybe.   There is nuance even in the endings however, and I'm sure if you cared you could look up a flowchart or something on the internet... I'm guessing honestly... but I think Undertale has garnered enough of a following at this point that it's probably out there on the net.  I think the game deserves the praise it's getting, especially considering the team it came from, but I can't say it's the best game in this vein that I've ever played. That honor goes to Mother 3.  9/10 go and play it.

First of all, let me just say, this is a game full of feels. I cried a bit during this game, especially towards the end of the pacifist route. I'm gonna warn you, it is impossible to get the pacifist route the first go, since the game is created that way, but when you do get the good ending, have a box of tissues with you. I cried. A LOT. I'm replaying it to see any of the little things I could have missed throughout the game, and overall this was a very well made game. The music is beautiful, comforting, fun, exciting, and some of the music just gives you feels depending on whats happening in the game at that moment. The characters are extremely loveable, and its almost as if they are real. Some of the characters you can talk to over and over, and they always come up with something new or funny to talk about. Also, some of these characters are extremely relateable in many ways~ It makes it much more interesting and exciting to play through and in a way makes you more attactched to these characters. I don't have the heart to do the genocide route. Not after having built relationships with these characters. This game really plays with your emotions, but in a more positive way. Honestly this is one of my favorite games, and I will always remember this game. If you are hesitating on getting this game because it has become so 'Mainstream', I suggest you get it. It is popular for a reason. Don't try and be the hipster outcast just because this is a game everyone likes. If most people like it, its usually for a good reason! I admit I was hesitating about getting it for that reason, but having played it, I realized that a lot of times, if something has gained a lot of fame, its usually because it earned it. This is one of those games that honestly earned all the popularity that it is getting. I hope more games like this will start coming out. This is one of those games where you know the creator put a lot of heart and thought into it, and I am very thankful for that~ So many wonderful aspects to this game, there is something for everyone in Undertale. :)  Happy gaming~

Undertale demands a lot from the player. It demands at least some knowledge of videogames (especially JRPGs), anime, and internet subculture. It also demands you have a sense of humor similar to Toby Fox, the game's developer. If your sense of humor isn't completely goofy and nerdy, you might think the game is far too silly. And if you're looking for a challenge, you're looking in the wrong place.  All of that being said, I found Undertale to be one of the most hilarious, well-written games I've ever played. It's not the prettiest thing to look at, and could surely use a visual upgrade, but the music is fantastic, the battle system is far deeper than it seems at first glance (most of the boss fights are pretty great), and few games will ever warm your heart like Undertale will. Undertale is not for everyone, and the fanbase would do well to remember this. However, I can say with certainty that Undertale is for me.

This game did Indeed caught me by surprise. I was browsing the top releases of the week and this game appears. I watch the trailer and its concept of combat made me want to play this game. Now, like a SOB I am, I pirated the game first (Yeah, go ♥♥♥♥ myself, I know.) But after beating the game I was so shocked that I decided to actually buy the game. The game is so powerful that it LITERALLY leaves a scar in a place of your heart. It is a masterpiece. I would recommend this to be a GOTY2015. The Story is Amazing and has a huge amount of content depending of which path you choose. Characters are filled with personality and you will fall in love with them. Battle system is quite an unique mix and it will bring you fun and frustration if you mess up. Every Enemy is Unique in its way. Bosses are really fun and challenging as well. Be warned tho, if you do beat the game on the Pacifist way, it will require 100 times the DETERMINATION to actually reset the game 100% and explore the other endings. I simply cannot explore the other endings due to the personality of the characters. I did the True Reset when I bought the game and I still did the Pacifist ending. This game will make you cry. Will make you laugh. Will make you Insane. Will make you think about it for weeks and even might get you sucked into the fandom of this game. In my honest opinion, games like these, where when you finish it and make you going to miss how it feels playing it for the first time. Thinking about how you could've done this thing in another way, or simply having to write a review of it, are considered masterpieces in my book. Toby Fox's KickStarter game was extremely successful and I was glad that the UNDERTALE team finished this product. Extremely well done to the team. I read that they might have comics of this series as it was listed in the goals of the KickStarter. I am quite excited for it and hope it becomes a reality. I simply need more UNDERTALE.(Maybe even a sequel...? But I honestly don't know how team's going to pull it off.) The fact that this is an Indie game, and has made so many people think and reflect about themselves, is quite incredible. Witnessing the influence of games like these feels me with DETERMINATION.  10/10 GOTY2015 Would make others play.

When I saw people saying that this was one of the best games of 2015 and I watched some gameplay footage, the first thing that came to my mind was: 'are you freaking serious? This is a child's game.' So... Suddenly for no apparent reason I decide to buy the game and give it a shot. After one hour playing, I was already convinced: This IS one of the best games of 2015. And I'm amazed by this fact, so many called 'triple a games' fail to be as fun as Undertale is. So far, there has been a very few amount of games that managed to keep me interested in playing it, this is one of those games.  In basic details, Undertale is a JRPG styled game where the objective is not to kill anything, try to solve all of your problems in diplomatic (sometimes not so diplomatic) ways. But of course, if you just want to say 'screw everything' and start killing everything that's in your way, you can do it, but mind the interesting consequences by the near-end of the game that are going to make you feel like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥. It's filled with awesome and lovable characters, lots of puns and stupid but very funny enemies (such as a block of ice with a cool hat).  Undertale is very well designed, it's an emotional game, it's not epic and great, it's simple and fascinating. The creator did a really really great job with this. I understand why there's a good amount of people complaining, it sure does not have a very good visual, even for an parody 8-bit game, but if you ever feel like trying something fresh, interesting and really entertaining, give Undertale a try.
ohhh man just PLAY IT ALREADY PLEASE IT ALMOST MADE ME CRY LOVE IT 10/10 WOULD LOSE MY DIGNITY AGAIN

This is one of the best games I've played in a long time. I've laughed until tears were in my eyes, I've gotten choked up, and I've recoiled in fear from my computer. Every battle is a pleasure, and every interaction is a treasure. Whatever you do though, don't skip through dialogue EVER. You have no idea what can change between playthroughs.  Papyrus was right - I have been drawn deep into a dark prison of passion. But that prison of passion is for every character in this game. And I honestly don't ever want to get out.

Wow, what a fantastic game.   The writing is absolutely fantastic, with interesting characters abound (My favorite is by far Papyrus).The battle mechanics are interesting enough to not get boring because of how each enemy is like a puzzle in and of itself, keeping you on your toes when multiple enemies ambush you and you are forced to think about the best way to dispatch them. The music is also excellent, in and out of fights.  The kill/spare mechanic is amazing with the way it affects the story (which is awesome). The story itself is engaging and kept me interested throughout the entire thing, even when late-game bosses were giving me major headaches. The game is tough enough to be satisfying, but not too overbearing.  In my playthrough, I tried to spare as many as I could, and my mistakes had pretty dire consequences. It was really interesting (and usually pretty emotional) when you see the consequences of your actions.  And holy toledo, let me just say, the ending to this game was like nothing I've really played before, maybe ONE single exception which I won't name as it would spoil what makes it... insane. Really creative stuff here.   Negatives: There's a boss and setting that gets recycled a few times in samey areas that, while not detrimental story-wise, was just a little bit stale by the end of it, at least until the final fight with said boss. Also the lack of initial explanation of the attacking/fighting mechanic (which I used rarely in my playthrough) made it a bit disorienting when I used it the first few fights. Also a personal irk, the graphic style is very charming, but I personally think the game could have benefited from full hand-drawn 2d art to flesh out the world. Sometimes it was hard to recognize what they were trying to depict in their small pixel count, but honestly, the style still works very well with the game.  Also, the lack of an options menu with volume control is a little annoying... the sound is very loud compared to anything else, so I couldn't voice chat with friends while playing.  Overall though, definitely one of my favorite games I've played. A fantastic experience that will have you laughing, tearing up, and questioning what the heck is going on. Major props to Toby Fox and the dev team for making this wonderful adventure.   TL;DR: This game deserves the hype the internet gave it. The fact it was made by such a small team is a testament to gaming as art, as this game IMO is a masterpiece. DEFINITELY pick this one up if you like RPGs, hell, even if you don't, you may just learn to love them. I can't wait to go through another playthrough making different choices and seeing how the game plays out.
Did Mother 3 give you feels? Do you like said feels? If so, play this game. Go in blind, and I guarantee that you will have a strong GOTY contender by the end of the experience.
It makes me cry when i see the ending everytime. Pros: everything Cons: it takes a bit to get used to the controls. but other than that, GREAT GAME! WORTH THE MONEY TIME AND EFFORT!
its a good game ,but its hard to change the name

This game is an emotional rollercoaster (in a good way). This game made me feel almost every emotion that I could feel. It also carried some of those emotions into real life. This game gave me determination (pun intended) to look for the good in the world and to work hard so that some day I could eventually make a difference. Alright back to the actual game aspect of the game. It's a turn based RPG with 2 options of dealing with enemies, either sparing them or killing them. Sparing is when you do all sorts of actions like talking or petting your enemies until you can spare them. While if you decide to kill them, you have to a little time minigame (it's hard to describe). What about the characters? They are fantastic. Even though then their voices qualify as a bunch of beepish sounds, you can still feel the emotion of the characters via their dialog. What about the music? It's the best I heard in a while only being rivaled by the Hotline Miami series. All of the music tells you the emotions of the situation at hand and all of it is placed at where it needs to be. What about the graphics? The graphics are in an retro 8-bit style with many vibrant colors. While some may be turned of the game because of the asthetics, overall to most gamers the visuals will be appealing. What about the story? Well the story is probably the best aspect of the game. It's seemingly querky yet serious without having things get all messy. When I say it's querky I mean that they are lot of jokes and puns in the game that always got a laugh out of me. There are many comedic bits aimed for both adults and other more innocent people. Also warning this game can get really tragic and really heart-warming. All right so thats the gist of the game, great gameplay, great music, and great visuals, an excellent story. This is an obvious reccommendation from me and personally this is one of if not the best game I have ever played. Also what do you call a lone skeleton... Bonely (Ha Ha).

I didn't think much of Undertale. I was curious, sure, but my attitude going into it was one of not really taking it seriously. With that mindset, I was massively impressed by what I ended up with. I committed to killing everything in sight on my first playthrough, and even under those circumstances the level of character development puts almost all major-budget titles to complete shame. With some characters getting only a few minutes to introduce themselves, the game always managed to garner my investment in them.  Further, the game is also subtle about what consequences your actions take. Friends watching me play were able to tell me of massive swathes of the game I was excluded from due to my murderous antics - almost nothing I would have realized was missing unless I had been told about it. Often times characters will make comments that seem to be in direct response to things you've done, but still you can't be sure. The game does an incredible job of toying with your expectations, and I never even encountered any of the fourth-wall breaking moments along my journey. And that's not mentioning all of the ways in which the game establishes rules for the sake of breaking them; the UI itself cannot be trusted, constantly doing things it shouldn't or not doing things it should in creative and memorable ways.  Undertale is the sort of game where playing with a guide will absolutely destroy your experience. In that sense, it's not a game for everyone; but if you're even remotely curious, disregard the hype and counter-circlejerking and all the nonsense that has ended up surrounding the game. It is absolutely worth your time.

I remember when Minecraft came out thinking the low-res graphics looked kind of silly for modern gaming. Then I played it and realized part of the reason the graphics were so minimal was because of the depth the world made it a necessity. The 16-bit feel of the game ended up becoming endearing in its own quirky way. Similarly, Undertale uses simplistic graphics. Like with Minecraft the reason seems to be due to the depth of the world, though not in a literal sense here. The story is rich and rewarding. The characters are, as a whole, memorable and likeable. While the gameplay can take a little getting used to if you don't want to simply murder your way to victory or if you're unfamiliar with things like mechanics (they don't just fix cars!), it felt fresh especially when compared to other pseudo-RPGs that have come out lately.  If you enjoy stories, even a little, you should play this game. If you don't, you should still play this game and see if it can't change your mind.

One that each person will hopefully, discover for himself/herself.  I highly recommend this game to anyone willing to play it (and if you want to go all in and support an amazing game dev, buy the soundtrack to the game as well). It is a damn shame that this game did not win GOTY (although Witcher 3: Wild Hunt was spectacular) and it certainly had the making to be that game.  Seriously, this game is all-round spectacular and should receive no less than a 10/10.

Spider bake sales, fourth wall breaking skeletons and an extremely terrifying flower, what more is there to say? Undertale, arguably one of the most interesting and soulful games of the year, arrives in the form of a simple throwback to old-style Role Playing Games. What initially began as an inconspicuous crowd-funding project on Kickstarter in 2013, developed into something much larger over the course of a couple of years. Toby Fox, who had previously composed music for the incredibly popular webcomic ‘Homestuck’, had once made a foray into the world of game creation for his popular Halloween hack of ‘Earthbound’. However, until Undertale, we hadn’t yet had the pleasure of seeing his full creative prowess realized.  As the game begins a cutscene plays and the player is given a quick synopsis of a war that took place several hundred years ago between Humans and Monsters. In the end, the Humans stood victorious, and as a result Monsters were sealed underground by a magic barrier and have remained stuck there since. Centuries later, a child of ambiguous gender climbs a mountain in the wilderness and, long story short, falls inside and awakens in the realm of the Monsters. In true retro RPG fashion, the exploration portion of the game is from a top down view with 16 bit graphics to boot, and if you can’t ignore the glaringly intentional decision to do this then it may serve to alienate some. Yet, the fighting mechanic of the game is highly irregular in comparison to other classic RPGs. During an encounter with an enemy NPC the fighting is traditionally turn based, attacks must be timed correctly by landing a blow at a precise time to maximise damage, but when an enemy returns fire, the player is thrust into a ‘bullet-hell’ type mini-game, whereupon you must guide a heart around which is meant to represent your soul and dodge projectiles. A neat mechanic is the variation of the projectiles you must dodge, some are simple bullets which fly around the screen, whilst others can change colours which require players to remain still, and one of them is even a dog that you have to avoid whilst it chases after you.  Despite all this, Undertale is one of the only games I have played where you are actively discouraged to participate in needless violence and killing. Through use of narrative in the tutorial and throughout the game itself, players are told another way to cease conflict with an enemy is through ‘ACT(ing)’ and then sparing them. This mechanic allows you to talk the enemy down in a plethora of ways- tell me, in what game can you defeat a body-builder sea-horse by flexing it out of the match? Or again, could you give me an example of a game where you pet an enemy into submission? It’s this creativity which gives the game its strongest flair, its undeniable charm. It’s not just the gameplay either. The story never makes any grandeur promises in the beginning of the game, if anything it appears extremely generic, but the way you interact with the world, even something as subtle as going on a date with a character can change the entire story. Speaking of the characters, this is some of the best-written cast ever seen in a game, you’ll find yourself busting a gut again and again at some of the dialogue, and feeling crushed at some of the more emotional sections. In fact, one of the strongest parts of the game is it makes you care about the characters, more so than in any game I’ve ever played. For example, in a game like Fallout 3, an incredible game in every sense of the word, if you choose to kill people instead of sparing them it doesn’t really bother you. Whereas with Undertale, even though fighting and killing is always an option within the game, (and especially with different endings and the ability to replay the game, you are sorely tempted!) I could never bring myself to even kill a single NPC, I was that attached to the world I had entered. The music as well compliments every section of the game, during boss battles the tracks provide you with such determination that no matter the difficulty you can’t bring yourself to give up, and during emotional sections you feel the anguish of the characters.  To be frank, this is a game that needs to be played to be believed, and in no way has any game made me want to play it again and again. It’s only around £7, so if you have the means and you fancy going on an unforgettable adventure with memorable characters and addictive gameplay pouring out of the seams, don’t hesitate!

Undertale is a good game, but it does have its flaws. Here is a simple list of pros and cons, spoiler free, you can consider before buying the game.  Pros  1 - The story, at its core, is good. Very nice premise that reveals itself as the game goes on.  2 - The characters are memorable and fun.  3 - The music is fantastic.  4 - The game has a decent amount of feeling to it, emotions, that make it quite immersive.  5 - The decision on how to play is dealt with quite well, and leads to interesting scenarios.  Cons  1 - The story, although good, can be a bit random and out-of-the-blue. Some of the biggest plot points aren't revealed until quite late, and can go over some folks' heads if they aren't paying attention. There are hints throughout the game, but it feels a bit ham-fisted at times.  2 - The characters are great, but can feel a bit one dimensional at times. Some of them have flaws, others merely exist in this creative world of monsters. Some feel like walking memes, which can be a little exhausting.  3 - The gameplay/combat. I personally had no problem with the combat system, but after watching a couple of my friends play through and listening to their complaints, I can see why it is an issue. Bullet Hell games are really hit or miss, and although the fights are fresh and creative, they can serve to annoy some players and detract from the overall fun of the game. If you aren't fond of Bullet Hell games, be wary.  4 - The humor may not be for everyone.  Overall, I'd recommend Undertale to just about any gamer that has a fondness for RPGs and story. It is a fun little game at a decent price, so there is nothing really to lose. However, that being said, it is okay to dislike Undertale. Some people might not like the combat. Others may dislike the characters. Many may grow to disdain the community this game has made, and that is totally fine. I'm personally not a part of it. Don't let hype or hatred skew your view about this game.  Give it a try, and judge for yourselves.

Wow. I'm honestly blown away by how amazing this game is. Ever since I disovered the trailer I had wanted it and was lucky enough to get it on the Christmas Sale, and I can say I was far from disappointed, even when I heard about all the attention it was receiving. There is just something so unique and charming about this game that you really couldn't hate it, especially going in blind. The combat is interesting and they really mean it when you don't have to kill anything. You wouldn't even want to given how loveable the characters are (seriously, you can tell so much love and effort has been put into the characters and their personalities). The music is also astounding, and it did fill me with   determination.   Not to mention it is also highly memorable and just plain good to listen to, especially in boss battles. This game is just so full of charm and love that I can't wait to give it a second playthrough. I heard the fandom was horrid, but I was lucky enough to stay away from it as well as spoilers before I played it. I personally think everyone should play this game, just once, and form their own opinion on it. I would usually joke in my reviews but this game deserves all the love it gets. Plus, who could resist cute pixel dogs? I sure couldn't.

(I played most of the game in offline mode, so disregard the play time :) )  I feel sad that somewhere out there, someones going to judge this game because of the fact it is 2D, or that the combat sucks, or about some other stuff... and i also feel sorry that this fact will keep them from experiencing this amazing game...  I have no clue how one guy, with such a small team, could create a game that feels so ALIVE! The characters are likable and unique, and depending on your choices, they will change along with your choices, you shape what they become, and some characters are VERY interesting, with theories about their backstories and origins. The story, even if it may seem simple at the beggining, it gets so much more interesting and complex as you play, you discover the truth in the world of Undertale and what has happened before your arrival... and how what you are doing now relates to it all in the bigger picture. The music... god, every song gets better and better as you progress, and each theme for each character fits perfectly, and they all have such awesome melodies, basically this game has the best soundtrack ive ever heard in a video game.  This is the first game ive ever played that has delivered such an emotional impact to me, in any game ever. It reminds me somehow of the movie Bridge to Terabithia, the kind of feeling that all of this could be a childs daydream, but brought into a whole new world of possible darkness and madness, with the player choosing what becomes of their 'timeline'...  The 4th wall is broken many times in this game, usually by the more powefull characters, one of the boss fights uses this aspect to make it one of the best boss fight experiences EVER. Its also so cool how the game uses key game words like 'SAVE' in different ways, its used in the song 'SAVE the world', which obviously dosnt mean save it to your file, but save it... and how different characters interact with the options you choose like 'SPARE' or 'ACT' when you choose them.  Overall, Undertale is an amazing game!  But on a personal level, i honestly do think this is the best game ive ever played, ive never experienced anything like this game, and considering such a small team created this and the same creator made this AWESOMELY wonderful soundtrack, i have no IDEA how so much awesome could be stuffed into one person. Thank you Mr. Toby :), this game will be legendary...

I guess I should throw my positive review on the pile of positive reviews.   So this game isn't second coming of jesus like some make it to be, there are some technical problems/limitations because of gamemaker and minor issues here and there which could've been easily fixed or improved.   However most of the issues are really minor and rest will bury under how well done the rest of the game is made. I think I remember every single character I came across, I remember the journey trough the differend areas, there didn't seem to be single bad song, I had a big smile on my face for almost half of the game and every time I have that smile I remember why I'm loving games as much as I do. (also wide range of other feelings from that to nervous breakdown..in a good sort of way?)  I heard many things about what kind of game this was before even buying it, most of them were really vague because of spoilers of course. Game does use many differend approaches and mechanics, but never seems to latch onto one specific one, so going trough the story as it unfolds gives the best experience, instead of thinking the game as visual novel, rpg, puzzle game, meta or anything else. Just play is as it is and get that really nice, warm positive feeling from playing it.   Oh, and remember to get the full ending. It's really worth it.    And maybe, somewhere in the future, there will be console release which means game getting ported to bit more proper engine, with all the minor technical difficulties ironed out and proper full dualshock 4 support. Just maybe.   - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -  Kaipa se pitää heittää positiivinen arvostelu positiivisten arvostelujen pinoon.   Tämä peli ei ole mikään jeesuksen toinen tuleminen mitä jotkut antavat ymmärtää, gamemakerin takia pelissä on teknisiä ongelmia/rajoituksia ja pieniä juttuja siellä täällä jotka olisi voinut helposti korjata tai parantaa.   Mutta kaiken kaikkiaan suurin osa ongelmista on hyvin pieniä ja peli on niin hyvin tehty että loput ongelmat unohtuvat. Taidan muistaa joka ikisen hahmon jonka kohdalle osuin, muistan matkan jokaisen alueen läpi, pelissä ei tuntunut olevan yhtään huonoa kappaletta, minulla oli vähintään puolet peliajasta iso hymy naamalla ja joka kerta kun minulla on se hymy naamalla muistan miksi rakastan pelejä niin paljon. (ja sen lisäksi laaja skaala muitakin mielialoja siitä hymystä hermoromahdukseen asti...sillein hyvällä tavalla?)  Kuulin monenlaista juttua siitä minkälainen peli on ennen sen ostamista, suurin osa oli hyvin suuntaa antavia ettei paljastaisi pelistä mitään. Peli käyttää hyvin montaa lähestymistapaa ja mekaniikkaa, mutta ei ikinä tunnu oikein tarttuvan mihinkään yksittäiseen juttuun, joten yksinkertaisesti pelin pelaaminen antaa parhaan kokemuksen, sen sijaan että miettisi peliä visuaalinovellina, roolipelinä, pulmapelinä, metana tai minään muuna. Pelaa peli niinkuin se on olemassa ja koe se mukana, lämmin positiivinen fiilis jonka sen pelaamisesta saa.   Niin, ja muista saada täysi lopetus. Se on enemmän kuin sen arvoista.    Ja ehkä joskus tulevaisuudessa peli saa konsoliversion, joka meinaa pelin siirtymistä hieman paremmalle moottorilla, jolloin kaikki pienet tekniset ongelmat ovat tiessään ja pelissä olisi täysi ohjaintuki dualshock 4 ohjaimelle. Toivottavasti.

This game is pretty dope. I mean, if you like puns, irony, memes, anime, Earthbound, and/or self-awareness cuteness you might actually start foaming at the mouth while playing this, and then go into shock. But even those who aren't familiar with some (or any) of the concepts mentioned above, commonplace in certain internet sub-cultures, Undertale is still worth a try if nothing else for its interesting blend of Japanese RPG battle systems and old school arcade 'bullet hell' shooters. But that would be selling the world and story of Undertale short.  You play as a child who has fallen down into an underground ruin that is home to a large community of monsters. Throughout the game you will meet, greet, fight, and/or befriend lots of very charmingly designed characters, all of whom are richly developed and often heart-achingly relatable. All of this is reflected both in the main world exploration and in battle. Though Undertale does at a glance look and feel like an amalgam of numerous games of also numerous genres with all the inherent pastiches and tropes therein, I've never really played anything quite like it. It takes a lot from other games but manages through immense ingenuity carves out an existence all its own. There's really nothing else out there currently quite like it.  The game is about 7-8 hours long if you play leisurely your first time through, but multiple playthroughs are absolutely necessary to get the most out of the game, due to the fact that the story and ending change in subsequent runs. Lots of games do this, but not to the extent that Undertale does. As I said before, this game is very self-aware, and this reflects on the new game plus (or plus plus, depending on which ending you get first).   So in short. Undertale is a charming little gem, with lots of fun characters, a unique battle system, and greatly rewards multiple playthroughs, and when I say that it rewards you for doing so, I really, seriously mean it. For me, the game didn't truly click until I played it a second time. It's only then that Undertale cracks open its soul and reveals to you the secrets of its universe.  It's real cool. Buy it.

It is, at it's heart, a love letter to the Earthbound/Mother series, and it subverts those expectations wonderfully through the gameplay. Your choices against the puzzles/opponents will matter throughout the game and make you rethink your decisions throughout. The cast of characters is nothing less than delightful; A dorky, obnoxious group of weirdos that I spent 15 hours battling, befriending, and ultimately caring about.  An incredibly simple battle system that is cleverly expanded throughout gameplay, and is masterfully leveraged against a host of memorable characters. This is the game that sums up the Indie golden age of gaming: subverting traditional gaming tropes to rethink your choices as a player and ultimately engage in the well-being of the world you're part of.  Loved the game, intend to continue to explore it throughout the years.

TL;DR Undertale is my number one favorite game. It has well developed characters that are compelling, with jsut enough humor and grimness to make entertaining. The gamepaly is fast and unique, and the story is well written. Best video game soundtrack ever. Easy buy!  Alright. Lets get to the grit.  Its hard for me to be too specific about these characters without spoilers, but these characters are great. Each of them has a massive amount of dialogue, and maybe I just like reading, but I inspected EVERYTHING in this game. NPC's were interesting and quirky, environments and music was thought and feeling provoking, but it gets out of the way when you need to focus on an objective. The game has a ton of repaly value, but after the second or third playthrough, you may find yourself bored with the characters you've interacted with again and again, but dependant on your playthrough, characters act differently, and the environments are different. The gameplay is different, utilizing a galaga style screen on which you dodge your foes attacks. This make your skill feel important to winning fights, and is also a very cool mechanic in general! This is where I would put a quote or in joke for people who have already beaten the game, but you couldn't understand. What's that look? Am I wrong?  ...   Villains were hated. Villains were killed. You felt bad. Or didn't. You went on. After all, what could you do? This game already has rules, and you better play by them.
Do not underestimate this game~ One of the most powerful indie games out there, showing you can aim for the stars with bare minimum, and actually succeed. Just Damn.

To me this game was...meh. I got it before I found out about the fanbase, but was mostly interested in the soundtrack and rather 'old style.'  Though I wouldn't normally do a rating system like this, I'm just organizing my thoughts so I'm not biased towards one element of the game.  Soundtrack: 10/10 - Loved everything about it. (Even if you don't like chiptunes, the composition of them was great) Story: 6/10 - It made sense half way through, but eventually I got kind of lost. Sorta weak, but it was enough, or expected. Characters: 8/10 - They really stood out in personality, but I didn't feel any special connection to them whatsoever (like this weird fanbase). The reason I gave 8 is because I liked that the monsters fought weren't just mindless 'robots' (figuratively) that were put into the game to be killed. They were beings that weren't ment to be killed. (key theme) Functions/Gameplay: 6/10 - I liked the combat system (much like traditional rpgs) and scattered puzzles, but that's about it. The gameplay felt dragging at times, but was still enough. Though I liked the puzzles, they weren't impressive. I didn't feel any overwhelming challenge (expect for Asgore). Graphics: Not good, but who cares?  Avg Score: 75/100 (not including graphics)

This one of the few games in which the community for it isn't the best. Namely, in terrible fan made stuff where people add in their own OCs (Original Characters) or causing controversy with one of the characters because said character belongs to a fandom that isn't looked too highly upon. However, don't let these things get in the way in enjoying this game. As the trailer says, you have the choice to kill or to spare every enemy and boss you fight. Also, every enemy in the game can be spared, but some are tougher than others and you might not figure it out the first time. Highly advise against looking at any guides until you beat the game once and are feeling like trying to go down a different path in the game.  Now that I said some good about the game itself there is some bad, and the community isn't one of it. The game's graphics are retro styled (8-Bit) and some might not like this type of art style. Also, the fights, while they are turn based, involve you dodging projectiles and later on this gets to the point where the game becomes very bullet hell-ish. Sometimes even frustratingly so. However, the worst offenders of this are two bosses that only appear in one of the paths you can take in the game. Thankfully, there's no achievements in this game so there isn't really any reason to play the game anymore than once if you feel so inclined.  That's about it and I hope you enjoy this game about as much as I did.

I feel like the market is oversaturated with indie games using pixelated/retro art that reminds me of the games I grew up with. Honestly, that was one thing holding me back from my initial purchase of Undertale. I figured 'Oh, it's just another one of those games. Nothing special.' But the gaming community was going crazy over it, so I decided to look further. Let me state something clearly:    I was wrong. This game is something special.   I'd also like to note I won't be adding any pictures because I feel as though it would ruin some of the surprise and fun that Undertale offers.   Basic Premise : Without giving too much away, you find yourself (a human) in the underground world of monsters. These monsters don't want you here, in fact most want you dead. Your goal is to get out of this world, but to do so you must make your way through all of these monsters. What makes this unique is that you don't have to kill everyone. In fact, each enemy has a special way you can 'ACT' that it will pacify it. For example, you can choose to encourage a sad looking enemy, or laugh at the joke of a stand-up comic enemy. That alone makes this a unique experience.   Graphics : As previously stated, it uses a retro style, pixelated art. Though I feel that it has become commonplace to see this style of art, it is stylized enough that it stands out. I normally am not big on these types of graphics, but I really enjoyed the overall feel it gave to the game. And after all, this game was more an experience than anything else. I believe that this graphic style added to this.   Sound : The soundtrack is wonderful. It fits the game and tone perfectly, there are many different types of tunes which adds more character to the experience. Just like the graphics it was a solid choice and added a lot to the game.   Gameplay : This game is structured around 3 things. The unique battle system, some spatial puzzles, and the clever writing. The battle system is like a standard turn-based RPG where you can attack your enemy or choose to do a different action. Based on what you do, the enemy reacts. Ultimately you can choose to spare them or kill them in most cases. What makes this unique is that when the enemy attacks, you dodge their attack via a small box where you control your 'heart' and dodge their attack (think old-school bullet hell style). Later on, they introduce different complexities like certain colors which have certain effects and so on.  The spatial puzzles were fine. Nothing we haven't seen before, but a nice break between the battles. I can't say I loved them, but I understand that there had to be something else. Maybe additional variety would have added to the experience since most puzzles take similar forms. That being said, they were tight enough and I can't complain.  Where I think the game truly shines is the writing. For those familiar with Paper Mario or EarthBound, it is heavily inspired by that feel. The writing is comical, over the top, but can get very dramatic as well. Also, the sense of humor is really clever and hilarious. I found myself actually laughing as I was playing (which probably made me look crazy). Also, the characters the game introduces are all great. Every one of them has a distinct personality and is delightfully over-the-top. Where many games attempt to be funny, this one truly accomplishes the goal, all while avoiding being cliche and boring.    Overall : I will admit this too: during the prologue, I was having trouble getting excited about this game. I put it down several times and just couldn't get hooked. Once I got through that segment and saw the title pop up again, I didn't put the game down. Seriously. I played the rest of it in one sitting.   That however brings up another point: if you are the type of person who likes long games for your money, this may not be the best fit. I completed the game in about 5-6 hours. That being said, there are multiple endings and different choices (as well as secrets) in the game, so plenty of replayability. It retails at 10 dollars on Steam with no sale, so that choice is up to you.  I will state again, though. This game is something special. I played EarthBound and thought that the story was good, as was the writing, but I didn't think it aged very well. This game gave me that same feeling, while bringing something new in the battle system. Even with its slow start, I am happy to have played this game. It's one of those ones that you will think about after you've finished it, not just barrel through and move onto the next one.  I recommend this game to any RPG fans, especially those of specific ones like EarthBound, Paper Mario, the Mario and Luigi games, etc. If you're on the fence, give this one a try. Power through the prologue and I don't think you'll be disappointed.

11/10  I'll be honest, this game seemed pretty simple at first, reminiscent of the RPGs I used to play as a little kid. The graphics weren't too fancy, the storyline seemed pretty bland and predictable, but when it went on sale, I decided, why not just buy the game?  Before I start talking about the game, let me mention that the music is SO DAMN GOOD. I could listen to the music by itself anytime, it's that good. The emotional rollercoaster this game puts you through is very unexpected, and the characters, no matter how insignificant they may seem at first, all play a very important role and demonstrate their own unique personalities. There is so much to say about how beautiful this game is, yet it's so hard to actually describe in words. My only advice is to just buy the game. Your life will change from that moment on.  One thing to note while playing the game though. DO NOT look up any hints or anything online. Play this game blindly, and rid yourself of any distractions. Fully immerse yourself into this game, and you will come to know what Undertale truly is.

I recently was listening to Undertale OST and I realized I didn't write a review for this game soooo here it is.  Sorry it might be a little long because there's so much things I want to say about it. It's probably going to be a messy review haha.   A friend told me to play the game so I looked it up, I saw the trailers and I told her 'meh graphics are ♥♥♥♥ it's weird and stuff... not the kind of game I like', a week later she got a crack of the game and FORCED ME TO PLAY THE GAME AT SCHOOL. AT SCHOOL. I was a bit reluctant but I did.   Yes I was kind and innocent and I got    rekt by Flowey    and it made me laugh I was like 'the ♥♥♥♥ is wrong with this game' so I just kept playing. (and bought it on steam ofc :^) ) The game is full of stupid jokes, so stupid that you end up laughing at them, sometimes the game didn't even make any sense to me, I couldn't understand how someone had the idea to make such a brillant game.   Then there is the story. Oh god. I didn't expect that. You're a little boy/girl you fall down to a 'world' full of monsters and you just wander in there meeting new people and trying to go back to the surface. Pretty simple right?  BUT. Once you get why you fell there. What happened here. And what you're doing, your choices. You heart just breaks.  The very begining of the game you discover everything, you laugh at everything and slowly you begin to understand that there's so much more behind this. You can say whatever you want, that I'm weird or ♥♥♥♥ but I literally cried 5 minutes straight during the game and I had to stop for a while because I couldn't do anything about it, I just couldn't hold back the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ tears.   What surprises me is all the choices you can make and what are the consequences of it. I've never seen a game going this far. All the details you can check, the conversations you can have with the monsters and what they say after every turn during a 'fight'. THERE IS SO MUCH CONTENT FOR A 10$ GAME JESUS.  And if you replay the game SOME THINGS DO CHANGE BECAUSE OF YOUR PAST SAVE ISN'T IT AWESOME?   The OST is perfect, every song is wisely chosen for the bosses / scenes etc. My favourite one is definitly 'Undertale' and 'Waterfall'.   I think everyone can feel different about the game but this one really hit me deep in the feels because of some things that happened in my life. I couldn't resist and got my very first tattoo of one of my favourite scene and probably the best quote of the game and it means a lot for me.  ' * But it refused.   <3 ' If you didn't play the game yet, you'll know later how beautiful this quote is.  This game is one of the best I've ever played if not the best.  Buy it and play it. Please.

Overall, Undertale is a great game and deserves any praise it gets. I'm not an emotional guy nor do I really care about the fate of fictional characters in any game/movie/book/show, but Undertale gave its characters such a personality and such a backstory that I legitamately felt bad for killing them, making me hesitant to do a genocide run. The music is just as great as the story and every song fits the theme of the area or battle perfectly. The design and art style of the game is nice and colorful, although nothing too spectacular. The only real flaws with the game are the fanbase and the game's replay value. I'm not the first one to mention the fanbase warning, but I'm sure the majority of these other reviews don't mention the fact that the game is sadly only truly fully playable about 3 times before you get bored, and that's including the multiple endings. One thing I recommend with this game is to go in blind to have the best experience and do it your own way for at least the first few playthroughs. If you want to get a specific ending but you couldn't really figure out how, just check online. The game is definitely a work of art and one of the best indie games I've ever played next to Shovel Knight.

Undertale is one of those games that don't really suit themselves very good for a review. Reviews, by their nature, tend to spoil, and Undertale is really one of those games it's best to go into blind. Suffice it to say Undertale is a very very good game by my standards and if you've ever played Earthbound, Dragon Quest, or any other classic jRPG from the NES/SNES era you will get a nice trip down memory lane with a fresh new story and a lot of quotable and memetic dialogue. If you have any interest in story-telling or retro gaming, you really should play it.

This is really a remarkable piece of fiction and a game that reignited my zeal for gaming. It handles new perspectives of play by using a style that felt familiar because of its clear homage to vintage titles. 'Undertale' forces you to consider each one of your actions, from the deaths you cause others to your own; we as a gaming community have become so desensitized to killing NPCs that the 'nobody has to die' paradigm of this particular story really puts into perspective the damage we have done all through our years playing.  Another thing I appreciated most of all was that the game mechanics employed the old-fashioned style of teaching the player how to play as they progress, instead of spoon-feeding instructions or building skills in banal fetch quests. I was reminded of classics such as Megaman X because of how important actually paying attention to memetic patterns actually mattered when it came to successfully solving any of the numerous puzzles presented throughout the plot. With a compelling story, original characters, hilarious jokes, and original world, 'Undertale' is everything I didn't realise I had been sincerely craving in a game in such a long time. Its goodness is genuine and in no way contrived, and never takes itself too seriously. If you want a game whose simplicity begins and ends with its controls, look no further. I would recommend this game to any one of my friends who are experienced with games or any novice to the hobby.

Yeah, this is just as amazing as you might have heard. And thankfully, it's by no means as terrible as its fanbase would imply. The story itself is really cute; nothing mindblowing in general, but the way it is delivered to the player is just unique. I had a hard time not feeling crazily immersed. You're gonna like it, I promise.  It has funny jokes and a tasteful sprinkle of dank memes as well. Very simple, shmup-like gameplay that will get you hooked very easily, even on the harder fights that are gonna take you at least 5-10 attempts, way more if you're not used to this kind of stuff.  Some are outrageously difficult, but every bit of progress feels rewarding, as you uncover new lines of dialogue or new attacks by your enemy. And the soundtrack during the battles will get you SO PUMPED. I AM SO PUMPED. Lastly, the game has great replayability. There are different routes you can take. A lot of them, actually.  Personally, I can se no reason anyone would have not to like this.   Try it, as cheap as it is there are only few better investments. Food or rent, maybe.

If you are anything like me, someone hyped this game up for you and you promised you would play it. So you start up the game and the premise is interesting, but about 5 minutes later, you're annoyed by everything and it sucks, and you just want it to end so you can say that you did it. You finally get to this part that you assume is nearly the end of the game and think to yourself 'wow, this is a short game.' and then, out of nowhere, the game is completely different. The story line comes to life, you get attached to characters, you start making decisions that matter, facing foes goes from feeling like walking through a cave without repels to meeting new characters and in turn new friends. Plot twists everywhere! Emotions smacking you in the face! You realize what you thought was the end was not even half way through the game! You check the clock and realize that it's 5 am and you've been playing for 8 hours straight! How many times must the game end before it's truly the end? And when you get there, will you want it to end?   It's a journey, my friend. And if you're going to play the game, please, please, finish it. All the way. To the very end. The true ending. Because it will move you and amaze you and change the way you think about games forever.  That sounds sappy, but it's true. If you're gonna play it, finish it. Or it doesn't count.

A lot of games try to be emotional. They show you something dramatic or sad and tell you how to feel about it. Undertale doesn't tell you anything. It sets up a situation, and then you the player choose how to resolve it, and live with the consequences. The point is that the feelings you develop playing this game are entirely your own. The game doesn't say 'Happily Ever After.' You create the ending and then its up to you to decide if it was happy or not.  This game has something that RPG's generally just do not; depth. Depth doesnt mean there's a lot to see or do. It doesn't mean that there's a ton of customization or enemies to fight. When you're playing a game with true depth, you recognize it because you wonder how things could have gone differently. There are layers to events in the game. The world changes because you changed it. It's not like the RPG Maker swill you see where you push a button to make the character say the thing, and then come back hours later and the character says the thing again because that's the THEN which comes after the IF of pushing the button in front of the character. I hate backtracking and yet I went back through the entire game 3 times throught the course of the game just to talk to everyone I had met and see how they were doing. I hadn't planned on doing it, but there was a reason I went back to see someone, and while I was there I just sort of tought 'I wonder how that person is doing' and things progressed as such.  I can not reccomend this game enough. It's the kind of experience that shows how an enteractive medium is so unique. This is a story that could never be told outside a video game. It's the kind of story that may challenge your understanding of what video games should be, or it may not depending on who you are when you play it. It all depends on you. That's how great games can make a player feel, the master of their own fate. That's what makes games special. It's funny, it's dramatic, it's inspiring, and god damnit the gameplay is fun and evolves through the entire game. The controls are crisp and satasfying, and the soundtrack is the first thing you'll download after you finish the game. Play Undertale, you deserve it!

Do yourself a favor and buy this game. One playthrough only needs 6 hours if you're not used to the game.  But I doubt you'll be able to only play the game once. I've played the game myself 9 times, and I still play it every now and again. There are 3 different routes through the game, each one with a different ending, and each one being absolutely brilliant. Please at least attempt the genocide run. It's my favorite run out of the 3.

BEST GAME EVER  UNDERTALE has an amazing story that makes you cry sometimes. You can choose a path that you will follow for the rest of the game: pacipist or genocide. Depending on your choice, the whole game changes. Toby Fox is probably the best game creator for his talent. His characters have a lot of structure and SO much to them. Sans is, by far, the most amazing character for his brain. But be aware of him in genocide, he's the hardest to beat.  TIPS  Play pacipist first or else you won't enjoy the game as much. You'll be confused and will miss out on so much. If you do paciphist first, you will learn to love the characters,and when you kill them in genocide, you're so shocked and sad of what you would have lost if you had played genocide first.

After hearing about Undertale and playing the demo, I knew I had to buy the full game. I absolutely had to, and I do not regret it at all. Undertale has easily become one of my favorite RPGs that I've had the opportunity to play, and I haven't felt so great about playing one since Chrono Trigger way back on the SNES (and not too long ago on the DS with the remake). I've only played through the pacifist ending (and the required neutral ending), but I honestly don't think I can bring myself to do a genocide run. I just don't think my heart can take it. Seriously, if you are looking for a great RPG, then do yourself a favor and pick up a copy of Undertale.

I don't really know where to start.  My first run was a fully-pacifist run, but I was told that I should have beaten the game on a normal run in order to get the real pacifist ending. At least I'll have another reason to do it again after my second run...  I've never been a huge fan of fighting in general, so I was really glad to be given an option to win every battle without having to hurt the opponent (save for one occasion - you can still spare it). That's right, instead of having your character forcing you into morally ambiguous fights, YOU are the character, and YOU choose the outcome of every encounter. The combat mixing bullet-hell-style dodging, as well as interesting mechanics, was a lot of fun to use while still being quite challening, especially at certain points.  The graphics are very reminescent of the Mother series, and it works quite well. This game is one of the very few instances where the retro art style doesn't come off as lazy and pseudo-artistic 'depth'; the game benefits from it, it probably wouldn't have been as immersive with another style. The soundtrack is excellent and fits the situations.   Moving on to the story... Well, I don't want to spoil it for anyone. As for the pacifist run, it was really touching, the characters were charming enough to make you care about them, and basically every monster had its own special thing. It was a very captivating trip, and made me feel good by the end. After many twists (and about 11 hours), I finally got the ending I wanted. I was happy with the outcome of my efforts and I was having a great day. I was ready to close the game for now, feeling good about what I had accomplished.  But I didn't. I won in the way that Flowey defined as 'victory' - I got what I wanted, but I decided I'd try the opposite way out of curiosity... and take the genocide route...  This was a terrible mistake. Don't be an idiot like me, once you get the ending you originally aimed for, just stop there. I feel terrible now, and it's too late to go back. I never thought I'd feel this sorry for fictional characters, I was not prepared.    The creator of this game knows what he's doing. I highly recommend it.

It's taken me awhile to figure out what to say about Undertale. For me, it was a game that came out of nowhere. It looked interesting and had good reveiws to say the least. It doesn't need much help. The only thing I saw at first was some fanart someone on Tumblr posted.   So, why would I pay $9.99 for a game I know absolutely nothing about... I honestly have know idea... Maybe it was just that picture of Toriel I saw...  What can I say about Undertale? Well, I've putten about eleven hours of my weekend into it. It started off normal enough. JRPG with a morality index and a splash of humor. Actually, make that a pool of humor. There were quite a few parts of this game that made me genuinely laugh. I started the game and played for about two hours. The next day, I played for... perhaps eight hours straight? I couldn't pull myself away. I lost track of time. The story was so captivating and the pacing so well executed.   Undertale manages to not blend together, but rather feel as a complete and definable story. And I really do mean story. No Mary Sueing and no unintentional tropes. It stands apart. It made me feel engaged the whole journey. It's the first game in a long time to make me feel something other than adrenaline or on-edge fear... It's the only game I've played that put me on the edge of crying...  If you're a person who doesn't care much about story, but rather graphics and gameplay, this isn't the game for you. If you despise bullet-hell combat, this is definitley not a game for you. I love stories that resonate, and Undertale delivered. From unique characters and hilarious dialouge, to overwhelming sadness and regret of your decisions, all the proper elements are present. It keeps you on your toes as the plot is revealed through a powerful narrative.  This is a game will remember everything you do. Every mistake you make. Every swing you take. It's watching you. Even on my pacifist playthrough, I would question my decicions. I don't think I could do a genocide route. Not after the ending I got.  I can't really say much more without spoiling the game it self. So, yeah. I really liked Undertale, Toriel is the best goat mom, and highly recommend it. I don't know if I can play it again though. What does that mean? I guess you'll have to find out for yourself.

This game represents everything a choose-your-own adventure story strives to be - an engaging art form with a plot thick like butterscotch sauce. Undertale provides a riveting story with in-depth characters and backgrounds, illustrated with beautiful scenery and a glorious soundtrack. The nature of the tale occasionally steps outside the fourth wall, but this is done so gracefully and as a true plot device rather than a just-for-laughs gimmick. The plot itself varies from nightmare fuel to a bit of dating simulator (if you so choose), but what you get out of the game depends mostly on the choices you put into it. Toby Fox et al. create a whole new world and a loving new family in the Underground, who will take you in as one of their own. And most importantly, it's all up to you what you give to them, and who you take away.
This came in a year that had Fallout 4, Metal Gear Solid V and The Witcher 3.  This game won game of the year.

Do yourself a favor and go into this blind if you can help it. The experience is far better as a surprise, but if you enjoy a worthwhile story and can suspend a little disbelief, it'll be more than worthwhile.

Undertale despite other than being a commercial success of an indie game, It's still a divisive one at that and is doubtless blemished with blatant flaws. Graphical fidelity is pants from start to finish, there was not a single instance when the game managed Not to be an eyesore. The plot gets really corny and unnecessarily convoluted sometimes. And the humour is even on and off lost on me. Battle mechanics are unbelievably simplistic to the extent of being there just for the sake of it.  I will love Undertale until the day I pass away. Undertale is not great if you were to mark it down on its individual criteria, but how the criteria per se harmoniously meshed in the game. Never have I been so impressed by the way the music of the game had its own story telling or how effectively it injected in subtle context via the spartan turn-based bullet hell sequences, or how it let certain characters accompany you throughout the entire trip with conversations on the phone... I will forever remember the first two times I finished the game (completely blinded, for which I'm very fortunate). To wit, Undertale may seem overrated to many, but to me, it is a masterpiece, the epitome of the medium and merits a special place in my heart.

Two years. Two years since September of 2015 when this game is released. It is really awesome to see a lot of thing sprouting from this game. Yes, it includes the AU's, the cosplays, the fanarts, the mods and more. The gameplay mechanic is really neat. You got three routes to go from which are the Pacifist, Neutral, and Genocide. I won't add any in-depth meanings of these but you should try to go blindly.   BUT REMEMBER , never do livestreams or letsplays with idiots telling you what to do in the game (i.e. 'dont kill anyone pls') because one wrong move will trigger these 'fans' and shout at you at your mistake. I suggest that you play it yourself. They are also fans of this beloved RPG game but there's a widely accepted rule that you should just let new players play the game as they are. Let them play  blindly .  I went to some random YouTuber's Undertale letsplay to see and take a look of the comments. Unfortunately, I found out that atleast half the comments are people telling the YouTuber to not kill someone and do the complete True Pacifist route. This is the only problem I have with the game.  Lastly, I would like to thank Toby for making this wonderful game. 10/10 I'd say.               Still here and wondering why I only have 1 hour on record? I played the game on a friend's computer and finished all routes before legitimately buying it for myself.
