TL;DR BELOW  This is the first bullet-hell game I have ever played (note to self, never play bullet-hell games again), the game has a fairly decent story to it and with a lot of interesting characters.    PLEASE UNVEIL SPOILER TAGS AT OWN RISK     PLEASE UNVEIL SPOILER TAGS AT OWN RISK     PLEASE UNVEIL SPOILER TAGS AT OWN RISK   You have been warned three times.  STORY: In the game you learn that there was once a time where Humans and Monsters ruled the Earth together before a war waged between the two. The Humans were victorious during the war and locked all the last standing monster into the 'The Underground' with the use of magic, making sure they were unable to escape without passing    The Barrier   . The Underground can be access through a large hole on top of a mountain in the middle of nowhere where it was once noted that whoever went into the mountain never came back.  There are 3 endings plus 2 bonus endings the Player can recieve... True Pacifist Route:    Complete the story w/o killing anyone and be friends with everyone.    Neutral Route:    Complete the story killing only some characters, not befriending everyone.    Genocide Route:    Complete the story killing pretty much everyone.    And the two bonuses Dirty Hacker: Tamper with too many game files. Post  Genocide: Doing a Pacifist Run after a Genocide Run gives you a... 'special'... ending.     GAMEPLAY: Just a reminder this was my first bullet-hell game I ever played and boy did I ever so many times felt like breaking my keyboard. But for the people who are interested/good at bullet-hell games, you should definetly give this game a shot, 70% garantee you're not going to regret it.  CHARACTERS: The NPCs you encounter have A LOT of personality, ranging from Skeletons with Puns to Anthropomorphic Goats with PIE, honestly the detail Toby adds with the characters just really make you feel like your at home and helps you relate to them. Extra points for making characters with different sexualities.  GRAPHICS: I   personally   feel like 2D games more appealing enviroments than 3D games do. My favorite example is the area    Waterfall   , it's detail just had me wowing when I first saw it.  SOUNDTRACK: Yes, some of the songs may just be re-editted versions of another song in the game, but they still have charms to them. Especially the Final Boss themes, they just feel so exciting to listen to and it really helps get your blood pumping and your hands shaking.  COMMUNITY:  Unfortunately, I feel like the Undertale community is just a redux of the FNaF community, just in a different game. But, weirdly enough, I'm more proud of being an absolute fan of Undertale than being an fan at FNaF   JUST DON'T, THEY MADE SKELETON PORN WORK SOMEHOW.  Let me just say that not every person who likes Undertale is bad... but majority of them just rub the game in your face, claiming it's the best, etc.    NEW

You all heard the same thing about this game: about how it touches you yet still has humor, good gameplay, great writing, and killer music. Well, it's all true. I just want to add that if you want the best this game has, go all in and kill nothing, or go all out and kill so much nothing spawns in any room. The middle road has the most boring ending and it's more filling to pick a side. Ethier side, this game it enjoyable in the idea that you truely set the story by your heart in battle and in some moments. It is worth buying and playing, just to see what this game has to offer, from the world and the people in it, to how you can shape it by your power. Simply enjoy this small game that has done so much right and more. If you are a fan of 'off the beaten path' RPGs with weird fighting gameplay and a goofy world filled with colorful monsters and a story you can be a part of, it is a must buy. If not, there's videos of people showing it off, fan art that grows bigger by the day, or try to ignore it, but I have a feeling people will be talking about this game for a while. In short, this game is almost the most perfect RPG. If you don't like RPGs, there's plenty more games to be played and loved, but I, and many others, will love this gem.

You've most probebly heard already about this game, alot. Most of it is probebly how good it is and how it messes with everyones head. Well, I'll try and tell you more about this game and let me say, the hype is justified on a large scale.  To start of, the game and it's character act differently depending on how you play the game, e.g violently or not. They will also notice if you've restartred the game as if they've already seen you. Is this new? No, no it's not but that does not mean that Toby Fox did a fine job in creating strong connections towards the games characters through this method.  The game works as a standard JRPG with an action sequens thrown into the battle. This is something I've pretty much never seen anywhere else. As said before, each battle offers you different ways to approach them.  Humor is a big part of the game and it's very dialouge heavy. This is what might turn some people away from this game. A large portion of the games humor surrounds youth and nerd cultures like anime, games, internet memes etc. Wich means that alot of the jokes can go over some heads.  Lastly, the design is amazing. The soundtrack is in perfect sync with the battle and helpes create an atmosphere.  As a summary, if you like RPG, internet humor (or just humor generally but internet humor is the biggest theme) and alot of dialouge with characters then this should already be in your library.  9/10

I've played about 10 hours or so on this game, went for a pacifist run. I'll just summerize the pros and cons.  Pros: Characters are amazing. The soundtrack is bootiful (buy that too, don't just listen to it in game) The ability to spare monsters is a unique mechanic in on itself, it's kind of like a puzzle in rpg format  Cons: Honestly, this is just me being nitpicky, but the bullet hell. I'm not saying it's all bad, I'm just not built for bullethell, but it spikes up in the final battle. I'm not saying it has to be nerfed just for my case, for there are those out there that love bullethells and want a challenge. I'm just not built for it. An absolutely stellar game. The writing is flawless and constantly entertaining, the gameplay is engrossing and full of surprises, and there's not a single character I disliked! It's one of those games with writing so good, you'll even be checking item descriptions and examining things multiple times just to hear what the game has to say.  You've probably heard that the game lets you choose your own path. If you play passively, Undertale has one of the most emotional, heartwarming, and memorable stories I've ever had the pleasure of experiencing.  However... If you choose to take the violent route, Undertale becomes one of very, very few games that lets you be a completely unsympathetic and unbridled villain. You're a murderer, and the game doesn't let you forget it. The story changes from being about a child trying to escape the world they've fallen into, to the residents of that world trying to stop you from murdering everyone they love. Your actions will make you feel terrible. Character deaths have weight behind them, and your actions will be remembered, and the outcome will be grim.  Some people see this as a flaw, the game treating you like the bad guy and scolding you for your actions. But, I believe that it's a very interesting take on things. You ARE the bad guy. And you're TERRIBLE. You're killing everybody, for no reason! Games are very rarely willing to put the player in that sort of position. Undertale does, and it does it with flying colors.  Give this game a shot. Go in with an open mind and I don't think you'll be disappointed.

This is one of the greatest games I have ever played. It is my favorite RPG of all time, though I personally don't consider it as a traditional RPG. This game is nearly flawless in every way, and I hope it attains the legacy of other phenominal indie games, such as Cave Story and Hotline Miami. It certainly deserves it.  As a lazy game designer, I've often pondered the idea how a game could merge good gameplay and story together without one overtaking the other. Some games have too much story, and end up having too many cutscenes or too much dialog. Some games focus on gameplay and don't have a story. Sometimes the game feels like you're just watching a movie that makes you do stuff here and there. It's a tricky balance to create, and isn't something one can just jump into.  Undertale nails this. It balances this concept of a flawless merge of story and gameplay near perfectly. The dialog is generally short, sweet, gets to the point, but at the same time it doesn't feel like it's lacking at all. The story is unique, engaging, and always makes you want to keep going, see what happens next, find out more about the curious world. The world and characters are deep, well designed, and quirky. The music is catchy, fun, and always conveys the mood perfectly. I don't know how such a small dev team put this much love into this game.  A lot of people say this game is a lot like Earthbound. I personally think this game is far better than Earthbound. Earthbound's combat system was dull, there really wasn't much input you as a player had, and  boy  did you have to grind (which involved a lot of dying, especially for new RPG players) Undertale's combat system is unique, not only in that it heavily influences the story, but it engages the players in a way that will never feel like you're just grinding away. It's easy to understand and throws new concepts in constantly. You can either go for the regular HIT AND KILL route that most RPGs go with, or you can go with the unique SPARE mechanic, in which you convince your foe to buzz off. Conving your foe to do so plays quite a bit like a text based Punch-Out, in a way. You have to experiment and figure out the correct order to calm your foes in order to proceed. It's way more interesting than just wacking everything over the head. Defending will be relevant no matter what, and wow it's fun. Each monster has a neato pattern for you to dodge, and the game never lets that concept grow dry. Every single new monster has a totally unique pattern, and some even throw in entirely new mechanics. It's so much fun, and it never grows old.  I beat Undertale, but the best part is, there's still a TON of stuff I've never even seen, though I don't feel like my inital playthrough was lacking in the slightest. There's multiple routes to reveal the entire story, see everything from a different angle, learn 'What would happen if I had done this instead of this?', it's honestly brilliant. Yes, visual novels have done this too, but never this interesting.   I only have one gripe with this game, and it's very minor; The humor. Not as a whole, honestly I was laughing my rear off at some parts of this game, but just certain jokes will likely fly past some people. For example,   the Tsunderplane joke will likely go over anyone's head if they've never heard of a Tsundere  . Other than a few jokes that only certain kinds of nerds will get, this game is still hilarious. I just thought some jokes won't appeal to some people, and may not even be relevant in the future. Which would be a shame, because this game deserves a LONG legacy.  I love this game. I  really, REALLY  love this game. This game is a wonderful experience that nearly anyone can enjoy, regardless of their skill level or experience with RPGs. It's like a video game version of Disney Land, and much cheaper. Toby Fox, thank you so much. What are you doing this Sunday? Can I take you to dinner? I'll foot the bill. Would you like me to be your personal foot stool? Can I buy you multiple dogs?   I'm gonna be playing this game for a  very  long time.

do you want skeletons? do you want robots who make you hot and bothered? Do you want emotional trauma, and a hatred for flowers for the rest of the year? buy this game 10/10 (seriously though. good ♥♥♥♥)

Don't let the trailer and screenshots fool you. This game runs deeper than just a novelty NES RPG.  Undertale is a marmite game. You'll either adore it, or you'll get little from it. This depends heavily on if you are the type of person who can set aside the random-encounter gameplay and breathe in the characters and the setting. This game's heart and soul is the journey, ambience, humour and unexpected twists, and not in just raw stimulation. Y'know, like classic RPGs tend to be. There is as much melodrama as there is sneaky subtleties, and even when you think you see something coming from a mile away it can still slip past your (emotional) guard. At least, it did with me. Several times.  It is far more than the sum of it's parts, and should come with a surgeon general's health warning warning : If you're a big softy, this game will stab you right in the feels gland if you let it, and the soundtrack will continue to murder your emotions double-dead long after you get the true ending if you dare to revisit the catchy, upbeat yet haunting melodies. The less preconceptions, spoilers and hype you have before going in the better. If in doubt, resist the temptation to look at lets plays for info and just try the demo on the dev's page. If you like the few demo characters and appreciate the playful but lonely feel of the game, then you're good to go. Even then, the demo zone is quite sparse compared to the main game.  What someone might judge to be a shallow, childish and hamfistedly false-retro game, it quickly reveals a deeper and more charming experience than your average nostalgia-goggles throwback. You get a side-order of surprising grimness and disturbitude here and there too. What you would be forgiven for thinking is static gimmick of a combat system actually springs into a number of mounting surprises throughout the game. Though the game does maintain it's whimsical, cartoonish theme, it manages some great shifts of tone. I'm hard to make laugh, but this game got regular and genuine chuckles out of me from start to finish, not to mention a number of times I started to seriously choke up. And dear god, the endings. A little confusing at first, but dear god the endings. It's not normal to feel 'withdrawal' from a videogame is it? I'm still stuck somewhere between afterglow and aftershock and it has been 48 hours since I finished the neutral-good and true endings. Even the evil ending is more than just a token nod to your actions, altering the narrative to fit your choice with surprising graveness.  ****The Good : **** -- The music couldn't possibly fit better. -- Even the nasty characters can be lovable little sh*ts. -- Humour that can sneak up on you when it wants to. -- It can also gutpunch and disturb you as much as warm your heart. -- You can eat bisicles and fried tennisballs. -- So much dog.  **** The Cautionary : **** -- If you can't attach to whimsical and playful themes, you may struggle to get into it. -- Some humour is deliberately unsubtle, and runs from sarcastic deadpan japes to deliberate dad jokes and on to slapstick and nerd culture references, your mileage may vary. -- The demo can paint the game a little too sparse, but is an overall good measure. -- This game will mess with your feelings, if you're a softy, you will likely hurt as much as you laugh. -- Easy difficulty, except for a few bosses in the 'bad' story route, but this does however leave the meat of the game unhindered by frustration. The bosses are cleverly designed so that a single fumble won't ruin your whole attempt. -- You're likely going to crave buying the soundtrack when you finish. <3 -- The emotional reactions generate tons of hype, be careful that your expectations are not set so sky-high that you end up disappointed as a result. --   Consider doing the 'true pacifist' route first. It saves time and adds perspective to 'other' routes.      **** The Bad : **** -- Consider the theme of the game, it is comedy AND mutedly dark in a whimsical retro package. If you only appreciate fully-fledged and elaborate 'adult' writing then this may not be your flavour. -- The endings can be a little confusing if you breeze through them. Some things are implied or understated, and can be lost in the absolute wrecking ball of certain powerful events. If you don't pay attention to certain small details, you might miss something! -- The best (most involved) routes require you to devote to aggressively pursuing combat or to use only pacifism, so you must decide early and not deviate to save a full-length second playthrough for the best / worst endings, though the shades of neutral ending work in their own right. -- The evil 'no mercy' combat route has brutal difficulty spikes that may be too much for some... -- Not enough dogs. -- The game ends. Seriously. Why does it have to end?

Undertale is the best RPG of 2015, maybe of all time. Maybe the best game of 2015. Possibly even the best game of all time. It's that good.  I wasn't sure I would like this game... it seemed like a homage to JRPGs, which I really dislike. So I pretty much ignored everyone saying what a great game Undertale is.   Well, I shouldn't have. What really makes the game shine are the amazing, tender characters, great music, extremely clever writing and gameplay mechanics that play with you while you play with the game.  There's nothing else really like it, it's just stunning how something so original can be so free of bugs and gameplay flaws.   The battle mechanics are so much better than any of the old JRPGs, though I hear they aren't totally unique. I haven't played any of the games that are said to have similar mechanics (paper mario? IDK).  The only things I don't like about Undertale is it's somewhat short (~6 hours) and some important plot information is too hidden. You need at least two playthroughs, careful searching and listening to npcs, as well making certain choices in order to find out what's really gone on in the past and going on now. It's good that the game doesn't spoonfeed you everything but I feel like some stronger hints could be dropped about a few important optional plot exposition points that I won't spoil.  I also only bought it after I saw some lets plays and streams, which was good because it convinvinced me to buy the game, but also bad because I feel like this game would be somehow better if I went into it completely unknowning. I do recommend going in completely 'blind' and not reading any guides, lets plays or wikis, try to be as unspoiled as possible. But even if you've had certain things spoiled, like I did, this is still something you should buy immediately and play.

Absolutely. Amazing. Everything about this game. You wouldn't expect a game with simple graphics about monsters and talking flowers to be realistic, but in certain ways, it is. Everything you do, every person you kill or spare, has a profound effect, not just on one playthrough, but on all the rest afterwards. This game plays with your emotions in the most amazing way. It will make you feel bad about killing and even about RESETTING. It is incredibly well done, and well worth the $10 (or less on sale) you have to pay to get it.  And the music- if you listen to it outside the game, it sounds like video game music. Well done, but not earth-shattering. The great thing about the music isn't how it sounds outside, but how it flows with the game itself. Each soundtrack is perfectly tailored to the character and scene. And I'm not even going to TALK about the easter eggs. (So... Many... In the music... In the game...).  At first, I was hesitant to get it, but I'm glad I did. Just looking at the game, it looks cutesy, but not that interesting. However, after playing for a few minutes, I was hooked. Each playthrough only lasts about 9 hours or so, but there are so many ways to end it (Pacifist, True Pacifist, Genocide, all of the Neutral pathways, and those are just the single-playthrough ends).  I have no idea how Toby Fox fit this much awesome into such a small file, but he did. This game is also incredibly intelligent. Now, that may sound strange, but what I mean by that is that it knows. If you kill a certain character, feel bad and exit to a previous save file and spare them, one of that characters KNOWS. And this same character can mess with your save files. And exit the game without your permission. And view previous playthroughs. Creepy as heck, am I right? All of the characters, even the random encounter monsters, have so much character. They're all adorable, and sad, and amazing. Alright, I'm done rambling. Sorry this took so long. If you took the time to read this review, then thanks, and if this game isn't worth 10 measly dollars, I don't know what is. <3

It's cute, occasionally very challenging, sometimes dark, more often whimsical, and the lore is much deeper (and more shocking) than any of the trailers could show. It provided some of the most insane and memorable moments I've experienced in RPGs in my entire life. It's really easy to dismiss it as just another retro styled indie game with pixel art and chiptunes shamelessly tugging at the nostalgia strings but in this one particular case, it ends up being so much more than that.  It's hard to explain just how amazing this game is without spoiling some of the biggest surprises it offers. All I can do is say, play this game, right now, and go in blind.

When I finished playing this game, a part of me thought that I would never play something like Undertale again. The other part of me is desperately hoping that's wrong, because I haven't felt so much joy from having played a video game since I was a goofy kid who loved jrpgs way too much,   Every part of Undertale is crafted such that you know that the whole heart of the person that made it was invested in it. It revels in the strange and funny personalities of each and every character you encounter, and it relishes from rocking back and forth between moments of touching sincerity, a uniquely silly brand of humor, and a surprising amount of gravitas.  If lovable characters, heartstring tugging stories, and a plot with the ability to masterfully shift tones in unexpected ways sound up your alley, I think you have every reason to give Undertale a shot.

10/10 Best slowly-walking-down-a-long-hallway simulator ever made   Disclaimer: I have played this game 4.995 times over now, I have many more hours than it says here.     I originally pirated this game as I expected it to be just eh. (it was in it's earlier days and I only had the impressions from the floods of undertale crap all over my tumblr feed. I came into this game expecting to be unimpressed and for the game to be sub-par.   I was sorely sorely mistaken.   This game is so good that I actually paid money AFTER pirating it (and admittedly sending to all of my friends) because I believe that this game is that worth it, and I wanted to write this review.    Now for the review. I don't know how to express it enough to explain how truly outstanding I think this game is, but I will try. I am thankful to whatever diety is out there for allowing me to spend my time on this game in particular. The story is absolutely perfect, it plays with your emotions like a thermostat, and it makes you feel like you actually have emotions to begin with. This is to the extent that I stopped .5 percent away from the end of the game just because I want to roam around and live in this world. The characters are easily loveable or hateable depending on your preference. The visuals are quaint, and perfectly match the type of game it is. Speaking of perfectly matching, THE MUSIC! (get ready for some extra length here, Skip to the break if you want to skip the music section) I have never heard music that better fits any select situation in ANY peice of media EVER. From the most obvious things of a fabulous robot's battle theme being a fast pased fasion-show-style song with an electro drum backing and some techno style sections, to the most deeply buried things such as the re-entrance of a dj character being fortold by a remix of his own battle theme. The music itself is also just well made, and being a little more than an ameteur producer myself, I applaud Toby Fox for such music that can both be dauntingly well fitting, and just great all toghether. I would pay for music like this, and I wish there was more music like this out there.   Break. Now on to the gameplay. It is actually NOT THE BEST out there, though it's pretty fun seeing what the next boss battle brings to the plate in terms of in battle visuals. The gameplay is just par to be honest. No real challenges to face while exploring, or interesting items to use that you can exploit to get to locations you arent supposed to get to. It's more of a taletale game with more exploration, and a bit of action sprinkled in. That's how I saw this game.  This game does offer a lot in the sense of control. You are given a lot of control over what you do. Each choice you make sometimes matters a lot, which is more that can be said of most telltale games and are most of the time irreversable. This adds even more to the realm of character development, as you see yourself as more of the character, and less of just a spectator.    TLDR; if you enjoy: great story, great character development, amazing music, smiling, crying, smiling and crying at the same time, being an obsessivly good person, or a murderous psycopath, moral dilemmas, long hallways, (spoilers [kinda]) endings that twist so much and so often that you arent sure what direction you were coming from to begin with (end spolers), addictions, goat moms, goat dads, goat brothers, dogs, skeletons, NOT flowers, cinnimon, butterscotch, snails, Having a bad time, and just a great game altogether...  GET THIS GAME!
Honestly, everyone should play this game
Why should you play this game? Well. It is pretty freaking amazing.

(example kill flowey in pacifist ending = no flowey)  Con's :There's alot of open boring hallways that have no point. :Alot of grinding involved in genocide run. :The fact that you cant rename your charecter exept through genocide run so you cant see all the naming easter eggs and do hard mode unless you beat the 2 hardest bosses in the game. :Somthing the game developers cant stop put is still worth pointing out the fact that the fans ruined undertale you cant look up any undertale charecters without getting porn or somthing equally wierder I was looking up toriel for images type in toriel i and it auto-completes it to toriel inflation  Overall if I was rating the game for gamplay and fights,etc I wouldnt recomend this but the story,charectors and the rest of the game overall makes this game a great eccperience nontheless.

I don't think I can say much more than other reviews already have but I really *really* want to add my one cent.  If you're looking for a RPG, a unique experience, or just some amusing and/or interesting characters. Then you should really give Undertale a try. The gameplay is a bit simple at first, but throws some neat curve balls here and there while still remaining enjoyable, the soundtrack is nicely done and adds very well to the overall experience, I don't want to go into characters too much for fear of spoilers and the like, but it's safe to say that they're probably the most memorable set in a game I've played in the last few years. Story wise it's both heartwarming and gut punching at times, and well... it's seriously one of few games that's made me question the choices I've made during the time I've played it, so much so that it's even made me reconsider some of the actions I've taken in other games, and I can say without a doubt that the time spent playing this was more than worth it.  If that lump of words is too intimidating and/or poorly thought out: It's a pretty cool RPG with neat characters, a cool soundtrack, interesting mechanics, and your actions have meaningful impacts on the game, it's even got SECRETS and REPLAY VALUE.  Numbers? 'Reviews' still need numbers don't they!?: Hell yeah I got a number. 10 out of every 10 EVER then cranked up to an 11. An eleven with a sweet skeleton giving you a thumbs up.  Okay I'm done now, thanks for reading and hope you give the game a try!

Don't like RPG's? This is the game for you. Don't like puns? This is the game for you. Don't like humor or amazing characters, you soulless monster? This is the game for you. (P.S. Get dunked on.) Don't like anything that happens to give other, normal people pleasure? I don't care; just play it.  Seriously, though. This game is a masterpiece. I first learned about only a week ago and fell in love with it the moment I saw it. It has amazing music that has me jamming out in the middle of a hard boss fight (MEGALOVANIA), lovable characters that make you smile, and brilliant dialogue that can be witty, heartfelt, and just downright hilarious.  The best part, though, is this. You know all that stuff that I just mentioned? Yeah, you have the power to destroy it all if you so choose. You can ravage the world, kill every character, and even lose that amazing, jamming music when it is replaced by that dark ambience thet gets ME scared. You can be an absolute ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to everyone or befriend everything and have some good fun. But the moment that you start to kill everything.....well...  Let's just say you're gonna be in for a BAD TIME.  Unless you enjoy being a soulless monster and a murderer, chances are, you're gonna be kind to everyone. Which is good.  On the off chance that you ARE a murderer, you are in for a treat. While the regular game (Pacifist Run) has a serene and lighthearted atmosphere filled with laughs and nice friends, the Genocide Run is not so happy. The atmosphere change is huge, and it is definitely somethng that you'll notice. In the Pacifist Run, the boss fights are hard but doable, and you get many different ones that usually will only take you one go. In the Genocide Run? Well... You're not so lucky. You get two boss fights. The catch? Holy jhsauighdsgfdsvjxchgvyxcfyds, they're THE HARDEST BOSS FIGHTS EVER. It took me hours to defeat the first one, and I still am having a VERY BAD TIME with the other!   My only hint for you future players is: Look for the patterns on the boss fight (of the Genocide Run) and memorize when they use what attack. Know when to heal and when to attack, and hopefully things will be a bit easier.  Anyway, if you want a game where your choices matter, this is also a very good game for you.  Every (and I mean EVERY) choice matters. Each one has some sort of importance, and the game remembers all of your choices, sometimes even in differing playthroughs. Let's say you play Genocide and then Pacifist. That Pacifist Run will be tainted from the leftovers of your killing spree, even though you already restarted the game and played with a blank slate.  Although this may seem like a bad thing, it hugely opens up the amount of possibilities of endings that the game has, so have a lot of fun trying to find them all (along with all of the secrets of the game).  Overall,   1,000,000 butterscotch pies / 10

It is always astounding when a crowd funded game that promises more than what is status quo actually delivers. With Undertale, you are confronted with a very reflective choice on whether or not you wish to play the game as standard RPG fare or...if you are DETERMINED, you don't have to harm a soul.  Graphically, the game can be quite...lacking, but for all intents and purposes, the graphics barely hold any weight when in comparison to the writing that shines brightly amongst all else.  The story, again, is our bread and butter. A meta-beyond-meta is approached when expecting to try for all dialogue and story branch options, and characters feel like they have more importance than a typical jRPG. Whether they can be combated or not does not take away from the fact that the simple interactions you have with them shape what your journey may become.  Controls are simple, as they should be. No unnecessary gimmicks to try and differentiate from other indie RPGs (except for the bullet hell dodging, which isn't overly obnoxious.), all while keeping a player engaged in the spikes of difficulty, whether in combat or understanding the puzzles that are the different branching stories. Full directional movement, three interaction keys, and menus galore. Its really all you need.  My god, can we talk about the sound design though? While throughout the game you may see a blend of genre and musical mediums, there is a theme that lasts throughout many of the songs along the soundtrack. It creates a very fulfilling atmosphere in any situation, and honestly, it bears more weight than just some simple retro blips and beeps you may come to assume about a game such as this. Composition is fantastic, and I feel like there is a balance of melody that can't be compared when listening to AAA symphonic orchestral soundtracks.  In closing, there may be some stigma to what this game was built upon (Kickstarter, a Homestuck composer, the supposed furry fandom of the game's characters, etc.), but don't let those detract from the actual meat of the product. The character interactions, the silly dialogue, determination, and a compulsion to see what is beyond a typical jRPG playstyle of just save scumming and going on murderous rampages. At 6+ hours of initial gameplay, for the price that it is, I believe the game is totally worth just the first playthrough alone. This is a simple RPG with a lot to observe, and plenty of smart design choices which freshen up a muddled genre. Comparisons to Mother 3/Earthbound be damned, this is a game that can truly stand on its own.

Pros:  While the story is painfully simple, it emphasizes player agency.   The 'Undertale' collective (i.e. the game, the official soundtrack, the free demo, the trailer, and even certain game files) are all distinct parts, each worth checking out on their own.   The game has an interesting NG+ mechanic that involves your choices in one playthrough being relevant to all future runs.  The Shoot-Em-Up based battle mechanic is interesting and used to its full potential.  The soundtrack, as well as the visuals designed by Toby Fox himself, are very stylized and pleasant. I know, the screenshots on this Steam page are very ugly, just rest assured that it looks much better in motion.  $10 is the default price for Undertale, and also is the exact amount that the game's worth to me. It's nice to see some modesty from an indie developer.     Cons:  The morality system is remarkably ham fisted. Enemies regularly try to kill you, unprovoked, throughout the entire game, but the game talks down to you if you choose to defend yourself. One possible route in particular is very presumptuous about your motivations for taking said path.  The narrative is a plain jane hero's journey from beginning to end.   The aforementioned narrative is also the main focus of the game, and nearly all of its merit is in its shock value. If you've played this game once (or, rather, once per possible ending), there's no reason to come back.   The game is horribly easy, except for two unique bosses, one of which reduces to rote learning.  Magnolia Porter shouldn't be allowed to draw anything, let alone contribute character designs for this game.  Undertale was clearly crafted to be memetic/'quotable' and pander to furries and tumblr users who use the word 'fandom' to describe themselves and talk about the creator of something they like using his/her first name like they're real-life buddies. (To be fair, Toby Fox made a name for himself by creating music for Homestuck. He couldn't have gotten that demographic off his ♥♥♥♥ if he wanted to.) Five Nights at Freddies did this too.  7/10, go ahead and play it. As much as its fanatics would make it seem like a boring, shallow flavor-of-the-month release, it has real merit.

Oh boy do I have stuff to say about this game.  First off, the beginning fits the game extremely well, and the humor carries through the entire game! (I would be going in depth in the story but this is steam, and I don't think that helps anybody.) The characters are lovable and humorous, the atmosphere really feels like the Mother series. (I know Toby Fox is a member of  Starmen.net) . The music is superb, one of the best games of 2015, if not, GOTY 2015.  I would recommend this to ANYBODY who loves the mother/earthbound series and that likes superb and hilarious story.

It's been a long time since a game made me experience actual emotion. Like, connection with characters, understanding their flaws and their dreams. Undertale is a unique experience. One that I, personally, feel is best done on one's own, with as little knowledge going in as possible. The game is a unique JRPG-styled game where your hits are timed and you have full ability to dodge any enemy attack if you learn their patterns. It's simplistic, but it's very involved. And it feels excellent. The story is absolutely stellar. I won't go into detail, but I suggest doing a total pacifist run either your first or second time through. I feel it's the most satisfying. The music definitely shines too. I recommend the soundtrack if you don't mind putting out a little extra for this game. It's totally worth it.  All-in-all, it's my GotY of 2015. Not flawless, but certainly a game that I felt was a unique and worthwhile experience.

Almost a year ago I had heard a couple friends talking about this game and decided to try it out. At first, I didn't believe this 2-D game with pixely graphics had much to offer. However, Once completeing my first true pacifist run, I was hooked. The plot is engaging, the soundrack is catchy and you get easily attached to the charaters. The battle sequence is very unique compared to other games because it lets you choose whether to fight or spare. There are so many different endings and secret easter eggs to find that keeps players engaged (As of writing this review I have 217 hours and even I haven't found everything yet) . I've done atleast 50 runthroughs and completed almost every ending (even the genocide run... 4 times) and can say that I absolutely love this game. The fan base can be pretty overwhelming and the humor is really cheesy, but the game itself is a definite treasure. I absolutely recommend this game to everyone and anyone. From butterscotch pies to skeleton brothers to talking flowers to tea time and weird dogs, there really is something in it for everyone. And even if you finish the game and decide it just wasn't for you, atleast you will come out knowing some clever puns and a bit of dating skills, right? I say give this game a try, it is so worth it.

It's a little late for me to make a review for Undertale, but after completing the game for the fourth time, and racking up my play time to over 30 hours (w/o leaving the game on overnight), I felt that I could be a guide for anyone considering this game to buy.  Let me point out many peoples' gripes I see. I hear a lot that people think the game is too short. This in part is true (each run took me about 3-4 hours), but if you decide to do each ending then the game will take a while to 'complete'. Honestly, the biggest issue I have with this game isn't even the game's fault. The game has so much more of a rich experience if you know NOTHING about it. Going through the whole story clueless about what's going to happen, or what the ending is going to be made this game a hunderd times better.  Now that we have some of the problems out of the way, let's talk about what makes this game so amazing. The price is amazing. If I could get a game for $10 (not on sale) that let me go through an amazing adventure spending over 30 hours, I would do it again every single time. A lot of the tags for the game really show what makes it so great. The game has a magnifient soundtrack, and the reason I haven't bought the soundtrack on Steam for $10 is because it is useless when you can just play any song on YouTube for free. I am not going to potentially spoil the game for anyone, but the game's story is so rich. You feel so attached with the characters, and the world feels really big when it is in fact quite small. The tags say 'choices matter' (again, I'm not going to spoil the story) which the big overarching theme to this game, where the choices you make have an enormous effect on what happens. The game's art at first seems really strange, but as you play through the game more you realize how the art and the music form an amazing atmosphere and mood wherever you go. One thing that is not really a spoiler is telling you how great, and innovative the battle sequences really are. Being given the option to either kill or befreind an enemy with the action segments thrown in makes a huge aspect of the game really unique. There are so many more great things about this game, but I think that just reasons alone would give anyone a good incentive to buy this game.  I can't give a game a ten, ever. I feel that a game is never really perfect, and that I can always pick out some flaws. This game has to get the same treatment though. It does have its cons, but the pros almost completely overshadow those cons. I would have to give the game a 9/10 for the amazing experience it has given me, and not a ten for the sole reason that I wanted it to go on forever!

This game blew my mind so unbelievably, inconcievably hard that I was almost unsure what to do when it ended. I even stared at the ending screen waiting for something new to happen. Otherwise, you're playing the game wrong... however, I have yet to do the exact opposite. Maybe I won't even do it... but what I do know is that I'm satisfied with what I got.

Having had the privilege of playing a game of such beauty and heart as Undertale fills me with determination.  For professional reasons I tend to get (way too easily) butthurt over some people calling certain games 'art' just because they have an uncommon or edgy graphical style. More often than not these 'art games' are all frosting and no real substance. When misused, the word 'art' can quickly start to lose integral parts of its various meanings and even turn on itself.  So, when I say that Undertale is art in the best connotations of the word, I really do mean it - I do not toss this compliment around lightly.

Undertale is nothing short of charming. It's fresh, it's different, it's got hilarious writing. The combat system is unlike any other I've ever seen, completely out of left field for an RPG. But it works, and it works great. It's a cross between timing your attacks and a bullet-hell dodging minigame (mostly the bullet-hell), and it REALLY shines on the boss fights. Boy does it get creative with those.  I cannot and will not spoil the story of this game. It's truly something amazing and it has to be experienced for yourself. Don't look up any spoilers at all, you WILL regret it.   My total clock-in time was about 6 hours but I'm planning a second playthrough to get a different ending. Oh yeah, and this game has multiple endings OOPS SPOILERS.  Conclusion: Definitely worth your time and your money. And the soundtrack is BANGING IT'S SO GOOD. The Hotlands music is THE BEST EVER HNNNGGGH.  Edit: If you don't get the True Ending, go back and play it again and get it. It completely changed my perspective. Undertale is just plain beautiful.

I'm trying, awfully hard, to find a reason to dislike this game. Me writing this is a sign of utter defeat to the former.  Undertale is incredible. Period.  As a fairly basic RPG game, you quickly realize the story isn't quite what it seems, as one of this games unique mechanics is the power of choice. You CAN kill everyone you initiate combat with, act like a complete homicidal jerk to everyoe, or perhaps find ways to solve the problems of enemies you encounter, and resolve literally every encounter peacefully. I've found myself giggling or bursting right out laughing at many of the choices this encompasses, with some brilliant dialogue writing making every choice feel unique.   Enemy variety is limited, but doesn't fail to feel unique at every new encounter, and all with interesting combinations making combat a bit more interesting. Leading to my next point, combat is unlike anything I've seen before in a game, where your 'soul' literally becomes part of a brief bullet hell depending on how you manage your combat. This itself is fairly difficult at times to control, but is still incredibly fresh and new compared to selecting a simple combo or attack in any other RPG game.   The art style feels gentle on the eyes, but takes amazing strides later on in the game, getting very abstract and unique in the different worlds and levels.   As a sucker for chiptune/8 bit music, this game is giving me heart palpitations with how good the music is! I swear it's some of the best music in a game I've heard south of Shovel Knight or Castle Crashers.   All in all, I feel I can't say much else without getting into spoiler territory, because all I want to do is sing the praises I have for this game! At 10.99 CAD, I'm amazed the developer isn't asking more for this, as it's easily worth double the appraised value. If you can't afford it now, make it a plan to play this at some point. You won't regret it.  Addendum.  I just finished the game. I have no words to how incredible the ending was. When a game can change from making you giggle like an imbecile at some gags, to cry like a river in some moments, it has to have some emotional substance to it.   10/10  Sadly, our current understanding of the laws of mathematics prevent me from hiking my score higher. Alas, it's literally a perfect game

Eh, it's a descent game, but pretty flawed. It can get really tedious and the game harshly punishes you for killing and goes so far as to insult the player, which is pretty stupid considering it's only a video game. Video games are a place where we should be able to do what we want without consequence, an escape from reality, dealing with this 'murdering is wrong' bull$hit is a pain in the @ss. It takes itself way too seriously, and the message comes off as hammered in because of it. Not to mention, the combat is kind of lacking. You can only use one attack for each weapon, and it gets kinda boring. The actual game world is OK to look at but the color pallete for this game was pretty dull due to the excessive use of black backgrounds and colorless sprites. Not to mention there aren't many places to explore in the world. Even worse, no sidequests, and the NPC's aren't that interesting except the main characters. The music and battle system is fantastic, but even then, I can't really see myself reccommening this game because due to all it's hype your expectations will be really high, and with the game's flaws you'll likely end up dissapointed if you're like me. At the end of day though, I still recommend this game because for it's cheap price it's worth a shot, so buy it if you have time to kill, just don't expect anything special. It's weak in terms of RPG standards. I give it a 6/10.  If you want a far more in depth review, take a look on my YouTube channel. The link to it is on my profile. On my channel I have an Undertale review, which I highly recommend you watch as it contains a lot more detail as to why I don't really like this game all that much.

Please get this game if you want to feel the rawest of true emotions :)

Here I was one late night browsing streams while really tired and I came across a stream of Undertale. I was watching a short portion of the game and hearing the game soundtrack and seeing the combat system which was very unique. It had me intrigued so the following morning I went on and did some research into Undertale and it looked like just one of those gems that hasn't made it out fully yet to the mainstream. I had some money in my wallet and I tried resisting the urge to by it to save my money. Sadly though I am a sucker for these kinds of rpgs with a real deep story so I threw the ten bucks. And holy ♥♥♥♥ I was blown away.  My first blind playthrough took a while but, it was an incredible one (Played it pacifist all the way through). The characters were thoughtfully made and filled with personality. Combat was very great and different if you went with the mercy route. And the story was deep and amazing. Hadn't had a game that gave me so much feels in a while. Play it while you can while there aren't really many spoilers out. It's a hell of a lot better experience trying to figure things out for yourself and being surprised. Play the game as you like though, kill or spare it's your choice.   tl;dr Great game, gave plenty of feels, amazing story, unique, and good soundtrack

I received this game as a Christmas gift from a dear friend. I would never have bought it even though I wish-listed it, because I had other 'good-looking' games that I had eyes on.  Now I'm writing this because Undertale proves to be much more enjoyable!  Let me break this up into 5 simple, positive points! :) 1) Characters, despite their 'simple' designs, can show many emotions. 2) Comprises a good mix of emotions to tingle your body and soul (Fear, joy, anger, happiness..) 3) There's many 'rofl' and 'wth' moments xD It's filled with surprises! 4) I have a weak spot for silly games and this is it :) 5) The 'don't kill' feature this game has is super cool. Imagine fighting a monster that constantly attacks you, but you don't fight back! Instead you talk your way out of it. It's really one-of-a-kind.  For negative points: Error 404 Not Found

I always write reviews about the games I truly love and the ones I truly hate. Undertale was the only game so far that I WANTED to write a review but simply couldn't. I didn't knew where to start. I have so much to say, I have so many items to point out, there are so many spoilers I could make for the sake of expressing the many feelings I have for this game! There are so many good points and so much writing to do that I simply couldn't pull the energies to do it for fearing not making the game any justice. So I'll make just a tiny and generic portion of everything I have to spill out:  This game touches your feelings. It gives you options all game long and you will pay the price of your choices in the future. You can be the nicest guy ever or the biggest d*ck in the entire universe. This game has ways of reaching for the very depths of your mind and emotions and yank everything out to scrub against your face with a big 'That's who you are, happy?'.  My reccomendation is that if you have kids at home, let them play the game and do whatever they want. And if they take a mean route, make them play again and this time be by their side to guide them through the 'pacifist' route. This will surely teach them to be kind to people and that it pays to make the extra effort to be a better person. If you're an adult (and mature at mind, of course), go play the game through both 'bad' and 'good' ways and you'll see what I'm talking about.

I won't give this a bad review simply because its overhyped. No. I know many people think 'oh my gawd bad game cuz popular gahhhh dyuxjtgydh'  It's sad how I use to be one of those people.   SPOILERS BELOW OK I didn't know why it was so liked, but I actually took the time to sit down and see what this game was about. At first, I was very confused. Having tons of animals attack me, and I WASN'T suppose to attack them? Thats not the regular gaming way.  Then I killed the goat mama, and I felt bad but didnt know how to NOT kill her as apparently you have to spare her 20+ times.  Then I realized, wow. I'm playing the game all wrong. This isn't right. What am I doing. -resets game-  Once I STOPPED killing everything, game was more joyful, I got a hug from goat mama, went on a date with a skeleton.  Got chased around by a fish like I was her favorite seafood.  And I had a wonderful lapdance by a robot.   The plot of this story? Good question, I'm not entirely sure.  I think it's more so, to treat everything like a living thing. (Unless you want to be a genocidal maniac then go ahead I'm not stopping you, but Sans might)   -cough- ahem, anywho   I really enjoyed this game. How different it was. The characters, and the way everything came out one by one.   And I can't really lie and say this game didn't change me, it did.  Mettaton, you will forever be my Waifu

To be honest when i started to play Undertale i had zero expectations, and was sceptical for its hype. Friends whom played the game were like ''Zomg when you're gonna play Undertale? You MUST DO IT!!!!!!1!!!11!'' and when i replied ''Dunno if i even want to..'' oh man, that was almost cardinal crime in their eyes.   However i never judging games before playing them hence adventure started. And after beating (probably) all endings....daaaamn...i haven't been so impressed for ages.   But first things first. Let's analyze the game.  Undertale is Indie RPG (more or less) made just by one guy, which is really impressive. Story isn't linear, it changes by your playing. Decisions you made ACTUALLY MATTERS. For every action there's consequences and that's why i love it.   Battles are interesting. Basically it's bullet hell where you try to survive. But worry not, it's not so hard as it sounds...well.. there are few exceptions but after learning pattern and with dose of determination you can do it.  The characters are so well written and have strong, unique personalities. Makes you questioning moral principes not just in the game but in real life as well.  The best thing (atleast in my opinion) is soundtrack. It's perfect for every situation which you encounter.  My final verdict is 10/10! Legendary game! (Explenation: There's no thing such as 'perfect' game. However this is closest thing what i found. The story worthy of replaying it,brutally changing by your action so you feel like you're playing totally different game and i love this concept.)  So yea....i finally understand why my friends were so obsessed.   Thanks for checking the review. Stay determinated.

I LOVE THIS GAME SO MUCH BUT IT HAS SUCH A GOOD STORY IT'LL RUIN IT IF I GO INTO DETAIL IT IS WORTH YOUR MONEY PLEASE BUY RIGHT NOW!!!!!!! In all seriousness though, this is a meaningful, touching, story rich game with the best soundtrack I have ever heard. I am not a fanboy, but it is a great game. Please get it.

I don't write reviews often, but I feel like this game deserved a special mention. Honestly, I haven't had a game that was this good in years. Good is subjective so let me clarify: This game is a rollercoaster of feels. I highly recommend going in blind without having read, or seen any playthroughs or spoilers. The main selling point of this game is the story. I've never played the Last of Us, but I assume it's also the same. Mass Effect was supposed to be also story focused, having a culmination of your choices come back to reward or haunt you. Undertale does this in its own way, which is great.  Now the 'combat', if you can call it that, is somewhat lackluster. It's quite refreshing (and challenging at times) to this series, only because it's different. The boss battles are quite unique, and the music... is absolutely fantastic. This game also breaks the fourth wall in the most appropriate ways that make it great. The 'grind' isn't bad, and there's very little back tracking required. I also recommend Total Biscuit's review on Undertale in his Top 10 Games of 2015 video (around the 35 minute mark). He basically nails it right on and speaks volumes about the game.

This is to @=EGC= Decimation008 and their downvote reviw mostly, but it also is my own.  I think you articulated your review very well, but honestly my man, I think you just took this game waaaaaaaaaaay to seriously.   I do respect your opinion though! I find this game to be -extremely- smart; everything goes full circle. True, there is a big chunk of meme culture in this game, but that's how stories are. I say 'story' because I felt like I was transported from trying to play a videogame to wanting to hear more and know what's next.  I don't agree with it being surface level and only including meme humor, nor the part about it being irrelevent in a year or so (and its been just under a year, yet people are still commenting and adding to the 92/100 Metacritic, hands-down Overwhelmingly Positive review). For instance, recognizing specifics of your loads and saves immediately gave me a bit of OG Playstation nostalia, when Psycho Mantis reads and comments about your saves in Metal Gear Solid.  I could comment about most of your thoughts but my main opinion is that you examined this far too hard. Its exactly what it claims to be, and the author knows that. Look at the steam page and which reviews he posted, the destription. He has built a story and persona in one. Again, full circle and encompasing,  This is pure curiosity, truly, but may I ask when you were born? I am recently 30 and am interested if maybe this game can only speak to a certain demographic, which * ISN'T * good, but again I think the author knew he didn't want it to be and thats kinda the whole point... he made a piece of art.  *I mostly watched my roomie play this.

Really good game. Highly detailed.  In the game, there are so many little details that most game developers would not pay attention to, like.. if you exit and go back in papyrus's kitchen many times really fast during the hangout/date, he'll stop running back and forth and say 'I can't feel my legs. That must mean I'm being a good host!' The game overall has a really great message, and the more harm you cause to others, the consequences increase. See how much time I have logged into it? Every few months, if not every year, there comes along a game that absolutely annihilates the idea that triple A games are the best in the market. In fact, they prove that triple A games have nullified our ideal gaming scenario: a somewhat immersive environment where no characters are even noteworthy. Undertale is an indie game that truly mocks triple A games -- a short experience, but an extremely memorable one, and completely immersive.  There are few games, especially triple A, where there are any standout characters. In Undertale, every character, even those shown for only small sections of the game, are interesting and aren't just white husks sitting on the screen. It's why I couldn't bring myself to kill all of them in a Genocide Run. (In fact, I've only ever killed one of the lead characters, and that was only on my first run of it.)  The emotions in Undertale are legitimate. The game starts off with humor that always hits on its mark. It'll have you laughing at every encounter, and want more and more. Then, depending on your choices, it can make you hate yourself, hate a certain character (you know who I'm talking about), and/or feel generally awful for the circumstances the monsters in the game are in. If you play Undertale and finish the True Pacifist ending, you WILL be in tears. It's depiction of loneliness, compassion, and grief will make you mourn for the character in question. It's an absolute masterpiece when it comes to the emotions presented in the game.  Above all, the game is all-immersive. I can't give out exactly why, because of spoilers (and I don't want to spoil this game at all, not even with a spoiler block), but you will be part of the game. At first, you won't notice it...but slowly and surely two characters will put you into the spotlight. And its those two characters who drive all the endings of the game.  Undertale has no plot holes, it's narrative is the best in any game I've ever played in my life. The amount of motivation the game creates is outstanding, and nothing is black or white (except for the characters that is). It's a complex narrative that drives you to finish it, and depending on how you play, the ending will either be the most satisfying conclusion, or it will be a devastation loss for no purpose. It's up to you.  Overall, Undertale truly slaps triple A gaming. It's a testament to why I almost never play any anymore. It only has three distinctly different endings (albeit there can be many different endings, but there are three truly different ones), but it is able to do what no triple A game has ever done: create a narrative solely focused on player choice without sacrificing gameplay to it.  Instead of dropping $60 for Fallout 4, take $10 to Undertale. (I hear Fallout has some serious problems. Too much hype, maybe?)  Oh, and the music is good too.  If you doubt the humor of this game, check the specs required on the soundtrack.

Vary rarely do games catch my interest with such intensity, or such great emotion. Very seldomly do they capture my passion, my spirit, my  determination . Incredibly unique RPG. A game where - dare I say - your choices matter. Most of the time in a purely mechanical way, but ultimately the interactions and connections you build to the characters in the game, and how your actions affect those connections will rise above the simple GOOD CHOICE, BAD CHOICE, NEUTRAL CHOICE of so many other games that try to be what Undertale is.  And while I would claim that Undertale is mostly a game about story and how it makes you feel, underneath all of that is a very robust and incredibly enjoyable RPG system. The combat itself in the game is unique in almost every encounter whilst still maintaining the same basic principles. Each boss fight introduces new mechanics or a spin on old ones, always ensuring that it's fresh and thrilling. I didn't once find myself 'grinding' or hung up on the same boring copy paste fights over and over.  And one can't talk about Undertale without discussing the music. In a nutshell? It's ♥♥♥♥ing awesome. It manages to invoke an array of emotions, but for me the boss music for every fight just made it so much more than it was. I think the music alone for Muffet's fight is what makes it my favourite encounter in the game.  Honestly, games for me are hardly ever worth a second playthrough - I always feel like I've exhausted the capabilities of the games storytelling after however many hours I sunk into playing it the first time, but Undertale will be my first exception. It's a nostalgic, well thought out and beautifully written game by someone who honestly just wanted to write a nice, compassionate story - there is no overbearing monologue or pretentious moral message that is being shoved in your face, it's just a story about humans, monsters, and you. And temmies.

The fact that I changed my icon to one of the characters should be enough for you.           Okay but really, if you want some legitimate feedback, here's what I have to say. I'd tell you 'Don't expect anything amazing, because this was made by one single person,' but I can't even tell you that because it's an amazing game regardless of the team of one. I'm barely even into the game so far and I can tell you it's just bloody perfection.   The music is amazing (I want to buy the soundtrack but I don't have the money :<), and anybody should be proud to own it, though that's not even close to all the game has to offer. The story and characters are beautifully crafted from the very beginning, and this game has an amazing grasp on your <i>emotions</i> (*cries while shouting angrily due to the uncontrollable urge to laugh in joyfully depressive hatred towards... idk something*). When you buy this game, do note that the game is in a pixellated art style, though I wouldn't call that a downside unless you hate pixels with a burning passion. Even then, you should give the game a try, anyway.  One thing I love about this game is that it's the type of game where everything you do shapes the future of the game. There's not a single story line; in fact, from what I understand, there are two endings you reach through extremes (thorough slaughter or intense love, though I'll talk about that in a second), and a very large number of endings you reach through mixed behaviors, simply depending on how you execute your slaughter-loving plan. Now, as far as the kill/love thing goes, that's another mechanic in this game I adore - you don't have to kill anybody (except for a select few). You can either make this a Hitler simulator and kill everybody and everything you meet, or you can go 'hippie mode' and give everything hugs, kisses, compliments and more until the entire world knows you as a friend.  Anyway, I don't want to say anymore because I don't think anybody will read this if it gets too much longer. Just know that you SHOULD buy this game. Don't be on the fence about it - if you can see that fence, hop over and buy this now. Hopefully, my review has filled you with DETERMINATION.

I wish I could list the pros and cons of Undertale, but I really don't have any complains about this game. It is a unique experience and I would recommend this game to everyone. With that being said, these are the strongest point of Undertale:  -Memorable characters: I have played many games in my life, but after completing them and after some time, I will tend to forget the characters and their names. For Undertale it is completely different, I can see myself remembering the characters and their personalities for a long time since I feel emotionally attached to them.   -Replayability value: Everyone will have a different experience with this game based on his/her decisions within the game and dialogue selection. This games has so many different secrets, options and dialogues that you can replay this game countless of times and learn something new on each run.   -Music: THIS is the best part of Undertale in my opinion. The music is AMAZING!! I can place the soundtrack of Undertale along with the soundtrack of Ocarina of Time and Final Fantasy VII as my favorite soundtracks ever. And it´s not only good, but every song fits the situation and the character that tries to represent. If this game doesn't appeal you for some reason, I recommend checking out the soundtrack either way.  -Funny: I have never laugh so much at a videogame as I did with Undertale!! The humour of this game is very particular and it might not please everyone, but personally I love it.  -Lore/Story: It is a very good story, and the way it is told is very unique. I would like to give more details regarding this point but I don't want to spoil anything since Undertale should be played totally blind in my opinion to get the best experience.  I might undertand that the graphics may turn down someone, but this game makes everything else right that it doesn't matter, and in fact, it gives the game a unique touch.  TL,DR: Try this game!! Trust me!!

I am a man. A manly man. The kind of man who lives out in the wilderness of Maine and has a beard. The kind of man that will supress his emotions for all of eternity. A man who will never show a flicker of a smile, or shed a single tear. I am the kind of man who will go into extreme detail about how manly I am, using all sorts of examples to show just show you that I am a man.  I bawled my eyes out playing this. Everyone was a unique and heartfelt character. Nay, they weren't characters, they were people. They each did everything their own way, and had their own motives for doing it that way. With each new development, my heart, my soul, broke just a bit more. And, by the end of the game, my soul should have shattered to pieces.  But it refused.  After this game, I feel stronger than ever, I feel invigorated. After playing this game, I feel like I COULD go out and wrestle a bear, but after playing this game, I feel like I SHOULD just give that bear a hug instead. That, no matter how much the bear tries to maul me, I will stand there and endure it, and we will become the best of friends.

An amazing RPG that pushes being a pacifist as opposed to violence. Along with turn-based fighting you can 'Act' your enemies out of fighting with certain commands (think of it like talking to demons in Shin Megami Tensei games). The game is loaded with great music, quirky characters and obviously gives off a huge MOTHER/Earthbound vibe. Your choices matter A LOT more than you'd think for a game so simple, so I'd say it has a decent amount of replay value as well to save or destroy as you please. Easily one of the best games of 2015 I've played next to Bloodborne, 10/10.  TL;DR Version -Enjoyable, quirky characters -Replay value -Great soundtrack -Provides thought provoking and meaningful choices to the player (aka Feels ;_;) -Basically a must for MOTHER/Earthbound fans (captures the true essence of the series) -Funny & heartwarming/heartbreaking

This game speaks and touches us on many levels, and not levels as in games but levels as in ways we didn't think it could be felt at all.  Undertale is a 2015 game that despite the technology we have to put high graphics, it has that classic 16bit charm that gives us nostalgia from when we were playing earlier games back in our living rooms after school. It has a very well thought out story line that makes you feel such emotions you never thought possible and yet it succeeded in doing that with colorful characters both on appearence and personality wise that we really enjoyed without a fault. The music track is expertly made that gives us the feeling within the moment to the decisions you make and the areas you visited as well that, in turn as well, touched your emotions in a personal level where you can connect with the characters within the game as well. And more importantly, the gameplay has a mix of classic RPG and FPS in a way where it's a creative style of survival and progression within the storyline as well. Finally the Decisions you make will do a unique outcome depending on which ones you believed is right and wrong and the characters in there react differently from what you choose and how you pick them as well.  Undertale is not only a great game of the year, but it is also one of the best game that most triple-A companies should learn a lesson from the fact that great games shouldn't always have it's money burned out on graphics or on gameplay and it should be made where it makes you enjoyed it as a real game should be. This is a game I highly recommend to play as the amount of time you spent here will bring you right at home.

This is what gaming is all about. As you can see I have played 10 hours of this game. I got it yesterday, 4 hours yesterday 6 hours today. This is not like me at all, I am a busy guy. Today I did not study for my degree, I did not go for my daily jog, I didn't eat, I just about went to the toilet (eventually). This game is completely magical.   'RPG' is a term which barely means anything anymore, it is so broad that the label 'RPG' is no guarantee you will like a game if you have liked an 'RPG' before. So I will first make some comparisons to other games (though I should first say that in most aspects this is like no game I have ever played before). The two comparisons I would make are to the original Legend of Zelda game and to the Pokemon Game Boy games.   Now I will attempt to tell you what it is about this game that has got me so addicted (the only reason i've stopped now is because i'm on the final boss and i've failed about 6 times). First of all the art style is beautiful, simplistic yet effective, the world you inhabit in this game is strange and wonderful, at first it looks pretty dull and dreary, but there are many different places to explore which have character and individual charm.   Second of all, the characters, this is a contender for this best thing about this game; the characters in this game are some of the best i've encountered. There are some lovely characters, warm, friendly and inviting, with emotional backstories and dark secrets. There are some absolutely hilarious characters who make you laugh out loud with everything they say, many who seem mean spirited at first, but by the end they'll have you smiling and when they call your character their 'friend' you really feel an emotional attachment. There are a few who are malicious, filled with pools of dark desire. I won't give anything away specifically about any of these characters, but to name a few of my favourites to look out for: Toriel, Flowey, Bratty and Catty, Temmie, Sans and Papyrus, Megatton and that kid that follows you around. Some hilarious, some dark (or seemingly so), some sweet (or seemingly so), but all beautifully crafted and developed. You will truly learn to love or loathe them.   This brings me on to the next thing about this game; the humour. This game is genuinely hilarious, this game had me laughing more even than Stick of Truth. The humour is oddball and fast-paced, the dialogue will have you laughing out loud on many occasions. This, along with the character development is what drives the storyline.  The storyline itself is extremely touching, it is one which starts of dark and mysterious and continues in this vein, revealing slightly more of itself as it progresses. Your choices matter in this game and your choices will have you feeling genuine emotions. I felt deep regret and sympathy as well as genuine happiness.   The second contender for the best part of the game is the battle system. This is truly a work of art. I won't give anything away about how it works, but suffice it to say for a turn-based battle system, it is a lot more than simply making a choice and clicking your mouse. It does allow you to make choices, but once these are made the true beauty of the battle begins and you see the craftsmanship that went into this game. The battles can also be extremely funny.   There are a lot of secrets to uncover beneath the main storyline, though I have reached the final boss, I am sure I will replay the game to uncover more of this, there are many mysteries and so many characters to interact with that i'm sure a second playthrough is warranted.   This game is fast becoming one of my favourites, there is nothing negative I can think of to say. It is fiendishly difficult in places, charming, deep, emotional and hilarious.   One last thing: take note of the tagline 'The RPG where you don't have to destroy anyone' remember this, or you may be filled with deep, deep regret.

I'm usually not the type of person to play 2D indie games. However, I got so many recommendations for this game that I winded up trying it out anyway and I can whole-heartedly say that I didn't regret giving it a shot. So if you have a similar mindset, take it from me and give this game a chance anyway.  It's definitely one of the most unique games I've played. Despite it's superficial simplicity, the world is lovingly crafted and the characters feel extremely genuine and well-developed. They're all unique, with their own way of interacting with the player, and depending on your choices within the game their attitude towards you will noticeable change. The fact that you can choose whether or not you wish to fight enemies really puts you in a spot where you think twice about your decisions - and no matter which you pick, it will tug on your heartstrings.   But the most important thing - in my opinion - is that Undertale has achieved what no other game since Pokemon Red/Blue has managed: it made me feel like a kid again. That feeling is absolutely irreplacable and unforgettable.
This game is best played if you know only about the routes and not the story of the game and I also recommend downloading and doing a true Pasafist run before doing a genoside run.

Despite what critics and people said about this game, I went in with no expectations. I didn't know who worked on it nor what is it about. I looked it up at the store page and it looked like Earthbound on screenshots, but i got dissapointed with the description: 'Dating a skeleton, omg so many dogs' Yeah, I thought it was going to be one of those meme game, but I bought it anyway to see what's all the fuzz about this game.   What I got is a funny as hell, heartwarming, sad, creepy, cute, and unexpected Earthbound-esque RPG about a girl traveling through the monster world that is a lot of fun to play. It has the best soundtrack Ive heard this year, great visuals, interesting and colorful characters, cool gameplay mechanics and a story I legitimately did not see where it was going. It was full of surprises and a lot of funny/sad twists.   Game of the year for me. 10/10.

I dated everyone, including a skeleton.  Will play and date again.  10/10  But in all seriousness, the game is packed with wonderful dialogues, music, and characters. The ways to SPARE your enemies are also delightfully funny, creative, cute, and sometimes... goes where no dog has been before. This game makes you question about yourself. Not yourself as a character in the game, but yourself as a player, as someone who has infinite lives via saving, and has the power to change the game's outcome.  I do NOT recommend that you spoil any part of the story before you get to the 'True Ending' : it will take a giant chunk out of the experience. I recommend that you backtrack once you reach the 'True Ending': the dialogues change in a way that fleshes the world even more.  However, as great as the game is, it is not without flaws:  If you are bad at bullet-hell dodging (like I was for 10 hours of gameplay), then this game will feel very slow. After all, I beat the game in 12 hours opposed to the average of 6 hours other people seem to take. Also, the dialogues can sometimes get very corny and predictable, and the quirkiness of the characters might overwhelm you.  For me, the pros of the game overweighs the cons and this game has truly been a wonderful experience. This game easily ranks among my favorites now. Now I'm playing it again in front of my friends in hopes that we can share the experience.

This game is a solid 8.5/10. At first I thought the 10 dollar price tag was too much, but I realized that this game stuck with me in my mind longer than I thought it would, so I'm chaning my review to give this game a much better spotlight.

TL;DR: An okay RPG with interesting ideas and now a ton of adorable fanart.  Undertale is a pretty nice concept, knows its genre and plays with a lot of tropes. No matter what, I'd recommend you give it a try. It takes an interesting approach to old-school turn-based fights.  It's clearly aiming for a retro look and feel, and pulls it off nicely (the OST is great and available on Bandcamp if you want to try it on for size first.)  As an RPG, either you'll get into it, or you won't. I found it okay, but the widely advertised heartbreaking factor just didn't reach me. That, and the way the game is both ostencibly meta and controlling.  So if you're into retro RPGs at all, I recommend you at least attempt a full run (wait for a sale if needs be) to forge yourself a proper opinion and decide if the hype is worth it.  (At any rate, that game spawned awesome fanart!)
