(I got this game as a gift for Christmas from a friend.)  You've heard all the great things about Undertale. I'm not going to repeat them here. I just want to point out one important element. The combat mechanics - which you still have to deal with even if you go a negotiation/pacifistic route, in order to defend yourself, if not fight back - are delivered in a 'bullet hell' format.  Mind you, it's very well-done bullet hell: madly inventive, wildly creative, with awesome music, animations, and (written, not spoken) dialogue. But, if you're like me and suck at anything that involves timing and reflexes, you may not be able to defeat this game. I had to resort to a Let's Play when I finally got stuck about two/thirds of the way through.  But it's an amazing game, as many have said, so I recommend it!

I was going to write something funny here like: 'Dated skeleton and flirted with mother 10/10', but Undertale is just two damn beautiful to give that kind of treatment to.  Frankly, there's a reason why this game that came out of nowhere is blowing up all over the internet and is getting the praise it gets: it's an amazing game. Sure, it might only be 3 to 5 hours long depending on how much you talk to the NPCs, but everything this game does: from the character, to the story, to the humor, to the battle system is so quirky, so unique, and so AMAZING that I really can not think of a single thing wrong with it.   I encourage everyone who is even SLIGHTLY interested in this game to buy and play it. Don't just read about it, don't just watch a Let's Play; pick up this game and play it for yourself all the way through; see everything that this game has to offer you in all the unique ways it does so.   Undertale is one of those games that simply NEEDS to be played first hand as you work through this story on your own.  While normally I'm a 100% Steam Sale kinda guy, I have no problem spending $10 on this game. It was worth every dollar .

A game where every character has depth, and every character has meaning- of course, if you discover said meaning, is up to you.  One thing that sets this game apart from all others is the connection it makes with players, and touch even those who don't play it and choose to watch. I met a frog in the first areas a bunch of times. You compliment him, and he doesn't understand. He no longer wants to fight, and would rather learn more about the world. I meet a more powerful version of this frog, and he understands my compliment- I, instead, have to mystify him. Eventually, among a deformed amalgamation of an enemy, I have to reflect upon the things I said to this frog, and see them within what would otherwise be a horrific sight- and it fills me with DETERMINATION.  Undertale is a game that focuses on story and bears a gameplay mechanic that's unique enough for me to remember every enemy in the game, whether it be to get washed by a certain colored bullet or to not move at all during a fight, I grasp the concept fast and enjoy my fights instead of grinding out kills on an enemy with no depth at all. This gameplay shines during bossfights where the entire concept is remixed into a fun, fresh fight to protect those you care about [which, you'll soon find, might be the person you're fighting in the moment].  I can't say enough. I really can't. If you're not a guy for story, it's got gameplay. If you don't need gameplay, it's got great story. If you don't like either, it's got a jamming soundtrack and has made me laugh for longer than I'm proud to admit. And if you don't like any of those things... maybe video games aren't for you.  You're gonna have a great time.

UNDERTALE is truly a magnificently crafted piece.    It brings homage to older RPG games that have influenced the modern gaming age so greatly, and yet puts its own amassment of twists and feelings on the classic RPG genre. One might even say that Undertale isn't a normal RPG at all.  The combat system is extremely unique, and the karmic system's massive impact on the game's storyline feel like inFamous, but multiplied by ten.  Be warned, this game has its own unhealthy counts of fourth-wall breaks, so watch out!  If one puts the rather unlikable and generally alienating fanbase of Undertale aside, they will most likely realize that this game is a very good one, and can easily be recommended to others!   If you are one of the few users who has not heard of this game yet, or have managed to not spoil yourself of the entire game, then dive head-first into this game! Plot progression feels slow at times and navigation through various areas sometimes feels like a waste of time, but that's just my own opinion.  I would easily tell anybody to go play this game for themselves, as Mr. Toby Fox has truly crafted a successful masterpiece that (might) will be remembered in everyone's hearts someday as a great milestone in indie gaming.   Happy gaming!

Like everyone else who is currently looking at reviews thinking about getting this game, I was drawn to it by the extreme hype spreading around the internet (mainly rule 34) but that aside I was geniunely interested to see if this game held up with all the hype. Now I went into this game knowing there were multiple ways to play it so I read up and found out that being a pacifist was the best way. So I set off sparing the colorful (ironically black & white) monsters. - The only con I noticed within the first few hours is the fact that you run into the same mobs multiple times and the entertaining value of their encounters wears off after the first time. But this isn't even really a big deal. - And I nearly finished the game before finally realizing why this game is so hyped. It's unique. The developers used techniques which I can't recall ever seeing in any other games. It tracks how many times you've seen a cutscene regardless of your save data, which makes for some really cool easter eggs. They literally force crash your game at certain points which (again ironically) makes it very immersive. And the game constantly breaks its own rules which (one more time, ironically) makes it extremely entertaining.  The Neutral - True Pacifist endings truly made my love for this game bloom. And just like that, I'm one of the cancerous fans.  I can't bring myself to start up the game ever again and do a genocide run. I literally do not want to ruin such a perfect ending. I only played through half of the game and it's easily a gem that I would recommend to anyone.  The only real bad thing about this game is you WILL NOT get the soundtracks out of your head.   I give this game a solid 5/7.   Now off to search 'muffet' on paheal.......again...  (oh also thanks to Joey Salads for gifting this game to me. ye.)

A beautiful, heartfelt and at the same time very smart game that turns everything you know about RPGs on its head. Undertale is a game that is a charming as it is dark, as lighthearted as it is sad, as humorous as it is solemn. It is a game that engages you in ways that most other games in the industry don't do. It is the only game I've personally played that made me weep.   If you can, go in blind, or at least with very little context of characters and story. The game's cleverness shines through much more, and depending on the choices and the path you take, you will be left with a truly profound experience that may haunt you for days to come.

I can't even begin to say how much I enjoy this game!  The general story is pretty much pieced together in the end, but there is still a lot going on and so many secrets I have yet to discover or find. I do love the story/writing, it makes me curious and I love being curious! I was also feeling sadness, frustration(but that was just me being bad at the game), and even fear. it was just an over stimulation of the emotions. The gameplay was different, maybe I just never run into a dodging-type game like this, but I thought it was different from the usual rpg where every attack is based on luck and numbers. This one is more based on skill, memory, patience, and literal determination. I'm not kidding, this is the first time I actually felt ready get back in there and try again just from a game over screen (although I've had moments where I took a break just to cool down).  The art style is simply sublime. I was in awe just from all the detail and character design. Oh my goodness don't get me started on character design, I'm big on character designs, so I could go on for a while about how cool/cute/interesting they look! *sigh* yes... even Jerry.  So I say at least give this game a try before you put it down for looking 'retro' or 'old'. Honestly it does look retro but the story and text are very refreshing. giving it a new, crisp feel! If you've tried it and still don't like it, thats cool. I won't judge you, we all don't like the same things. Thats what makes us different from one another.

It's not often I choose to write about a game in general, however, I have to say that this has been one of the most emotionally compelling games I've played in a long, long time. The game in itself is more than enough of an experience, no matter how you decide to play it of the various possibilities, and at times, you may even find it tugging at your very heart strings here and there, but... it's an emotional ride I very much approve of with all of my heart.  As for the gameplay itself, while it may seem to be a bit of a 'run of the mill' RPG at first glance, the combat system itself has a very unique feature, akin to playing a bullet hell game, that really gets you involved with the fights themselves and give a more personal and interesting touch to it all. It makes most of the combat much more enjoyable and gives you a greater sense of accomplishment when you do everything right, as opposed to just mashing buttons over and over again... not to mention, the soundtrack alone has enough power to push you between sadness, happiness, and even overly excited for what's to come.  Overall, I've thoroughly enjoyed every second of my time with Undertale, and would suggest you give it a try yourself... even if it doesn't seem your cup of tea, you may be surprised to see what'll come of it in the long haul. I know I was, and it was the most pleasant surprise I've had all year from a gaming perspective.

This game... What isnt there to say about this game?  It's beautiful. The story, the music, the characters, everything is so good.  --Story--  Not going to get spoiler-ey here at all, just want to say that the story of this game is wonderful, and, well, may include multiple playthroughs in order to... get it all.  Story == 10/10  --Music--  There was not one track in this game that I didnt love. Seriously, that's not something that I can say for a lot of games, this is one game that I wouldnt mind paying $10 for the soundtrack (Which I plan to do very soon)  Music == 10/10 No question.  --Characters--  I dont think I've ever been on a date with a skeleton, so that's cool. But seriously, the characters in this game are all mostly fantastic, and you get invested with them very quickly.  Characters == 9.5/10  --Graphics--  This I usually dont care about in games, but UnderTale did it very good, the game has the pseudo 8-bit/16-bit style, which works very well for the game that it is, I couldnt imagine it being a 3D game at all.  Now, the sprite work, most of the time, it is really good, like, really really good. But, the only real 'problem' that I personally had with the graphics, would be your character's sprite. I dont know why, it just kinda put me off... oh well  Graphics == 9/10  --Gameplay--  Have you played EarthBound?  Have you played Touhou?  This game is EarthBound and Touhou mixed together. It's pretty great actually. The only real problem I have with it would be the difficulty spikes at bosses, not that that is an entirely bad thing, it just seemed a bit weird.  Gameplay == 9/10    Overall Score 9.5/10  It's not a perfect game, but it's damn near close enough. Congrats Toby Fox and artist who've worked on this, you've thoroughly impressed me.  If you haven't already played UnderTale... Do yourself a favor. Buy it. One of the best indie games that I've ever played.      --Joke Review--  I dated a skeleton and filled him with 'Determination'  10/Anime

I don't think i've ever cried out my eyes before, but this game changed that entirely. Perfect music to suit the atmosphere, loveable characters, and an ending, that if you can get to, that truly satisfies. But beware, this game will bring the feels, and when it brings the feels, it will bring them hard.   In my experience with playing this game, I was going into it a little bit mystified about how it would turn out and completely curious. I mean I already fell in love with the Motherly Character Toriel, and more or less hated the planty guts of the Flower upon its first encounter and trickery.  The moments that came after, was a rollercoaster of feelings of joy, sadness, laughter, and just about everything inbetween. You will have the happy moments in the story/game, to where you will be laughing so much and forgetting about some of your problems, hopefully in real life, and in game. And there will be moments that, will test your resolve, and moments that will have you shedding a tear or two (or a few dozen in my case.)  I never realized how time flew by when I played this game. At first it was an hour, then two, and so on. I couldn't pull myself away from this game because I was so in love with it, to where it changed the aspects of RPG's that i've played. To where in a certain sense it breaks the cliche of 'All monsters are heartless', to with the paths you can choose, and the choices you can make, more or less makes this game feel less like a game, but more a story of hope and a beautiful picture of artwork, despite how distorted it can be.  Please, support Undertale and their creators, and give this game a whirl, i'm sure you won't be disappointed. Because I know I wasn't. *Slowly proceeds to eat a Glamburger*

Honestly the most refreshing game experience I've had in years. It breaks away from the standard formula of the RPG, and focuses more on the role of the story and progression therein based on your actions than the need to grind for experience and the newest and best gear.  Don't let the simplicity of the aesthetics fool you, it's all instrumental in cultivating a specific feeling and weight to the events presented. Further breaking away from the genre, your actions actually have an impact, and you feel every consequence in visceral ways depending on how you choose to proceed.

'Down here... It's kill or be killed!'   HEY! This game is best played without knowing anything about it. Play it before reading, really. Then come back and read this.        Undertale is good. It has amazing characters, a fantastic soundtrack, addicting gameplay, and intresting use of breaking the fourth wall that will keep you playing. From the lovable Pasta-enthusiast Papyrus and his brother sans, to game show host Mettaton-I'm sure you'll find a favorite character. However, this is only if you 'spare' everybody. Thats the thing about Undertale, you can play the whole thing without killing a single person. You baiscally can Jesus and go around fixing peoples lives.  Now here's the UNDER-HAND....O-other hand. Undertale is praised for everything I said above, which is all good. However, if you choose to play as Satan's BFF, you'll go and kill everyone. This is where Undertale becomes...not-so fun. The music is made wonky, the chracters dont have any development, and you have to grind forever (The only way to access the Genocide (No mercy) route is to kill EVERYONE). But...it's made not enjoyable. You're supposued to not like it, it's suppoused to not be fun. I'm not gonna tell you to try it or not, but...you may have a bad time.  Yeah, there's also the neutral route. You honstly would run into this route if you dont know anything about the game. It's alright, thats all I can say about it.   Yeah, so overall Undertale's really good. Worth the money, 100%. Also make sure to suppourt the creater, Toby Fox. He seems super cool, deffinatly someone to look out for in the future. He also made Temmie.

Undertale is a game I went in with very low expectations but came out obsessed.  I had seen the hubbub arise when the game was new and first gained a following. I saw posts overtake my dashboard on tumblr and several of my friends fall down the hole of addiction. One of my close friends played a number of tracks from the OST to try to pique my interest. At first I felt uninterested and uninspired to even check out the game, let alone play it. However, several of my friends who have very similar tastes in storytelling and gameplay were urging me to play the game. I became interested, and lo and behold, a wonderful friend purchased the game for me.  Playing blind, I completed the entire game, both the True Pacifist Routes and Genocide Routes, in a week.  The first playthrough took me 16 hours. I can get through it in 3 hours now. I'm still playing the game, still enjoying it, and I have played over 143 hours to count since I received the game three months ago.  I am still obsessed with Undertale to this day. It is a game that is very enjoyable, very impacting, and resonates with the heart. There's a reason I call it one of my all time favorite games and all time favorite stories.  Do not be deceived by the game’s first hour of play. The RUINS, where you begin playing, is not very interesting to a first time player. Until you get to know her and finish the entire game, Toriel acts much like a simple tu-TORIEL. For me, I did not find that part of the game impressive at all for my first runthrough. It was only as I continued forward that I got sucked into the world of Undertale. As simple and basic as the game seems as first, I assure you, it will get far more complicated and far more engaging to the player.  Do not be deceived by the game’s graphics. While they seem so simple, basic, and uninteresting at first, the more you play, the more you will be able to appreciate the visual beauty of the screen. There is a lot of thought and design in the pixels. There are beautiful color palates, downright gorgeous rooms, and gloriously beautiful moments in the later battle sequences.  Do not be deceived by the basic MIDI soundtrack. As a trained music composer, at first I thought this music was very uninteresting. However, the more you play, the more charm the melodies give you. The more they get stuck in your head. The more you fall in love with them. The more you realize the music that was composed was EXACTLY what needed to be composed, and that they actually have very good form and compositional structure.  Undertale, in truth, is much more than meets the eye, ear, and first impression.  It’s a story beautifully told and full of impact.  This is a game that is full of charming and endearing humor. The terrible puns, the trolling teases, the ridiculous situations, the tongue-in-cheek, the irony, and the fourth wall references all combine into a distinct, lovable sense of comedy. This is a game that will make you facepalm, laugh, and at times howl in amusement.  This is a game that is full of lovable, three-dimensional characters. The characters are so three-dimensional and interesting that, with every playthrough, you learn something new about them. A bite of an implied backstory. The motivations behind their actions. The depths of their hearts. Their likes and dislikes. Their characterization. Their penchants, their tendencies, their manners of speech. Some stories have boring characters, some stories have interesting characters, and some stories – like Undertale – have living, breathing, lovable, unforgettable personalities.  This is a game that dives into the depth of the heart and explores the soul. Though there are many lighthearted moments in the game, it also is incredibly deep and full of mature concepts. It is a game by which a player can question morality or feel encouraged about the goodness of kindness. It is a game that demonstrates the power of love and the horrors of hate. It shows the meaning of forgiveness. It explores trauma, even gets into very solemn moments about depression, suicide contemplation, and handling a genocide. The game can go into many serious concepts while bringing the story, at the end, to a resolving and encouraging finish.  This game breaks some unexpected gaming boundaries. The fourth wall is something most people have never experienced the like before. The game CHANGES based upon your decisions – and even going back to a previous save file won’t be enough for you to escape your actions. The fourth wall is integrated into the very lore of the game, and there are moments that will legitimately surprise blind players because you do not anticipate some of the plot twists.  Frankly, this is a game that is very well-written from a literary perspective. The story’s trajectory is nicely balanced. Information and experience collide and slowly build up to surprising reveals and connections you never would have anticipated. In the game, you think you start with a simple journey. By the end, you are bawling from emotion at the experience.  This game is a true journey.   This game has everything I could want. Great, catchy music. Beautiful visuals. Entertaining humor. Heartwrenching pain. Memorable characters. Great representation of many types of individuals. A cool setting and world. An engaging and well-written storyline. Fun gameplay experience. Challenges. Depth, maturity, grit, encouragement, cheer, hope. A lot of hidden secrets, areas to explore, and juicy information to uncover for the truly dedicated player. Lore that brings you a lot of knowledge, but also leaves hoards of room for theories and discussion.  Please, if you haven’t already, go play Undertale. If you are someone who is at all interested in games with good stories, then this is meant for you.  I assume most people who are reading this have been spoiled on some aspects. For those of you who haven’t, I will only say one thing, if you want to have a little guidance (this is the guidance I got before playing and I think it was worth it to hear this): the best gameplay experience for first-time players is to start with what the fandom called the “Pacifist Route.” Don’t kill anyone. Play to the end. Then, when you have done that, do what the fandom calls the “Genocide Route.” Literally obliterate everyone in every area of the game before going forward; seek out every possible monster that lives there; make sure you see the line “But nobody came” before transitioning from one location to another. See what happens. Be patient and have FUN with those incredible boss fights.  And above all, my friends… stay DETERMINED.

Undertale is a 5 foot pool that you can dive into for miles. The outward simplicity of this game is an illusion that will draw casual players into a world where your choices matter. There is rarely a game that can look like this while giving you the depth of a huge RPG.

NOTE: I have completed the game but ONLY playing the pacifist route, so that is all I can vouch for.  Before I do a big long pros and cons list, just a quick note. This game makes you consider what you're doing as a player. When you kill someone, you as a player have murdered someone. Sure you can go back to a previous save and they'll be there, but you are now a murderer. The game knows that, and it tells you that it knows. The game works like this in other ways too, but it is something not done in any other game I know of and I believe this game is worth the purchase for this ingenious design alone.  Pros: Incredible storyline, whether you like storylines in games or not (personally I do not) this really is a gem that you can appreciate. Atmosphere, truly makes you feel all types of emotions through incredible soundtracks, strong characters, and powerful backgrounds. Combat, if you enjoy bullet hell style fights then it's an added bonus, if you don't then it in no way takes away from the game experience. Decisions, I feel like everything I do in this game means something and has a real impact on what goes on, probably because it does. Characters, not much to say here apart from each character is wonderous, fully flushed, and thoroughly intruiging.   Cons: Repetitive, The last hour of gameplay to me feels like the same thing over and over again, worth it for the ending but it does start to feel like lazy game design. Repetitive, I've met this same boss like three times now... Is this a glitch? Repetitive, Look I'm sure there's a point to this but why are you saying the same speech for like the billionth time? Repetitive, HOLY F*CKING SH*T IF I HAVE TO WALK THROUGH THIS SAME F*CKING HALLWAY ONE MORE D*MN TIME!   This game tries so hard to be 'deep' by walking you through the same places over again after revealing more information that it becomes dull and repetitive, especially in the last 1-2 hours.   All in all, incredible game. I recommend.

Undertale  Rating - A+ Genre - RPG Creator - Toby Fox  Review  Undertale was a hyped game for quite some time until we all finally were able to play it and the wait was definately worth it. The rich story , the awesome characters and the concept executed so perfectly just adds it up to a great game. The combat system doesn't work like a traditional RPG , however this doesn't mean the game is bad but instead of attacks and such you can ACT , FIGHT , or use ITEMS then you can SPARE them those are the 4 things you can do.   If you FIGHT then you are playing the game on the GENOCIDE route. Not fighting , but instead ACTING will put you on the PACIFIST route. The different routes also make the game have alot of re-playability.  The game itself has great pixel graphics , funny jokes , good secrets and the AMAZING story is great. The story itself (SPOILERS AHEAD) Is a very heart-warming tale of a human waking up in a world of monsters you play as the human , you will meet amazing characters with lots of personality giving the game a way more real feeling to it you go through multiple areas each one more detailed than the last , and I am not going to lie I cried playing this game.  The Ending of the game is A very big plot twist (SPOILERS NOW) Where Flowey (The first character you meet in the game) kills King Asgore (King Of The Monsters) and becomes OMEGA FLOWEY and with even more detail where the game will crash frequently as Omega Flowey is 'Breaking The Game'.  Personally I think the soundtrack is probably one of THE BEST soundtracks in a game EVER and I ain't lying!  Overall Undertale is a great game and I urge anyone who enjoys any kind of RPG or pixel-graphic game to play THIS GAME.

The game's major weakness: Practically everything is a spoiler. If you know little to nothing about this game, now is the time to play it.   Undertale is a twisted spin on RPGs with a retro art style. The basic concept is that you don't have to kill any enemies if you don't want to. This creates many diverse ways the game can be played, which the creator has taken into account and planned for. With all these branching paths, it is best to go in knowing as little as possible to get a more personal feeling while playing, instead of simply looking up how to get the 'best' ending. Looking up a walkthrough or watching a lets play really does invalidate the point of the game, so I can't stress enough how important it is to avoid spoilers. Unfortunately, due to the game's massive success and popularity, most players, myself included, already know too much on their first playthrough and don't get the full experience.  The gameplay is built on very basic RPG elements, but they are actually incorporated into the story. There are a few weapons that all act mostly the same, you try to stop a white bar in the center of a meter to get the most damage. Not the most complicated system, but still somewhat challenging for new players. Enemies, on the other hand, have personalized attacks and optional ways to spare them. The real unique part of combat is that it becomes a bullet hell when enemies attack they player, and even this isn't always as straight forward as it seems. Depending on certain choices you make, this can be anywhere from stupidly easy to hair tearingly difficult. Outside of combat, there are many puzzles to get through in order to advance. Aside from two bosses whos' solutions weren't immediately obvious and some optional puzzles I skipped the first time around, this game was a cake walk; but, there were some options I didn't take that would have enhanced the difficulty severely.   I want to do the hard playthrough, just to say I beat it; but the story is drastically altered by it, and the ending is unspeakably dark.    The game doesn't lack for beautiful scenery, if you can at all appreciate the pixel art style. Personally, I think the game looks amazing; but I know some people don't see pixel art as anything but an easier way to make a game. This game makes me question those people's sanity, as it is by far one of the most breathtaking games I've played.  The soundtrack is definitely one of the best features of the game, as the lead developer is moderately well known for their previous musical works. The music mostly sounds like chiptunes, with a smattering of realistic instruments in the background. The atmosphere is intensely amplified by the music, or lack thereof in some cases. However, if you are interested in buying it, be warned that many tracks are under a minute long. Almost all the songs are designed to loop, so most end up being shorter than they seem in game. This is mostly made up for with there being a staggering 101 songs on the album, and the sheer quality of the best songs. Maybe consider buying the official metal cover instead. It's more expensive, but it doesn't come with songs that are under a minute in length.  The story and lore of the land are top notch. I found myself deeply engaged when clues and backstory were provided; but I'm a sucker for those things, regardless. The world feels like a real place with a long history. There's lots of diverse areas,   despite taking place entirely in a cave under a mountain,  with details and secrets hidden everywhere.  One major gripe people seem to have with this game is that the characters are too,'tumblry.' I can understand where they're coming from; but it seems like a silly thing to complain about, and I didn't really notice anything too edgy. I found most of the characters to be very similar to people one might meet in real life, from angsty teens all the way to pushy salesmen.   If you really don't like a certain character, though, you can always kill them.
A pleasant experience all the way through.

Undertale is probably one of the best RPGs I've played. The characters are great, the gameplay is unique and interesting, and the humor is UNDER rated. (SANS!!! aw, c'mon. youre smiling. I AM AND I HATE IT!!!) If you like games like Earthbound/Mother, you'll love this game to bits. (get it? cause it looks like its 8-bit? GOD DAMN IT, SANS!!!)  Also, the soundtrack is the most kickass thing. Every song is has it's own style, such as the up beat bass line of 'Death by Glamour', or the acoustic lick from 'Undertale'. Its probably one of my favorite video game soundtracks of all time.  And the story. OH BOY, THE STORY! This game will send you on an emotional rollercoaster, full of sad, happy, and downright hillarious moments. It also has alternating paths, which are dependent on your actions. You can effect the ending in minor or major ways.  Which is where the coolest thing of this game comes in. The alternate endings. This is one of the only RPGs I've seen where you can decide everyone's fate. Will you make friends with everyone, or will you kill everything in cold blood? Or do a bit of both?  Overall, this game is one of the best games of 2015, and it's so cheap, too. Just buy it already, damn it!

The artstyle is very cute and reminds me of the Mother (or Earthbound) series. everything is so colorfull and quirky in a way that melts my heart! The music is also phenomenal, with each song telling a story and giving you some nostalgia on the way. I guess it is ok to listen to the soundtrack, but be careful, you do not want this entire game spoiled because you were curious. Overall, I would recomend this game so much, I would want to buy it for you! If you are interested, GET IT NOW!!! It is SO worth the $10!!!

This game approaches the conceptual teaching of empathy and compassion in a very unique way. Every aspect of this work of art was created with every possible perception in mind, rewarding experimention and tinkering with the game mechanics while often 'breaking the 4th wall' to express it's outstandingly well timed humor. Every single detail is so meticulously planned out that it causes the player to think in ways they never imagined before as well as feel emotions for things that would, in any other game, be just another part of a sewn experience. This is one of those games where the actual 'game' part of it is the effect that it leaves upon you afterwards. Whether that feeling is depression, joy, contentment, or inspiration, there comes time the realization that this masterpiece was created by a very small group of people using a tailored passionate idea from one man's mind and the generous donations of dozens of supporters who saw the potential. Undertale is a game that really does what it sets out to do: it makes you feel joy, melancholy, despair, hope, the whole 'good things to feel during games' gambit (which means that it leaves out frustration and anger, in my case anyway). It's an absolutely bizarre experience that will have you constantly double take and go, 'wait... did that really just happen?', and the answer is always 'yes'.  The game is story heavy and emotionally I feel, it's very powerful. It takes the core concept of a 'journey' and sprinkles in some strange and silly antics in between the world building and personal experiences you have (a single playthrough lasts about five hours). It's a game that makes you think and consider your actions, because unlike say, Until Dawn, the tone of the game is VASTLY different depending on your choices. Just be aware that the game is quite  smart , and will know if you've done wrong. Even if you try and hide it.   The characters are diverse and flawed, which is actually a strength and not a weakness, as it makes them more well-rounded and generally still very loveable. The music is extremely fitting and does a perfect job of setting the tone for the current area or situation, don't even get me started on the final boss's music.  The combat is turn-based, and mostly consists of meter-stopping mechanics for attacking and bullet hell-ish dodging for defending. Not a fan of bullet hell? That's fine, I'm not either. You just use it to dodge the enemy's attacks, and it's extremely simplistic and straightforward.  My only complaints are that:  1. I am dog-♥♥♥♥ at this game. 2. The replayability largely rests on how willing you are to be a genocidal maniac. 3. I just want MORE!  TL;DR: It's a fairly short, emotionally powerful game that will take you on a journey and make you feel things you've never felt before. Full of laughs, extremely strange, but knows when to be serious. Replayability depends on how  determined  you are.

This review is designed more for people who don't know much about the game itself and are questioning whether or not it would be a good rpg to pick up during the sale or when its not on sale.  Undertale is an odd ball out when it comes to RPGs. It isn't your typical build a party, fight every enemy in tedious turn based battles, and explore the overworld. No. Undertale is a game where you take control of a kid and go throughout the lands exploring and meeting people. You don't make parties, but you do have to battle things. The neat thing about Undertale is that you don't actually have to fight anything, you can just be peaceful and avoid enemy attacks until your enemy gets bored and gives up. Plus, there's a great cast of characters to meet, which is a very nice part of the game. The gameplay is good, and there is actually a decent value to the replayability, as each route you choose gives you different choices in the game and a different ending. The best part of the game however, is not the game itself, but rather the soundtrack. The soundtrack is amazing, and you should download the bundle that has the soundtrack. It's worth it. Trust me.  So, if you're looking for a fun RPG experience, veterans and newbies alike, this would be an excellent choice. It isn't a conventional RPG, but that's what makes it the most fun. Only con would be the fact that some of the puzzles are difficult to get through, but they're fun. Overall 9.5/10

I became curious about 'Undertale' after numerous coverage of this cultural phenomenon. After receiving it as a gift, I decided to give it a go. I definitely see merit in the game, with its modern take on turn-based RPG and a twist to its levelling system. The graphics are a miss for me at times given some inconsistency in the style department. The combat is based on 'bullet hell' shooting games, thus requiring some sharp reflexes on the player's part. Unfortunately, I am neither partial to bullet hell games nor possess sharp enough reflexes, so I found combat in 'Undertale' a nuisance. By mid-game, I got so frustrated that I don't find the game interesting or enjoyable anymore. However, for those who do well with bullet hell games or can tolerate it more than I, I will recommend 'Undertale' for its interesting take on turn-based RPG and its tropes; else, I would say stay away.

A lazy game with a fantastic soundtrack. Note: My 6.3 hours in the game was an entire playthrough of the 'pacifist run' i.e. forgoing half of the gameplay (pressing the attack button at the right time) in order to get some different dialog boxes from the NPCs.  Pros: -The soundtrack is so good, you'll feel like you're playing a good game (or wish you were). -A few genuinely funny jokes or interesting moments. Unfortunately these have nothing to do with the gameplay and would be just as effective as comics or short animations (or even fan fictions).  Cons: -Feels like it was made in a few days. -You walk through the game. The only gameplay is a bullet dodging minigame that isn't very fun, for me at least. -Graphics aren't anything to write home about, especially for the classic pixel art style they are trying to mimic. -FNAF-style cancer community that can't see any flaws in this experience.  A lot of the cons about this game can be summarized as it being 'lazy'. Good artists could remake all of the basic pixel graphics in Undertale in a few hours. The gameplay can be recreated in about a day.  It feels like a lot of corners were cut in the production of this game just for the sake of it being easier to make.  You get the feeling that some really talented people were working on this game, but never gave any real effort and got by with the minimum.

Decent game. Decent plot. Nothing more. I wouldn't recommend it to anyone these days because there's a big chance you've already played or seen it before. The soundtrack is totally worth getting as it is the best part of the game no doubt. The graphics are just average at best and the gameplay is too simple for it's own good. The gimmick of the game is that nobody needs to get hurt, but there is nothing interesting about how you do so. Simply choose the right dialogue options in the right order and maybe once or twice do something new. The story is also something people rave about and how its 'an example of how video games are art and wooshy wooshy'. Honestly if I could sum it up I would use two words 'Lore dump.' Half the game is walking through passages and having goofy conversations, the other half is standing in what feels like a library just reading, reading and reading so much exposition. I do not love undertale. I think it's a good game, but I would not recommend it.

I just don't get it. I didn't grow up with Earthbound, and I got my fill of player-choice-consequences with the original Deus Ex, so the retro vibe didn't thrill me, and the idea of sparing your enemies felt way behind the times.  The writing was often lovely, the soundtrack was solid, and I can totally see how one could get sucked into the rabbit hole of repeat playthroughs and mucking about with save files. I've spent hundreds of hours doing the same on Dark Souls because the lore was so deep and hard to access.  But the Underground isn't Lordran. I just didn't want to explore it again. For every charming monster there was a half-baked meta-joke or a nonsequiter that pulled me out. The world varied so wildly between saccharine, self-aware, genuinely funny, and tragic that I couldn't latch on to any one part of it. So many filler areas, so many empty hallways and one-off characters. The final boss was excruciatingly hard, and too many of the sequences wore out their welcome almost instantly (the Papyrus/traps/puzzle section just DRAGGED. ON. FOREVER.) And while I understand Alphys's appeal to a broad swath of anime fans, all I could think during Hotland was 'PLEASE JUST SHUT THE ♥♥♥♥ UP. WHERE'S YOUR ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ SELF-RESPECT?'  I will say that Temmie Village is a stroke of pure, demented genius. ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ I loved that place.  But overall, no. I didn't enjoy playing this game. I understand why many do, but I can't bring myself to recommend it.

The short version: if you dislike bullet hell, and aren't fond of JRPGs in general, this game probably isn't for you!  Slightly longer: I know I've only got the 1.3 hours, but the combat/battle system just didn't do it for me, I'm afraid. I should have predicted it - I've never been super fond of JRPG-style combat, and I really dislike anything that smacks of 'bullet hell,' and having random encounters pop up constantly just made me not want to play any further. It's absolutely a personal preference kind of thing, and given my preferences I probably should've just given it a miss to begin with. Ah, well!  On the better side, the story was doing a good job of drawing me in, and I liked the characters I'd encountered. I was sad when I accidentally killed a monster early on, when trying to just wheedle down its health! I also felt I probably screwed up the encounter with Toriel and felt bad about that. From what I'd read online, the rest of the story and overall mechanics remain intriguing to me, but I'm afraid that the combat is likely to keep me away.  One more: The Linux port runs great! Thanks for that!

A stream of conciousness narrative. MILD SPOILERS.   You fall into a world filled with things called 'monsters'.  They are colorful and vibrant, in comparison to you. They have a thriving society in a world you can  almost  picture as it is described: breathtakingly beautiful and exotic. The monsters also have a thriving grudge against humans, who some millennia ago sentenced them to this world of peace and  mass hysteria  propagated by their king, who hopes to instill in them a hope for the surface world.  As the story progresses, a demonic goat tries to mother you. You are attacked by Rosencrantz and Guildenstern. The king wants your soul. The music builds 8-bittically and the caverns look all “retro” - while the puzzles and battle-system remind you that your soul is not, in fact, a small pixelated heart.  You meet skeletons who mock your favorite childhood fonts, animals who speak in meme, dogs who want nothing more than to be pet. You are given the choice of killing them, or satisfying their every strange desire. At some point, you become confused and die to a stray…something white?  You are “encouraged” upon your death by the schizophrenic second voice inside your faceless skull to return and try again. And you do. You go to dinner, you go on a date, you meet a fish wearing a tin can! You meet a dinosaur who is your friend, wait, who is this person,  wait , who is  not  your friend??? You pick up a great many uniquely named items and Pose with the second coming of Michael Jackson.  Finally, you learn that the king’s recent desire to kill humans was sparked by the death of his son and also there was a human. …Since nobody else is bothered by this apparent plot hole, you decide to continue plodding onward and on  sloooowly  reading line after line of  monologue  and you hear that your ancestors (or rather some random humans who may have been fictitious) were evil because they killed a monster who turned the other cheek and plodded silently back to his parents to collapse into dust at their shattered feet.  Somehow, you reach the castle you've been looking for. The kingis there. He thinks you’re  really great , and he’s so glad to have met you and the six others  just like you , and he wants to make sure your affairs are in order, and  he attempts to brain you with a trident . You deal with that problem but suddenly remember one other shallow psychopath you met earlier but it’s not like before with that practice dummy nobody warned you about,  right??  He/It/Kthulu proceeds to give you photoshopped nightmares, and you realize you must've made a mistake somewhere along the way but it’s too late because your game is crashing! And it won’t end!! And you’re really so confused and sick of the whole mess by now that you finally just  It’s Over.   Eighth grade returns to tell you that your life is pointless. The snowman was pointless. The …thing you just killed? returns to tell you to try again, don’t worry the ending’s better. “I’d really give it a shot,” says the fan standing next to you, “just think of all the teeny-weeny little bits of backstory you missed – at least two other psychopaths, I promise! -- in fact my heart will be broken if you don’t find something to tell me-' – and you quietly close Steam, open Programs, and press Uninstall.  The sound of silence does not fill you with determination.  3/10

I've hit a point in this game where I don't know if I'll continue, but I decided to put up a short review in the meantime. I can't imagine my opinion changing if I decide to continue this.  We all play games for different reasons, but ultimately it's to have a fun experience. This game will not bring that unless you just want to jump on a bandwagon of LV for a mediocre product.  The game is automatically being played off on false nostalgia. The graphics, sounds and part of the combat system is familiar to a lot of older gamers. However, the reason you played those old school console JRPGs was because they were fun. You had exploration, characters that were interesting, a variety of spells and attacks, and a reason behind everything.  In Undertale, the exploration is limited to different paths that sometimes lead to a funny/cutesy/quirky thing. In one scene, I saw a fishing rod that had a picture attached to it. I couldn't tell if the picture was a philosophical parable or a very simple joke. The combat has a feature to talk your way out of battle. I found the most useful feature is Fleeing a battle because the battle system is boring. This was the one aspect I was hoping would be a lot of fun. Instead, I found myself wanting random battles to never happen. I quit talking my way out of battles because the dialog that spews from an enemies mouth is, frankly, bad. It's not funny not entertaining. It's bland.  The music and graphics are something. They captured an era, and it's the one positive I can give the game as of now. They're ugly as sin and the main character looks like a reject from The Simpsons: Bart vs. The World, however, that's what this game was going for and they nailed it. When I left the first area start my quest home, the graphics went from Commodore 64 to a weird NES/SNES look. I could dig it. The music is charming, and probably the best part of the game. It fits the environments well and it's about the best reason to recommend Undertale.  You may have heard this game shares similarities to Earthbound. Yes and no. Yes, because it has some art aspects that look Earthbound-y, but no to everything else. If you want to play Earthbound, there's many options available. And it's actually going to make you happy playing it because it's fun, cute in a way that's relaxing, and has a decent overall plot line for an old game. Undertale just keeps dragging on and on.  I don't think this game was created with a bad vision. I think it's just a very poor game and has been grasped by a certain type of indie community that feels certain games that shouldn't be popular should be popular. There's people that are going to legitimately love this game. And good. Not everyone needs to love the same thing. But I think the overhyped community, the missionaries of this game, have spoiled it. This game having certain words associated with it like 'feels' and 'deep meaning' damages the game more than honors it.  If I finish the game, which as much as I don't want to, probably will to mark off my backlog, I will update the review if I feel it needs it. But as of now, I have to say don't bye into this weird hype. I don't watch My Little Pony even though it have a strong (non-physically) community. Undertale is no exception. Bad is bad and quirky isn't always good.
This review contains spoilers, read at your own risk.

I tried to like this game, but after being depressed over it and mulling over my issues with it, I just can't say I'm glad to have played it. I wish I never played it, that I could forget it. The good things about it aren't worth the terrible disappointment I faced in the end. I've heard arguments for why its ending is fine, or perfect, but after months I still cannot find it even acceptable. Disregarding the fact that it made me depressed, made me go from functional to a hopeless wreck, it still has the worst ending I've seen in any video game, which ruined the rest of the (honestly unpolished and full of plot holes) story. The gameplay was fun, though not nearly as hard and bullet-hell like as I originally believed and feel it's lacking. I know that almost no one will have the same negative reaction, the same degree of contempt, that I have for the end of this game. I know many of my friends love this game, despite its flaws, or what I am convinced are flaws. But personally... I would have been better off never having played this game.

I'm trying to figure out why people like this game so much. It's super slow and boring.
Psst! You should get Earthbound instead :^)

Undertale is a game that is hard to reccomend. While it's by no means a bad game, it's a game littered with a lot of unpolish that I often wonder whether I'm playing an actual RPG at all or just a parody.  The graphics are very mixed; sometimes they can be of very good quality, and at other times they can look identical to MS Paint. I feel the developer was unsure how to artistically design the game; I understand that for an artstyle it's trying to be unique, but in terms of quality, it does not look pleasant on the eyes.  For example, why is that the first level with Flowey looks retro, yet when I reach the Snowdin level I see extremely detailed trees? It doesn't make sense.  Gameplay, for the main part, is pretty mixed. I do enjoy the combat system and fighting enemies. Sadly, what I don't enjoy is the 'spare' mechanic. I feel it's a completely glorified way of making you feel bad for killing enemies, despite the fact that the majority of the enmies in the game either want to kill you, or are just extremely annoying at times. Why should I spare Papyrus if, logically, he's trying to attack me? You can't play with emotions with inconsistent writing.  Overall, Undertale is not a bad game, but it's not a particuarly good one either. If you get this game, I will just let you know that in my honest opinion there are thousands of better RPGS out there.

Even though I don't recommend this game, I'd say it's still worth 5 bucks to see what the fuss is about. But it's overhyped. Massively overhyped, in fact. Even when appreciating the game for what it tries to do and what it wants to be, there's many flaws in its execution. I'll mention several of them here but I feel the need to stress that you should make your mind up about this game by playing it, not through any review. That way, when you meet a fellow gamer who played it, you can have lively discussions about what did and didn't work for you in what feels like the most polarizing game of 2015.  What didn't work for me: the humour. Absurd comedy is very hard to pull off. I'm a fan of The Fast Show and Monty Python and what's presented here is not good absurd comedy in my book. It's not good surreal comedy either: it feels like the developer heard about surreal comedy from a friend and then tried to mimic it. Other than that, there's maybe three puns that are grin-worthy.  The combat: you'll be playing 'bullet hell' mini-games a lot. These are made frustrating by stiff controls resulting in the game being harder than it has any right to be. Only one fight was truly enjoyable to me (spiders). The bullet hells are enemy attacks, to actually defeat opponents you must either attack them or figure out what to say or do to appease them. And that ties into my biggest gripe:  the game doesn't respect your time .   Would you figure out that in order to defeat a monster you would have to try and hug it four times (getting no response other than '...' every time) and then ignore it twice? I literally thought that the only option was beating it to death because no other option advanced the combat state and then when I killed it, it turns out that the game commits the capital sin of having  very  strict requirements to get the 'good' and 'bad' endings...  Because of this, I stopped caring about the characters very quickly. To defeat my opponents I chose the path of least resistance where I could, simply because there's no rhyme or reason to most of it. Midway through the game I was ready to walk out of the monster realm and send a nuke back in for good measure. That said, when you get frustrated... grit your teeth and work through it. Don't quit the game midway, play it through. It only takes about 6 hours and you need to see the ending at least once in order to have the full experience. I nearly didn't get there, but I'm glad I did, if only to be able to discuss it with others.  The game did succeed in giving me 'the feels' once or twice. But it does so in a very ham-fisted way that left me feeling used and rather unsympathetic towards the game.  If the humour gels with you, if you can stand the combat (there's a demo that you can test) and if you are willing to work through it to get the different endings then this is genuinely a good game. If not, then 5 bucks and 6 hours of your time is the price of admission to have an opinion about the latest 'best indie game evarr'. And while I think that's a price worth paying, I wouldn't  recommend  it to anyone.

So basically, you journey out on a grand quest as a 9 year old child with a stick in efforts to kill an immortal, semi-omnipotent god entity that will either  A. kill you repeatedly forever B. lose to you, but regain ultimate control over the underground as soon as you leave the underground C. lose to you, and force you to spend eternity underground ensuring that he does not regain ultimate control D. lose to you, and force you to spend the rest of your life underground ensuring that he does not regain ultimate control *until you die*, which will happen eventually.   He exists across save files (berating you for making decisions in other timelines and realities) and outside of the actual controllable game itself (in the menu), so the only way to actually 'defeat' him is to uninstall the game and then reinstall it, then never play it. If you play it, he exists again in some form, regardless of what you actually do in-game.   The only way to 'win' Undertale is to download the game but never open it or play it. Does anyone else see a logic fault here?

BEFORE SOMEONE DOWNVOTES THIS, READ MY REVIEW  This game is really quite interesting. Not in a good or bad way, just interesting. Let me some this game up in pro's and con's fashion:  Pros: - Amazing, beautiful soundtrack - Enticing story - Cool looking enemies - Unique battle system  - Some deep and rich characters  That's it for pros. Everything else in this game (so far) I see is simply not good. Let's start with the graphics; the most controversial topic of all. Let me just put this out for the world: I adore retro-style graphics. I live and breathe it, like games like Super Meat Boy. This game looks like it took NES graphics, ♥♥♥♥ on them, and chewed it up before being bought. It's not HD retro graphics! It looks like something the Atari 2600 would muster! Trust me, there ARE ways to make the game look good whilst maintaining retro graphics! But this was not the way to go. Bland colors, ugly sprites, etc.  Next, let's talk about characters. Everyone won't shut up about Sans and Papyrus, and it's easy to see why. They are quite funny. But, they are extremely under-developed and 1-Dimensional. You see no other side to these characters. What you see was what you get.  Next agenda is how people say how you can go about without violence. This speech mechanic is not at all what I thought it would be. It is literally an attack in how it functions. It's not say, in Mass Effect with your options to say something. No. You have a choice of attacks, and you keep using the same. one. over. and over. until the enemy 'submits', or they literally die. It's literally calling an attack something else.  My third problem is the price. This game looks and feels like a homebrew or a video game done within a week. It should not be more than $5.00, much less $9.99. If it was significantly less cheaper, I wouldn't really be mad at it.  My next issue with the game is its clunkiness. I do love RPG's that have multiple routes branching out, but here, it kind of seems clunky. At no point in the game, do I ever have to return to a single point and it all feels linear, even when I have no idea where this place is in the map.   Finally, I hate how people compare this game to Earthbound. Sure, you have equipment. But is it shown on your character? Do you have any stats? Do you have any different attacks, or a magic attack? No. You can't have a party or a team.   Let's end this game on a positive note. I like the battle system, as long as people don't shove the whole 'no violence' thing down my throat. It is very skill based, and it is quite fun to find the patterns in some attacks. Finally, the music. God this music feels like it belongs in some triple A title, not an indie game. It is so good that the soundtrack is better than the game itself.   CONCLUSION  Don't buy this game. Buy the soundtrack. If this game goes on sale for less than $5.00, then buy it.

TL;DR:  p: ~funny ~good soundtrack ~great characters  c: ~boring on 2 of the 3 routes ~TOO easy ~Grinding ~walking simulator ~Not much content ~Just watch someone play it instead of wasting your money on it ~Super Short (4 hours for pacifist, 12 for genocide due to grinding (about 2 of those hours are actual gameplay))    Pros: The game is good for quite a few laughs, most of the humor is pretty funny with some of the npc's. The music ranges from fitting to AMAZING. the mechanics are simple and easy to use (however they're a little too simple). All the characters are memorable and a joy to talk with.  Cons: It's pretty boring, the gameplay is ok on 1 of the 3 routes, on the other 2 routes you're either walking around waiting to kill something or you're walking from point A to point B with minimal gameplay in between. If you want an actual challange you have to sit through hours of grinding and it will perminately keep you from getting the 'good ending.' not to mention that if you want that 'good ending' you sit through nothing but walking and then running when you incounter and enemy. there's a puzzle here and there but they're extreamly simple, and most of them can be solved through 2-3 trys via trial and error. some of the characters are also extreamly annoying or overused. basically everything here could be experienced by just watching a youtuber play the game, and if you do watch the youtuber play the game, that's it, you would've seen everything the game has to offer. There's only about one or two secrets in the whole game that you'll miss because the other ones aren't even secrets. Also the game is SUPER SHORT.

Undertale is absolutely amazing! It looks at RPG mechanics and turns them on their head, random monster battles especially. You can talk your way out of any encounter, usually yielding hilarious results. Or you can fight like you normally would, but killing an enemy actually kills them, since you're in the world of monsters; random encounters stop happening and towns become desolate because you killed everyone ...that's why it's dubbed the 'Genocide Route'. But if you go the good/neutral route and talk your way out of battles (which I recommend, especially for first time players), you'll find some of the smartest writing I've seen in a long time.

I bought this game yesterday because it seemed like a steal. $10 for a game with that good of reviews? Heck Yeah! Unfortunately, I don't think this game is for everyone. It certainly does things right otherwise it wouldn't get such good reviews. But personally, the majority of this game didn't spark my interests and I found myself simply playing it through because I didn't want to stop, and I wanted to see if it got better. The brightest part of this game is most definitely the ending. Unfortunately, as someone who didn't read much about the game until I was most of the way through, I didn't totally understand the combat options and just easily slaughtered all of the enemies that came my way. I didn't know sparing enemies would actually change my game. This game definitely has sparks of light that shine through, such as some of the characters: the things some of the characters say are funny, charming, or cute. Unfortunately, I found most of the gameplay to be relatively repetitive and I found myself mashing keys to skip through dialogue just to finish the game and get to the end. If I had the choice again I would not pay the $10 for this game. The graphics didn't live up to my expectations from the reviews, even with the uniqueness of the graphics it was clearly what the dev was going for but it just didn't resonate with me. This review will likely get many downvotes as most of the community adores this game, but I am writing this to the small majority who may need to know that this game is not for everyone. It is a very linear game that has a few hours of mediocre gameplay lead up to one big quick ending that is touching but just not worth it. In the beginning I found a few of the quirks quite hilarious but it got old fairly quick as well as the same joking style got carried through, it seemed more immature than funny. Thanks for reading, I hope the community doesn't totally hate me :).

I don't consider the following to be a spoiler (it's meerly a design choice I disliked) but seeing as some people enjoyed being lied to and replaying the whole game (I guess you can call that 'replay value') I've censored it just in case:   My main gripe with this game is that it's linear in the sense that the first 'boss fight' pretty much determines the outcome of the game while doing everything it can to convince you that there is no choice. The game forces you to replay it but it doesn't become apparent until the middle or the very end of the game.    Having a game lie to you, and then build lies upon lies until nothing is certain is probably what sold so many people on this game - and at times it makes for an interesting plot twist. But I have to say, this is 'To the Moon' level of storytelling. Cute and heartwarming but nothing spectacular as most people will tell you. If it drops below $5 on a sale you might want check it out.

This was a really hard game to review, but ultimately I had to say it is not worth a purchase at 10 dollars. If it drops under 5, then it might be worth it.   This is by far one of the best concepts for a game I have ever played. Every action you do makes a huge difference. And the stories in the game are really interesting. That said, in my 8 hours of playing, at least 5 were just walking through a long, boring, empty hallway or something. There is so little in the world that this game at times that I would call it a walking simulator. The dialog is interesting in this game, when taking a friendly route, this game is amusing. It is not laugh out loud funny like so many people say, and at times it is just annoying. But I did laugh once through my run through, and other times I enjoyed reading the text.   If you are willing to get passed the hours of mindless walking, then go for it. This game is not as great as anyone says, but it isnt bad. Do not pay 10 dollars for it. 5 might even be too much in my opinion.

This game annoys me, not because of any reason specifically, but because i really don't know what to make of it.   On the one hand, the premise of the game is amazing; the story is interesting and the characters loveable and hateable in equal measures. It has the ability to make you feel the strongest of emotions and make you make decisions you would in real life. The soundtrack is first rate; it's original and fun, setting the tone perfectly, and some of the puzzles are really quite well designed.  On the other hand, well the game just isn't very fun. From a personal standpoint, the whole 'Bullet Hell' combat system just serves as an irritant rather than an enjoyable game mechanic, not to mention enemies pop up constantly forcing you to tolerate this mechanic. While some of the puzzles are enjoyable and make you think, others are downright confusing and make no sense. There isn't one overriding reason why i don't like the game, but it just wasn't clicking with me. Other people will enjoy this game and have enjoyed this game, and gotten a massive amount out of it. Me, personally, i don't think i'm even going to be able to complete the game.  The worst thing about this game though is the community it spawned. the FNAF fan club was bad, Undertale's is diabolical. Never has a larger mass of scum and cancer gathered together over the floor of a game like an itchy, red blanket before. You get lynched for even mentioning a single negative thing about a game, what's that people say about stupid people in large groups?  This game is not inherently bad, far from it, it's one of the most original and thought out games i've played in a very long time, and stands out in a sea of mediorcity and Pay2Win monkey grinders. But i just don't like the game.

Welp...that ended badly. I got to (what I assume is) close to the end until the game's greatest weakness caught up with it. But, I will make this a fair review, so I'll list the positives.  -There really aren't any unlikeable characters, all of them a pretty tolerable, and some are great (Sans and Papyrus are the highlight characters) -The writing can be quite good at times. -The history and lore of the monsters is pretty cool, I wish it was given more focus aside from one area though.  You've probably noticed that I haven't praised the actual gameplay, and there is a reason for that. The gamplay is either barebones or deceptive. The game's whole gimick is that you don't have to kill anyone. This sounds kind of cool at first, but I quickly found how shallow this is. There is really no difference between sparing a monster and killing it. The only difference is if you kill it, you gain exp(I'll come back to this). The game gives you no real incentive to be peaceful, except to get the best ending(which apparently you only get on you're second playthrough? ♥♥♥♥ that). However, the only way to have any fun is to be peaceful, because the combat otherwise is ♥♥♥♥ing awful, and mindnumbingly boring. But even being peaceful gets boring after fighting enemies multiple times, since the Act tab is so shallow and the way to 'beat' enemies never changes. Bosses become a hell of a lot less fun to fight after 10 times of trying.  Now I think it's time to get to Undertale's biggest flaw. Obviously the best way to play the game is going the peaceful route. But, the game is no longer an RPG if you play this way. As I've mentioned before, you don't gain exp if you don't kill anything, therefore you gain no levels, and most importantly, you're HP doesn't ever increase. You are stuck with 20 hit points. In RPGs, your character is meant to grow along with the enemies, so that while the game is still challenging, you stand a chance. In bullet-hell games, the game starts out easier, and as your skill as a player increases, the difficulty increases. Undertale fails at both of these. The enemies get stronger as you progress, but you have no way to get better in an RPG manner. Also the style of the combat changes so often that you have no time to truly better your skills. This is what beat me in the end, as I was dying to regular enemies. Now to be fair, I've never been that great at bullet-hells, but I love RPGs, and that is what the game is advertised as. Sorry I was expecting an RPG to be an RPG.  There are more problems as well. The whole game feels like a shameless tumblr pandering scheme. With the 'lol so random' humor that the game uses too often, and all of the LGBTQZXVN+ characters and relationships in the game. Undertale does nothing out of the box or provocative. It stays so safe.  Also, there a zero settings in game at all. You can't change the volume,controls or aspect ratio, which is unacceptable and inexusable in modern pc gaming.  I have no desire to finish Undertale, which I think speaks a lot to the game's ability to make me truly engaged with my character's plight.The plot is certainly nothing fantastic. All in all, Undertale isn't awful, but it has some major problems that should be known.  5/10

(Summary at the bottom)   This game is not bad on its own terms, but I have to vote my conscience and I personally did not find anything to like about this game.  I grabbed it because of the enormous hype surrounding it and especially because there were comparisons to Earthbound, a beloved game from my childhood, but I don't understand the hype or the comparison.  If you are considering getting this game, you should understand what you're getting into:  This game is very heavily focused on story and atmosphere. Gameplay is repetitive, trial-and-error, and the encounter mechanics and inventory system are bare-bones and in some cases clearly not thought out with particular care.   But these flaws are not all mistakes; some of these problems were introduced DELIBERATELY in order to emphasize the writing even more. Much like trying every dialog option in an RPG, the trial-and-error encounters encourage you to try a variety of actions in combat and see the prose that results, enjoying them for their own sake.  Since this game is fairly story-centric and it's hard to get any info on the story without spoiler, I will summarize the first hour: You meet a flower who acts all weird and then this creepy goat lady tries to kidnap you but you convince her not to kidnap you, but she still gives you a big long hug which is extra creepy since she just met you. Then you meet the flower again and he acts even weirder and says some ominous stuff that makes so little sense I don't even remember it even though it was like 30 minutes ago. Then you go through a long sequence of two skeletons trying to capture you but not really that hard while they odd-couple argue amongst themselves, all the while assisted by cute dogs trying to murder you but not really that hard.  The take-away for that summary is that the game is 'quirky', but for me personally a lot of sequences fell flat. I think the game is supposed to be funny, but I didn't understand the joke half the time. Why was the clingy goat lady funny? Why is turning around really slowly to shake someone's hand funny? I think a lot might be lost because of the graphics. Going back to the Earthbound comparisons I had heard about: the comedic tone of Earthbound is very Japanese, and in true Japanese style, it conveys most of its comedy through its writing. Undertale seems like it was trying to convey more of its ideas graphically, but this means that  unlike Earthbound, the low-res pixel art holds it back,  which is why I think I'm not getting a lot of it. A very overrated game.  That's basically my review in a nutshell. I really hate to give this a negative review, but lemme still talk about it honestly. After all, this is a debated thing, and I do want to share my honest opinion.  First things first: THIS IS NOT RECOMMENDED FOR THOSE WHO ARE BORED EASILY! Basically, what i'm trying to get here, is that this isn't your typical rpg game. In a positive and a negative way. First, this game is awesome. It really is. It's story, its world, it's unique gameplay, it's characters, Papyrus being my favorite... it has everything an rpg needs to be an RPG  The story is of course essential to an RPG-type game, and it's strong in this game. It might not be as fleshed out as others are, but its strong. The world is very engaging and you want to know more about it as you go on. However, you don't get as much information from this world as you would want. After awhile, you want to know more about it, and you just don't get the info you want to make it more interesting and loveable. And as of course when its a story-driven game, it's pretty linear, so that's another setback to its engagement. Also, the story will get boring after awhile as well. Not terribly, but in a way that you will feel a bit unsatisfied.  Fortunately, the characters in this game are amazing. All of them feel unique and exciting, and some you will definitely love. Buuut, again, after some time, they get pretty old, jokes included. Not saying all of them would, opinion is an opinion of course, but I'm sure even you will get those vibes that you just dont want to hear his or hers talking, perhaps you even want to skip some dialoque. But, that isn't saying they are poorly executed. The character development is so good my brains we're filled with hopes and ideas like waterfalls. Gameplay is definitely the most unique part in the whole game. The gameplay in Undertale is centered around talking and negotiating battles rather than fighting, with an option of fighting. These battles can be ended with 3 ways in total: Kill, spare or flee. Killing of course gives you gold and xp, but also can trigger either the neutral ending or genocide ending (which we will get to a in a few moments). Sparing is the hardest thing to do basically. In battles you can negotiate the enemy with talking, cheering, flirting, or even threatening. These of course are based on the enemy. You can achieve sparing or fleeing with doing some of these options. Either the enemy is influenced by some kind of hatred or sadness etc., you can respond to these emotions with these kind of options, but some are effective, and some are not. Then, when enemy is ready to end the battle, you can spare the enemy. Then you can also flee battles, which aren't that easy. You still have to do these things in order to leave a battle.At first, you get the hang of it, but it gets gradually harder and harder, and you even might have to look up ways to do these with some enemies.  Oh yeah, the fighting. Now the enemy attacks you usually with projectiles, that can induce a lot of damage. Some enemies are really easy, but some are hard as hell. How you respond to these projectiles is this little box on top of the option bars and below the enemy avatar, where you control a heart-looking object. This is your soul, and once a projectile hits it, you lose health (duh). How you fight back, is with this timing system. You have to hit the right spot in the right time with a straight line going side to side. If you hit the right spot, you deal a significant amount of damage to the enemy. A perfect hit might even kill enemies with one shot. This is a bit dissapointing for me atleast. I just wished they would've put more effort into fighting as much as in negotiating.  But then, theres the endings. And there's not just 2 endings, but 3. These endings can be triggered with some of the options in battles or befriending some of the characters. It's amazing to see how much devotion was put into making these kind of endings. 3 ways to end a great game. 3 ways to see the story come into a end. 3 ways to say goodbye in a satisfying fashion. (I dont really want to talk about the endings, cuz spoilers :P)  All in all, its a great game. I liked the majority of it, but towards halfway to the end, it became a bit dull and boring. Thats why, I'm recommending this to those who enjoy story-driven games, rather than full-action games.  7/10 Characters and Story (I would've given it a 6/10, but I loved the characters so much that I decided to give it a 7). 9/10 Gameplay and Endings (Same category because the gameplay influnced so much into the endings). Overall rating: 8/10 ( Again, I would've given it a 7/10, but because of the sheer devotion to this game work put into developing the characters, I would gladly give it a 8/10).

Cons: ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The characters are extremely annoying. Almost all of the humor falls flat. The fact that people consider this to be the best RPG. The fact people try to compare this to Earthbound. The fact this game has a fandom.   In closing, it's not a bad game. It's not good by any stretch of the mind, but it's not terrible. What it falls victim to is the fact that people act like it's some masterpiece. It isn't. But with the amount of budget-priced games on Steam that are much better than this, don't pay $10. I quit playing before I got to Snowdin Town and got a refund. Regret: 0/10
