In one sentence, Undertale is a role-playing interactive story, with bullet-hell game play elements.  Right off the bat, I want to say that the strongest part of the game is the music. I'm super impressed by the music, and even as I type this now I am listening to a remix album that I highly recommend listening to, even if you never have or will play the game. It sets the mood in all the right ways - it's super charming, whimsical, fun, somber, tense, and everything else music needs to be to engaging and entertaining. If tobyfox never makes video games ever again, I hope he at least keeps making music.  Sadly, for me it's all downhill from here. Starting with the lore. I love lore and whenever I got hints of it I just ate it up. But unless I missed a lot, it's very scarcely delivered. There is one area with lore written on the walls and one area where characters tell you a story. Besides those two information dumps, it's not like you can wander around the world and pick up bits of history here and there. It's a shame, because I would have really enjoyed getting more information about the setting of the game. Most of the information is about characters, however.  Which is my next gripe with the game. Characters in the game are pretty frustrating to me. Now, obviously I am in the minority because everywhere I look people talk about how attached to the characters they were and I just do not see it. Almost every character you meet tries to kill or hurt you at some point. While they attack you they say the most random non-sequitur stuff. Even the non-combatant characters mostly just say nonsense. I think this is the games try at humor. Now, I thought I loved dadaist humor, but Undertale takes it to a different level. Maybe it's trying too hard to be random and funny, or maybe I'm just a jaded old man, but the 'humor' in the game did not connect with me one tiny bit. And the dialogue that isn't trying to be funny comes off as pretentious.  I don't really want to comment on the story of the main character and what happens to you as you play, too much, because people seem to think there's something to be spoiled. I don't know why, as when I got to the end I was still confused why people guard the game like there's some sort of big reveal that will blow your mind. Once again, maybe I'm a jaded old man, but I feel like if I had read or watched the game's story before playing it myself I wouldn't have lost out on anything. I thought the ending was weak and boring, and mostly just frustrating for ... reasons. Out of respect for spoiler-phobes I won't get into it now.  So the game play is pretty simplistic. You ever play the Bioshock 2? You know that hacking mini-game? Basically dealing damage takes the form of a horizontal bar at with a needle moving left-to-right across it. The objective is to land the needle as close to the middle as you can to deal the highest amount damage points. After dealing damage, consuming an item, or checking on the opponent, it is their turn and you are tasked to a large variety of bullet-hell patterns throughout the game. It gets pretty hectic and ties into the character or story in creative ways. I thought it was pretty well done, and I was lucky enough to never die, except for the 'final' 'boss' once, although I came real close a couple times.  That's Undertale from my perspective. For a moment I was going to say I feel bad for not liking it, but I shouldn't. Not everything can be great for everyone. It's just not a game for me. I look for a very different kind of story when playing games that are story focused. And that's okay. I'm very happy for everyone who has enjoyed Undertale, and I hope they get tons more games like it in the future.  Peace.

Undertale's gameplay is simplistic and minimally interactive. The bullet hell minigame is something you would only have to play for 5 seconds in a WarioWare game, but here it is the center piece of the combat. It is a really dumb mechanic, and one of the most abstract and asinine ways to contextualize the player's input I've ever seen.   There are very few additional systems in the game for the player to interact with, things that might be taken for granted in other RPGs. No skills, no stats, there are only 2 inventory slots, there's no overworld, it's completely linear for the most part and so on.   Furthermore, the breaking of the fourth wall is a particularly lazy and pretentious story telling method for anything that isn't pure comedy. Is it still 1998 here, and everyone's impressed that Pycho Mantis knows you played Castlevania? Hidden save files and commenting on the player's meta gaming is not clever. Any game that has good storytelling and engaging, properly contextualized mechanics has no need to break simulation and rib the player for playing the videogame like it's a videogame. A more impressive game would be able to tell this story using its characters, and give the player something engaging to do while it was doing that.

DISCLAIMER  Before you read this review, please grant this one request: read the whole thing. If you cannot do that, than please just read the last two paragraphs. I am not trying to take away any joy you find in this game, I am just stating how I feel. Thank you for reading this.   REVIEW   This game is alright at best in my opinion, but what has happened to it saddens me.  Firstly, I must applaud the creators, for what has been produced by such a small team is quite impressive. In addition, this game's premise is creative and the art style, though pixelated, pontificates the great effort put into the game.  With that said, this game has some issues in terms of character personalities and plot lines.  I oft begin with the plot. It is rather rudimentary in terms of the protagonist's goal, to leave the underground. However, in the first moments of the game, the player is introduced to a morality system of sorts (the aforementioned 'premise'), which is interesting yet leads to all players thinking that they MUST take the high moral road. This is problematic, as it leads to a one minded way of thinking that stifles the game's intellectual creativity. Ergo, if you go into this game as biased player (meaning someone has told you something about the game) or an emotionally sensitive player, you will fall into the standard demographic of players. As I observe some of the other reviews, I see that there are some people who agree with this notion.  Now, I believe the best way to address the character flaws is to describe my experience with the game. I bought this game around late September early October 2015, and I had heard nothing about this game whatsoever besides the name itself. I will save my breath and tell you this, I am dry, sardonic, misanthropic, and cynical, so I got what many would call 'The Genocide Ending' on my first playthrough. Yes, I was under the impression that the introductory statements about sparing creatures was supposed to be sarcastic, and that the player was supposed to act ironically and kill everything like in what the public would call 'A Standard RPG'. Consequently, once I defeated the final boss of that ending, I never launched the game afterwards for awhile. Hence, I was under the impression that game was supposed to have a dark or 'Edgey' ending and that I did what I could. Of course later I realised that there were more endings and I began to experiment a bit more.  You may be thinking two things:  'You must of been biased, nobody would get THAT ending on their first time.' or 'Wow, you are a really terrible person.'  However, whatever you may have thought, I feel that I ought to justify why I got such an ending. As I previously mentioned, I was nonplussed by the level of seriousness in the early stages of the game. Therefore, I failed to take the message seriously. Secondly, and this is where the character flaws come into play, I hated every single character in this game. 'Hated' is a bit of an understatement as well, I would much rather say that I LOATHED EVERY ONE OF THEM WITH EVERY GRAM OF WILL THAT I HAVE. Now I know that such a statement is an opinion, but come on, they have such archetypal personalities. Let's see: every motherly figure ever, check; deceptive antihero framed to be the villain with a tortured backstory, check; secret villain who is only revealed later on, check; the most annoying, insufferable, childish, idiotic, excuse for a character with a 5 year-old's sense of humor, GIGANTIC CHECK. There are more archetypes, but I tire of listing them. In addition, there is a segment of the game where, right after you are introduced to a character, they interupt you multiple times immediately making a slightly impatient person hate them. Oh, and that character who I demonstrated a sever disliking to, happens to be the centre of comedy in most of the game.  While I am already on the topic, the comedy in this game is meant for two demographics, young children (and/or people with an immature sense of humor) and internet dwellers. I hate both of those demographics, and I am not alone. Henceforth, when you get people wincing and sighing at the humor in this game, they most likely find the humor appauling.  There is one more thing however, the saddest thing of all, that I must address. The primary creator of this game, Toby Fox, made this game and did not expect the insane spreading and popularity that ensued. He, like all creators, had an idea, and he wanted to share his idea. The fact the he gained revenue and popularity was great, initially. However, it slowly spiraled downward destroying the reputation of the game. That is why I delayed writing this review. I unsure if complaining so intensly about a game made by mostly one person, but I finally decided to do it. The greatest tragedy of this game, is that anyone who actually enjoyed this game will not be remembered. The people on the internet have ruined this game, and what they have done will never be undone. Toby Fox will not be remembered as the guy who made a poignant game which touched many, but the idiot who spawned another cancerous and disgusting fandom. This is unfair to him, because all he wanted to do was share his idea. Had this game been released around the time that Earthbound, a game that inspired this one, it probably would not have been ruined, due to the fact that less social media existed. You want to know why this game is bad to so many? You want to know why so many people hate this game?  People. YOU people. I do not fully hate this game, but because of all you people this game will be scrutinized, torn apart, and destroyed. It will be left and remembered as a game of the times, which all future generations will laugh at. If you asked me after I finished my first playthrough, I would have reluctantly reccomended this game, but now, I cannot bring myself to recommend this game.  Well done.

Let's start with the good:  - Great soundtrack, for the most part. - Entertaining dialog and a few spectacular jokes. - A ton of clever (and often hilarious) easter eggs if you're willing to look for them. - Papyrus  The bad:  - The characters are all incredibly shallow and generally consist of a gimmicky archetype or one note joke and nothing else.  - The combat system is abysmal. It's an incredibly simplistic bullet hell but with text pompts you have to click through every 5 seconds. There's a few creative gimmicks in later boss battles but everything else is a chore and the polar opposite of fun and that's if you play the 'Pacifist' route which is more involved and what the game clearly wants you to do. Playing different results in even more shallow, repetative gameplay. I get that this is a story driven game and combat isn't the point but that doesn't excuse making gameplay so unpleasant it turns the game into a slog just to see what happens.  - Ugly, muddy graphics. There's some clever spritework here and there but overall the game is a muddy mess that's unpleasant to look at, the player character sprite is especially bad.  The ugly: - Extremely cringy 4th wall breakage. I've seen a lot of inane, awkward LOL WE KNOW YOU'RE PLAYING A VIDEOGAME/READING A WEBCOMIC but this game honestly takes the cake because of how preachy it is. It's a video game, Toby, lighten up.  - Severe lack of technical proficiency. The game hitches and stutters along, even on a high end computer to the point that I was unable to play in fullscreen without getting motion sickness. This is completely inexcusable in a paid product. I've played plenty of other Game Maker games that don't have this problem so it's not an engine issue.  Overall I would not recommend this game unless you really, really like wacky, yet shallow, webcomic style humor and have a huge amount of nostalgia for NES games. There are definitely things to love here but they're mostly overshadowed by awful gameplay, technical ineptitude, and shallow characters.

I know I'll be blasted for my opnion, but I still want to review this game.  In concept it seems like a great way to have an RPG flow down a different river: You don't need to kill anyone to complete it. Great idea! I was intrigued. The flower in the very beginning was entertaining and I was looking forward to playing the game from that point forward.  However, that's where all the positivity stopped for me. I felt like the game was forcing too much onto me to try and get me to like it, and I didn't. The flower was the best part where I felt like they were just trying to do 'something natural'. Everything else felt forced and was a pure turn off for me. Trial and error puzzles were just tedious and annoying. Trying to be funny, old school style, was just not working at this point and seemed as if I was trying to be distracted from the larger picture of the game: They really had no idea what to do with it overall.  I got as far as (to try and remain as spoiler free as possible) 'the house where I forced my way through a doorway to a pair of skeletons'. That was all the more I could take. This may be a great title for some, but it isn't for me. And right at the skeletons is where I lost all interest in playing as I felt I wasn't really playing a game, more just sitting back and moving the main character from room to room in order to further the story. Yes, I'm aware that that is the basis of EVERY RPG, but I had character attachment by then. I had zero care for anything in the game by this point, no understanding of anything that was transpiriing that lead me to try and push farther and farther in order to resolve some epic issue, or whatever.   It was drab, boring, uneventful, and just tried too hard to be something different rather than be something different naturally and get me to care about any of this world.  It is great for some, but I am not one of them.  2/10 - 1 for the concept, and 1 for the flower. Will never play again.

Undertale is a great game with lots of effort put into it. I enjoyed this game for the first hour or so until it became more of a chore than an enjoyable experience. undertale is the game that makes me wish for an 'I guess' option, so treat this vote as that.   this game gets a lot of praise everywhere I go, so because it was on sale, I decided to give it a go, and I don't get why it is praised this much.   as always, let me start with the positive points:  + the battle system is awesome, as a bullet hell fan, I loved it and the variations made it constantly interresting  + the random encouters are not annoying, and I never needed to farm once  + the musics were really cool, and I completely understand the praise the game gets around the music  + this game was a lot shorter than though it would be, and to be honest, I am glad, because it was just the right length for me    while this game as quite a few things going on for him, there are points that didn't work out so well in my opinion:  - a lot of people say that this game hurt their feelings, but it didn't do anything to me, most of the characters were forgetable and they were for the most part a**holes who wanted to either kill me, capture me or stop me from going back to my family (I can only think of 3 who didn't do that: sans, the guy from the lab and the ghost).  - the game has a backstory that didn't interrest me at all, and it didn't make me want to look more into it, as all you do in the entire game is find the barrier to go back home, that backstory is barely mentioned and isn't even used in the main story.  - this kinda goes with my first negative point but the game often made characters appear out of nowhere, makes you kill them and then talks about them as big charaters expecting you to feel bad for killing them. all I knew is that they wanted to kill me, why would I feel bad for defending myself? this felt like a poor attempt at making the game sad more than anything.  - a lot of feature in the game is almost useless, such as the phone, the spare option and the entire act tab  - the graphics look really cool, but am I really the only one who thinks the main character looks ugly?!?    all in all, this game has a great combat system but a (in my honest opinion) poor story. so I would recommend that you get it when it's on sale only if you like bullet hell games, if you want an interresting story with memorable characters though, I recommend you look for something else.   Final rating: 5.5/10

This game was once something I could get behind. A good soundtrack though rather reminiscent of certain other RPG games, decent sprite work, and a story with moderate good flow and characters. But this game in my opinion does not really live up to the hype or deserve it overwhelming praise.  Let's look at all the pros of this game:  - good paced music - good for at least 2 play throughs with genocide and pacifist  - characters though overpraised are still likeable  These points combined with the fact that Toby Fox is an indie developer is impressive.  But there is a problem, this game is hardly the concoction of one person's imagination. Between the many obvious inspirations drawn from other similar games Toby modded before, to soundtrack a little too similar to those of games over a decade old is uncanny. I am not ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on the developer get, game development is hard and cudos to Fox for making something this big.  But my biggest problem is at the core of the popularity of Undertale vs other indie games and the community itself. The fact that Toby was not a one man army is often ignored by people, a common excuse given by people blindly defending the game is that he worked alone.  Tony had help, from the actual user Temie (yes Temie is the title of a artist who helped Toby), as well as the plentiful people providing additional ideas and character concepts.   People ignore this fact and worship a false image of a one man game making machine, the sad part is projects better than this game has solo creators and received none of the attention.  If people would like to stick to RPG themed projects then one must turn no farther then Bethesda fans. The mods for another acclaimed RPG Skyrim give up years of their life to make brand new worlds, mods so massive and packed with delicious content that it would take 1000 Undertales to hold a candle to them. Falskar, Enderal, the forgotten city which has literally won a writing award. All these amazing projects and the authors never received a penny or wanted any. They create for the enjoyment of others even better...and yet we are swooning over ludicrous spaghetti memes?  This brings me to the main problem I have with this community is the cash in fandoms. Things like Undertale have so many Alternative universe's that are exactly the same it makes me ill. Most are pure cringe or pure drivel and keep people from actually enjoying the game normally.  I have gotten off track and shall end here, between overpraise and cringe community I am done with this game.
Tumblr: The game

The absurd level of hype surrounding this game probably had a part in why I didn't enjoy it. It almost made me continue playing just to find out what all the fuss is about. Admittedly with the amount of games I've yet to try this year I wasn't ready to give Undertale a lot of time to pull me in and since it didn't do it right away, I decided to move on to other games.   Apparently Undertale has a bunch of neat ideas later on, but the basics of the combat system put me off from the get-go. I know the fight/act system is a popular topic as a lot of people consider it a strength, but I just didn't find it appealing or fun.  While I don't personally recommend the game, it's probably best to try this one out for yourself.

Three days grade school, three days high school.    Those were awkward.    Three days college. I'm glad I took a day and hitchhiked around the hive. Everybody knows, sting someone, you die.    Don't waste it on a squirrel. Such a hothead.    I guess he could have just gotten out of the way.    I love this incorporating an amusement park into our day.    That's why we don't need vacations.    Boy, quite a bit of pomp... under the circumstances.    - Well, Adam, today we are men. - We are!    - Bee-men. - Amen!    Hallelujah!    Students, faculty, distinguished bees,    please welcome Dean Buzzwell.    Welcome, New Hive Oity graduating class of...    ...9:15.    That concludes our ceremonies.    And begins your career at Honex Industries!    Will we pick ourjob today?    I heard it's just orientation.    Heads up! Here we go.    Keep your hands and antennas inside the tram at all times.    - Wonder what it'll be like? - A little scary.    Welcome to Honex, a division of Honesco    and a part of the Hexagon Group.    This is it!    Wow.    Wow.    We know that you, as a bee, have worked your whole life    to get to the point where you can work for your whole life.    Honey begins when our valiant Pollen Jocks bring the nectar to the hive.    Our top-secret formula    is automatically color-corrected, scent-adjusted and bubble-contoured    into this soothing sweet syrup    with its distinctive golden glow you know as...    Honey!    - That girl was hot. - She's my cousin!    - She is? - Yes, we're all cousins.    - Right. You're right. - At Honex, we constantly strive    to improve every aspect of bee existence.    These bees are stress-testing a new helmet technology.    - What do you think he makes? - Not enough.    Here we have our latest advancement, the Krelman.    - What does that do? - Oatches that little strand of honey    that hangs after you pour it. Saves us millions.    Oan anyone work on the Krelman?    Of course. Most bee jobs are small ones. But bees know    that every small job, if it's done well, means a lot.    But choose carefully    because you'll stay in the job you pick for the rest of your life.    The same job the rest of your life? I didn't know that.    What's the difference?    You'll be happy to know that bees, as a species, haven't had one day off    in 27 million years.    So you'll just work us to death?    We'll sure try.    Wow! That blew my mind!    'What's the difference?' How can you say that?    One job forever? That's an insane choice to have to make.    I'm relieved. Now we only have to make one decision in life.    But, Adam, how could they never have told us that?    Why would you question anything? We're bees.    We're the most perfectly functioning society on Earth.    You ever think maybe things work a little too well here?    Like what? Give me one example.    I don't know. But you know what I'm talking about.    Please clear the gate. Royal Nectar Force on approach.    Wait a second. Oheck it out.    - Hey, those are Pollen Jocks! - Wow.    I've never seen them this close.    They know what it's like outside the hive.    Yeah, but some don't come back.    - Hey, Jocks! - Hi, Jocks!    You guys did great!    You're monsters! You're sky freaks! I love it! I love it!    - I wonder where they were. - I don't know.    Their day's not planned.    Outside the hive, flying who knows where, doing who knows what.    You can'tjust decide to be a Pollen Jock. You have to be bred for that.    Right.    Look. That's more pollen than you and I will see in a lifetime.    It's just a status symbol. Bees make too much of it.    Perhaps. Unless you're wearing it and the ladies see you wearing it.    Those ladies? Aren't they our cousins too?    Distant. Distant.    Look at these two.    - Oouple of Hive Harrys. - Let's have fun with them.    It must be dangerous being a Pollen Jock.    Yeah. Once a bear pinned me against a mushroom!    He had a paw on my throat, and with the other, he was slapping me!    - Oh, my! - I never thought I'd knock him out.    What were you doing during this?    Trying to alert the authorities.    I can autograph that.    A little gusty out there today, wasn't it, comrades?    Yeah. Gusty.    We're hitting a sunflower patch six miles from here tomorrow.    - Six miles, huh? - Barry!    A puddle jump for us, but maybe you're not up for it.    - Maybe I am. - You are not!    We're going 0900 at J-Gate.    What do you think, buzzy-boy? Are you bee enough?    I might be. It all depends on what 0900 means.    Hey, Honex!    Dad, you surprised me.    You decide what you're interested in?    - Well, there's a lot of choices. - But you only get one.    Do you ever get bored doing the same job every day?    Son, let me tell you about stirring.    You grab that stick, and you just move it around, and you stir it around.    You get yourself into a rhythm. It's a beautiful thing. Janet, your son's not sure he wants to go into honey!    - Barry, you are so funny sometimes. - I'm not trying to be funny.    You're not funny! You're going into honey. When you reading all those great rewievs, please, take a moment and read mine. Seriously. They are all wrong. This game is truly, truly bad example of forced hype train.   As a game it is mediocre at best. Combat is primitive, there is no variety in enemies and items, humor is stupid, story is primitive. This is all true, I swear. Listen to me. Something happened to people's minds here, and they all went insane.   The main gimmick of this game, and what supposedly makes it more than primitive turn-based RPG, is the opportunity to 'mercy' your enemies, while gaining no experience. Experience in this game is BAD - that's the thing. Killing things is BAD - that's the other thing. Its primitive and stupid, and i not consider it as a spoiler.  But having one gimmick doesn't make a good game. But for its cost you can always check it out. But beware - it's not that great as everyone tell you it is. Really. Its not that good.

I wanted badly to like this game, and I can understand why so many people do, but sadly at the end of the day it just isn't good enough.  The Good: + The story at its heart is good and indeed is touching at points. + Choices have tangible impact on the world, unlike some much 'bigger' RPGs.  The Mixed: = The writing is an extremely mixed bag. In places, it is very good. Most characters however are pretty much one-dimensional caricatures, with one or two shining exceptions. There's a severe lack of nuance with most characters. = The humor is at times quite entertaining, surprising, and 'meta'/genre-aware. At other points, though, it is dragging, predictable, and repetitive.  The Bad: - Controller support. Does it work? Yes. But there is zero sensitivity for sticks, which is exceedingly annoying. You get 100% speed or zero, with no subtle touches. You may or may not find this as frustrating as I do. - The gameplay....oh dear the gameplay. Undertale is ultimately a bullet-hell game. With poor controls. In which you can't shoot back (  usually  ). I like this in theory, since it makes playing a turn-based RPG a little more interesting. However, unlike most turn-based RPGs, combat has absolutely zero tactics. You have exactly one attack (whether that is attacking or doing the 'right' action to talk them out of fighting). You use your one attack repeatedly. When it's their turn, you dodge. If you are low, you use an item to heal. Each enemy usually only has 2 different attack patterns to dodge. Once you learn them, you can either A: avoid them perfectly quite easily or B: probably still get hit by them, depending on the attack in question and your personal skill at bullet-hell with bad controls. At the end of the day, combat is just BORING. - The grind. Random encounters are exceedingly tedious, given the aforementioned combat system. If you're playing pacifist, it's moderately entertaining the first time you run into a new enemy to figure out how to non-violently defeat them. However, you are then probably going to run into 10 more of them, which you will do THE EXACT SAME THING TO. A genocidal run is even more boring, since you pretty much just attack. - The boss fights. Boss fights manage to be simultaneously boring AND frustrating. Most of them are interminably long and consist solely of you picking the same action (whether it's fight or something passive) over and over again while dodging the same three attacks. - The difficulty. Disclaimer: I am not good at bullet-hell-style games. So I found this game exceedingly frustrating, mostly because the difficulty never really seems to hit a nice middle-ground where things feel challenging but doable. Every single attack/encounter is either trivially easy, or just something to tank through with healing items. Dying is frustrating, you have to start over from a checkpoint and redo a lot of boss fight that is already a boring, same-y grind. If, on the other hand, you're better at bullet-hell-dodging, then honestly it's probably just going to be 100% trivial for you. Non-bosses are pretty much never difficult, regardless of your skill, with one or two exceptions (  god help you if you don't Clear Mind before Talk-ing to a Madjick and get your controls jumbled  ). - The repetition. There are high points of this game. But so much of it is just beating the same dead horse over and over again. As previously mentioned, boss fights normally consist of doing the same thing for 10+ turns with zero variation. Going through an area consists of fighting the same random encounter (maybe two) 5 times. Characterization of many individuals consists of them meeting the same trope 10+ times. Dying at any point, which is pretty easy to do, will cause you to have to repeat some amount of this repetition. No place was this more aggravating to me than with   Mettaton  . The first time it was funny. The second time it was a callback. By the fourth or fifth time you encounter them, it's just an annoying, worn out joke, that culminates in a frustratingly long and boring boss fight. - NG+ mechanic. A particularly frustrating example, in which you can't   get the good ending   unless you play the game again. Yes, I know that you can beat the game, then savescum to get it, but that just strikes me as cheating and not what was really intended, as well as just kind of making the narrative pointless.  Tl;dr: Undertale's strengths of story and humor can't balance out the repetition, boringness, and occasional frustration of the actual gameplay, as well as its semi-frequent flubbing of its strengths. I sadly made the mistake of watching a ~10 minute video of all the funny things that happen and then made the mistake of buying the game, only to find out that that was every single funny part of the game, and the rest is pointless unfun padding out the next highlight.  Recommendation: Go watch someone play it. You'll get all of the good and none of the bad.  P.S. It could be a pretty awesome game if someone actually designed a turn-based RPG with a fully fleshed-out combat system based on the bullet-hell execution (especially if you got bullet-hell the enemy on your attacks)...  P.P.S. Temmie is love, Temmie is life, though.

This game would be fun. It is also ruined, making it impossible to enjoy. You see, the game has no option to actually reset. It's not just well-hidden, or even done by uninstalling and reinstalling.  It just doesn't. So if you were planning on enjoying it fully more than once, well, you're S.O.L. And theres the fact that a game full of secrets has the gall to only give you one chance, on the first playthrough, to find them all. So I hope you can get it perfect in one! Because this game will actively endevour to make you have a worse time if you don't. It' snot that you CAN'T play it over, it's just that the game remembers your choices, and gives you no chance to find anything you missed. That, and if you enjoyed it the first time you played, well thats it. The game will never let you do that again. But I hear you: 'Isn't this game all about the weight of choices?' Yes! Which is why it's bull that it never lets you see how things would have gone differently. Not to mention that it's a VIDEO GAME: the entire point is escapist entertainment, which it withholds on the basis of no more than '♥♥♥♥ you, you didn't do it right.'   P.S: This is all coming from somone who played full pacifist, and just wanted to see if I missed a few things. It's even worse if you went with the alternate route.  TL;DR: A great game, ruined by it's inability to play more than once. Defective product.

This is my first impressions of the game. I got the Neutral ending and it didn't really inspire me to get the other endings which is a shame. I probably won't replay it, at least not for a long while. Some of the characters were actually pretty annoying but thankfully you can get rid of them early. Interesting bullet hell mechanics in the fights and a lot of mind♥♥♥♥ and meta commentary. Music ranges from catchy to great. I got this gifted to me. Unsure if I'd spend my own money on it. Toby Fox doesn't know when to let go of a gag sometimes. This is gonna be a hit or miss for most, for sure. I can't say for sure if you personally will enjoy it or not. My initial reaction to the game before playing it was apathy. Sadly, that hasn't changed much. But I got what I wanted out of it, a quick little RPG with enjoyable music and unique mechanics and ideas.  Chances are if you're already sold on this game you will enjoy it. It didn't click with me emotionally or thoughtfully in any meaningful manner. I think this is one of those games where you absolutely 100% have to be invested in the cast of characters, and I wasn't entertained by or attached to any of them.  It relies on the player forming a connection with the cast so it can take you where it's trying to go, but if you don't connect it falls flat on its face and I feel like that's what happened to me. I was near gritting my teeth every time Sans and Papyrus were telling one of their puns.  There's really no doubt about the fact that if I'd replayed it two more times with the two different routes I would've gotten more out of it, but I was just not spurred on to do so.  I couldn't tell you why this is, perhaps because my number one goal in the game from the start was leaving the underground alive, and not necessarily making friends. That, and I tend to value my own well-being and safety above everyone elses. That's not me trying to be contrarian, that's a core part of my personal philosophies.  That said I feel like the message of the game was pretty hamhanded. I was figuratively rolling my eyes toward the end when light was shed on certain parts of the game. There's nothing wrong with a game giving you another option than just killing, I'm a big fan of, say, Fallout, where you can do a lot of different skill or speech checks to bypass conflict in favor of keeping the peace between everyone, but I feel like this game got grating in its criticism.  Sometimes a situation actually does call for surgery with a shotgun.  In the end, this game was nothing special as a whole for me, but it did have pieces of it that made me laugh a bit, or were otherwise enjoyable.  If you're NOT anything like cynical old me, hey, it might just click for you. And like I said earlier, if you already know about it and think it sounds like a cool thing, you'll probably enjoy it.

If you're only looking to play this game because of the reviews it got (and would otherwise not bother) then I would recommend not getting it - it didn't change my opinion and I only finished a play-through because I felt I had to.  It was alright, but considering the ocean waves of praise it was getting I was expecting a lot more. Some very good music, a number of genuinely funny bits, a lot of 'dang, that was clever moments'… but a great number of frustrating combat experiences where I was left reloading saves to take on boss fights multiple times. I became very impatient with the game and just wanted it to end. It also has a very 'Internet lulz' sense of humor to it, the type of humor funny to 30-something forum posters.  Again, the game was alright. I don't have a nostalgia for any of the kind of aesthetics the game presents, and a general disinterest in purposefully touching story lines in games (I'll read a book or watch a film instead). Unless you're actively interested in these retro, artsy, 'one-guy-made-it-but-not-really' kinds of games, I'd recommend just standing aside. You're not going to miss out. It's not that complex or deep of a story.

Way overly hyped. Good but the hype makes it unenjoyable because it's all like OMG IT'LL CHANGE YOUR LIFE about the ending, and yet it's just 'they all live happily ever after'. The characters are said to be like 'real humans' but they're all generic archetypes. Alphys is the Otaku with a Tragic Backstory, Undyne is Vriska+Meenah, Toriel is just incredibly stifling mom + ex-wife of king. Asgore is just nice guy who has to kill you. Asriel has no real personality given besides friend that turned evil. Papyrus is the idiot with a heart of gold, Sans is the slacker with a heart of gold and a dark secret. Mettaton is just egotistic. All servicable as characters and pleasant, but heavily over-hyped to where you're like 'this is all they are?'  Meanwhile the gameplay... the difficulty curve is ridiculous. It's either overpowered or no threat at all, there's no gradual curve, it's just two levels: blisteringly hard or completely easy. The save points are out of date as well. And graphically, it doesn't even really follow retro rules; it's faux-retro, though heavily expressively so. It also uses the music to make you feel emotions even if the scene isn't impactful, much like an Adam Sandler film.  I also disagree with several parts of the story. The 'determination' gag is never fully explained enough to where it doesn't cause a plot hole, and the jokes about no character understanding relationships (both romantic and platonic) makes it harder to bond with them when they're acting insane the whole time. The UI also has issues, I couldn't tell when I could spare enemies at times, and the only way to change the color for it to be more obvious is something you can't backtrack to.  The background character designs (and Undyne and Alphys's) often feel slightly derivative of Homestuck and yet original, a project the creator worked on, but not exactly, so that is more of a non-issue but worth mentioning. The music feels similar as well, but that is due to most of the music in the former being produced by the same person. It is also labelled by the fans as 'Earthbound's spiritual successor' but feels nothing like it.  Furthermore, the message is obvious within 5 seconds. 'You don't have to kill anyone, if you're determined and keep at it and be a good friend it'll all work out.' No interesting other interpretations, just that throughout the whole thing. The item management is non-existent as well, and the bait and switch on the protagonist name was honestly annoying and felt slightly like a betrayal to the player.

Doing well thought-out reviews is a community service, and I do it for my Steam friends. If you don't like my review, thats fine. Down-vote it and move on.  I will not be entertaining any new comments in the comments section below. I answered many questions and addressed many criticisms (which you can read below in the comments sections), and am now done and playing other games. I will most likely be deleting any new comments as to further not encourage any more discussion. Discussion thus far has had limited ability to lead anyone to new understandings, and it is boring.   -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------   There is a fundamental flaw in the core concept that drives this game:    When a monster attacks me of their own free will, and inflicts serious damage, I personally feel obligated to finish off that monster instead of showing mercy. In fact, the term  monster implies exactly that - an evil being.  There is nothing profound about not fighting monsters in an RPG game.    Undertale  has a huge following, and gets alot of community love. I wanted to really like this game, but ultimately, it just made me frustrated and put me in a bad mood. But I gave my money for the game, so here are my thoughts:   Cons:  -The core 'gameplay' where skill is involved, is dodging things bullet-hell style. And I think it is frustrating as heck, as implemented here. There are a few times where you need lots of luck to not take damage.  The fact that I had to go through with alot of this before I could 'spare' a monster was exactly why I finished them off.  -This game is the very definition of linear.  My first and only playthrough of the game took 5 hours with absolutely no backtracking. I was on rails right to the end. This bothers me because I thought, as a gaming community, I thought we had gotten past these RPG dark ages. -I thought the art was fairly poor (backgrounds more so than the character sprites). Lots of hard lines and stark contrasts. Lots of empty 'white' space. -There is humor in this game, but most of it is not for me. Tongue-in-cheek puns kind of stuff. It gets old quick. -There was alot of different character 'themes' that tended to make the whole thing not jive. You have skeletons and gods and animals and some that even looked alien. Levels where the same. -Most puzzles were mild annoyances instead of being clever or requiring serious thought. -Further, once a puzzle mechanic was introduced once, it most often was never used again (ie the flower bridges, shooting gallery, snowball golf thing, etc.) -The main character looked quite ugly and disheveled, which to my knowledge, had nothing to do with the storyline. -The dialogue can be very interruptive at times (yes, I am aware that this is on purpose), and can get old fast. -The actual 'sounds' that the dialogue make are loud and hard. Very annoying over long play sessions.   Pros:  +Music was pretty good. +The storyline gets significantly better towards the end, but you need to sit through about 5 hours to get there. +Replayability is high. +Price is very reasonable. +The 'meta' game thing is fresh.   Clearly, this game just wasn't for me. I am not into breathy, linear RPGs with minimal artistic cohesion. I think the storyline is what everybody loves here, but it was not enough for me to recommend it. Peace.

I feel like one of the few that didn't like this game. A friend of mine really likes this game and having been such a big fan of OFF I had high hopes for what this game could accomplish based on reviews and what my friend had suggested. But, in fact, I requested a refund. There is nothing I find fun about this game. The controls are awkward and go against everything that I've ever been taught in RPG gaming and not in a innovative way but in this convoluted mess of controlls. I should not have to use this much of my keyboard to close a menu, I wasted so much time in the battle screen dying because I kept clicking the wrong button because I can't figure out their absurd mapping scheme. And the battle system itself, while unique, is not fun and probably my least favorite element of this game. I'm sure the battle system has some big revelation later in the game later on but initially it's just not fun to play and creates way more of a headache than a challenge. The music is atrociously repetitive, the jokes are horrible, the dialogue drags on and on and on and tells you nothing and hitting the x button will scroll you through it but you still have to hit enter AFTER that just to close the dialogue box. Not to mention it won't recognize you are trying to interact with something unless you face it (it doesn't auto turn). The puzzles are boring if not extremely easy, the story is not in any way intriguing off the bat. A lot of reviews praise the story so I'm sure it gets interesting but you have to wade through so much garbage to get there that the game looses any value. I have zero interest in the story let alone when compared against everything I dislike in the game play. I wish I could get through it enough to see what everyone is talking about but I gave it more than a fair chance and I don't see myself regretting putting it down.

>The 2015 edition of ''Help, my tears are crying'' game.<  UnderTale is a carefully crafted game with psychotic twists placed throughout the game. It's an amazing game that has quirky humour and lovable characters, an unique battle system that makes the game original for it battle sequences. Music that shakes your whole body with emotion. And its strongest point, a hidden story that is out of this world.  I'm clueless on how Toby have achieved that with the budget of a 12'' Subway sandwich. But he done an amazing work and by all means he deserve fame. This game, UnderTale. It's seriously wakes waves and tremors of emotion if you REALLY get involved in the story. As a personal confess, the true final boss fight had me crying the whole time. I didn't wanted to fight back, i wanted to stop. But with determination, i've carried on and passed through. And it really paid off at the end with a satisfying end to close the story and making you feel you've done the best for everybody you encountered during your journey to get back home.   UnderTale is a master piece to my eyes, it takes the throne when it comes to story and emotional situation. I'm giving this game a solid 10 / 10. Would have gave 11, but we'll be realistic. Toby has bestowed upon us an amazing game to us, the players, and i will be eternally in his admiration.

I've been playing RPGs since the mid 90's and have a healthy understanding of what makes one great. All unnecesary flexing aside, this is one of the most well done games, RPG or otherwise, that I've ever played.  It's challenging, writing is impeccable and frankly astounding that it was done by a single person (MASSIVE respect Toby Fox). The feel is that of a puzzle, strategy, and RPG rolled into one. The battle system is totally unique and somehow has elements of timed accuracy (think golf games), Final Fantasy style strategery, and of course the completely original mercy system... The humor is so on point that I've laughed out loud at a several junctions, can't wait to finish it and restart with a different approach. The beauty lies in the adaptability and will absolutely be replayed over and over.
Just play it, everyone else is right, it's incredible

Can you, a small child who has just fallen down into a large cavern, survive in a world full of monsters whom want your soul? An interesting question, that's for sure. Do you have the determination to make it through? Undertale is quite the experience. While the primary arc of the game is quite serious, it does a great job of weaving decent amounts of humor to help those rough times melt away... if not slightly.  In playing it, I felt like I was playing a game in the vein of EarthBound, one of my favorite games of all time.  The Good : The Music, the plot twists, the various smashing of walls, the unique battle system, and the fictional world. The Bad : I'm not sure how well younger players would be able to appreciate this game. It can get quite serious, and in order to truely be a hero, you're going to be playing the game on a budget, and constantly solving puzzles. I also kinda wish the ending went a little differently, and I truely mean a little differently. In any case, not a showstopper.  The Ugly : That stupid troll. (You'll know what I mean once you start playing.)  Overall : I think this is a game any EarthBound fan would enjoy. I also think the game could be liked by many others.  There's lots of care baked into the pie that is this game. The dev team should feel proud.  Great work guys!

This is genuinely the best 'experience' I have ever had. Not just a game or a story. Undertale is genuinely an achievment in story-telling and I have never experienced something that has moved me so deeply in any medium (film, books, art...etc)   I HIGHLY RECCOMEND GETTING THIS~

It's perfect. This is quite honestly one of the best games I've ever played in my life. I absolutely recommend this game to everyone. The game has the humor and storytelling of Earthbound and Chrono Trigger, and I'd argue that it's on par with both of those games.   - Gameplay:  This is a turn based RPG at heart, the battles consist of timed attacks akin to Paper Mario, or if you prefer a more peaceful route, you can try to negotiate, hug, flirt, play, and even pet monsters to try to win the fight without violence. Defending yourself against attacks takes you to a brief bullet-hell segment, where you move a tiny heart around the screen dodging all manner of projectiles. The very active battle system entierly breaks up the monotomy of traditional JRPGs like Final Fantasy, Dragon Warrior, etc. Turn based RPGs aren't generally my cup of tea, but this one keeps it engaging enough to keep it from being tedious.  There's also no grinding for level ups. Monster encounters are actually few and far between for the most part, and once you defeat a boss in an area, the random encounters stop, allowing you to explore and find the MANY secrets in the world.  My first playthrough took me roughly 9 to 10 hours, but I got it AGAIN to replay on Steam.   - Story:  I'll do my best to avoid spoilers, but it's so hard because by the end of your first playthrough, all you'll want to do is talk about this game. This is one of those games with so beautiful of story that will stay with you forever. There are three endings, each one is so brilliantly unique and staggeringly different from the other two. The ending you get is determined on how you treat the creatures on your journey. NOBODY has to die, but that's up to you to decide. Your actions in this game have incredibly deep, and sometimes perminant consiquences. The 'true' ending is the single most satisfying ending of any game I've ever played, and I hope you're able to find it for yourself.  The game also is very aware when you try to do something cute. Not far into the game, you're presented with a difficult situation, maybe you screw up, or choose violence, and spill blood. You're very quickly called out. So you feel bad, and load up an old save just before and do it right this time. Instead of being called out for killing, you're called out for going back to change things. This game knows when you're trying to be cute, and you WILL be called out. It's a very new and exciting experience.   - Presentation:  The game has very NES style graphics. A lot of indie developers take the 8-bit route as an excuse to be lazy. Theres so many games that use 80's sprites nowadays that it's just getting silly. Undertale is one of the few that uses this graphical style to GREAT effect. Everything is quite plain when it needs to be, and yet so colorful and bright at other times.  The chiptune music is some of the best. Period. It performs the job of conveying feelings flawlessly, and I still can't get the catchy as hell tunes out of my head. I find myself listening to them on my phone constantly. There are dozens of tunes in this game I could listen to for hours on end. I've found myself entering a new area, having the music stop, and going back a zone to listen to it a little longer. There's hype as hell boss music, creepy and unsettling tunes for the darker moments, and some tunes that just made me burst into a fit of laughter. Every song feels VERY good, and theres a TON of them.   - Overall feel:  It's not until you play through the entire game that you understand the 'theme' of the game. There were parts where I was as uneasy as wandering through a horror game, there were parts that felt right at home in a game for children. There was plenty of good Disney-family-level comedy, as well as some more adult-level humor. Sometimes the game preaches the values of honesty and love and friendship like a kid's story, and other parts that were absolute terror-inducing nightmare fuel. It's an absolute rollercoaster and I loved every second.   - Final thoughts:  Please buy this game. Please play it all the way through, and find the 'true' ending. I'd give anything to lose all my memory of this game just so I could play through it again for the first time. THATS WHY I NEED TO LIVE THAT EXPERIENCE AGAIN THROUGH YOU.  10/10 It's the perfect game.
A charming game filled with loveable characters, great music, fun gameplay and amazing fourth wall breaks. It could really do without certain internet references, but they're not too in-your-face.

OK, so, after having some time to actually think about the game, I thought I should probably give a more in-depth review. So here we go.  This game is ingenious. It has unique, three-dimensional characters that are often impossible not to fall in love with. It's got adorable, dweeby jokes and important messages about the way video games are typically intended to be played. If you're not down with dorky and often juvenile (though clean!) humor, bullet hell mechanics, absurdly challenging boss battles that you will have to replay repeatedly to get through, or confronting the morality of your game-related choices, this probably isn't the game for you.  I do feel tempted to complain about the in-battle puzzles - some of them are not only difficult, but counterintuitive - but I also feel like this is the point, as you can get through a few battles without solving them and still get a decent ending.  So, in conclusion, this is still the best RPG I've ever played and all the others can go suck it.

Pretty good game. I'll give it... 8/10 I guess. Its not terrible but it isn't the greatest thing ever made.  Anyway here goes. The game involves a child who falls into the underground where monsters reside due to a war long ago between humans and monsters. Long story short your goal is to escape the underground and this can be done in multiple ways. You can kill everyone, you can be neutral and do what you think is best at the time, or you can be a pacifist.  Each of these play styles will grant their own story dialog and possible hardships.    You are going to have a bad time if you do a Genocide run.     Not all enemies are the same. Doing a pacifist run you need to figure out how to spare them or flee. Sometimes a fight is inevitable and you will have to hurt your enemy. The game has plenty of humor and jokes in it. That said sometimes doing certain things in a fight can have humorous outcomes.  The game will remember if you replay it. It will also remember if you did a Genocide run. Would advise a pacifist run before you do a Genocide run unless you want to remove your games save file for a fresh start. There was also a hardmode but it seems to end after the first area and unsure if that will ever be completed. Leaning towards it won't be completed.  Steam achievements aren't a thing and probably won't be either.  In the end I had fun, I had humor, it has a story but you need to dig around sometimes to find it. Might also need to do all 3 play styles to get the full story out of it.   It was a good use of $10 imo.

I had high expectations for at the start and those expectations were thoroughly sated from going through this little treasure of a game. Undertale, a game that takes place in an underground area where monsters tthat lost to humans in a long ago live trapped due to a magical force field. You fall down the hole and end up in the underground searching for a way out. The game combines elements of earthbound and an adventure type game where you make choices in every fight to deal with the enemy. The battling combines two things, RPG mechanics and bullet hell which can come off as being a bit hard but considering I did a pacifist run (Where you kill no one and you gain no experience) I assume the game isn't too harsh on bullet hell. This game is amazing though. Amazing music, characters, story... pretty much this game is nearly perfect and while I do have a small annoyances with some parts, to be honest, it is so pointless to complain about it. The game gives off a nostalgic feeling as if the creators knew exactly what to do to make a good game, a good RPG that can make you laugh, cry and just smile. Honestly, this is a game that is worth the cost and while only having around 6-8 hours or so gameplay, it is still worth 10 dollars. The game had the feeling of mother 3's goofiness as well as character and story development. It had a nostalgic feel of cave story to me, possibly because of the character in general. 9.75/10

Only one game out of all the games I have ever played, has ever convinced me to stop playing it, even though I know there is more content, more story, more character development, and cooler boss fights.  This is the game which did that, in the best possible sense.  Portal's story came close, when I needed to burn my beloved weighted companion cube. I cried for hours and eventually returned to my laptop to finish the level. Curiosity about the rest of the game pushed me past my desire to halt the storyline at a place where my cube was still safe and unharmed.  That's right, I'm heartless enough to burn my weighted companion cube, out of sheer curiosity towards future puzzle solving.  Undertale stopped me from playing undertale.  I don't know about what happens in Undertale, completely. I don't want to. It's that brilliant.  A seemingly negative game trait (a player not wanting to continue playing) is actually a great way to describe this game in general. What seems like an insult is actually an incredible compliment on the developer's creativity.  That is my highest compliment.  Oh, and it has bullet hell mechanics, and a killer robot sings you a love song.  Are you, like, so hyped for the destruction of humanity?

Why is this game so good? The graphics really put me off of it in the begining, but now that I've reached what I'll call the end of the second act, I'm in love with this game. There's no way I ever would have seen this coming, but this game is fantastic. Pick it up asap!!

There's nothing more to write about this game. Nothing more to read. It's magical. It's splendid. It will blow your mind. It will challenge your ideas of how games can touch you, dazzle you, and surprise you.  The music is incredible. The art is perfectly suited for the task at hand--sucking you into another world and refusing to unhook its tentacles from your brain.  The first playthrough is worth the price of admission. I was going to write a glowing review after finishing the game with 8 hours on the clock, but then I played through it a second time. Wow. Words fail to describe how incredible the game gets in the second playthrough, just how much material isn't available during your first trip through Undertale's charming subterranean prison.  The soundtrack alone is worth $20. Don't read this, just buy the game. Play it. You won't regret it. Mr. Fox, I doff my hat to you for creating one of the finest 'video games' the world's seen in, of all things, RPG Maker. Well done, sir. Well done. It's interesting battle system is what intrigued me the most that made me continue to play. As I finally finished the game overall it never truly felt like a game. It felt like a true adventure while admitting that it's a video game. If games ever had to be a piece of art this game very much does justice in that area. (Spoiler free review)  I don't normally write reviews for anything. Honestly, this might be the first review I've ever written. My friend recommended this game to me, and I dove into it not knowing what to expect. At first, I thought it was just going to be some silly game. Don't get me wrong, there are a lot of silly, funny, and completely dorky parts in this game. However, the amount of thought that went into this game's story is incredible. It's amazingly deep and keeps you guessing a bit about what's really going on. The characters that you meet are all dynamic in their personalities and quirks, and the game really succeeds in relating to the player. You don't just feel like you're playing a game - you're a part of it and all that comes out of it.  With the battle system, this gives you a whole new way to approach enemies, and the way that you interact with them and the NPCs changes everything. You pretty much play how you want to, not how the game wants you to. You can rush through it, killing everything and just staying on the main path, or you can take your time helping people and exploring every nook and cranny. There are multiple endings depending on your way of playing, and they're all well written by the developers.  If you aren't sure whether or not this game is worth $10, it most definitely is. I just finished the first playthrough of it in roughly 16 hours, so there's a lot of content for you to enjoy. The game is charming, immersive, and an all-around wonderful experience.
Just play it and you will undertand everything.

I'll be honest; when I first started playing Undertale I didn't see it as anything special. When I played through the first area the only thing I saw in this game was something as a homage to the Mother series and nothing more beyond the usual RPG fare. This quickly changed however when I was forced to fight a main character as the first boss and realized that there's much more to this game than meets the eye.   Undertale is more than just a simple tribute to old RPG's, it's a deconstruction of the entire genre and of the audence that plays it. Every choice you make in the game is significant to the development of the story along with the characters in it and these choices are sometimes not easy to make. More often than not you'll find yourself questioning your own individual character as you make these decisions, wondering if you're really working in the character's best interests or feeling guilty for caving in and killing that one monster for a level up and boosted stats. The fact that most players can't even bring themselves to make the worst choices against the characters they've grown to love in this game should speak volumes as to how well developed they are and how much of an influence they have not just in the game's universe but on the player themself. It is an adventure that I won't forget for a very long time and happily reccomend it to anyone who has $10 and a few hours of free time.   Also may God have mercy on your soul if you choose 100% it for all 3 different endings.
Game of the Year.

Undertale is an RPG that lets you decide the fate of the monsters and humans. It is a game that finds a way to connect you with all the characters, even if they aren't very nice at first. It lets you see through the eyes of a child that can change the fate of the world. When you play this game you'll encounter a variety of random and hilarious moments, along with several that can bring many tears to your eyes. You might be the special guest on a tv series, or even being a puppy that can pet other dogs, there are no limits to your heart and soul. Just remember if it's a good idea to have love at all. Whether you're murdering everything that stands in your path, or teaching everyone that they can live without hurting each other, you are sure to have a blast. You will meet many friends/foes that you can interact with, from a music loving ghost to a unbalanced child. Just remember that every droplet of blood spilled is going to change the outcome. No matter what you choose to do you will stay determined to reach the end, but just make sure it's the real ending...

Undertale is a game that may surprise you at any point in the game. Even after you finish it. Simply put, you're not going to expect some things to happen even if you think you've already seen the unexpected, if this makes any sense. Even after I beat the game for the first time, the game surprised me again and again. There are no clichés here (or very few).  When you first start the game, the first thing you notice is its distinctive graphics. Whether you like them or not, they are very unique and the designers should be proud of their work for breaking out of the typical sprites or cartoonish graphics that are so prevalent in RPGs. Not only the graphics are unique, but you will also see some very particular details in the areas because of them, because of the way the game is designed. A rock is just a rock, or maybe not, you'll see.  Speaking of rocks, you know how in other RPGs, there are items under certain rocks? I didn't find any here. I found something better, dialogue. It's easy to think that the only things that matter in games are better equipment and items, but when you think it through, isn't it more rewarding to have more content for exploring the game? You discover more about the game world and find things you wouldn't otherwise. What's the penalty for skipping side content in other games? You're less strong. Here, the penalty is you don't get to experience stories, you don't get to learn about the world and more importantly, find out if a rock is a rock or a dog. This reminds me of my favorite game (Final Fantasy 8), so I may be biased on this point.  The last point I'll bring up is a very crucial one and very important for me in any RPG: The soundtrack. I have nothing else to say, except it's amazing.  I won't say anymore, because the game is best experienced if you don't know or expect anything about it.  Enjoy it, it's an amazing game.

It almost turned me into a person that frequents tumblr, just to sate my Undertale fix (the funny stuff, not the weird skeleton ♥♥♥♥ing stuff).  My brain shuts down due to the pure emotion that goes through me when I overthink things about Undertale.  I find my self frequently talking like god damn Skeletor.  I amost threw out my back from excessive posing.  I can NEVER look at a cartoon smiling flower the same way ever again without dropping to my knees and almost bawling. You will be accused of being a filthy maggot that eats up anything sappy and emotional. You will be accused of being an edgy turd that is 2edgy4me. I've always had mixed feelings about  EarthBound . On one hand, the quirky humor and intricate plot made up for the fact that I'd always disliked turn-based RPGs. On the other hand, it didn't really innovate on the core gameplay and had a lot of forced grinding. And then along came this game. For me, hearing that it was basically  EarthBound  minus the things I disliked about  EarthBound  was enough to sell me on the idea, but in case you want to know more...  This is a game that not only discourages grinding, it discourages fighting at all. Monsters you encounter will still warp you into a battle screen, but very few of them are actually out for blood, and you can usually find clever ways to pacify them and send them on their merry way, and wind up a little richer in the process. (One of my favorites is that you can almost always just beat them to within an inch of their life and then spare them, turning the game into a school-bully simulator.) And you'll want that money for healing items and the occasional armor upgrade; the late-game enemies don't mess around. But you're not at the mercy of the Random Number Gods; every enemy has a unique graphical real-time attack to try to dodge, whether it's a visually-challenged dog who swipes at you with a sword or a depressed ghost who pelts you with tears.  If you're thorough about exploring, you should earn enough cash from regular encounters to stay stocked with items without having to wander around picking fights. And even so, you'll spend far more time solving puzzles and chatting with the Underground's wacky locals. The dialog would be worth the price of admission alone; there's a reason these characters have found their way into the hearts of players all over the Internet and inspired a tidal wave of fan art not seen since the  My Little Pony  craze.

Charming characters and environment, meaningful choice-making, and an exceptional narrative.  Clever twists and turns make this game unpredictable and exciting.  A wonderful RPG that leaves a lasting impression.

Undertale is what many would say to be a game just filled with silly jokes or just a short playtime. Others would say that it's just an overhyped game that's not gonna be remembered in a year. For me, it was like an experience that I will never forget for sure. I first played the demo way back when it was released in 2013 and I was impressed quite a bit. As a person who had played throught Earthbound and Mother 3, I was hoping for this game to not be a shoddy attempt at being another Earthbound game but failing. But when the game was released and I saw the trailers and watched some gameplay footage, I instantly knew that this game was for me. The entire game, while it plays like a typical RPG is more like an experience. You are a kid who is given the choice to either make friends or to start a homcidal blood bath and what makes it more interesting is how characters and the game itself changes based on your choices that you make. The music itself is a blast to listen to that I even will listen to it every once in a while. I think that given the games' multiple endings give this a high replay value and I highly recommend it to anyone who is a fan of Earthbound or just games with a retro look to it. Props to you, Toby Fox. Props to you.

Undertale is one of those games that came into being at just the right time.    The last few years have been full of some really great games, but also a lot of bad ones that have left a lot of people skeptical, discouraged, and bitter. The impact of the good ones was watered down by the overwhelming number of the bad ones. Undertale came along at just the right time with just enough quirk for people to try it out and hope it was a good one.  And it was.  This game is absolutely drenched in charm and atmosphere. Fun and imperfect characters that you grow to enjoy (or hate) as you play, unique combat that's frustrating, rewarding, challenging, and mind bending all at once, puzzles to give you a rest from battles or to brighten up a calm area. The soundtrack is amazing, it sets a serious tone or amps you up or helps you relax in just the right places. (I've listened to it for a week straight so I'm highly biased on this point)  That's the main thing I think this game does well, set the tone and the atmosphere. This is an experience. One that no player two players will experience in the same way. Because this game isn't for everyone.   That's the inherent flaw in this type of game.  The main reason I enjoyed Undertale is because it's suited to the way I play games.  It's full of tiny secrets that you'd only find by going off the main path and poking your nose into every nook and cranny you can find. I investigated every single thing I came across and I was rewarded for my efforts. The more I find, the more I want to search. Sometimes it's as little as triggering a slightly different string of dialogue or it's as big as finding an item that could give me a boost in battle (or non-battle, whatever your prefrence),   I enjoy the feeling of discovery and wonder.   Undertale let me feel that in a way that was enjoyable for me.    That feeling doesn't appeal to everyone.   However, it's biggest flaw is also it's greatest strength. No one is going to experience it in the same way that I did.   For as many different kinds of people there are in the world, that's how many ways this game can be experienced. I liked the characters so I found them enjoyable to interact with. I liked the style of the world so I found it enjoyable to explore. I became invested in both because I grew attached to them through the story that I also enjoyed.   Everyone is different. Everyone has different things they like and hate. That's okay.  I enjoyed this game because I didn't let the 'OH MY GAWD THIS IS THE BEST GAME EVARRRR!!1!!1111!!!!' hype raise my hopes beyond expecting that it was probably pretty good. I went in knowing there might be parts I didn't like and tempered my expectations accordingly.  But that's me.   While I don't think it's the greatest thing ever created like a lot of people do, I understand why they feel that way. I thoughly enjoyed my time playing it and I'll hold the memories of my journey in my heart for a very long time to come.  Because this is my type of game.   If it seems like your type of game, don't go into it expecting the best thing ever, but expect to enjoy your time playing.

I'd read plenty on Undertale before I played (as is the norm for me and games) and was pretty hyped once I got my hands on it. I already loved the characters and the story seemed fun. It seemed light and fluffy with a dark shadow cast over it, which only recieved a bad reputation due to the more rabid fans and people who just didn't focus on the right parts of the game (like those who've purposely fight to get a certain ending).  However, I then played the game.  To begin with, I was right. It was nice and fluffy and innocent and I enjoyed it. Then I got to   Papyrus'   battle and lost several times. It annoyed me but I carried on and had a good laugh making him run back and forth between the living room and kitchen. Then   Undyne's   battle was a bigger pain... Then   Muffet's  ... Before you knew it, I was suddenly no longer having fun and just spent my time googling ways to get past any and all scenes quickly. By the time I hit   Asgore's   battle, I'd resorted to file editing just so I could beat him (I was LV1 with 0EXP and 20HP and all boss attacks effectively violate your health bar in general). It wasn't until that last bloody fight that I found out I'd wasted my time avoiding conflict as I could only get the best ending by beating the game once... Then the final boss came along... Don't get me wrong, beat him second time around, but I honest to god had lost all will to game by this point.  Now I'm replaying to get the best ending and then intend to avoid the game for a while. Honestly, I like the story and love (most) of the characters, but the battle system is as fun as having your beanbag ran over by a steamroller. Regular battles you can live with the annoyance, but boss battles are like having a hacker on a PvP server... You just want to kill them so very badly but know you can't without one hell of a run around beforehand.  For the story, characters and bad jokes, I recommend this game. But, for the combat system, I recommend you get it on sale. A fun and fluffy game spoilt by ugly jagged battles. 7/10, will end up challenging my DETERMINATION again.  (Note: Haven't gone into detail about most things, so this should be spoiler free for the most part. Will leave the 'had to beat the game once' here anyone who doesn't know that will be driven insane like I was.)

Undertale is a quirky jrpg-esque game with strong influences from Earthbound and Cave Story, with its lovable characters and wonderfully witty dialogue. If you like the impossibly upbeat and can laugh and embrace absurd humor, you'll find yourself right at home. Something to note is how steeped in internet and video game culture this game is. Although not being vastly knowledgeable in the subjects they touch on won't impact the gameplay, it might just leave you a little perplexed. However knowing all of the in-jokes and references, will only make you appreciate the level of detail that has gone into this game that much more, exponentially.  Getting right down to it, there's not much to say about the story that hasn't already been said in other reviews. It cannot be stressed enough that this game gives you, the player, real consequences for every single one of YOUR actions. No detail was too small and no context was left unobserved by Toby Fox and his team. And EVERY SINGLE ACTION you do in the game has a greater impact then one could imagine from a game. Emergent gameplay is the name of the game here (pun intended). The team that created this game has gone to great lengths to subvert tropes and make you really appreciate putting yourself in someone else' shoes (namely the main character).  When entering this game for the first time, it's highly recommended you throw away everything you knew about video games. Absolutely never give into your curiosity and really think about everything that you're actually doing. You will come to quickly learn that the habits that have been cultured by video games are not accepted here. Also the game is incredibly meta and you may find yourself on the receiving end of a 4th wall breaking comment. Finally, to really pound into your thick skulls that all actions have consequences, the game has only one save slot and the game will remember every single action you took in all of your playthroughs. This can be subverted by messing with the appropriate files in the directories folder. But if you're going to such lengths, what was the point of playing this game at all?   Never do anything YOU yourself wouldn't do if put in those situations or else you might just have a bad time.
