Undertale is by all means one of the best games of 2015, if not of the entire decade. This is a game with heart and love that you will hardly find in any other one. The emotion, kind spirit, and warm, joyful, yet bittersweet atmosphere is touching in its every being and will not let you go even long after you finished the game.  This game will take you on an emotional rollercoaster and most likely, is going to make you cry. The characters, from the funniest and most innocent skeleton to the most psychopathic flower, are all likeable and memorable in their own way once you learn their story that has its three different endings, dependent on your way of playing. Each of your decisions will influence the end essentially. To fully enjoy Undertale,  do not spoiler yourself.  Enjoy it at your own parse and in your own manner. This is one of the most important aspects of Undertale.  Undertale will not hold your hand and guide you, telling you every secret and every detail you have to know. You will have to find out your way on your own. You will not fully experience this game without slamming your head against a wall and keeping to do things that are seemingly fruitless. That is another major point of Undertale. If you strife for completition, you will have to pay a high price as well. This game is full of wonderful and deep going details and secrets that you have to explore.   Whilst on one side Undertale appears kind, colourful and cute, almost childish, full of running gags, charming humour and adorable, cute characters, on the other side it takes itself very serious above this. It carries an important and very, very emotional message, features a deep and twisted story and intentionally breaks the 4th wall in an astonishingly manner, making that an essential part of the game and its meaning.    Certainly, the game's pixel-y and RPGish style is not something for everybody. I think however, that you have to look beyond mere appearance. Undertale is not about aesthetics or gameplay itself, it is about story, a lot of story, about bounding with its characters, about love to detail, dogs, maturity, dogs, pacifism, emotion and so on. It is about the game and its genre itself.  ***  All parts of Undertale fit seamlessly together, from visuals to story to gameplay to soundtrack.  Due to its 8 pixel style very simple and fundamental, the world and in particular the character sprites are nicely drawn and have their own quality that puts them above generic graphic perfection of AAA titles.    The music is another major aspect of Undertale, for it fits  perfectly  at every single moment, with reoccuring themes -- the so-called   leitmotiv  [en.wikipedia.org]   placed throughout the game and a simply beautiful track that accompanies you for the entirety of the game, both sticking out for its pure beauty and yet not sticking out more than a soundtrack should.   The combat system is the gameplay's fundamental core, of course. You have the choice to fight and eventually kill your opponent, befriend or shoo them away through various ways to act in order to spare them, use items and flee. A lot of character interaction and story happens through these fights,  all  of which can be concluded in a nonviolent way. The fights are all unique and thrilling, albeit maybe hard for people who struggle with bullet hells. No boss fight feels like the others, whether you choose to kill or spare.   ***   Play this game. Be filled with...  DETERMINATION .    Should you have any questions regarding the game  once you have finished it , check the  Undertale Wiki  [undertale.wikia.com]  or the  Undertale subreddit .

Undertale is a pleasant surprise that keeps tricking you with how quirky and lighthearted it can be, yet deep and layered at the same time. It's full of awareness that it's a game, but never goes 'LOL I BREAK 4TH WALL CUZ IS FUNEE'. Instead, it reacts to how you play, meaning it's as deep as the player is willing to go.  A person can totally play the game once, not get the best ending, and be satisfied with the 6ish hours of gameplay they get. It never forces you to get 'the perfect ending' or 'the worst ending'. But because the endings are actually completely different, they're worth replaying the game to see. Even the act of replaying the game is itself worked in as part of the story, as many characters maintain awareness of what you did in previous runs. But again it's never overdone, but rather subtle nods that makes the game itself feel alive.  There is no wrong way to play this game. It's an experience.

First off, I don't mind admitting I SOLELY bought this game based on the hype it's been getting over the internet; more specifically, a couple choice Youtube channels I follow. Born and raised in the N64 era, while I could appreciate retro games, I didn't feel the same pull as them as other gamers; I haven't played and finished many games from that era, so they hold no nostalgic value to me. As such Undertale's graphics, musical style and battle system didn't quite draw me in; if anything, it's obvious affinity for a time before mine made me feel like it was directed to another audience and was probably not quite for me. Still it was only 12 bucks, I wasn't playing anything in particular, and the last indie project I sunk my teeth into- the Stanley Parable- was a brief, but quite enjoyable affair; that plus the aforementioned made me say 'oh, what the heck' and give it a shot.    It wasn't something that IMMEDIATELY grabbed me; the first half of my play time- only a few hours or so- were enjoyable but spread out over a few days. The characters were endearingly quirky, the dialogue was well written, the musical score was excellent to my pleasant surprise, and the battle system was fun and unique; I had nothing bad to say about the game thus far and was enjoying myself, but I couldn't see what all the hubbub was about.    By the time my first playthough was over however, something had changed in my viewpoints; characters had gone from endearing to people (er...monsters... whatever) that I truly cared about, certain plot twists hit me out of nowhere and threw me for a loop, what I had been doing up until this had meaning that I wouldn't have expected, and the final boss (for the 'normal' or neutral' loop) was something that was quite terrifying and unexpected.   Before I knew it I was back for more; I couldn't just stop here. I needed to get to a better ending! To leave the world the way it was would just be depressing, so I wanted to play it and get the BEST route. Many hours later, I did; along the way however, the game had pulled me into its clutches even more, sprinkling in even more climatic and downright suspenseful moments along with a few poignant moments that really touched my heart. By the time the end credits rolled around, I left this game feeling satisfied, enlightened, and wishing for more.    Sound a bit sappy to you? Well, there's a good reason for that; Undertale's plot, humor and allegorical message also serves as a allegorical message that speaks directly to the player. It pokes fun at the tropes of RPGs, it impresses upon the player of the consequences of their actions in a way few games seldom accomplish, and even speaks to- sometimes criticizing- the reasons we play games to begin with. Whether it connects you on an emotional level as it did with me or not, if you call yourself a gamer, you'll get something out of the message the game is trying to get across.    Now, literally only one day after completing the game, I can say that this game is- without a doubt or exageration- one of my favorite games of all times . It has style and substance, a perfect blend between gameplay and story, and is unique in a truly novel and wonderful way without ever feeling gimmicky. The soundtrack, just to reiterate, is AMAZING; good enough for someone who ISN'T a fan of this style to go and buy (alongside the free tribute album, Pianotale, which is exactly what it sounds like, and is quite good); I have been listening to this all day at work today, and it has not once got old. Long story short; it's an EXCELLENT game. If you're feeling like something new, give this a shot; you could do a lot worse for $12 :)

Normally, I write long, detailed reviews. If I can't come up with a few paragraphs' worth of information, I don't review. But this game. THIS GAME. I can only begin to construct the bare bones of a review: this game is awesome. The graphics are cute, the characters are compelling and memorable, the humor is great, and the very concept of the game is so refreshingly unique - not only the idea of befriending rather than killing monsters, but the sheer level of meta-commentary on both your actions across saves and resets, and on RPGs in general. The music is wonderful too (of course; it's Toby Fox - you might know him as the guy who did a lot of the music for Homestuck).  But despite the fact that I don't have a long analysis to share, I still feel compelled to review it - solely to tell you all that this game is something special. Solely to give it the thumbs up that I feel I am duty-bound to give to a game I enjoyed so thoroughly and profoundly as Undertale.  Buy this game. 10 bucks is ridiculously cheap for something this good. It's worth every cent and more.

You can choose to kill no one, everyone, or some, and each way gives you different ends. It's super endearing, and will definitely leave an impact.

It has been a long time since I have played a game that made me smile so much all the way through. In so many ways, this game is a huge love letter to all the old school nostalgic RPG games of the 8bit and 16 bit era, while at the same time having enough heart warming characters, story and music to carry itself without relying on said nostalgia.  Talking too much about the game, even how the game itself plays is almost a spoiler in and of itself, the game really shines on a straight blind play through. The game's length is perfectly measured, but like Portal, it never overstays its welcome, and ends when it needs to.  And finally, for a game as short as it is, it somehow managed to be so much more charming and wonderful than pretty much any of the multi million dollar AAA games in existence. I will always remember Undertale's experience, while those massive budget titles ultimately feel like just another notch on the belt.

You've gotta get this game. Undertale is an insanely unique RPG where you can choose either to kill everyone you see, or befriend or spare them. It can be long or short, depending on how you choose. Both routes(Pacifist Route or Genocide Route) have advantages and disadvantages. Genocide Route advantages: If you kill, you level up and get more health. Genocide Route disadvantages: You will be hated by all of the monsters(except one not saying who). Pacifist Route advantages: Monsters won't hate you(except one that you can't befriend only if you do the Genocide Route). Pacifist Route disadvantages: As you can't kill ANYONE to get the true pacifist ending you can't level up to get more health. Also, if you're getting this game, you should also get the soundtrack. SERIOUSLY. GET IT.

It's kinda hard to escape the Undertale hypetrain. It's certainly the flavor of the moment and I'm finding it hard to disagree with the vast enjoyment. A light, goofy turn based RPG much in the vein of Earthbound, Undertale is short and sweet game with a unique little hook; nobody has to die. It's that little hook, a quirky cast of characters, and a unique sense of humor that really makes Undertale such an enjoyable time. Combat is (mostly) simple; you can fight or you can attempt to passify enemies with various acts/retreating, while the enemy attacks with shmup style bullet patterns. Even with the shmup elements, you're rarely going to have much trouble (with a few exceptions) with combat, so if you're looking for a real challenge and there really isn't much customization going on outside of some weapon options. If you're looking for meaty gameplay mechanics and systems, Undertale isn't really doing that. It's much more about story, humor, and characters. There's also some meta-commentary for the completionists out there, but I won't spoil that for you. I really enjoyed my time with this game; not sure if I'll go back again, but I certainly did enjoy my time with it.

The moment I beat it (or thought I had!), I knew this game was a must-play for anyone looking for a ultimately satisfying experience.  Finally, I'd like to relate this game to Cave Story. If you enjoyed Cave Story, and are even slightly wanting a similer experience, this game is most certainly for you.  Bravo!

This game is great. As far as it being a JRPG, I'll say that while there is a lot of dialogue, it manages to avoid the mindless 'bash the attack button till you win or die' thing that turn based stuff usually seems to turn into. Oh and there's the soundtrack. I dunno if I'm just biased because I like the style in general, but I think the music is fantastic. Besides in what other game can you have 30 hot dogs stacked on your head? So yeah I absolutely recommend the game and the soundtrack both.

Undertale is a game about player choice, humanity, and perserverence. I would highly recommend playing this game with as few spoilers as possible, the more you discover for yourself the more this game is worth. after a play through (or three), then look up all the exciting extra stuff you can find, because this game is best experienced with a blank slate.
I just...  ...why.

What I love about this game is how it mixes various elements into one cohesive game. It's an emotionally touching story with lovable characters and multiple endings. It's art with its thematic exploration of video games and morality. It's a bullet hell (though really only two fights provide any challenge). It's a puzzle game. It's an RPG / open world with its exploration, equipment, and fight ui. It's comedy. It's also DANK MEMES (e.g. tsunderplane) which can often be a bit cringey. It's definitely overrated, any 'overwhelmingly positive' game probably is, but it's also worth playing.

This game is fantastic and is a perfect example of why games don't need the flashiest graphics to be good. On the contrary, the amount of work you can do in developing a game  without  the best graphics is, naturally, much greater.  Undertale's most redeeming qualities, to me, are the Story, Characters, Music and the Battle System. It's very special when you are capable of feeling such strong emotions for these Characters. The rest of it is still good, of course, but you can clearly tell that it's mainly windowdressing for an already good product.  There are multiple endings. But I can almost guarantee you that, for a game like this, replay value isn't a concern. Especially if you get the best of best endings... and you have a conscience, you probably won't want to do a  True Reset  and would rather walk away.  I wish Toby Fox and his collaborators  GREAT SUCCESS , and yes, I would recommend this game to a friend. In fact, it's because of a good friend that I found this game. And I will continue passing it along.   I downloaded this game separately from Steam through the Humble Bundle, and I won't be playing the game again, after getting the best ending! But I logged about  nine  hours.

Why haven't you bought this game yet?

An absolutly fantastic game, one of the best rpg's and one of the best games period that I've ever played. It has an amazingly gripping story line which'll make you actually feel for the characters and feel genuine emotions despite the games semi-simplistic graphics.  The music is amazing, and I'd say even worth spending 10 dollars to download. Every track is memerable and is just amazing to listen to  The story is a complex, but at the same time easy to understand story that'll make you feel emotions you wish you hadn't, and depending on what route you take will make you question your morals and whether or not you ever want to hurt anything in a game again.   Speaking of the story, the game has different routes, giving different endings depending on your play style and providing a great insintive to replay the game once you've beaten it already in order to fight new bosses and see new story lines emerge.   The battle mechanics may be one of my favorite parts of the game. The fact that you don't have to kill anything is innovative enough on it's own, but the way you fight enemies and can avoid getting hurt by using your skill with the keyboard to avoid their attacks is superb.   The graphics are simplistic but never make you struggle to understand what you're looking at on screen. You can tell the developers spent a lot of time making the art for this game and some scenes can be very beatiful to look at.  Over all I believe undertale is a fantastic game, and one of the best games of all times, up there with other gaming classics. If I did have to have one critism I suppose it's the game is a bit short, I took 5 hours to beat one of the easier story lines so there's still tons of gameplay for anyone to play. If the developers ever made an Undertale 2 or dlc for the game you can be sure I'll be one of the first to buy it.  (Summary) WORTH THE $10, 10/10

Okay, so before any of you say or judge this game just by the 8-bit graphics, or how it looks or how it's set up; This is a GIANT EXAMPLE OF THE PHRASE: 'Don't judge a book by it's cover'!!!   I remember seeing this game reccomended to me many times and passing it off as just another RPG game that I have no interest in. I don't care for RPG games, but this is one GIANT exception.   This game has a great storyline, especially for those who are faint-at-heart or violent beings. I, personally, didn't have the heart to kill everyone (not telling you what happens, but I do know), but apparently when you even harm a single soul after playing it through, it will make you feel terrible. This game touches hearts, which brings me to the characters.  Where do I even begin? The character development in this game is PHENOMINAL! I cannot stop playing it! Even though I've completed it about 3 times, I cannot put it down! This really twists your head around characters you wnat to hate but grow to love! The challenges they are put through, as well as the lore behind their origins, it really puts the player to think where they all originated from before the underground.  To keep this from being about 300 pages long, I will summarize this game in a few sentences. (why you sould buy it).  This game has many different ways you can play it, each way the characters view you from a different standpoint. Every way you play the dialogue changes, leaving many possibilities for how the game is played or ends. The characters are very well-made and developed, as well as the storyline and the entire concept. It really puts your emotions into account with each desicion you make.  I give this game a 10/10. Five stars, will play endlessly.
This is the best game I've played all year!

This game has won its way into my heart as one of my new favorite games of all time. I just completed the True Pacifist run, and I can honestly say that this is a game you should NOT miss out on! If anything, this is one of the few games I've played that I wouldn't mind experiencing again!  ***MINOR SPOILERS BELOW***  PROS: -Engaging story -Pacifist Route makes the game very relaxing and is sure to put you in a chipper mood. It also adds a degree of difficulty as you have to find a way to defeat monsters without hurting them, while their attacks can still damage you. -AMAZING music. I mean, Asriel's theme? Homygawd~ -The characters you build a bond with are just so lovable and quirky in their own way. Even side-characters and their conversations are interesting to listen to, and give so much depth to the world of the Underground and the lives of its denizens. -Lots of memorable moments- ranging from ones that make you burst out laughing to ones that tug at your heartstrings. -Lots of clever jokes thrown out here and there -8-bit style is well-executed -Despite having 3 main areas for you to travel between, the world seems massive in scale and has so many fascinating areas to explore- from the friendly town of Snowdin to the mysterious caverns of the Waterfall.  +/- -The battle system incororates some 'bullet hell' style gameplay. Some boss fights can become rather frustrating, and I even restarted my game because I was unsatisfied from the amount of times I died. (NOTE: KEEP LOOKING EVERYWHERE FOR GOLD, BUY HEALTH ITEMS, AND USE ANY GOOD ARMOR YOU CAN FIND!)  CONS -You have to complete the Neutral Ending in order to be able to get the True Pacifist Ending. I feel like it's just a drag that you can't immediately get the 'best ending' on your first playthrough. But on the plus side, despite being a nightmare to look at, the Neutral Ending's boss isn't that hard as I expected...  Tl;dr- With memorable characters, lots of laughs, emotional moments, epic music, a nice difficulty curve, and an interesting world to explore, Undertale is a game I couldn't recommend enough. Do yourself a favor and give it a shot!  10/10, without a doubt!

Undertale might be my new favorite game. It has a lot of competition with Earthbound and Chrono Trigger, but Undertale is the most refreshing and unique game I've played recently, perhaps ever. It takes the worn-out JRPG genre and flips it on its head, allowing the player to have mercy on enemies. However, what is truely impressive about this mechanic is that each new enemy feels like a different experience, keeping the game fresh further than its whimsical concept alone could support. Not only is Undertale different, it uses this difference to be more emotionally impactful than most other games, actually making the player think about their actions. Undertale is a true masterpiece.

WARNING: I made this longer than I intended. The summary is: I love the game, and you probably will too, but don't expect it to be some LoL type addictions. You'll probably spend about 15 hours in the game. But you'll love it.  Okay, let's be real. If you have spent any time looking at the reviews you probably noticed at least one of three things: 1. Just about everyone who is raving about the quality of the game has (generally) under 30 hours ( this obviously includes myself) 2. There are many people who love to portray either the game or themselves as the most intellectual things to ever grace the planet (shot's fired) 3. What is this 'Hoi I'm tEMMiE', butterscotch pie, 'You're gonna have a bad time' garbage  So here are my answers:  1: you really won't spend that long on it. And that is totally fine. It's $10 and can be beaten once in about four hours. But there are multiple ways to play, so you'll probably spend about... 12 hours on it? I still think that's solid.  2: the gameplay/experience is great. Don't expect graphics. Expect surprisingly three dimensional characters and amazing music (assuming you're into more electronic type music). I wouldn't classify it as some great art piece of a game, however I will say that the dev, Toby Fox, put some real care into the game and it truly shows.  3: that's the fan base and they're fantastic. I think I've spent about as much time jamming to the sound track while surfing  reddit.com/r/undertale  reading the comics and whatever other thing someone who's more creative than I made.

This game is one I simply cannot recommend enough. The combat is pretty easy to understand, and graphics are, well...They may leave something to be desired, but, then again, ol' chunky graphics usually let more room for a story to take place. And what a freaking story there is.  I don't want to spoil any parts of the game for anyone, so all I can say is play the game if you even have a slight interest in it. On battle phase the characters look very well made and the gameplay is actually rather fun (though if you don't like bullet hell then you're going to have a   bad time   )  I highly recomend this game, there's almost no reason to pick this up short of 'i don't have enough money.' This is probably one of the best games I've ever played. I love choice and consequence games and this game puts a great deal of emphasis on the consequences of your actions. Be a kind but determined pacifist, and the story will feel rewarding. Be a ruthless killer, and the game is ruthless in return. Regardless of what path you choose, the narrative is powerful.   The gameplay is a twist on traditional RPGs, allowing the player to talk their way out of a fight instead of killing their enemy. The game also forces the player to dodge enemy attacks, instead of simply relying on a chance system to determine if the player takes damage. This unique fighting system is coupled with a solid story and an amazing soundtrack, making each fight feel rewarding.   All of these elements combine to create a fantastic experience that is fun. Even when the game goes a little easy or hard on you, it's usually to further the narrative. And, even when a boss kills you over and over again and you are forced to backtrack a little to get better items, the soundtrack manages to recreate a consistent thrill that makes failure much less tedious.   The only real downside to Undertale, in my opinion, is that the game can get a little too overwhelming. It works wonders for the overall experience, but players who are highly emotional or have anxiety issues should take breaks. Toby managed to make me incapable of harming these characters without feeling intense regret and you will probably have a similar experience.  TL;DR: If you want to play a RPG with a great narrative that puts emphasis on your choices, I highly suggest playing Undertale.

Undertale is truly one of a kind. I picked up this game because of all the hype and reviews and knew what to expect to a certain degree. Knowing what it was probably decreased my entertainment with it somewhat, but even still this game had many great and surprising moments, and fantastic memorable characters. It only got better and better as I kept playing and got deeper and deeper into the story.   I would recommend playing the game before knowing too much about it but I will go onto a little more detail (no story spoilers) below.  What makes Undertale so great can't really be explained fully, there is simply too much depth to explain what makes any given moment fantastic. The game plays with it's own rules constantly and keeps referencing itself, twisting mechanics that you thought you learned earlier in the game. On top of all of this it portrays story through the gameplay mechanics themself, and you feel a direct connection to the story through what you are doing in the game.  Long story short, Undertale is a game that I think every gamer should playthrough in their lifetime.

A story with many layers to peel back and fun, well-written and fleshed out characters that will leave you wanting to return again and again. A gameplay experience that compliments this story by refreshing itself with new mechanics and unique confrontations consistently throughout the not-quite-too-short time it takes to make a single run through. Great character designs and awesome sound design despite the technical limitations. There are scenes to make you laugh and scenes to make you cry, and neither ever feel out of place because the pacing and storytelling are that good. Undertale is one of those rare pieces of art that's more well thought out than most releases 10x it's size, the kind of discovery that reminds me why thousands of years after the hero's tale was settled upon, we still come up with new stories to tell each other. If there are gripes to be had they are that fighting enemies with the intent to kill requires no strategy, tactics or thought other than timing and dodging, making it a strictly less interactive and fun method than talking your way out every time. It can be argued as being intentional, but if all Undertale did was flip what most games do (make the violence interactive and the talking more like a menu) it suddenly seems much less original and interesting, and at times it felt a little like that. As it stands, I dread starting a Genocide run to complete seeing the rest of the story because just thinking of thoughtlessly button mashing my way through the game makes me bored. I have a couple minor gripes mostly relating to the game's ending(s) that I won't post here because, y'know, NO SPOILERS. Undertale is an experience for people who love video games and stories. I'd give it at least a 9.5/10 as an honest-to-god rating. It's not the biggest adventure out there, the one with the most secrets, the most twists, or the most characters. But the amount of good ideas packed into this little package is full to absolute bursting. I honestly have a hard time thinking of anyone who I don't think would enjoy it at all. But I'm sure I'm not telling you anything you haven't heard before. The hype surrounding this little game is, to say the least, DETERMINED. Stop fighting it and know that someday you're gonna end up playing it to see what everybody's talking about anyway.

This is a very good game! It's wonderful to have an RPG where you don't have to kill anyone or anything, and it's not necessary to build up your level to get through. (During my playthrough, I only needed to 'grind' for a little bit once, right at the end of the game, and that was just to get in a few fights so I could get enough gold to buy more healing items.)  The combat system is creative and fun. It's very nice and refreshing to see a combat system that is aesthetic and visual, and which you get through not by making move after move after move, like I do with most other RPGs that I've played, but by avoiding the white 'obstacles' as they fly towards me. It's a combat system that rewards reflexes and co-ordination, so it feels more like you're in an actual battle, where you have to have your wits about you! Plus, some of the patterns that the obstacles fly in are very creative and actually fun to look at, which makes it all the better!  Also, the puzzles (and 'action scenes') elsewhere in the game are fun too. They're creative, well-thought-out and varied, so the game keeps feeling fresh. They, along with the fights, are challenging enough to keep me on my toes but not so hard that they become frustrating. Admittedly, I did need a few tries to get past some of the 'bosses', but I managed them all with a bit of practice.  The game's story is engaging and interesting. It's also excellent that there are several different ways that the story can change, based on the choices that players make. That means that there is a lot of replay value for the game - I'm certainly going to play it again and see if I can do things differently. Plus, the story is well-told, well-paced, and skillfully moves between atmospheres - sometimes gentle and happy-go-lucky, sometimes sinister and tense.  The music is very good, too. Sometimes grim and creepy, sometimes bouncy and joyful, sometimes soft, gentle and soothing. It does a good job at setting the atmosphere - especially in its use of silence! That's right, this game also knows just how to use silence to make an impact!  I like how funny the game is. I don't want to give away anything that happens, but there are a lot of funny parts.  Some people might think that this game is too short, but I don't think so. The game's story has a nice length, where it doesn't outstay its welcome, and doesn't feel like it's padded or like it drags. Plus, like I said, there are several different ways in which the story can progress and end depending on what choices the player makes, so it's good that you don't have to play through a really long game to see these different endings.  The only real crticisms I have to make of this game are quite small ones. Firstly, I think that the backgrounds sometimes look a bit bland and uninteresting, with flat colours or undetailed pathways. That might be deliberate - maybe that style was done deliberately as a homage to old RPGs? I don't know, since I haven't played many old RPGs like the Earthbound series, Final Fantasy Series or Chrono Trigger or things like that. Anyway, other times the backgrounds look okay.  Also, I don't think the game has quite enough imagination or vision. Don't get me wrong, this is quite an imaginative game, and there are lots of interesting, creative moments in it, but... well, the game's world just seems to be a bit too similar to our own, with not quite enough fantastical flair. Hopefully I don't give too much away here, but, Undertale takes place in a world different from the human world, full of monsters. However, the world just seems a little too human. There are human-like houses, human-like jobs, human-like ways of communicating... I dunno, it just felt like it could've been a bit weirder and more creative - more DIFFERENT than what we're used to. But then again, maybe that's just me - I like weird, creative stuff. And, like I said, this game is still creative and fun.  All in all, this is a very nice, well-made, fun, and even uplifting game. Thank you to everyone who made it, and well done!   EDIT, WRITTEN ON 4th JANUARY 2016:  I've recently finished this game without killing anybody, and I had a wonderful experience! So much more of the game opens up for you! You can explore whole other areas, you uncover more of the story, you learn more about the characters! It was very satisfying, and I loved the different ending. I actually had tears streaming down my face at the end of the final 'boss fight'. I admit that that was mainly because of the beautiful, moving music, but the themes and the events in the story were very beautiful and touching too. I love stories that talk about peace, kindness and friendship, and how important all those things are, and Undertale does that well! This game not only deals with those themes with its story and its characters, but it actually makes kindness and friendship important parts of its actual GAMEPLAY, and I love that.  Thank you, thank you, thank you to everyone who helped make this game! You did a good job!

Every enemy has its own unique attacks and weaknesses, and not like the majority of RPGs with their attack being 'Fire Punch' and their weakness being 'Ice'. What is there to be said that hasn't been already?  You know what this game is. Bar and none. You have seen it. Everywhere. E v e r y w h e r e. You have seen everyone rave about it and sing it's praises. No one will shut up about this game! And that is for good reason. Undertale isn't just a game to me. It is an experience. It has an absolutely fantastic (and hilarious) memorable cast of characters who, when they aren't giving me stitches in laughter, are making me cry sweet, pure puppy dog tears. The story is absolutely incredible, in which you play as a fallen human who fell into a monster world, after a war between the 2 species which lead to the monsters being banished underground, and saying anything else will spoil your experience. I'll just say that this game plays like a choose your own adventure book, making the path you choose really stick with you no matter what. I have pure faith every ending will leave you happy. And there isn't just the main 3 endings either (Neutral ending, where you choose who lives and dies, Genocide, where you kill everything you see and kill every enemy in each area until none remain, and Pacifist, the complete opposite)! Any person you kill and let live WILL affect the story. Every. Single. One. And if you are like me, you always felt SOME remorse for killing SOMEONE, due to how well developed every character is. There is no hero or villan in Undertale. Everyone has their good side, and their bad side. Even the FINAL BOSS of the neutral run can have his goodness inside of him! The only true heroes or villans are the players, and the game definetly lets you know this. And the only way to truly experience this game is to do the main 3 endings, to BECOME THE HERO, BECOME THE VILLIAN, AND BECOME THE VICTOR! You do this with the most unique combat system I have EVER seen in years. You have 2 options, 1. Use the FIGHT option, and with some well timed button presses, kill the enemy, or 2. Look at the ACT menu, experiment with your options, and eventually give MERCY to the enemy. No matter what you do though, in between turns the enemy will give attacks through a small box in which you control a Soul (a small heart), dodging emeny fire (anything white will harm you). You heard that right: BULLET HELL IN A ROLE PLAYING GAME. And that is just scratching the surface of this game! Enemies can turn your soul different colors, which changes how the entire game is played, the music is absolute ear bliss, and most of all, *SPOILER*   IT HAS THE SEXIEST KILLER ROBOT GAME SHOW HOST I HAVE EVER SEEN! I'M BLUSHING JUST LOOKING AT HIM, AND HE CAN'T EVEN SEE ME!  Undertale is absolutely, positively the greatest game I have played this year. No questions asked.

Although it feels regrettably quite short and can be very hit-or-miss in its quirky brand of humor, Undertale has a great amount of heart right from the beginning. Of course, one's experience with this game is determined by one's choices, but the random NPCs aside from the bosses are the true stars of the show. Each one is unique and shows distinct personality (often worthy of a larger role than they actually recieve) in only a few lines--while so much of the dialogue is optional, skipping it ruins the experience imo. The biggest problem with this game is the amount of hype it is recieving.  It's good but at the same time, I think that's what's killing it for a lot of people. People are overhyping it to fantastical points and it really ruins the experience for others.   However, that's the biggest complaint, honestly. All my bad experiences with the game have just come from my expectations being really high for this game thanks to the interwebs. For 10 dollars (possibly cheaper when it goes on sale), this game is definitely an experience that's worth it.   The combat is a fun bullet-hell turn based system that is accompanied by a well done soundtrack that I still listen to often. I don't really like turn based systems because it always felt kind of slow but with the dodging of enemy attacks and the possibility to always spare enemies, the combat was still fun and refreshing compared to other turn based games I had played before. Especially if you play the Pacifist route, where you have to keep dodging and try to do the correct actions in the right order to get the enemy to like you.   Soundtrack, as I stated before, is really good. Each important moment has it's own song to go along with it and now when I listen to the songs on Youtube or on my phone, it just brings me back to the moments where the song starts playing.   Now for the big part, the story. I'm trying to keep this spoiler free so all I will really say is that.... It's pretty good.  The humor and likability of the characters are honestly the best part of my experience with Undertale. The closest example I can think of to describe the humor is the Internet.  Like, seriously. If you are a dank Internet kid, I think you would enjoy the humor and presentation of this game a lot. It's quirky and very enjoyable for those who browse reddit, tumblr, etc.  I did expect something alot more emotional because of all the hype I was reading (This goes into my point at the beginning). Towards the end of my True Pacifist run, it really felt started to feel like something out of a Shounen manga like Naruto or One Piece. It just felt REALLY cheesy rather than the 'emotional moments that made me cry' (-Some person in this review section) that people have been praising like crazy. There have been no points where I felt the need to cry where as other people have apparantly broken down in tears even when I watched the Genocide Run.   Maybe I'm a heartless ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of a flower.  Nonetheless, still a very enjoyable experience with nice twists and turns. This is a spoilerfree review of the entire game.  Man what a ride this was. You can get 2 of the 3 endings in about 9 hours even when messing around and trying to be a completionist. The third requires a complete replay so add about 8 more hours. This means at best you will get a total of 17 hours out of this. Possible is also that you will require yet another playthrough due to your actions to get all 3 endings which will leave you at about 24 hours total.  The music is really freaking awesome, there is a lot of different soundtracks. Enough to buy the soundtrack DLC? I dunno I usually download music from Youtube and will do so here as well.  The gameplay consists out of you either attacking by hitting the attack button in the right moment or trying to take an enemies will to fight via different dialogue options and then just letting them live. The dialogue usually isnt all that fleshed out with about 4 options on average that consist out of stuff like (cry) (tell a joke) or something like that, no actual dialogue. Usually choosing a single option is enough sometimes you have to go deeper and do the right thing in the right moment, but generally it isnt all that hard. And attacking is literally just pushing a button at the right moment. The interesting part comes in between, when the enemy attacks and you have to dodge. Every enemy has their own attacks which even changes when multiple enemies appear at once. This together with the design of your foes means that despite the game having random encounters they dont feel like a burden, like they do in so many other games. Often you will face enemies you have never seen before with new attacks and dialogue solutions. The random encounters can be a but annoying however if it is enemies of which you know you will get hit by at least once and it just puts your health at an awkward position without actually endangering you. Random encounters are usually very rare however, so they shouldnt bother anyone.  The story is pretty awesome, particularly if you realise how much you havent seen when going for the other endings. The people you meet are all unique and memorable. SInce this is spoilerfree I cant really say a whole lot other than 'worth it'.  The game also involves solving puzzles, none of which I found very puzzling and I suck at solbing puzzles. They were fun to solve though and enriched the gameplay in a positive manner.  All in all it is worth it at full price, the trailer should give you a good final idea wether you want this or not.  Or perhaps I should review this in the manner of a typical steam review? In that case: Made me hate flowers 10/10

In my eyes, Undertale is a masterpiece. In anothers, its a boring, terrible game. Undertale is definitely not the game for everyone, but it's not just a series of inside jokes for all RPG players. If you...  a) Have a sense of humor b) Can resist watching spoiler-heavy posts and videos c) Can bear with it until its not-so-good beggining is over  You should really get this game. I'll tell you why.   Sound  Undertale has my favourite video game music of all time contained within it. During boss 'fights' (or dating a skeleton) the music fits the theme perfectly, and the pace slows down or speeds up to match the mood, and helps to craft a game where a character's death actually  means  somthing, not just a 'You have gained 420 EXP and 100 Gold!!!' moment. Seriously, look up some of the tunes from the boss fights in the game- instead of listening to 'actual' music, I'm listening to Undertale music 24/7.  10/10   Gameplay  I want to say that the game is never boring, but that's not true. It does have its filler, containing much less substance than other parts of the game, but it still meets, if not passes the greatness of many other games. The only issue is, Undertale sets such a high bar that when it subjects you to its filler, you can't eait to get to the more interesting segments. The parts that are good are flawless on the other hand, are, well, flawless, and both hilarious and emotional when you get to them. Another great thing about Undertale is its replay value, which is immence. You can play Undertale in so many ways- you can be a pscycopath that kills everything or you can NOT be a pscycopath that kills everything, and instead of fighting, flirts with talking planes and date more skeletons.  9/10   Characters  You have probably played an RPG before, and unless it was a joke one like Day of The Tentacle, you have probably run into hundreds of faceless enemies- Kill, Loot, Repeat. In Undertale, it's Flirt, Defend, Spare, Date, Compliment, Eat Spagetti, Win Date, ...Repeat? This is pretty much one of the boss battles in a nutshell, and this character is so memorable, just like all the other amazing characters are. You've got everything you could possibly imagine in this game, like a Pscyco Killer Scary Flower That Is Actually A Moster Prince. If you have something more original than that, I'll call you a liar.  10/10    Verdict  This is an amazing game, and most of it doesn't come from the actual gameplay, but the story. It makes itself both hilarious and emotional at the same time, makes you care about the characters, and the music is amazing. Unless you have been in a traumatic accident with a JRPG in your past, play thid game, and even if you have had issues with JRPGs, play it anyways.  10 Skeleton Dates/10 Skeleton Dates Best game 4020

... I love this game!!! Up until Undertale I thought my favorite game last year was either Mario Maker, Splatoon, or most likely Xenoblade Chronicles X. And while Xenoblade is giving Undertale a run for its money, right now Undertale is my favorite game of 2015. 10/10 for sure, and here is why:  Story -- 10/10 Undertale's story is charming on its own. I don't want to spoil too much, but I will just say that the reason why Undertale's story stands out so much is because the player's actions dictate how the game rolls out, creating a game where different things can happen each playthrough and making the story even more interesting then it already was! Plus it means your actions really do matter! And the characters are so funny and awesome!  Music -- 10/10 This game has so many songs that I really do love! The battle themes are particular my favorite, especially the themes for a certain character met in the third area of the game.  Gameplay -- 9/10 Undertale has a unique battle system where you don't have to kill anyone or you could murder everyone. This affects how the story plays out. Dodging attacks in Undertale is also very literal where you have to move a red heart (Your player's soul) around to doge attacks coming out you. I only wish dodging attacks was a little easier and the game made it a little more obvious about how to spare (not kill) certain monsters. Also if you think the game is too short; Steam glitched out for me and I have actually played probably 15 hours or so. It is short but not too short. :)  Replay Value -- 10/10 This game has so much replay value because of all the easter eggs and choices the player has to make. Plus, the game recognizes that you are replaying the game and characters may recognize you...  Overall: 9.75/10, but I will round to 10/10 If you have any interest for this RPG I can't recommend it enough! I hope I have given you DETERMINATION to buy Undertale!

To review Undertale would spoil Undertale. This is a quick summary of my experience with the game.  Setting aside the loveable character design, fantastic writing, absolutely gorgeous soundtrack and unique approach to turn-based gameplay - Undertale is what you make of it. Your choices affect the game in ways you would (and will not) not expect. It'll make you regret decisions. It'll make you question everything thrown at you. Then the next thing Undertale does will utterly shock you, surprise you or have you laughing hard. Its unpredictability makes it engaging, interesting and completely unique to any game i've ever played.  I cannot express how much I love Undertale. If you are even considering this game, you will not be disappointed.

This is, I believe, the best game of 2015 when it comes to story and nature. Obviously the graphics are not anything like The Last of Us or Until Dawn, but I believe that is what allowed for the game to be so excellent. Not bashing those two games in any way, I should mention, as I'm also a fan of AAA games. Many games become caught up in the sea of how realistic it can appear to the eye, but they tend to lose their meaning within that sea. Undertale has the ability to make you happy, sad, angry, meloncholy, and everything inbetween. You become attached to every single character in the game, no matter how small. So many games can hardly even make the main characters interesting with so much backstory and exposition, while, in Undertale, EVERY SINGLE CHARACTER is different. Even Frisk, who never even says a word, is given a personality based on your own desicions. At surface level, I did not think I would be remotely interested in this game, but I fell head over heels into it. With tonnes of laugh-out-loud moments and scenes filled with emotion, this game is so worth the money paid. Toby Fox did an amazing job with the story, mechanics, music, art, etc. Speaking of the music, BUY THE SOUNDTRACK AS WELL! It's so well made and helps move the plot and causes emotion so much more so than many other games. And as for the mechanics, the game is difficult at times, but does not drag on. For some fights, this is very obvious to whom have played the game in the genocide route, they are formulated so perfectly in order to make you feel so much more empathy-less when they are over. I honestly cannot praise this game anymore so than I have... amazing. Great job, Toby Fox.

Undertale is by no means a perfect game...but it has provided me far more entertainment and downright FUN than most other games I've played recently. It beats out numerous AAA titles in terms of story and originality. You really come to care about the NPCs in this game (my personal favorite is the GREAT PAPYRUS!) which cannot be said as often as one would wish. In fact, it is a game that, though I love it so much, I cannot bring myself to play again lest I destroy the happy ending everyone has achieved.  Positives:  -Story, while not complicated, is engaging -The NPCs are alive with personality -The game 'breaks the rules' of typical rpgs in ways that I will not spoil but find absolutely delightful.  Negatves:  -The puzzles really aren't all that impressive (A small complaint) -Defeating some bosses takes some lateral thinking that requires one to bend one's mind into unusual shapes. -Sometimes, the jokes can get a bit stretched. (But not often)  All in all, I'd still rate this game 10/10. It is everything I could have expected and more from a title of this price.

I can't sum up everything I think about Undertale in a review. So I'll just put in what really matters...  In a way, Undertale reminds me of Half-Life 2. No, wait, where are you going? Hear me out, okay?  When I played each, I had not seen much gameplay and did not know too much about the story. I tried to avoid walkthroughs for both. And I found that I enjoyed both an incredible amount without knowing why. Maybe it's the feel of freedom. Or maybe it's the interesting story and characters. (Okay, HL2 had less of those last two.) Whatever it is, I loved them both.  Anyway. Undertale as an RPG is pretty underwhelming. There are less than ten pieces of armor and weapons respectively (I think), only a total of 95 enemies, excluding special and boss monsters, (I also think) and minimalistic pixel graphics (Which I know for sure) (and which actually help to add character to the game). But that's the thing... Undertale is more than an RPG. A couple of things make it prety unique as a game. Firstly, it's the only RPG I know of where you dodge enemy attacks in a bullet-hell environment. Secondly, it gives you the option to spare every enemy you fight.  I'm not going to spoil the story, only say that it and the characters are really great and could probably rival Telltale Games. A bold statement, but then again that's how I like my fonts. (Reference, I guess...?)  Case in point: Buy Undertale instead of watching someone play it if you can, because having the choice to spare something and making that choice is something else. If you can't then watch someone play it. It's not the same, but you still see what the game has to offer.  If you ignore this game without even looking at it... . . . Y o u ' r e g o n n a h a v e a b a d t i m e .  A game where you don't have to kill anyone, and feel guilty when you do. And still has good jokes. And, if you play the game and see, still has a better love story than Twilight. (Reference.) 10/10 for the butterscotch-cinnamon pie. Thanks, Toriel.

All the feels.  No description does this game justice. I've already spent 30 minutes on this review only to erase everything and start over several times now.  But hey, think of it like this: Take a dash of the Yume Nikki/Earthbound gameplay, with a bit of Cave Story artstyle, add a bit of classic JRPG battles (but ones where you can be friends with everyone instead of killing them, if you so choose). Then imagine the story unfolding in different ways depending on if you're good or bad, with critical plot points to be found in the details of the game that make you realize how wonderfully crafted it all is. The game is littered with all these small hints that are left to the fans to speculate about their meaning, kind of how some parts of the Dark Souls series is intentionally left open to interpretation. These details will change as you do new playthroughs of the game, giving you extra information regarding all the background story to the game.  Undertale has made me feel kind of how it would be if you were in a Hayao Miyazaki movie like Spirited Away, but where the story can take a very, very dark turn if you are so inclined. Like other reviewers have already said, this is more of 'an experience' than a game. It certainly has an active gameplay component, but it's basically a Yume Nikki style visual novel with moral choices for each battle. The battles themselves are usually kind of lackluster if you're used to more intense gameplay, but you don't really have to any grinding if you're going through a pacifist run. In genocide however it's a different story so if you chose to kill everyone: it will take a bit of extra time and it can get tedious.  Overall I would recommend everyone to at least give the demo for this a try. This is a game that has storytelling at it's core. Just make sure to ignore the community. I haven't really had a problem with the community myself, but I guess when people are deeply affectionate towards something that really stirred their emotions, they can have a harder time recognizing other people might not feel the same way.  Summary: I really liked this title and will remember it forever. If you do decide to get this, play it however you want but I recommend it this way: spare everyone in the game, explore the world and talk to the characters, become friends with the main characters and let the story unfold to the natural end. Then if you want more, there is more. This is the point where you might want to look up a wiki or talk to a friend who has played the game.

I'm not gonna write a big, detailed review of the plot etc. simply because I am really not sure how to - this game, as it was said in a couple of reviews that I've read, is a little hard to... eh, comment on? But slight (!) spoilers and personal opinion ahead, I guess.  First of all, the game is well-made. Didn't experience any bugs   besides those I was  supposed to  experience  , the music is amazing and, despite what some might consider as childish graphics (as I've seen people say on some occasions), I personally thought that the game was pretty enough.  I've only played through the True Pacifist route - I didn't kill anyone, didn't fight anyone besides the two final bosses of the Neutral route and don't have any wish to reset; and even if I did, I wouldn't have the heart to. In the end, even the characters I initially considered slightly annoying grew on me.   Well, a character. I, at first, didn't like Undyne very much, but she's actually great.    It's described as 'The RPG game where you don't have to destroy anyone', and, honestly, you don't even want to.  But it fills you with determination.

Now I know this game is called overrated occaisonally, and I can see where it's coming from. I don't agree with that opinion AT ALL, however. This is one of the best games I've ever played, and at forst, I could BARELY TELL WHY. And then I realized:This game is absolutely amazing. The soundtrack is great, the combat is unique and challenging ((at times)), the boss fights all have unique properties, and the game certainly has an interesting sense of humor, certainly bringing a skeleTON of laughs. But above all that, it was the emotional attachement to the characters as you play the game as a pacifist. At first, this game had just been a suggestion from a friend, and I knew very little about the game. The trailer does NOT do this game's slay/spare system justice. It doesn't tell about how the bosses and overall story will change. !!(Spoilers for a quick sec)!! At first, I was convinced I couldn't save Toriel, and I was forced to kill her. As I saw her tumble into dust and saw her heart break, I felt as if something had socked me in the chest. Then, I discovered you COULD save her, and I reset the game and did so; however, this game does not let you forget your sins. Flowey reminded me that I HAD murdered her, but this incedent made me realize how strongly the game made feel for a character, despite having them on screen for less than half an hour. And I knew from that moment on, a genocide run would be impossible.  Bottom line: GET THIS GAME.

Being honest I didn't take much interest in Undertale when I first saw it, mainly because this style/genre doesn't interest me an awful lot, however after seeing some cleverly written dialogue within the game as well as all my friends raving about it, I decided that there was no harm in trying it. I can safely say, that buying this game is the best $10 I've ever spent on anything in my entire life. Somehow this game that I had no intention of really acknowledging has now become my personal favourite game of all time. The writing and dialogue, as well as the cast of characters which was what originally interested me are perfectly written with clever uses of comedy as well as subtle commentaries of how people and society behave and act, being elegentally woven into the games atmosphere rather than shoved down the players throat. As well as the comedy being extremely well done, the game knows when it wants to be very serious and focus on the central idea of the game, being the justifications of your actions, and believe me when your enemies have this much character to them, you better have good reason for doing what you 'must' do. The story and writing is extremely strong however accompanied by the soundtrack just makes the experience and immersion infinetly better. Each piece is greatly unique and great to listen to, hell as I'm writing this review I am listening to the soundtrack right now. What surprised me the most however was the fighting mechanic and the gameplay towards that. The options to attack or passively spare your enemies is a lovely touch and adds a layer of complexity to the fighting. The challenge of dodging the enemies attacks is deeply satisfying as well as not being too challenging to make the player angry, well at least in my playthroughs i didnt get mad Overall this is a masterfully crafted piece of art, there arent many games where I would play twice in a row and enjoy the experience more the second time. Give this game a try, it'll fill you with determination.

I hate traditional turn based games. Final Fantasy, Poke-Mans, They both bore me. The only turn based games I liked were the first Paper Mario games, the Mario and Luigi franchise, and the original Super Mario RPG. But I'm adding Undertale to the top of that list because it also has an amazing story, and you could consider the turn based actions as a part of the storytelling. Not just the bosses. You need to play this for yourself. Don't spoil yourself with this game. Watch 1 or 2 gameplay videos like from steam train or something, but nothing more, and only if you need absolute confirmation this has an amazing story. I'm not done with it myself, but I know from thus far how much actual care was put into this game.  10/10 Never Forgetti, Papyrus's Spaghetti

You may be asking: 'Why do you have 2 days' worth of hours put into this game? Isn't it just a dumb ol' story-based RPG?' Well my friend, that's because this game has so much gosh darn replayability that you can and will put at least a day's worth of your life into it. In a good way. This game will change the way you play RPGs and may even change the way you go about your daily life. I know it did for me.  A  few  lot of reasons to play Undertale: - You will fall in love with at least one character in this game, I gurantee it. And if you don't, you're playing the game wrong. - The soundtrack is amazing, and each character has their own track which fits their personality perfectly - If you play the game a certain way you will end up hating yourself possibly more than you hate the final boss. - There are skeleton puns galore - I've never played a game that used the word 'tsundere' even once, let alone twice. - Beating some bosses is a legitimate challenge and learning how to beat them is satisfying - Each boss has a unique style of combat despite the game's limited combat mechanics, which is honestly really impressive - Speaking of combat mechanics, this game is super simple to learn, but difficult to master - So many little secrets, like you have no idea. I had to look things up on the wiki to make sure I wasn't missing anything. - There are at least 4 dogs. And if you don't like dogs, well, it's possible to kill them I guess but that's a bit cruel.  Recommended? A thousand times yes.

This is not the place to get too in-depth with a discussion of Undertale, so I'll be brief;  Undertale is a very important game. If you haven't played it yet, you probably should.  I do not mean to sing it's praises. It's not a perfect game by a long shot. In fact, I have some big issues with it, most notably with the way that the plot is structured. After my first playthrough, I was left dissappointed and unsatisfied.  But then I played it a little more. And then more after that. And by now, I've played it a lot. Even though I didn't enjoy it at first, I kept going. Hell, I'm probably going to keep playing even after I beat my current playthrough. Why?  Because Undertale may be one of the smartest games I have ever played. It is consistently surprising, even after 20 hours of gameplay. There is an absolutely absurd attention to detail, and I am not being hyperbolic. It is so, so clever. And more importantly, It is really, REALLY good at making you think about your choices. Undertale will hit you where it hurts; it will force you to act and then force you to confront the consequences of said actions. It is a tour de force of emotions. It may not be pretty, but from a design it is absolutely beautiful.  I love Undertale. I really, really do. It took me a while to realize it, but I love this game. Because for everythat it does, for all of it's failures and triumphs, it always succeeds in provoking thought. Even when it fumbles, you can pull something meaningful from it. Undertale will teach you about yourself just as much as it will teach you about the medium it exists in.  Also the soundtrack is pretty ok.

There are constantly new enemies being introduced and the gamepay and puzzles continue to stay fresh. It actually gets better as you go along. If you've been thinking about getting Undertale, DO IT!!!

This is a great game. however because alot of people have put it on such a high podium it doesnt deserve, im gonna look at the cons. dont get me wrong i love the game too but people need to see the problems    besides the toxic community, they already know about that.    it uses a lot of the same songs just very slightly modified. take for example the Dog song, temmie shop and the 'dunked on' theme. they are all the same song just modified versions of each other. or how about spider dance, napstablooks house theme and DUMMY!, they all have similar sounding melodys in them. but in the games defence, Toby Fox cannot read sheet music (or at least ive heard he cant, thats why we dont have alot of sheet music for the game) so he would have a hard time coming up with new music if he couldnt put it down on paper.  another problem is the insane difficulty spikes in the genocide route. you breeze through the first 2 areas and then undyne the un-fricken- dying comes up and is the SECOND hardest boss in the genocide run. same goes for sans. and his fight has NO invincibilty frames, lingering damage, and some of the most insane attacks to dodge (if you can even do THAT) and whats worst is there is no way to make that fight any easier. people may say 'frying pan and real knife and use all the good healing items' but i used them all on UNDYNE which, has the same sort of ability as sans because it feels like your invincibilty frames have dropped to only one second. that means more damage is taken, which in turn means i need healing items more often and better ones. and the graphics i understand are supposed to be a throw back to older RPGs like earthbound, but they still lack any sort of detail to make it really pop out at you. i would also expected some COLOR in the fights! and i dont mean blue (papyrus/sans), orange(asgore/ some hotland enemies), purple (muffet), and yellow(some of mettatons attacks) attacks and your soul color  this game is good, dont get me wrong but it still has problems. i dont mean to discourage it but all the nice things have been said about it and nobody has worked up the nerve to speak up and say its not the best game ever. i give it a 9/10 not perfect but lovable and quirky

I ran into this game during the Christmas sale of 2015. I saw it was rated overwhelmly positive so I picked it up for 7 bucks. All I can say is WOW at the fact that this was created by ONE developer. It has a amazing soundtrack that superglues you to the game to keep playing (My favorite is the Ruins because it gives me nostalgia). The gameplay is very unique compared to my 2 favorite RPGs (Paper Mario: The 1000 Year Door, Paper Mario). The game is 24+ hours if you want experience EVERYTHING that this game offers. Luckily I did not spoil this game like I tend to do with games like Until Dawn. All of the characters make you feel like you are in the actual game and are very relatable to. My final verdict is to get this game if you have not spoiled it. If you have, do NOT buy this game. Otherwise, I rate this game 10/10. Amazing soundtrack, relatable characters, nostalgic graphics.

This game is what most games have forgotten what games are made for: just to have fun and have a good time. It is not like 'kill all the monster and get bonus levels' or 'collect all the items and do all the side quests'. It is really absolutely just to have a very good time. It is funny, it es emotional, it just entertains the player. But it is very deep and philosophic, too. As I played it, I did not have the thought 'I have to play it, because I want more EXP or kill more enemies' I played it, beacuse I really wanted to know, what comes next, what the story is and just for fun. This game made me laugh more than all the other video games together I played before. It really gives you just a good feeling. And it's RPG-elements are SO MUCH better than those of big-budget-RPGs like Dragon Age. Really, in Undertale, you have the feeling that the NPCs actually live, and have their own thoughts and emotions, and that they are REAL and not just NPCs. This game made me survive a really hard time and helped me literally to start laughing again and love something and really get emotional. Thank you for this. This is more, than a game, this is really a piece of Art. Go and play it, really.  What I want to mention especially is, that all the characters are nice, what gives the game this wonderful atmosphere. No one says something bad about the other, and when you as the player get judged, than only by your actions. It is the game, where I, personally, like every single NPC. And I think, the gerat NPCs are one of the reasons for it's absolutely wonderful atmosphere. Go and play it. And the soundtrack is just wow. It is literally just wow. One of the best Soundtracks I've ever heard.

Wow.  Just. Wow.  I don't even know how to expressmy fealings about this game. So many triple-A titles out there for 50, 60, even 100 dolars. That aren't even half as good as this indie game. Pretty much everything about this game is absolutely amazing. The story, the gameplay, the soundtrack, oh man, the soundtrack. The caracters, the jokes. It's even progressive. Honestly, $10 isn't even half as much as this game is worth.  Two of the things that I found most impressive was the nailing of the 'choose your own path' theme, and the fourth wall breaking. This game makes you feel bad about killing. And it's an RPG. The reason why is that you don't need to. You don't need to kill anyone at all actually, if you want to go through the Pasifist Route. Or you can go around slaghtering everything in your path, regretting more and more until eventually you come to peace with being a monster. And on top of all that... It's part dating simulator!  If you don't own this game, you will not regret taking a few seconds of your time and $10 dolars out of your wallet, but I can't promise you won't regret your actions in the game... 10/10

Undertale. What can I say about this that hasn't already been written? Undertale is a top down RPG where the choices you make have ramifications. There is no wrong way to play, Undertale - but you will experience it best if you play through more than once, and if you try different things each time.  Definitely not a game that should be judged by its cover. 10/10 worth getting.

To be fair I am a 16-bit RPG fiend. I think SNES is the Golden Age of video games and brought out the best games in history. Obviously, this game is designed for people like me. Retro RPG Nostalgia. This is the best game I've played in a long time.  What I liked: Memorable and dynamic characters. Great soundtrack. Innovative battle system. Pokes fun of classic video game cliches. Extremely replayable. Level Design. Amazing story.  Some things I did not like so much: Difficulty obtaining items. Limited Inventory (which felt like an intentional design consideration). Difficulty leveling up (There are a finite quantity of monsters to fight so you can't grind. Again, an intentional design consideration.)   If you don't like retro-games or RPGs this game might not be for you, but if you do this is right up your ally.

This game is truly one of the best games I have ever played. The story is genuine and heartfelt, the soundtrack fits the game perfectly, and the 'bullet-hell' defence minigame spices up the battle mechanics, even if you choose to do a peaceful run of the game.  In most games with branching storylines, only your dialogue choices and actions against a few key NPCs will determing whether you get the 'good' or 'bad' ending. Not so in Undertale. The smallest and most insignificant enemies are people too, and if you kill them, the game will treat you like the murderer you are. If you battle an enemy and win, they are dead, and dead forever. There is no protection of the 'important' characters.  So what will you choose? Do you go with your RPG instincts and kill the enemies to improve your stats? Or you do what the game tells you to do, and be nice? There is no hiding behind 'the game mechanics made me do it' - your actions are your own.  My only problem is that it's a little short, particularly by RPG standards, and while the character design is unique and interesting, the enviroments have rather bland texturing. Buy it, play it. Easily my favorite game of 2015.

I... There's no honest way for me to put into words my feelings on this game. Not appropriately anyway. Before playing it for myself, I had heard plenty of people, friends, celebrities, reviewers, websites, etc. all saying how great of a game this was.  None of their commentary prepared me for the game that Undertale actually is. It is wonderful. It is charming. It is heartbreaking. It is heart warming. Undertale encompases EVERYTHING I love about narrative games. Literally everything: convincing and charming characters, compelling story, choices, forks in the road, consequences... EASTER EGGS GALORE. Tongue in cheek humor, blatant humor, dry humor... Emotions.  I can't recommend this game enough. I simply can't. It was so good, and I'm STILL feeling the effects of it, even now. I literally just finished it, and knew that I had to write a review. This is a game everyone needs to play. It doesn't matter if you're a traditional gamer, casual gamer, CoD type gamer... Everyone should play Undertale.  AND DON'T YOU DARE ONLY PLAY IT ONCE AND QUIT AFTER THAT! There are reasons you should play it multiple times, but I cannot and will not explain why, only that you should. I'm sure you'll figure it out on your own. :)  IN the end: Undertale is now my absolute favorite game, and I am honestly looking forward to seeing what the Undertale Team has in store for us next.

This is absolutely a necessary game to play. It may look a bit unappealing in the pictures, but this game combines a fantastic story with a beautiful soundtrack, excellent gameplay and completely memorable characters in a way I haven't seen from an entirely original game in a very long time. Everthing about it is fantastic in my mind, and I've never cried at the end of a game before, but the emotions felt at the end of this game (and even throughout it) brought me to tears. It even has a message that seems to be completely lost in modern games today, where eveything is dark and grim, and there's no hope. Even if you don't get emotional, at least understand that this is one of the best games in the last decade, and maybe even the last two, and it can't be missed. Don't let the hype scare you. It's completely warranted, and Toby Fox has created a masterpiece.

Undertale. Pros: - Good soundtrack. No, seriously. Go give it a listen.  - The combat. It's a bit weird, but I found it to be pretty okay once I got used to it. You have to time your attacks, but you also have to dodge enemies' attacks. By the way, the enemies are pretty bullet-hellish. That's what makes it -really- fun.  - The story, plot, and characters. If you're playing Undertale and you already know what's going to happen, it wouldn't be a good experience anymore. The story, plot, and characters are pretty much what's going to keep you going if the combat and graphics don't cut it for you. It's an emotional, crazy, fun ride.  - Dialogue. Just get past the 'tutorial section' and you'll know what I mean.  Neutral Points, Also may be Cons: - Graphics. I'm a big fan of pixel art and stuff, but I'm pretty sure not everyone is. Plus, combat is in black & white, which also might not appeal to everyone.  - Game length. I went through it pretty fast, but that's mainly because I was binging it and didn't really stop to look around and explore. I'd say a regular playthrough would last around 2.5 - 3.5 hours. Though, I'd say the game length doesn't matter; the content does.  Stuff and Verdict: I'm trying my best not to spoil anything because Undertale is meant to be played through blind. Seriously. Knowing what to do and knowing what happens because of what you did will take away a LOT of the enjoyment from the game. If you do plan on buying the game, avoid spoilers. Don't go on any subreddit or watch an LP of a YouTuber. Pick up the demo, see if you like it, then pick the game up. Once again, Undertale is an experience that'll stick with you for the rest of your gaming life if you do decide to grab it.  Score: 9/10. It ain't perfect, but it's pretty damn close. I'm only removing 1 point since I did find the game to be a tad shorter than expected. Still good, though~!

Undertale is a game like no other.  I have never seen a game as well thought out as Undertale. It's hard to talk about without spoiling something. It is extremely story driven. This game makes you feel what the characters feel. The music is extremely captivating. Besides all of this, it is EXTREMELY unique. You are not required to kill anyone, however, you are given the option to do so. Before playing Undertale, I never played retro styled games. I strongly disliked them because I was so used to modern graphics and gameplay. Undertale gave me a new respect for retro games.   I would love to say more but I don't want to spoil it.

(SPOILER FREE)    I went into this game almost blind. I only knew it was an RPG, and that people loved it. At first I found it hard to get past the odd graphics, but once I did, I was hooked. I completed my first run of the game in 6 hours over the course of two days, and I'm already an hour into my second run. There's so many layers of humor, tragedy, and excitement that its almost impossible to put down once you're into it. Not to mention that you can get a different ending almost every time depending on the choices you make.   The characters you encounter are surprisingly 3 dementional for a 2-D game. In that they too have layers, motives, and much more then meets the eye. They are also very detailed and intriguing in design, and that doesn't just apply to the main plot characters. But also to the common monster's you encounter on random, with each one having their own personality and unique traits.  There is however, one character that no matter how you play through is always evil. But he/she even has a few intriguing traits. (Assuming you play through a few times) Despite their only motive being pure insanity and destruction. Not to mention a few 4th wall breaks.  For the encounters and game-play, its pretty basic. You can either fight, act, use an item, or have mercy. Attacking brings you to a very brief time based mini-game that does more damage depending on how well you do. Acting allows you to reason with the monster, making them more comfortable around you. Allowing you to 'spare' them. And each monster has a specific quality that you can exploit to make them like you. Item's are primarily healing buffs. Mercy allows you to spare or flee the monster. Although you can only spare them if their name turns yellow. Which comes from them not wanting to fight anymore.  After your turn, its theirs. And each monster has a unique attack at your heart, that you need to carefully dodge. It starts off simple but progressively gets more creative and difficult.   The environment is also quite well detailed and creative. And the puzzles, while being a bit repetitive at times, never fail to amuse me. Not to mention the music is also great as well.   All in all, Undertale is a solid game, with no legitimate complaints from my point of view. Its a game that could easily go toe-to-toe with any AAA story-telling game. Toby Fox did an extraordinary job and I personally can't wait to see what he does next.  10/10
