How to feel guilty about everything you do: the video game.  This is maybe the first immersive game I have played in about as long as I can remember. Replay value goes through the roof because there are so many different ways to do things. There are constant hints and foreshadowing throughout the entire game, none of it too subtle to miss but none of it so blatant as to ruin the experience. It's a goofy, silly, childish game, with dead serious hard hitting adult subjects. I played it 6 times, and have yet to do the genocide route for number 7. (was too busy trying get the real ending) It breaks the fourth wall in probably the most amazing way ever, and is smart, it knows when you're cheating or have erased your save file and calls you out on it subtly. The gameplay is nothing special, neither are the puzzles, but the writing is ♥♥♥♥ing amazing the complexity and the way they went so out of the box.  8/10 storline (A lot of it was too happy-go-childish for me) 10/10 replay value 7/10 gameplay 4/10 graphics 9/10 immersiveness (impressive for a 2d pixel game) 11/10 value for the money you pay to buy it (seriously, how is a game THIS good so cheap?)  Someone told me this was voted best game ever, beating even ocarina of time. I don't know if I would agree, but it's certainly up there. If all games were as entertaining as this, I don't think I would ever leave my house.

I do admit, though, what makes it not just good but exceptional, is the replayability of it. I see how, if you just played through it for the first time expecting mind blowing stuff, you might be a bit confused. Not that the first play though isn't great, but there are some major strengths this game has (that I've never seen done before?) that you will miss if you don't do a second, even third, playthrough. And the game itself is just short enough for that to not be too dull. Not to mention lovable and unique characters, and a stellar soundtrack!

Wow...  What can I say about Undertale that hasn't been said before? It was one of the most moving experiences I had in a video game this past year.  If you spent any amount of time looking at this game, you probably already know that the main selling point is that no one has to die; every monster you encounter, every boss you fight, you can talk to them and convince them not to fight you. You probably also know that the game has several different endings, most importantly a Neutral, Pacifist and Genocide ending.  For your own sake, do not look up anything else about the game.  Undertale is a game best experienced completely blind. And while many fans of the game will tell you to immediately aim for the Pacifist ending, to restart the game if you ever kill anything, I have to tell you: do not listen to them! Undertale is not something you need to play 'correctly', it is something you need to experience for yourself.   When I personally played it, I wanted to do a Pacifist ending first, but I made a mistake along the way. After thinking about it for a while, I thought that I simply needed to live with the consequences of what I did, and it made my experience so much better. I had several moments in the game where I looked back at that mistake and felt sorry about the way things turned out. It might sound strange, but it was a far more compelling experience than just thinking 'good thing I reloaded and fixed it'. Eventually, I finished the game with the Neutral ending, and while it felt like a complete game, I wasn't satisfied. I went back to complete a Pacifist ending, I discovered parts of the game I never even knew existed, and finally, I felt good about myself for finishing this game.  The story, the characters, everything about this game feels so amazing. I honestly haven't felt such a connection to the characters I talked with in a long time. To give you a bit of perspective, Undertale is the only game I ever played in which I simply couldn't bring myself to replay it just to experience the 'evil' ending. Honest to god review from someone who loved the game to death. Let me go over the cons first, because there are way too many positives in this review section. - A bit easy, but it can be forgiven. - ♥♥♥♥♥♥ post-atari but pre-nes graphics (With the exception of a few scenes and the battles/shops) - Bad fandom (You've probably seen them.) - Plot Dumps. Lots of reading. - Battle system where only their turn matters (It's unique, but I'd sure like it more if it wasn't a case of 'press a button and then leave') - Game acknowledges it's a game, tries to go meta, and fails because it's a game (That's only a small one though) - SoQuirky tumblr humour. - Kinda cliche in a lot of places  Now let's go over some positives. - God tier soundtrack. - Incredible writing / Character development. - Heartwarming - Includes a 'strong and independant' woman, a homosexual relationship and ambiguous genders (For the SJW types. Don't worry, it doesn't preach it.) - Multiple routes, lots of secrets, easter eggs and extra content to last you a long while. - Extremely fun bullet hell RPG setup - I did kind of like the humour i guess  This game isn't for everyone. It's a niche RPG that tells a satisfying story and will stick with you. There's a demo you can play that will take you to the end of the first area, and if you don't like it by then, then don't buy the game. Just watch a lets play if you liked it but don't want to blow £7. It's a story game, you really won't miss out on anything but the fustration of getting slammed.
It's fun. Props Toby, Props.

Undertale has a lot to say with its world and characters. It wants to remind you that it's worth putting effort into everything you do. It reminds you to be playful and take every joy out of life.   It wants you to know that you are loved, and that it is worth being loving. It wants you to feel powerful -- to know that you can use that power and kind spirit to improve the lives of the monsters (people) around you.  Undertale has a lot of barriers to entry - if you don't enjoy the retro style, the graphics won't immerse you. If you don't enjoy chiptune music, the soundtrack won't inspire you. But if you do enjoy these and you have a desire or a need for the core message that's being delivered, you won't see the minor imperfections. This game becomes a perfect 10.  I love it. I don't give a damn, I love it and it's my favorite piece of art ever.

Why UNDERTALE? Why to choose:  *Bad Graphics *Stupid dialogues *Vague fight system *Awful story ?  That's what a typical hater would say. [PAPYRUS] NYEH HEH HEH! [/papyrus]   For me, Undertale is a unique game, fined in every aspect.  Story about a human falling into underground may to be pointed as a 'bad copy of Alice in the Wonderland' because all you will see is a human child venturing through the monster underground world, full of dully looking, childish monsters.   From loving frogs, depressed wasps, cowardice cyclops, healthcare vegetables, bad-joking birds, poshy hat lovers, playful small and big dogs, self-confident weightlifters, dirt-hating cleaners, shy opera singers, mad cute dogs (tEM lOVES dOGS), both true and fake slimey cakes, loving walking volcanoes, flirty thunderplanes, heaty ropes... and many more, like pun-loving skeletons, goat people...  Weird looking locations, stupid mazes, illogical fights... welp, you gotta start somewhere.  This game's all so weird it's hella epic!  FINAL VERDICT: 11/10    THE STEAM AWARDS   NOMINATION: THE “VILLAIN MOST IN NEED OF A HUG” AWARD     REASON: The 'true' villain of UNDERTALE - Flowey, originally Asriel Dreemurr, deserves a hug, a big warm hug, because in the end, he was not much of a big bad guy, too. He just needed love, not L. O. V. E.

This game isn't as perfect as people may say it is, but it's polished to heck and back and is a real masterpiece of it's genre.  An RPG of the finest caliber. The characters are wonderful to interact with, so great in fact that you wish they were real. The moral choice system is spot on, the world reacting in a way that makes sense to your actions with no bar to represent good and evil. All actions and paths the player takes have very obvious consequences, and it never feels like your choices don't actually matter, unless the game forces that kind of result in a way to convey certain tones. The only bad part I can think of is a boss battle against a character near the end, where it really seems sloppily done and doesn't fit in with the environment of the area nor the tone of the game as a whole. The combat is marvelous overall though, normal JRPG mechanics with an interesting Bullet Hell system to let you avoid any attacks, it sounds easy, but in reality, it can be quite a challenging game. Honestly, if you think you'll like this game, you probably will. If you like RPGs and games with a good sense of humor, then you should give this a try.

***Undertale SPOILER FREE Review***    Let's talk a little bit about Undertale. Now, in all honesty, I feel my review of this game is going to be quite a bit different than a lot of other people out there, because my experience with classic J-RPGs is pretty limited. I’ve never played any of the games in the Mother series, Final Fantasy series, or even any of the traditional Pokemon games. Now before you get out your hammers, nails, and crosses, hear me out. I’m in a rare situation where I can a write a review that isn’t so damn high on nostalgia that it goes to Taco Bell at 2 O’Clock in the morning to order everything on the menu, only to forget about 10 minutes later and fall asleep in the parking lot. That being said, I highly recommend watching or reading other reviews after this one if you want to see some comparisons to older games.   So, what exactly IS Undertale? Well, according to the Steam tags, Undertale is a Cute and Funny Retro Indie RPG, that can also be a Dark, Psychological Horror Comedy game, as your Choices Matter and can lead you to Multiple Endings. As a Single-Player game, it is very Story Rich, as it should be, including some elements from other types of games, such as the Bullet Hell from Binding Of Isaac and the Dating Simulation of Hatoful Boyfriend. All of this is packaged and presented in a beautiful 2D Pixel Graphics style, coupled with a Great Soundtrack, that allows for a ton of replay value. It also has memes.   To me, Undertale is a game that seems like it was designed to hit a specific demographic, and failed miserably. By that, I mean it attracted way more attention than it intended to. But you know what? I think that’s a good thing. Like I said earlier, this game is of a genre that I had THOUGHT I had little to no interest in, but since it’s so well made I feel like I’ve actually grown as a gamer after playing it.     Normally I’d start off by talking about the game’s visuals, but there isn’t really too much to say when it comes to pixel art. It tends to be either good, or bad. There isn’t really too much of an in-between, and Undertale’s pixel art is good. (Look, I’m not an artist, I can’t draw a stick figure without a ruler. I’m not the person to ask about the pixelated graphics style)   Now for the music, something I feel I can spend a little bit more time talking about. I myself am I pretty big fan of video game music. The music in this game is like, insanely great, to the point where I’m listening to the soundtrack as I write this review. There are some games that I’ve played where it feels like the music is a second thought, you know, something added after development just to make the game less dull. Undertale would walk over to those types of games and hit them with a comically-sized hammer, before making a pun that breaks the fourth-wall and makes you smile, even though you didn’t really want to, that’s just the type of game it is. The music sets the mood perfectly in almost every scenario, something many games fail to do. Sure, some games may get the intense boss-battle music or the friendly town music down pretty good, but most games don’t have a soundtrack that is fantastic regardless of where you are or what you are doing in the game world. After playing Undertale for a little over an hour, I had to stop and look up who the developer of the game hired to make the music, and to my surprise it WAS the developer. So, props to you, Toby Fox, for being another person I can add to the list of people I will never be as talented as.   So, what about the actual gameplay? Undertale plays like you would expect a turn-based RPG to play like, but with some pretty big differences. First off, rather than just selecting an attack, confirming it, then having your opponent select an attack and confirm it, Undertale’s combat has a surprising amount of depth. When you perform an attack, you need to time it properly and hit a “sweet spot” to achieve maximum damage. When your opponent performs an attack, you do not immediately receive damage, but are able to avoid their attack by moving around your “Soul” in a manner similar to most top down shooters. This essentially means that if you are good enough, you can complete the entire game without taking damage. However, that won’t be easy as the game continuously ramps up in difficulty, and throws in new mechanics to keep fights interesting as the story progresses.   All of this is great, but is there anything else to it? Yes, actually, quite a bit. The game advertises itself as “The RPG where you don’t have to destroy anyone.”, and one can accomplish this in a very unique way. If any of you have played Dishonored, you would know that in order to peacefully beat that game, you would have to subdue your targets through methods such as strangulation and shooting sleep darts. This differs greatly from Undertale, because in Undertale you don’t need to do anything to the enemies at all, except talk to them. Undertale has an ACT menu whilst in battles, and accessing it will give you specific interactions with each enemy type. By using these different interactions, you can persuade the enemies until they are no longer interested in fighting you. Now, if you’re as cynical as me you might be thinking, “So what, it’s just a gimmick, right?” Surprisingly, no. Undertale is a very adaptive game, and changes DRASTICALLY based upon the decisions you make. And I mean DRASTICALLY. To the point where, it’s worth playing through the entire game multiple times to see how your decisions of violence or nonviolence shape the world around you.   So, I think that about wraps things up for Undertale. There’s a lot more to talk about, but I’d rather just end things here to avoid any spoilers. Undertale an experience that I enjoyed greatly, and if anything in this review has peaked your interest, then I think you’ll enjoy it too.

This Game is good. It isn't the best rpg, or the greatest game of all time. Many fans hype it up to be THE GREATEST THING EVER, but I can't really agree with it. I love games like Earthbound. I love Mother 3 as well. I find those two games to be better than this one. This game has a strong beginning, but it gets worse as it goes on. After Waterfall (which is the best area in the game IMO) the games slowly gets worse. Once the character Alphys gets introduced the game feels like it has to talk to you nonstop to remind you 'IM FUNNY RIGHT?” It gets a little irritating. The game also gets more linear and boring. The combat in Undertale is... all right. The bullet hell inspired selections are really fun, but have huge difficulty spikes. But combat is repetitive and boring, and when you’re doing a genocide run it’s SO bad. The pixel art in Undertale is a little ugly at times too. The over world sprites are bad, showing little to no detail. The battle sprites all much better, but in a weird design choice aren't in color. It does give the game some style however. I know some people might not enjoy the lack of color, but I don’t mind it too much. It may seem like I hate this game, but I don’t. I might not feel like it's the greatest game of all time, but it’s still good, and DEFINIETLY WORTH PLAYING! It’s an experience. By the way I don’t find Ocarina of Time the best game either so I’m not just saying it isn’t the best game because of that. I can’t get into why I don’t like Ocarina of Time in this review however.

It's been a little over a year since Undertale came out. Chances are at this point that, if you're reading this review, you've heard about this game somewhere on the internet and are curious to see if it really is worth checking out.  Short answer:  Yes. It's fun and funny and doesn't cost much.  Long answer: Despite what you might have heard from the especially rabid fans out there, this isn't the best game ever. No game is, really. What it is, however, is a very well done RPG with quirky humor and lovable characters that those who have played the Mother series or some of the earlier Mario RPGs would be right at home with. To get a little idea of what I'm talking about when it comes to this game's sense of humor, check out the 'about this game' and trailer above.  Anyway, utilizing an interesting 'bullet hell' method of dodging enemy attacks as well as methods to 'spare' enemies, this game brings quite a few new ideas to the table while playing with some of the genre's typical conventions. All of that is helped along with one of the best soundtracks I've heard from an indie title.  I admit, I was put off by a lot of the hype wrapped around this game when its fandom took off but my friends kept telling me to give it a chance. In the end, I'm glad I did and I hope you'll give it a chance too. You just might find it as charming as I did.

I actually remember playing the Undertale demo in 2013. I almost forgot about it entirely until I saw it on my steam homepage and said 'Oh yeah, that game is a thing.'  I had a good time with the demo, and an even better time with the game. The story is wonderful, characters are charming, and the music is incredible. It's a perfect tribute not just to the MOTHER series, but to RPGs as a whole.  That being said, I do have some minor gripes: The regular enimies never use the soul changing abilities the bosses do, and visually there could have been a lot more done. The biggest issue is the game's replayability. After playing through it twice, going through the Ruins and Snowdin felt like a drag (and don't get me started on the Alphys stuff; I get it's purposley kinda annoying but on playthrough 2 it's just regular annoying).   Regardless, you really should give UNDERTALE a shot. Yeah the fandom is sucky, but a crappy community shouldn't stop you from experiencing Undertale's brilliance.

EDIT for the steam awards in december:  I feel like this game deserves either (or both) the ' I'm not crying, there's something in my eye ' award (I've seen plenty of people talking about how they cried when playing the game). I've seen someone ask a question to a person who just beat the game: 'So, at what point during the final fight did you start crying?'. This is also the reason why I nominated it for the ' Villain Most In Need Of A Hug ' award. I literally cannot think of a game that would deserve that second award more than this game.  -----------------------------------------------------  First of all, DO NOT WATCH VIDEOS OF THE GAME. If you do, you're going to lose a huge part of the fun that the game offers.   So, let's see what I can tell you about the game without spoiling it for you:  - you play as a child that climbed up a mountain (from which, as legends say, nobody ever returns), fell down, and is now underground in a world full of monsters  - the monsters may or may not be the type of 'monsters' you'd expect  - the characters are amazing  - the game pokes fun at stereotypical RPG/gaming elements  - the game offers you different ways of going through the world and storyline, which causes BIG consequences  - the games is full of different types of jokes, including puns (consider this a 'PUN WARNING')  - it gets very emotional at times. Might feel kind of like a rollercoaster. Keep in mind, what happens in the end depends upon YOU.  - the game has a fandom that can be both awesome and terrible, depending on which sites you visit. If you're going to play, try not to visit fan-sites before finishing it as fanart contains spoilers. Lots of them.  - the soundtrack is amazing. If you want to hear some samples, I'd recommend you google videos of 'Undertale OST - Megalovania' ; 'Undertale OST - Spider Dance' or 'Undertale OST - Ghost Fight'. Those are my favorites. Just don't look into the comments or descriptions as, again, those contain spoilers.  - the type of humour that the game and it's creator have... If you want to see if you're going to enjoy the humour, just... look at the game's Steam Store page. Read the 'About This Game' and 'Reviews' section. It's one of the few games where it might actually be fun to check it out.  Overall, I think that the game is... well, kind of a masterpiece, really. Oh, and it has a demo which can be found on the game's website. Try it out if you don't believe me. (fun-fact: the demo's manual changes depending on what you do). I'd say it's pretty impressive that all of this was made by a single person.

A cult game of 2015.  Pros : 　• Fantastic story-writing. 　• The developer thought of everything. You can make so many choices, and the characters are aware of your choices. Even when you think they could not possibly be. 　• Excellent music with professional attention to leitmotifs. 　• Game is small and runs not only on Windows, but also on Linux. 　• Minimal hardware requirements. Runs perfectly even on the slowest of modern hardware. 　• Excellent community support. Stuck in game? Questions about plot? Desperate for more content? You can find anything in the Internet about this game. 　• More than meets the eye. Way, WAY more.   Cons : 　• Graphics are rather bad, except in a few select parts. 　• Understanding the game’s plot requires commitment. If you are not ready for that commitment, the game will leave you with a bitter taste. But if you are willing to push through that, the game will reward you immensely. 　• Fanatic fans. If you letsplay this game, make absolutely sure you will NOT read ANY feedback until you’re through. They WILL be full of spoilers and aggressive back-seat gaming that DO ruin your experience and leave you with a bitter taste. Do NOT listen to them. You get so much more out of the game by discovering it on your own.   I do mean that. The game is designed to challenge existing gaming conventions, and you get the best experience when you let it subvert and reshape your expectations.

The hype surrounding this game is astounding. If you're reading this and haven't played Undertale yet, that's likely to make you very apprehensive about purchasing it. Therefore, I'd ask you to try and not let the rabid fanbase turn you away from this game, and let pure curiosity and information drive your purchase.  In case you don't know, Undertale is an RPG. But it's a special RPG. In this game, you play as a human who has fallen into the Underground, a place full of monsters, trying to get home. The typical JRPG shticks of random encounters, turn-based combat systems, and more are all in place, but there are a few changes. For one, instead of automatically being hit by enemy attacks, or having a random chance to dodge them, you enter what's similar to a 'bullet hell,' avoiding the attacks as they come at you. Additionally, there's one other key difference: you may spare the monsters you're fighting. In fact, you don't have to kill a single monster in the whole game. Or you can kill all of them. It's up to you.  As you can probably tell from looking at it, this game is very retro-inspired, both in visuals and soundtrack (which I adore), and its similarity to Earthbound is uncanny. If you enjoyed that game, I'd recommend Undertale without a second thought. I wouldn't be surprised if you liked it  more.   But that's where the hype factor comes in.  Overwhelmingly positive reviews on Steam and a giant fandom tend to worry some people. I can understand that, but...   Undertale is by far and away my favourite game of all time.   Well, I say game, and I really should say experience. As a game, the spare mechanic can be looked at as nothing more than a gimmick, and another way to do damage. I had a lot of fun playing Undertale, but not due to it being a 'fun' game, per say. Rather, I greatly enjoyed what it did.  Earlier, I compared this game to Earthbound. There's something to take note of. Even if you didn't like Earthbound as a game, did you like it as an  experience?  Or, perhaps more importantly, did you like the humour?  The two biggest areas I see this game falling flat as an experience are purely arbitrary: the morals and the humour. The first I can't say much more about due to spoilers, and the second is purely preference. If you play this game and find the morals are preachy, and can't handle that, or you think the humour is bad, it's likely you won't like Undertale. Unfortunately, there's not a great way to tell these things before playing (other than watching a Let's Play, which would ruin the experience, in my opinion).  However, if you  do  like these elements, I believe Undertale will be a gem. Maybe it won't be your favourite game of all time, but I think you'll enjoy it. I certainly got far more than $10 out of it.  At the very least, I'd recommend trying it. If you can, ignore the hype, ignore the fandom, don't watch Let's Plays, and avoid spoilers. Don't ruin the experience before you even get started. If you end up not liking it, that's fine. I completely understand...  But if you do, you'll be glad you spent that $10. Trust me,

Ok, first off, let me say that undertale is one of the most unique games I have ever played. Most ganes today are focused on satisfying the player through killing (FPS games) and gathering in game loot. The fandom may be pretty terrible nowadays but don't let that keep you from playing the game. The graphics are a little mediocre but still pretty great (especially since basically one guy did literally everything for this game), the music is absolutely amazing, and the story is deep and meaningful. Play this game to see for yourself and don't let the internet tell you how to feel. The game does not equal the fandom. You might laugh, you might cry, you might come away from this game a different person. It also has an ingeniously designed combat system, that is undoubtedly simplistic, yet somehow simultaneously deep. I can honestly say I've not played a game like it before, and it's overthrown my previous record holder for feel-sy indie game, 'To The Moon' (also incredible though).  And who could leave out the amazing soundtrack? I mean really, even when you think it's reached peak epic-ness, it somehow takes it a notch further when the game finally calls for it in the later stages of it.  Oh, and omg I left out one huge piece:  I highly recommend the pacifist run first. Not only is it rare to have such an avenue in a game, but it was seriously built for it. Then you ought to play again through the 'genocidal' run, and murder everything you can. There are huge differences between the two.

I've never seen anything that wore its influences so boldly on its sleeve (in this case, Earthbound in giant neon letters) while remaining one of the most original games I've ever played. I've also never seen a finer example of what video games can do artistically that no other medium can.   I went from ashamedly laughing at goofy puns to giddy laughter when I stopped caring about my own self-judgment. I found myself legitimately unnerved and even frightened by things that I never would have thought could affect me in such a way. Few games have struck me with such a wide range of emotions.  One of my favorite games of all time and I think an instant classic. I would even consider this required reading for aspiring developers, even those who are not fond of the genre (though the JRPG exterior is misleading, to say the least).
My only complaint about this game was that I couldn't date both skeletons.

Ah what to say about this game. When I was in junior high I remember faking an illness a few times so I could stay home and play final fantasy IV. This game, is nothing like that, but it gave me feelings like that game did.  I've felt many times over the years that high production values for video games, while a boon in many ways, is also the enemy of expression.  Take a solo project like Undertale, and put a little TLC into it, and I'm reminded of those old times when a few pixels could move me more than any big production could  Give me 2 frames of animation where Toriel holds my hand and guides me through a dungeon as my only friend in a scary new place.  I'm honestly reminded of Cave Story. This game, is nowhere near as grand in scale, but it's charm far exceeds most games of this era. And like cave story, it's a one man project of the utmost care.  Definitely recommend this beauty of a game. It's 10 dollars on steam, drop the extra 9 and get the soundtrack though. It's 101 tracks of pure awesome (if you have it on random though, beware the track with the insane laughing flower, your nightmares will never end).  I'm gone through it twice and have spent 16 hours on it. I think this will be one, much like FFIV that I have to break out every few years just to experience it again.  An afterthought. I don't get why people say the crux of this game is the humor. It's amusing, and silly. I wouldn't say it's 'funny ha ha'. Your mileage will vary.

All aboard the feels train on the first game thats ever made me have an existential crisis, I mean, it literally askes you NOT to make a new game after getting the best ending to let the hero of the story 'live his/her life in peace and happiness.'   Screw you guys for making sure I don't touch the title again for a long time, you beautiful basterds. <3   99/10.

This game has been sprouting up everywhere, and everyone has been singing praises from the heavens about it everywhere. It made me turn my head and consider purchasing it, but I didn't want to allow any of it to affect my own experience of the game, to prevent from raising the expectation levels too high, so I blocked it all out. Eventually, I gathered the funds necessary and began my own run of this game, to experience it and construct my own opinion on it. I decided to do be a perfect Pacifist with my run, and not kill anything, and also achieve the best possible ending doing this, without help. With all the preemptive information out of the way, let's get down to business with this review.  Gameplay: 8.5 / 10 Undertale is a game sporting a hybrid of genres, that provides an interesting, unique and fun twist on an RPG experience. To begin with, the primary gameplay involves solving puzzles (which can range from incredibly easy to moderate, depending on who you ask) to progress, and bullet-hell style battles, which can range from fair to frustrating. Needless to say, if either of these are types of gameplay someone doesn't enjoy, this game is likely not for you, since they're the primary bulk of the actual gameplay. In these battles, one has various commands they can perform depending on the monster(s), which will ultimately affect the outcome of the game itself. Due to this, especially when trying to achieve the pacifist run, some battles will seem like they drag on too long, or provide too little feedback that progression is actually occurring, and can cause some extra frustration figuring out what to do next. There are some annoying parts about the gameplay, and some which may even turn off players. Specifically, without spoiling when, where and how, the game will force close itself multiple times, and the player has to re-open the game several times. Why? Why couldn't the game just pretend a reboot or something, all in the same session? But overall, the gameplay itself is very enjoyable, again, assuming the player likes puzzle-solving and bullet-hell gameplay.  Story: 8 / 10 The story at its surface is pretty simple, and to remain spoiler free I'll not mention too much of it here. The bulk of the points comes from the cast of characters the player can choose to befriend or oppose, as that seems to be the primary focus of the story here. The player can kill everything that moves if they desire, which will spawn some scenes the player will either feel guilty about, or just shrug off and keep moving. Killing absolutely nothing is also a possibility, and the route I personally chose, which will allow the player to meet a quirky cast of characters, that are each fleshed out and given screen time. The writing of the game is generally light-hearted, but it has its serious and even philosphical moments, which I feel works out great. However, I could also see some things about it overall that wouldn't appeal to everyone, or could be grating.  Music: 8.5/10 The music in the game is all well composed and atmospheric. It has that weirdness, initially, of blending chiptune instruments with real instruments. It's not bad, and I personally enjoyed it, but it could come across as unfocused to some people, or may even turn people off entirely if they don't like chiptune sounds. Ultimately, however, each track does its job of immersing the player into what's currently happening in the game, and setting the stage.  Graphics: 5/10 The graphics aren't bad, but they aren't anything special either, in my opinion. Looking at screenshots of this game, none of them sport anything that really pops out, and makes me want to jump into the world. There are some moments where it's decent, due to the lighting conditions making some areas look fantastic, but I still believe the same thing could've been accomplished with less bland graphics. Even the player's sprite doesn't sport much animation other than walking for the majority of the game, until certain scenes.  Overall: 8 / 10 Ultimately, Undertale is a solid and fun experience someone could enjoy under the aforementioned premises of liking puzzle solving and bullet-hell style gameplay. The parts all piece together to form a whole unique experience, and the player may be left with memorable scenes and characters. I could personally recommend it for any gamer that would like a challenge. It may not always be fair in battle, but it's most certainly fair when it comes to continuing and surviving, so if you fail, just dust it off and try again. And again, and again, until you finally succeed, triumphantly pressing forward with your determination!

This games has it all for RPG fans who love a good story. It's similar to Nintendo's Earthbound only the meta of the game gets very intense. I haven't had the heart to do anything but the pacifist run from the start, but I don't regret doing that as the game has you feeling shocked, remorseful, and determined. You'll come to love, hate, and pity the well-written cast in this story, and their fates depend on if you want to befriend or obliterate them.  On either the pacifist, genocide and even the neutral playthrough, the simplistic (for the majority of the game) graphics gives it a stylized charm and the music is down-to-earth great. The gameplay is very enticing for bullet hell players and will keep them on their toes.  Honestly, it's my favorite indie RPG for 2015, and its intense story telling is going to very difficult to top off. My only regret is that I didn't help fund the game back when it was still on Kickstarter. A game that has you question and test your morals to this extent should be played by all RPG fans. I warn that anyone who decide to pick the genocide playthrough are going to be 'in for a bad time.'

Undertale is an RPG in which you play as a boy who is wanting to get back home after he lands into a land of monsters. The game is unique in that you don't actually have to fight anybody. There are extra options in the 'Act' menu which are all defferent depending on what monster you're fighting. The goal of the game is to get to the castle and escape the land of monsters, either by fighting every monster you encounter, or leaving them be. Along the way, you meet an interesting cast of characters that you can befriend which may or may not help you in the end. It all depends on how nice of a person you are.

One of the most positive experiences I've ever had playing a video game. Even if you aren't an Earthbound or RPG fan, I strongly recommend that you give this game a shot. If you are an Earthbound fan, this game is a must-buy. It's only $10. If you haven't played the game yet, stop reading the review and play the game.        The gameplay places a spin on traditional turn-based RPGs in that all enemies can be defeated without having to kill them. Defending from attacks is done in a manner to shmups where attacks a represented as dodgeable bullets. The patterns are incredibly varied and are contextually appropriate for every enemy and boss in the game. The story is hilarious and heartwarming, featuring Earthbound self-awareness while having more heart and humanity than most, if not all triple A titles in recent years. The game is short for an RPG of the style, as evident by the playtime, but every moment feels engaging, whether it be from dialogue from the colorful yet extremely fleshed out and fully realized characters, or the unique combat that plays well in traditional gameplay sense, while placing those mechanics in a context that fits into the world as well as challenging the status quo of traditional game design. If the overwhelmingly positive reception hasn't convinced you yet that the game is worth your time, then take my word for it. The game should not disappoint. At $10, I have no qualms recommending the game to everyone. Truly excellent.

What can I say about this game? a few things actually. Undertale is a game made in a similar style to Earthbound, quirky humor and all. where it diferentiates, however, is both in combat and in story. there are two main ways to end any encounter- FIGHTing and killing your opponent, or finding out how to SPARE them. defending against enemy attacks is done in a bullethell-esque sequence where you have to avoid enemy attacks- which gets frantic when you have two or three different enemies attacking at once. Story wise? to avoid spoilers, the story changes based on if you SPARE or FIGHT bosses and mooks, with multiple variations of each- making replay value surprisingly high. even if you probably won't want to go back after getting the definitively best ending.

So here I am, writing a review for Undertale. Which is amazing seeing as how I have never left a review for any game I have purchased here. Ever. Out of the 300+ games in my library I have never once felt the need to leave a review for a game I've played. I have Skyrim which I touted as my favorite game of all time, and not a single peep about it in the reviews section.   But Undertale. This game. This perfect game. It will make you feel things about a game you didn't think possible. It will keep you up at night wondering if you are making the right decisions. It will do things you didn't think possible. And at the end it will leave you questioning. 'Should I really start again?'  I would give a summary of the game and things that it does oh so right, but that would spoil the experience. Because that is what this game is. An experience. All I can really say is what has already been revealed in the trailer.  Undertale: The game where no one has to die.  I will however leave you dear reader with one tip. Talk, read, and interact with everyone/thing you can.  I can not reccomend this game enough. 10 out of 5 gold flowers.

getting this game around the time of final exams was both the best and worst decision of my life. best, because after completing the pacifist run, my entire outlook on life felt completely refreshed, no exaggeration. the characters, the storyline, and the music left me feeling more uplifted than any game has done in a really long time. i felt completely satisfied in a way i was never expecting.  i started Undertale feeling that all the hype i'd seen over it was just the usual over-excitement that surrounds something relatively mediocre. I was so wrong.  (possibly very slight spoiler. just being cautious)   half an hour in, and I'd already formed an emotional attachment to Toriel (aka Goat Mom), and frankly, would have been satisfied just spending the rest of my time with her. however, the game must go on. exploring the rest of the world was certainly an experience, one which i absolutely had to go back to see again once I'd finished the first time. the entire in-game world is so full of life, it's amazing. so many little details that didn't have to be there, but were included anyway that just made Undertale all the more special. i feel like this game is going to stay in my heart for a long time. it's definitely one of my all time favourites.   now, buying this game was one of the worst decsions of my life because frankly, i can't stop thinking about it. i should be studying as i write this review, but oh well. just gotta stay Determined.

Undertale is game about a lost child who falls down a moutainous abyss and their journey to get home.   Well, maybe that's not the best way to describe this game.  Undertale is a game about being kind to others, the value of friendships, the consqeuences of our actions (no matter how small) and figuring out if even the most evil and vile people in this world truly have a chance at redemption.....and also about petting dogs.  Undertale is a Bullet Hell and RPG game with a similar tone to Earthbound and Mother 3. I highly reccomend it to those who enjoyed this title.   Although a short game around 6 hours, I could not stop thinking about this game even after completing it. Did I make the right choices on my journey? Did I explore the world thoroughly? Even in a such a small game, I just wanted to emmerse myself and explore fully.  I can easily say that Undertale is one of the best games I have played in my life. It's left a large impact on me, and I certainly won't forget it.

This game is pretty damn great. The jokes are funny. The music is fantastic. And the feature that you don't HAVE to kill is great. I like that alot because it is something different.

Where to even start with this thing...  Well, since this is a pet peeve of mine, I'll put the summary at the top, so you don't need to expand and look for it. Fantastic game, one of the best I've ever played, and almost impossible to put down. 10/10  Now for the more nitty-gritty stuff. There's a very basic plot of your character trying to get home. Along the way, you meet plenty of colorful characters that can be either befriended or destroyed. And yet, there's just something about it that makes this feel more important that rescuing the galaxy or preventing World War III. There are little details everywhere that work to make use of the graphics that wouldn't look out of place on an SNES. Hand-holding animations, snow being kicked around, and tiny facial changes depending on someone's mood.   PROS -Absolutely fantastic mechanics. Arrowkeys, an A and B button, a menu button, fullscreen toggle, and a quit button. Those are your inputs, and the game manages to do so much with it.  -Soundtrack is phenomenal. I have listened to some of the tracks for hours, voluntarily, and not gotten bored.  -Story, while simple, is able to be followed easily -Elegant simplicity. This is an engineering concept where the simplest solution is often the best. Here, it applies fully. Though there is some level of complexity, there is never a moment where you need to collect twelve rat tails or do something that is completely unrelated to the task at hand. -The best ending is completely worth the effort  Neutral -Short (10 hours or so, give or take). Might not be everyone's cup of spiders, but it's something about it.  CONS -When a boss fight is hard, it can be more than a little frustrating to figure out what to do -Can't play Twinkle Twinkle Little Star on the piano -As with the fights, some puzzles can require a little sideways thinking to solve -Little replay value  Overall, it was highly entertaining while it lasted, though I find it unlikely I'll be returning. Still, it's the journey, not the destination.

There's a demo for you to try if you're new to top-down view RPG style games or you're not sure about buying it. Dating cool spaghetti-obsessed skeleton = 10/10.

About 2 hours in, I wrote a review for this game saying how good it is, and that everyone should play it.  I've now completed a pacifist playthrough and my opinion has only strengthened.  Undertale is an incredible game, full of both a distinct sense of joy, but also of fear and unease. In it, you are a small child who has fallen into the underground, and you wish to return home. Along the way you encounter many a monster, and can choose to either fight and kill said monsters, or befriend them in charming and wonderful ways.   The game's combat is incredibly unique, a distinct mashup of bullet-hell and JRPG. You take turns against your opponent, and their attacks come in the form of them throwing all sorts of attacks at you. You have to move around to dodge the attacks, and the attacks are wildly varied based on who you are fighting.  On the other hand, in your turns you can choose to either FIGHT or ACT. Acting allows you to perform non-violent actions, and just about every enemy in the game can be fought with these actions. The most interesting part of this is that you never have to kill a single enemy, and if you do, there are often severe consequences- even with random encounters.  Of course, you COULD opt to kill EVERY enemy, but where's the fun in that?  Undertale is a piece of art, truly one of the greatest games of the millenium as of yet, and I'm DETERMINED to get people to play it.   10/10 GOTY

This is one THOSE games. One of those games that leaves its mark to the gaming history, even if people dont want to admit it. It is completely unique, weaving gameplay, story and atmosphere together in ways that no pretentiously deep game could ever accomplish no matter how hard they try. Undertale is an exciting journey, a mysterious journey, funny journey, scary journey and finally, a sad journey.  I could tell you about the gameplay, graphics, the soundtrack or even the story, but it is pointless. Undertale is something that breaks the normal reviewing norms. It is actually impossible to figure out if you should play this game by reading a review or a recommendation, it is such a bizarre creature.  Of course, I am not the one to say 'YOU SHOULD PLAY THIS GAME RIGHT NOW, YOU PLEB'. But if you care even slightest about video games as a medium and you have been following it spread and grow through your life, you suggest you experience Undertale, since it will not leave you empty handed. There is only one exit from the underground, and you WILL carry an emotion with you when you go through those doors. Hopefully, it is not the one you were expecting.

It's galling, it's vicious, it's touching and compassionate. Undertale, you guys.

Fantastic. Absolutely fantastic. I don't even know where to begin.  First of all, if you are looking for something easy, LEAVE NOW.  Still here? Good! Then welcome to UNDERTALE: Where nobody has to get hurt. This game is a weird, yet astounding genre of RPG, bullet-hell, and dating sim (trust me on this one.) It has appealing graphics for older gamers who may have enjoyed classics like Earthbound, yet up-to-date witty humor with a kick of old-fashioned (in a good way.)  Also, the soundtrack. This soundtrack is A.M.A.Z.I.N.G. I fully 100% recommend you support Toby Fox and purchase his soundtrack. It's got all sorts of genres of music, between silly and fun, or just flat out scary and nightmarish.  The gameplay is also very note-worthy. Being a somewhat unrepresented style of gaming is the option to spare your foes that you inevitablably encounter throughout the entirety of the game. The gameplay can be intense and demand much of the player's attention and skill. The combat system is very open, with most enemies have different ways of being defeated, and harder ones requiring more focus and attention.  Anf finally, this game has feels. Feels as FAR as the eyes can see. I'm not ashamed to admit certain moments of this game had me going from anger, to happiness, to tears in a matter of minutes in a single period. If you are in for the story, then congratulations, this game has an AMAZING story, with memorable characters, who have amazing and unique personalities.  To be fair, this game isn't as perfect as I paint it out to be, however. Some flaws include the gameplay in comparison to some other titles you may play being relatively short. I completed the game in roughly 7 hours in a complete, nonstop playthough, achieving one ending. Which brings me to another point. If you are of the type who will only play a game for one ending, and then stop, then UNDERTALE may not be appropriate for you, due to the player's choices VERY HEAVILY affecting gameplay and, ultimately, the game's outcome. However, this also means that if you truly love UNDERTALE, then the replay value is definitely a big plus for any of those wanting to explore the intricate and magical wonder that is UNDERTALE.  Conclusion: Is this game flawless? No. I don't think any game is, honestly. Is it amazing? YES. YES YES YES YESSSSSS. I recommend this game in it's entirety. An amazing soundtrack, fantastic world, memorable characters, and one big mixing pool of nostalgia, fun, and feels. GET THIS GAME!
This game..good god, this game. Easily one of the best, if not the best games I have ever played, and it's only 10 bucks!! If you decide not to get this, you're doing yourself a huge disservice.

Every character, even the random encounter monsters you fight, have a personality and by the end of the game you really feel you have come to know these characters and become part of their lives.  If you want to play a game in which it's abundantly clear the creators put enormous detail and care into every aspect of the game, from the art (for the style), story, characters, MUSIC, and gameplay then please consider picking up Undertale. I recently came across this right after completing a playthrough of LISA: The Painful RPG. LISA was appealing to me simply because of the fact that the game is not your typical 'Friendship will solve all problems'. It was cruel, brutal, and dark. I was enamored with LISA and I was surprised how well an Indie game was able to capture what I was looking for, while the AAA RPGs seem to be missing the mark.  Undertale showed up on my queue recently, and the concept of the game seems like exactly what I wouldn't be looking for. 'Killing is unnecessary'. Although this is true, the game offers very different playthroughs based on if you kill, or don't kill. The reviews led me to purchase this game anyways, and at $10 I wasn't too worried even if it didn't end up being what I wanted.  This game absolute crushed all bad perceptions I had, and was an amazing experience. One of the biggest gripes I usually have with these types of games is the ending. This ending was extremely in-depth, and I was completely satisfied with the result. The game continually climbs in entertainment, and at the end it has a proper climax that leaves you wishing it wasn't over.   Quick summary.  Graphics - 8/10 Graphics are absolutely fine, although at certain points they may look sort of unpolished. They do not detract from the game in anyway and they are fitting. At the same time I kinda wish there was more emphasis on the art.  Sound - 9/10 Music was solid, and very fitting to scenes that they are a part of. They meld well with the backgrounds, and fit the mood exceedingly well. I feel that there is room for improvement, but absolutely no gripes.  Gameplay - 10/10 Combat was very well done, and is an extremely unique approach. The combat system expands constantly the further you go into the game, and new concepts are introduced to keep it from being stale. The puzzles were decent, but not overbearingly hard, and travelling through areas was eventful and did not feel like filler from scene to scene.  Control - 9/10 Controls are simple, and it would be easy to play with a controller or keyboard. I played through on controller and felt I had very good control of what I was trying to do.  Story - 10/10 The story blew me away. My perception of happy / friendly types of stories has changed drastically. This is exactly the type of game that I do 'not' like, yet It was executed beautifully and I feel as if there are games that I now have to give a chance to.   TL:DR - If there is any interest whatsoever, purchase the game. The reviews do not lie, and you will be delightfully surprised at what you find.  Edit: After playing a Genocide run and noticing that there is even more music that wasn't available in the pacifist run, I have to say that the sound should be 10/10.

I petted a dog where no dog got petted before, then cried violently being chased by a fish, then stacked 30 hotdogs on my head. I got guit tripped by a flower. This game is insane. Only downside is my skeleton boyfriend dumped me after one date and the spagetti is terrible.  Seriously though, this game does not let you forget any decision you ever make and it the most terrifying and enjoyable game ive had the option of only paying 10 bucks for. There's a vast and undescovered ammount of story, and to each playthough should you dare to play over or tweak with the games setting should more and more uncover story wheter for good or for bad because some secrets feel quite terrifying. Nearly all characters are easly to love and love easily. Every option with every NPC can affect options presented by others, characters and the game will remember things you said and remind you later ocasionally. The story is a difficult option to discuss as because of thise the direction and ending of it is extremely flexible. its why its often recomended if you havent had spoils to not look at them and make your own decisions first time around, but the game is enjoyable even if you had already known all of it. Hello ladies and gentlemen, today we will teach you how to bake a Undertale.  First you take the talking to enemies aspect from the shin megami tensei series, then mix it up with some quirky humor and overworld elements from the Mother series, and finally add a dash Touhou hell-bullet shooter to it, make sure the oven is preheated to 350 degrees, put it in, and soon you got yourself a Undertale!  Seriously though this game may be one of the best games I have played since Mother 3, the characters are quite memorable, the story is pretty solid, the music is absolutely superb and you will find yourself playing the game multiple times trying to discovery every nook and cranny you can.

Absolutely wonderful. I know every YouTube channel under the sun is playing this right now, but it really is different when you're at the controls yourself. The writing is wonderful, the characters get into your head immediately (I seriously challenge you *not* to read Papyrus' dialog outloud in a silly voice), and the mechanics flow directly into the story itself. Everything fits and it feels like nothing is wasted. I should have been annoyed at some of the backtracking. I should have gotten impatient with the lack of a 'run' option for my character....but I just can't! I did a ton of backtracking on purpose because I wanted to go see what my actions had changed.  Undertale is being hyped to all hell right now, but I'm so glad I didn't let that put me off playing it for myself.

If you are considering whether or not to buy Undertale, know that you will never forgot the story it tells you.  Undertale is thrilling, comedical, and utmostly heartwarming/heartbreaking. With the choice to treat others knowing they will return the favour accordingly, how much will you endure before you snap, or will you sit through it to show that you really are a good person? This game will shatter your expectations and instead give you a masterpiece of an indie game that you'll never forgot. From an insane soundtrack to writing that touches every aspect of emotion, this game sees it all. Once it all comes to an end, do you really have the heart to reset everything good you've put in motion, or redo it all just for one more genocide?
Everything in this game has a hidden meaning and has heaps of replayability. 10/10

Getting the most out of this game takes DETERMINATION... Multiple playthroughs are required to fully experience everything.  Thankfully, it's filled to the brim with oddball humor, unique RPG gameplay, and has a great story. The graphics may not be as fancy as some pixel art based games, but the game has its own charm IMO.  For me, one of the highlights of this game is the attention to detail and the length at which it remembers your decisions. There are many choices you must make throughout, and they are all important to the outcome of the story and your quest. Seeing the different ways the game changes with your choices, and how the characters react to you make replaying everything actually interesting and fun. I would go into more detail about this, but I don't want to spoil anything!  My rating: 9.5/10 You should get this game!

This game is perfect, everything you do matters, and your choices deeply touch the story and alter it.  The one thing missing from this game, which is not a big deal. Is character customisation.  The game is quirky, and remdins me of Earthbound, and I personally love this game more than it.

All in all it's easily one of the best games of the year and something I'll keep coming back to in the future.

Well... I haven't actually read many of the other reviews for this game, but considering that there's over 4000 of them by the time of me writing this, there's probably not much I could say that hasn't been said already.  But I will say this: Undertale is a truly special game... the kind that doesn't come out often. It made me laugh, it made me cry... it made me feel disgusted with myself. It has the best of humanity in it, and also the worst.  If that sounds hyperbolic, well... maybe it is! Play for yourself and see. It's a good time.
If u don't buy your a loser.

I'll do my best to keep this short and spoiler-free  I'd give this game a sincere 9/10 (in contrast to an IGN 9/10)  Is it worth $10? No, its worth at least $20  Why? 1.) The story is very good  -The overarching story is very engaging and revealed to you piecemeal, if you bother to examine your surroundings, or dumped on you towards the end. In both cases, its conveyed very well.   -Little things and trends that you may observe become far more impactful later in the game  2.) Characters are engaging  -The characters are decently deep. If you really read the script and appreciate their struggles, you should be invested in them.  3.) Music is good and has good timing  -The music was memorable and entertaining (especially the boss fights)  -The music matches the mood and pace of the actual fights very well. When plot-reveal music plays it is very well attuned to the surrounding areas  4.) Puzzels and boss fights, on the whole, are well designed and entertaining  -There are some puzzles that aren't particularly difficult, but they are easy to get through and relatively entertaining  -The real 'puzzels' of this game are the fights. It is effectively a bullet-hell combined with observing your opponent's dialogue to convince said opponent not to fight, Alternatively, you can just kill everything.  5.) Jokes were pretty good  -Plenty of running gags that don't get old.   -Plenty of references  -Can't think of a bad joke that wasn't intentionally bad  6.)The Novelty of the game  -This is an RPG where you do not have to kill everyone and there are only two big roles for you to play. Will you be a pacifist or a murderer? No wizards, priests, monks, or warriors here folks.  -Depending on the choices you make, the story and atmosphere change dramatically.  -If you intend to go fully one way or the other, you better be fully cogniscent of what those choices mean (or you're gonna have a bad time).  -The dev(s?) think of everything, as a result there is a very meta-feel to the game. The meta-feel is in no way a bad thing, it is executed wonderfully.  Overall, it attains a level of novelty that few indie developers ever reach but still maintains an incredible production value even with a small team.   Recommendations:  If you play through it the first time, I would highly recommend pacifist first. If you play through it in the opposite direction first, it might seem hollow since the characters wouldn't have been very fleshed out at that point. That being said, do what you want. But be prepared to have a bad time
Easily one of the best indie games out there. It's short, but it's like a slap in the face. It gets its point across and it's over when it needs to be, no dragging on forever unnecessarily.
made me cry more than once 10/10

Undertale comes together to make something greater than the sum of its parts. The graphics are solid for a retro title and the music is nice, but paired together they make some truly beautiful and impacting moments. The script runs the gammut from comedic to dramatic to heartbreaking to hopeful, sometimes all at once, and does this while turning RPG tropes on their head. And all of this without touching on the world, characters, story, gameplay... I could write whole pages about it. But instead, I'll just say this:  If you like RPGs, play this game. If you like video games, play this game. If you have seven free hours between now and your death, play this game.

Where to start. I guess that if you like the mother series, this is just plain buy it now material. besides that, all aboard the feelz (mid to late game or serious spoilers will not be present in this review) This review will be based on 5 different catagories gameplay story characters art style music TL;DR - not much to complain about (excluding lack luster puzzles)... at all. unless you hate RPGs or emotion, this is a MUST BUY. Probably an guarenteed game of the year on many, MANY lists  Long review Gameplay: The gameplay revolves around a nicely made, interesting little combat system. your 'soul' inhabits the shape of a heart and is used to dodge, jump, guard, and a host of other things enemy projectiles of every shape and form, even resembling the bullet hell genre at many points. The actual attacking is a bit lack luster since it is a non essential mechanic, something RARELY (if ever) seen in games. The movement in the world consists of a classic pixel RPG open movement style. The only gripe I find with the entire game is its lacklust puzzles, but at least they have a few jokes and accept the fact that they suck.  Story: I can't say much because spoilers but you have 3 main endings under the community given terms pacifist, neutral, and genocidal. Each of them revolve around, you guessed it, the way you interact with the world. Lemme tell you, this game has nice world reaction. Something you did at the VEEERY start of the game can have a giant flow change later on, even letting you basically skip bosses because you did something as simple as hold onto an object to use. and not to spoil much but OMG DEM FEELZ. Few games make me cry. but I had to stop for a good while and just process one of the endings. Narative is essential to this game and it is some of the best I have ever seen.  Characters: While slightly stereotypical and sometimes dragged out, most if not all main and supporting characters are very varied, and very likeable. and to the flower, you are just all over the place. Even enemy fodder has hopes and dreams, really making you contemplate the idea of killing them like how every RPG mindlessly does in droves.  Art Style: This is a very mother hommage art style. It is simplistic, yet complex. Scenes really pop out and there is a duality going on between the overworld and combat art styles which actually mixes very nicely. Overall the only thing i find a little annoying is that some movements by characters can seem slightly awkward but it adds more comic effect than anything else.  Music: I can't put into one reviews the variety of songs there are, something for everyone. even when you have 1 song remixed about 5 or 6 times it is still amazing every single time. This game has some of the greatest music I've heard in a mother-esq game. The only gripe is if you dislike pixel-ish music, but even then there is high quality songs too.  Overall, few to no flaws outside of personal taste. If you like mother, rpgs, good story, feels, and just about everything to do with breaking the 4th wall (and a bit of OMG WHAT THE HELL for dessert) you MUST get this game. I think everyone should play at least 1 playthrough of this.
This one's absolutely oozing with charm. I really recommend you jump in blind and give it a go.
If you played and loved Earthbound or Mother, play this game

This is an amazing game. An RPG where you don't have to kill any of the monsters. Or you can go and kill every monster you see, if you want to be a terrible person. If you haven't bought this game yet, buy it now. It's an experience that you shouldn't miss out on. And I recommend getting the bundle with the soundtrack as well. The music in the game is great.

I HIGHLY HIGHLY RECOMMEND this game to all the JRPG lovers.  This entire game had me hooked after the tutorial section. And there is nothing horrible I can say about this game outside the only fact I wish it was even longer!  + Combat is fun and intuitive. + Story is adaptive and beautifully created for the choices you make.  + Each character stands out in it's own unique way. Even the enemies stand out on their own.  + Dating skeletons. 'nuff said. + Soundtrack is a total positive hit for me. The songs are not extremely over the top. And fit the mood. + The tributes to Earthbound were very well received. + Petting dogs. Pet all the dogs! + Each character's personality had me fall in love with them. All unique and colorful. Never a dull moment with any character. + Each enemy can be handled in a multitude of ways.  + Beating the game's perfect ending really made me hesitant to start another run just from the living personalities made of the NPCs. + Humor, jokes, and the horrible puns all cracked more than a laugh from me. + Many enemies have their own personalities and gave me a smile when I didn't kill them.  This game earns it's overwhelmingly positive rating. The 10/10 comes from me and deserves it every moment. I highly recommend this game to you, your friends, and your friends' friends. Come in for a journey of laughter, frustration, joy, hardship, tears, and determination... and unravel the tale.. of UNDERTALE.

Undertale does impressive things for its size. If you're looking for a casual and happy RPG loot-fest experience with some good story on the side, this definitely ISN'T the game for you. All of its mechanics, from fighting to story progression, are handled incredibly decently, but Undertale's real strength lies in it being the most impactful experience that it can be, and the whole game is crafted around being just that. Enemies, story, bosses, all tailored to evoke something from the player. It makes it hard for you to not care. Even if you want to.
This game has it all. Great story, great characters, great music and great gameplay. A must play for any RPG fans!

This game was great. GOTY. I didnt expect too much other than a funny game when I saw some people play a bit on youtube, but damn. This game was great! It's probably one of my favourites in the last few years. 10/10. Made me feel,

Undertale is an rpg. Its game where you fall down a hole and might end up on a date with a skeleton. Sorry for the massive spoiler, but that'll be my only one.  Its just a game about walking and mashing z, much like as the same way Cave story was merely about walking through tunnels and doors. If you have never played Cave Story, go ahead and play it too to catch my drift.   This is a game where I dragged my feet to actually invest time into it, I made excuses and pondered over its success and if it would only be remembered as over-hyped youtube trash or considered to be for 'trendy meme-lords.' Then I sat down and played it. All of it. Lost my save file due to a computer hardware issue and started anew and beat it in one long sitting.   It was an experince. It was a wonderful, timeless experince that relied on something many AAA or internet humor derived indies miss. It had heart. It had memorable characters. It had a friggin great soundtrack. It made my girlfriend cry for 2 weeks straight and made her friends draw skeleton pron which made her cry even more.   I love it. Love love love it. I loved it so much I have gladly uninstalled it and have no intention on playing it ever again after beating it to a 'complietion.' Something I havent done since I last owned a console game as a child.  Is this game perfect? No. But its downsides vary person to person.  Some people don't like the combat system at some points. Some don't like the couple of puzzle segments (I'm one of them- thankfully in retrospect the number of puzzles isn't stifling,) and some don't think the writing is all that great. I'll even say that if your a TOTAL 100% Complietionist this game might not be for you.  No one has the same opinion. And thats perfectly fine.   If you want a game thats charming, but not overly cutesy, buy this game. If you want a game that has wit that without falling into a satire conga hell, buy this game. Above all if you want a good story with a lot of heart buy this game.   Oh and keep your fingers nimble, trust me.  (Writing such a long semi-poorly written review...It fills me with DETERMINATION.)

Absolutely game of the year for me. The game's style is completely different depending on which way you play it, and it pulls it off really well. It has solid characters, and a pretty nice plot. Overall just a really solid game. It's been nearly a week since I've played this game, and I'm still thinking about it. Definitely give it a try if it seems like the kind of thing you'd be into.

Oh Undertale. How you have made me smile, made me want to go on a date with a skeleton, and most importantly made me cry at the conclusion to this amazing game. Undertale is an RPG by Toby Fox, and is just simply amazing. I first heard about Undertale from Jim-♥♥♥♥ing-Sterling-Son, and was intrigued. I then saw some more gameplay on the game and bought it. And boy was I in for the ride that would make me appreciate characters like non other. The plot to Undertale is simple on the surface. Many years ago monsters and humans had a big war, monsters lost, and were banished. You are a human who falls down into a mountain into the word of the monsters, and thus your journey begins. The gameplay in Undertale is unusual. Like any other JRPG you have your items and your attack. However there is also the 'ACT' and the 'MERCY' buttons in combat. These two buttons allow you to interact with an enemy in a way other than attacking them. This allows you to 'SPARE' the enemy after you have said or done a certain thing to the enemy. This is where the ending to the game comes into play. There are multiple ending to the game, neutral, good, evil. No matter what on first playthrough you will get the neutral ending. After the first playthrough you are left with two options spare everyone you encounter, or kill literally kill everyone. This is the most interesting part of the game. Like I said earlier this games surface story is generic, but if you get either of the two alternate endings you will be thrown into the feels well with nowhere else to go. This game is in my opinion the best game to have come out in the past few years, and I gladly will reccomend it to anyone.  I rate this game a 10/10
This game is absolutely amazeful. Super High Recommend. Great cast of characters and great gameplay. Super great soundtrack to go along with it too. This game is amazeful, just buy it.  10/10
This game really warms the heart.

Absolutely incredible. This is the first and possibly only review I have writen/will write. Its that good. Dont even question it. Prepare to Cry 10/10

This is probably one of the best RPG game I've played recently. It's not a super long game but it delivers what it promises. Also teaching us some lessons about what it means to be a person. Kind of adding fun and educational elements altogether.   Oh and the sound track is very well done. LOVE it.

This game is, at the beginning, near-perfect! The way the story is crafted is meant to be very cute while still being able to be taken seriously and tell a story: the way this game creates suspense and drama at certain points is masterful, and the classic gameplay and look to it is meant to give it a rustic and classic storytelling sense to it that makes it come across better: this game is very close to perfect...At least, at the beginning. This game is very long, around 6 hours for me to get the true ending, and it feels like the pacing at some parts is lacking (I'd say this is only the case for the location Hotland: which has no real towns or areas to explore or look at, it's a pretty set path with very little things going for it that previous locations). This is mostly fixed by the main characters, who always have a chance to shine and grow on you: what makes Undertale different is that most of your best friends are actually enemies at first, and you as the main character have the option to kill or save each and every one of them, and each boss fight provides a unique gimmick to it to spread things apart. Some aspects of it, such as the idea that even killing random encounter enmies is 'cruel' and 'still murder' provides a fresh idea to RPG's that hasn't been seen in a while, and definetely makes this game something everyone can find something about, even despite the pacing. The style of it all is so cute that it's impossible not to crack a smile during the whole thing!

The dodging mechanic in this game is the same as a top-down shooter while your attacks are turn based like the old RPGs  The puzzles in this game are not that difficult in comparison to other games I have played and shouldnt really take more than 10mins if you are struggling  I really liked this game due to not having experienced playing a top-down shooter genre in many years, a genre which i adore very much so my review may be a bit biased. This game is still great even if you have no experience in a game similiar to this  The game is well worth 10$ to a unemployed college student, this is a masterpiece
If your into indie games and love a good rpg / top down shooter you should give this a try. did i also mention that it also has a great soundtrack and multiple endings. :D

One of the best games I've played in the last couple of years.  Undertale boasts memorable characters, great writing and catchy music. The battle system is so much fun and let's not forget all the dogs. Buy this game already.

Never has a game met, and then exceeded my expectation quite like this game did. Undertale goes straight onto my short-list of best games I've ever played. It might not provide hundreds of hours of gameplay, but it provided me about 7 unforgetable hours on my first playthrough. 10 / 10 - it's polished to a mirror sheen and stupid good! If the game looks at all interesting to you, play it! You are going to have a good time ...unless of course, you kill absolutely everyone.

In my first playthrough I did a pacifist run. I did not, however, get everyone as yellow in the ending credits.  Putting aside the story line, which is pretty much across the board acknowledged to be heart wrenching and inspiring, one of the things I especially loved about this game was how it kind of reached out to the player behind the computer screen.   There are points in the game where a character will shut down your game, forcing you to re-open in. Also, from playthrough to playthrough, without a hard reset of the game (manually clearing it) it will remember your decisions from previous playthrough. It forces you as a player to really evaluate your decisions, being unable to really go back and just reload save files.  Going further, this game has not even been completely *solved* yet. There are sorts of... secret characters/events that have been found by activating certain parts of the game file.   But yeah. Like everyone else says - great humor, story, characters, music... gets ya right in the feelzzz. Reminds me quit a bit of Cavestory in some ways, but something completely different in others. A great addition to any indie game collection.

This game is amaizing. Easily worth the 10 bucks. What can you expect of this game? Amaizing music. Great characters. Interesting(to say the least) plot. Even more so if you like RPGs, but this game is really open to anyone, fans of the genre or otherwise. I strongly suggest you give this one a try, you won't regret it.

I laughed a lot, I cried a bit and I enjoyed every minute. Also love the soundtrack. This game will probably stay with you for years if you complete the true pacifist ending. Definitely worth your time.

I could go on for hours about why I love this game, so I'll just put it in as few words as I can while explaining everything. It's fun to play, the music is spectacular, it's extraordinarily witty, it hit me in every emotion (and powerfully, at that), and made me grow attached to these well-developed characters. It's funny seeing a game like this priced for $10, when it's essentially priceless for how well-put-together it is. I'd call it a masterpiece if it didn't mean I'd be being cliche about it, but that's honestly what I think this game is: a masterpiece.  10/10

This game leads heavily with a great story and great characters. Your actions really carry weight throughout the game which is what I really liked it. Undertale also managed to make me shed a few tears of joy in the good ending. Highly recommended!
Honestly, its one of the most unique and awesome games I've ever seen. I'd rather not spoil anything, so I'm just going to tell you to play it, and to do so however you want.
