Great game  This game is the best game i love the story, the characters and the music, i love it i hope we see more about this creator.

It was a Saturday. I was just relaxing when my brother told me about a supposedly amazing game called Undertale. He told me I should get it as soon as I can. After that, I looked up some reviews and a trailer. Basically, it had a 98/100 on Metacritic and was a fleshed out blend of Earthbound and Pokemon. I was hyped. We went to the store and I bought a Steam card, and then buying that game knowing nothing about it. But after about an hour of playing it, I learned something... something dear to my heart: 'Oh my god this game is amazing' To be honest, the intro level of the game isn't extremely fun, as it holds your hand. But after that, you get a boss battle the propels you into an absolutely bueatiful open world of snow and humor. Basically, I'll put this review into segments:  Graphics: Charming 8-bit style that reminds me of EarthBound Beginnings/Mother 1. Music: I can't even describe how much this soundtrack makes my ears have a seizure from pure joy. Story: Surprisingly deep and dark, but not complicated. To boot, the game is hilarious. I cannot find a real problem with this game. So far it's an absolute 10/10 If you have leftover money, don't spend it on AAA games like Tomb Raider or Assasins Creed Spend it on this absolute gem of an RPG
This game ripped my heart right out of my chest and suplexed it into a million pieces 10000/10
Such a great game, so much power packed into 10 hours.

Undertale is a fun little rpg that gradually unravels itself into something more complex and emotionally taxxing as it progresses. Depending on how you want to end the game and the choices you make, there are a number of endgame paths to choose from, and all sorts of secrets and flavor texts to discover! You'll want to play it multiple times to get the full experience, but be warned: not every reset can wipe away everything you've done, not entirely at least
Fantastic game with tons of content

I'm going to say that anybody who gives Undertale a negative straight up has no soul! This has to be one of my favorite games of all time now! It might even replace Skyrim as my #1 favorite video game. Or maybe that's just the overwhelming emotions, this game gave me, talking.  When I first got Undertale I was going to do a genocide route right after doing the pacifist route, but after finishing the game I would rather kill myself than kill any of the characters. It makes you feel so much emotion it made it difficult for me to beat the game because I would almost cry. (I'm not kidding.) I'm actually suprised I didn't cry to be honest.  Even though Undertale is an indie game, it is hands down, the best game I have played this year. (I'm a sucker for emotional games.) Out off all the games somebody should definitely not pirate, Undertale would be #1. (Seriously though, ♥♥♥♥ people who pirated this game.) I reccomend Undertale to anyone who has a computer.  The only thing I would have to say would be a negative in this game are the controls but you get used to them so quickly.

This game is an unexpected bundle of magic and charm. The characters, music, and story are all stellar and the ending is one of the strongest I've ever seen in a game. I've never played anything like it and normally this genre isn't to my taste at all, but this game does things that turn the expectation you have for a video game right on its head. There were a few moments where I felt like giving up, because I'm not great at dodging in bullet hell, but I'm overwhelmingly glad that I persevered because the pay off is worth it. It's incredible and sure to stick with me for a while. Lovely game.

I've been thinking about this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ masterpiece for two weeks now. Everything about it is just so... right.  Compelling characters, kickass music with a handful of sweet leitmotifs, unique and non-tedious combat system, satisfying storyline.  It's sort of like OFF, but not tedious and long-winded. Like, I knew I wanted to keep going 20 seconds into the title screen here but couldn't stomach more than an hour of OFF.  Good replay value. Secrets. Good psychological mind-games with the player. Totally picks the brain of a speedrunner-type person if you go through killing everything and one of the enemies adapts his combat-style in order to get to YOU instead of just killing the character.  Good at making the whole 'save point' thing actually part of the canon of the game. Introduces a boring/♥♥♥♥♥♥ looking character right off the bat and makes him actually interesting.  10/10. Like, 9.something repeating. Very, very small elements of tediousness that go away fast. Maybe necessary for the feeling of the game idk it was well-paced and I don't regret it.  Genuinely hard fights here and there that you can totally surpass after like, five deaths usually.  I spent 30 dollars on gifting this to people and regret nothing. Love you, Toby.

I bought this game on a whim. I needed something to waste away a few hours in between school projects this semester, so I picked it up after hearing a bit about it. And wow, did I not know what I was getting myself into. I figured it would be a fun, casual little RPG I could clock a few hours in. And it didn't disappoint, don't get me wrong. What surprised me was how much MORE than that it was. It's been a long time since I felt any sort of real emotional connection to a cast of pixelated sprites, but this game pulls it off beautifully. The compelling story, memorable characters, and superb soundtrack (I can't stop listening to it, even as I write this review) come together in a perfect mix that will make you smile one second, and tugs at your heart the next.   10/10

I've never played anything like this game. It's a very lovingly crafted turn-based bullet hell hybrid, but that doesn't even scratch the surface of this game. It was an emotional rollercoaster from start to finish... One that YOU control through your actions.  You'll be filled with love for the characters and their world, or filled with hatred for all other living beings. You'll laugh with the denizens of the underground and their antics, or you'll look down upon them as you wipe their blood off your clothes. You'll see what friendship means to these wonderful creatures- or you'll see what it means to be a monster yourself.  But no matter what path you take, you'll be filled with DETERMINATION to see it through to the end.  Its a nice, quirky game with lovable characters, fun ever-changing gameplay and a really great message. Easily the best turn based RPG I've ever played. I was really surprised by how much I wanted everything to go well for the characters, for them to live hapily ever after, given how little I typically care for characters in RPG's. Theres something very special about how the world and characters are built in this game, its hard to describe it.  Side note: the soundtrack is kickass as well!  Only complaints? Unless you're looking to have a bad time, the game is rather short. It's completely worth it though, undertale provides an experience you can't get anywhere else. It's a damn shame there aren't more games like this.

The game is what you want it to be.. But be aware, it won't forget what you've done.          Flowey never forgets.  11/10 Best game of the year

After beating this game, I can easily say this is one of my favorite RPGs. While it is a lot shorter than most RPGs, what it fits into that short time period is amazing. First thing you'll notice is that you can choose to spare monsters instead of killing them. That one mechanic affects the game a lot more than you would initially think. The choice to spare a monster or not has much greater effects on the story than I belived it would initally (after being jaded by Fable's very poor morality choices and the 'changes' it does based on them (read: next to nothing changes at all)). I cannot say much more about this mechanic without spoiling anything but I can say one thing; the game's tagline in the trailer is not lying. You can beat the game without anyone dying.  The characters I can not say much about either, but they are a varied bunch and they are very memorable too (as looking up Undertale online will prove (although do not do that until after beating the game. Spoilers again)).  The soundtrack is also one of my favorite ones I have listened to in an indie game too. Again, like the characters, it is a varied bunch and does not always stick to 8-bit tracks either.  For £6.99 (or the regional equivalent), I would definitely recommend it.

now one of my favorite games of all time. definitely story-driven with a ton well-developed, lovable characters, all of which allow the player to become fully immersed in the game. the actual gameplay isn't something to overlook either. it emphasizes puzzles, especially because every 'enemy' encounter in a pacifist run is a puzzle--you have to figure out the correct inputs to be able to comfort and spare a monster. not only that, but the monsters also attack using a bullet hell that you have to dodge, and it varies with each monster (plus each monster can have more than one attack), so it doesn't beome dull. additionally there are several mechanics throughout the game that alter the way you dodge the bullets, so it REALLY doesn't get old. you will experience every emotion while playing--definitely fear and sadness, but mostly joy and laughter, as all of the dialogue/text in the game is extremely funny. you might have a little bit of rage if you find a boss too hard, but that only fills you with DETERMINATION. the game is very forgiving--its save points are strategically placed before and after big/lengthy events so you rarely have to worry about backtracking to the last save point (even if you're a compulsive saver like me). don't even get me started on the soundtrack: something I have not stopped listening to ever since I bought the game. Toby is a master at composing and utilizing the motifs he creates throughout the entire experience. Every time I listen, I discover a melody from one song that reappears in another, and done flawlessly so. in-game, the music is half of the emotion; it surrounds the story and graphics to complete that feeling of immersion. there's goofy songs for goofy moments, creepy songs for creepy moments, intense songs for intense moments, etc. this game knows exactly what it wants to be and doesn't struggle with trying to be two many things at once. it also knows exactly what the player will expect from it (not only in terms of gameplay but also general story tropes) and does a magnificent job of keeping the player surprised and eager to explore every nook and cranny. people keep saying this is their pick for Game of the Year 2015 and if you play it, it's extremely easy to see why. I created a Steam account just to purchase this game and it's the best decision i've ever made.

If you like your fast pased action games, you might want to give this one a pass. But if your into games that silently judge you, go ahead and pick this up. Just er...pay attenion to the whole turtorial thing, cause that might end up biting you in the but later.

<!> MINOR SPOILERS AHEAD!! <!>  Okay, now that that's settled, let's get started.  Undertale is a 'friendly RPG where NO ONE has to die!' Yeaah. Sure. I'll get to that later. It provides an excellent soundtrack, ranging from those that can pull at your heartstrings - like His Theme - to silly/fun ones - in themes such as Bonetrousle - to one that really get you pumped for battle, like Spear of Justice! With such a wonderful range of songs in the OST to choose from, I guarantee ('scuse spelling lmao) that you'll be listening for hours, if you enjoy the game!   If you DO join the game, however, I wouldn't exactly recommend getting too involved in the nastier side of the fanbase. In all honesty, this - and that GOD AWFUL BOSS FIGHT I'M STUCK ON [*raging intesifies*] - is the only downside of the game. Avoid misspelling the game - Ie. Undertail - and don't use keywords such as 'sin', unless, you know, you WANT to...  There's such a loveable cast in Undertale, ranging from: the lovely Goat Mama; the adorable, friendly flower *wink wonk*; the wacky Skele-duo; Alphy and Undyne (sitting in a tree, K-I-S-S-I-N-G.); and the L E G R O B O T. Not to mention, my personal favorite, the dark and not-at-all fluffy ASGORE! I'm sure that the characters in the game are one of the best parts.  The battle system in Undertale is a love letter to retero-style, bullet-hell RPGs. I think it's really smart how Toby builds up rules upon the fighting system and TOTALLY DOESN'T BREAK THEM A QUATER OF THE WAY THROUGH THE GAME. But, yeah, the whole way you battle in this gem of an RPG really hits you with some good ol' nostalgia.   Overall, I believe Undertale is an excellent game, and I highly reccommed it to you!
Undertale messed me up deeply and dealt me grave psychological wounds.  11/10 would play again despite it begging me not to.

A simple game about a kid and some goats and skeletons.   And a flower.    Yet, it's filled with love. Yet it actually made me care about it's characters like I never did in any other game. Yet I had went through the entire emotional spectrum while playing through the story. Yet the entire game is filled with so many little details, that I'm still lost in it even after finishing it a month ago. Yet the soundtrack is so amazing that I cannot stop listening to it. Yet everyting about Undertale feels like it's a once-in-a-lifetime experience, a masterpiece of a game that I'll remember for dozens of years.    And all this was made by one man, while the AAA industry spends millions of dollars to make a game that has only one thousand of the depth and enjoyment of this game.   Thank you Toby, for restoring my fate in video games.

Storyline is great. Your actions have far reaching consequences- killing someone is always a big deal as it should be. People react to the deaths of other people. There is a deconstruction of the aspects of the standard RPG. A large part of the story paints the fourth wall as a medium, where the rules of the game itself are explored as actual elements of the 'verse itself, subject to bending or exploitation by savvy characters.  Combat is great. Rythym game for those who want to fight the enemies, puzzles for those who want to spare the enemies. Bullet Hell for defense and sometimes the entire purpose of the combat. There were a few situations where I could not avoid damage but that is probably due to my lack of skill- attacks were always fair even if difficult.  Overall, I would give this game my recommendation for people to play- especially people who like thoughtful games like 'To the Moon' but are okay with the game's engine being put to the background.

Undertale is a wonderful game and is done right in so many ways it might be better than Papyrus' spaghetti [*WHAT DID YOU SAY?!].   You start off the game in a a cave alone on a bed of flowers. Though it the flowers might appear to be 'insignificant', they really aren't. As you progress through the game, you are given three (or four, depending on what you did) ways of playing the game. As you enter the next room, you are introduced to a smiling Flower, appropriately named Flowey [*Howdy!]. He teaches you the ins and outs of the Underground and shows you his LOVE with 'friendliness pellets'. Though your new mom (or mum) doesn't like this and stops the Flower from spreading LOVE over you like butter. She shows you around the RUINS and teaches you to talk to the monsters and not to hurt them. This is where you make your choice. Kill or be killed, or love and be loved.   Along your adventure to travel back above ground, you'll meet a lot of monsters as you progress through the Underground. Depending on what you do, they'll love you, or they resent you.   Undertale is a game that teaches you what friends really mean, and how it feels when you hurt others. The mechanic of the game is amazing and wonderful, much like the music and Mettaton EX's legs. I recommend this to anyone who has a computer/mac, it's an adventure that you should never miss out on.   If you're going to buy the game, buy the Soundtrack. I've never felt so many different emotions from just a soundtrack alone. And if anyone reading this wants to pirate this game,   You're going to have a bad time.   Buy the game to support the Dog so it can do more text-to-speech created games.    I want Undyne to teach me how to make spaghetti like she does, along with her teaching me how to suplex boulders, because she can and I want to as well.      Overall, this game is a masterpiece full of puns that are bad to the   Bone   and if this review gets 10,000 ratings I will let someone call me before I    destroy the Barrier and    entertain people! Buy the game and do the snail race! bOi!!!

TL;DR This game should be experienced by every gamer.  Normally I'm not the kind of person who would go around telling everyone he knows that they need to play a specific game but Undertale is a game that I believe anyone who enjoys games should experience. This game is the first game in a long time to affect me in anyway beyond simply being a game to have fun with. This game is the first one in a long time that I feel actually has heart. It knows what it wanted and it went for it.  In Undertale you play as a human who is purposefully androgynus who fell down into a world filled with monsters. You encounter many memorable characters on your journey out of the underground, many who want to kill you and many who just want a hug or a song. The game is a RPG where you have the option to fight every monster you come across like most standard RPGs and that option leads you to a timed attack system or you can ACT to either pacify or befriend them. Either option will result in the enemy attacking you which takes place in a bullet hell type event and then the process completes until you die, you kill the monster, or you MERCY/Spare the monster.  While the gameplay is fairly simplistic the simple fact that you can beat the game without killing anyone is something everyone should do at least once. What is amazing about the game is the music. It's positively amazing and it seems to hit the right tone for each area of the game, for every boss fight, and for every story beat perfectly. I haven't been this interested in a games music since hearing 3rd Eye Maiden in Touhou 11 and I like this games music so much I bought the soundtrack.

One of the few games that I took the time to play twice, in the course of two days no less. After I beat the game, I spent about an hour on YouTube and wikis seeing how things could have played out had I done things differently.   Overall without going into any plot elements, game's good and I 100% recommend it. Definitely worth 10 bucks.

Let me start by saying, I 'recommend this game!'. I enjoyed it. It made me laugh...it made me think (it didn't make me cry). The storyline was fun, the puzzles, while simplistic, were fun. The writing was clever, the music was really good. The graphics...well, they weren't. Not that graphics are required for a great game...but here, the simplisity was like playing an Atari game....but definitely at certain points, they were clever and added to the overall storytelling.   I guess, if I hadn't see the over-the-top hype, I would have been excited to say this was a great indie game and worthy for folks to purchase. Where it feels off-base is the over-the-top praise. I'm not sure what is causing the high volume and over-the-top, 'this is the best game I've ever played!!' comments are coming from. It's a great indie game. It's worth $10. Buy it...enjoy it.

I wish I didn't get spoiled for some things, but it didn't ruin my experience and thankfully certin things remained pure.   This game is easily in my top 5 games. And probably will be.   Also I'd 100% recomend you buy the soundtrack with the game. I didn't for some reason, but I don't mind it because I'm happy to give the extra $2 to Toby. Undertale is hands-down the best RPG I've ever played, and easily my Game Of The Year for 2015! I have so much to gush about but I'll try to keep it simple.  The gameplay is relatively straight-forward and simple by most standards, but where Undertale really shines is not only in its incredible narrative, but how its gameplay mechanics are an important part of that narrative. It's hard to talk about why I love this game so much without spoiling the experience, but I will say that I love how Undertale gives a real sense of consequences to your actions. I love how this game toys with, subverts, and utilizes RPG and video game conventions in unexpected ways. I love how this game actually, legitimately, really makes you feel bad for doing bad things in the game without using any kind of cheap 'karma' system. I don't even remember the last time I played a game that gave me feelings the way this one did. The characters are unforgettable, the music is top-notch (seriously, get the soundtrack bundle and thank me later), and the writing is basically perfect. If you have even a passing interest in video games you would probably enjoy this one. Hell, even if you don't you'd probably still enjoy it.  Please play this game. Please play Undertale.

I highly recommend this to anyone who likes RPGs.  My personal experiences started from meh to hitting my fist on my desk in frustration to 'I BEAT THE GAME!' This game is extremely innovative for the RPG genre. Most RPGs would say 'KILL EVERYTHING' but, in this it says 'the choice is yours.'   **SPOILERS** I think.   For example, you have 3 main ways of playing. Pacifist Neutral Genocide  If you were to do a genocide run for example you'd be completely ♥♥♥♥ed at the end. But, it changes the way the game and works and it almost makes you feel sad for your actions. Not to mention that ♥♥♥♥ing jumpscare at the end. UGH. Whereas, If you were to do a pacifist run, It would change the way the game goes through the story.   You can do so much with one simple idea and it branches to a massive project. I think that this game is one of the best games I've played this year. Hopefully, you'll enjoy it too...  Just don't get dunked on. ^_^   ~ Polaroid.

Undertale is pretty hard not to have heard of lately. Everyone has played it. Everyone loves it. I tend not to put a lot of faith in reviews (which have been overwhelmingly positive) but the screenshots looked inviting, so I gave it a try this weekend. I was not prepared to fall in love with the game, but I did.  It has everything a great game should have: memorable characters, witty dialogue, fun gameplay, and a soundtrack that’s worth listening to on its own. But what really sets Undertale apart is how it masterfully toys with your expectations. This starts very early with the “slay/spare” combat mechanic, which is featured in the trailer, and keeps escalating for (at least) the entire game.  I won’t spoil anything, but I will tell you that if you play the game as you would a typical RPG, well, you’re gonna have a bad time.

(Knowing that this review might get someone to buy this game... it fills you with determination.)  Undertale... oh, what a tale it was. I bought this game, already fully aware of what to expect, however it STILL managed to surprise me... in a very positive way. You get into the game, get attacked by a flower and then instantly saved by Toriel, one of videogames' sweetest character to ever exist. She teaches you the ways of being a decent human being: DON'T try to solve everything with brute force, try to talk it out. And if you thought this only meant that you can talk your way through key moments: nope, every single fight ('cept for some boss fights) can be won without issuing a single attack-command. Once your guardian has to leave because of unfinished business, the RUINS are yours to explore: here you might stumble across interesting creatures, such as a number of talking frogs, vegetables trying to make you eat healthy, a melancholic and adorable ghost, John Cena... Once you're reunited with Toriel, you go ahead and move into a small house, where you have your own, fully decorated room. And let me say this: if there was a chance to STAY at that house from the very beginning... I would've taken it. However, life can't always be awesome and so you move out to explore the world, get back to your OWN world and maybe make a few friends along the way.  The strongest point of this game -in my opinion- are it's characters. Toriel I've already mentioned, but there's also the skeleton brothers Papyrus and Sans, the adorable, albeit shy and scatterbrained Professor Alphys, the talkshow master Mettaton... there are quite a few, and ALL of them are simply awesome. I think most people know that this game has multiple paths and whichever you end up with depends on how many 'enemies' you've killed. See, this is interesting, because it means that for me, it is flatout impossible to EVER get a 'genocide' run (you kill... essentially everything and -one) going, simply because every character is WAY to lovable to harm in any way. Sure enough however, being pacifistic as hell is also really, really rewarding. I don't want to spoil anything, but I'll say this: the 'pacifist' ending honestly is one of the most heartwarming things I've ever witnessed. And I'm not exaggerating.  So, should you buy this game?? Yes, yes you totally should. Should you PLAY this game?? No, you should FEEL it. Should you ♥♥♥♥ off Sans?? Only if you want to have a BAD time.
Fantastic soundtrack, really funny game, it's just brilliant. The most fun I've had with an RPG like this in a long time, and I heartily recommend it to anyone.

Life isn't fair, and neither is this game. But if you have true DETERMINATION, you can persevere. The only thing I will warn you about is this.... prepare for feels. Oh... and if you kill? Prepare to pay for it. You ALWAYS have a choice.   10/10 Butterscotch Cinnamon Pies.

What a great game.  I know singing Undertale's praises is just another shout into the void, but it truly deserves all of the praise it's been getting. I assumed at first that it was just another passing Internet trend that I wouldn't be sucked into, but eventually I was gently shoved by a friend into the game, and now I've been trying to articulate just how great it is for the past three weeks.  The most fascinating thing about the game, and probably its biggest selling point, is that it really is what you make it. Every single choice you make, from deciding to kill a random monster to deciding to befriend that cool fish girl who tried to kill you five minutes ago, matters, and your decisions impact the game in a significant way. Not only do your choices affect your current playthrough, but they affect every subsequent one which makes replaying the game a new experience, whether you choose to go down the same path as your last game or not. This, in combination with the cast of characters you'll meet and come to care about along the ride and the genuinely interesting story and lore, is what gives Undertale such great replay value, but will make you hesitant to ever play it again after you've gotten that 'good ending' you've probably heard about by now.  When something gets loud and unanimous hype, I know I and so many others easily are turned off from said thing. Don't be. Play Undertale.
This game will fill you with determination.

This game is a masterpiece. Earthbound is my favorite game, and Undertale manages to work in all the elements of charm and quirkiness that make Earthbound so amazing to me. Every character is unique and interesting- you just want to get to know everyone. From joy to sadness, few games have made me feel so many emotional connections to every event, but this game sets the tone from beginning to the end. The music frames every moment perfectly and will have you humming along. The graphics are simple but take nothing away from the experience.  Even after finishing Undertale, I can't help but watch other people play for the first time just to see their overwhelmingly positive reactions. Nothing feels forced or like work. This is one of those games that set a standard for gaming, and leaves gaming community talking about it for years to come.

Legitmately one of the best games I have ever played. Undertale is a funny, sad, emotional and terrifying trip through a deeply innovative, but strangely innovative setting. Undertale follows the story of a small child who falls into a bizarre underground realm, populated by monsters. This conventional premise, however is turned on its head in the very first encounter. You don't have to fight the monsters, but can instead take the correct actions to befriend them and end the fight peacefully. Monster attacks are also unique, taking the form of tiny bullet hell minigames in which you must dodge the monster's attacks with a small red heart, representative of your soul. even the most basic encounters in Undertale are therefore unique and entertaining, and the boss battles become fast-paced amaglams of dodging and hugging. However, Undertale always gives you a choice. You can chose to fight and kill the monsters harassing you, but every possible choice in Undertale resonates through the storyline, and you will have to face the consequences of both playing violently and playing peacefully. The game's moral system is deep and affecting, making its points without forcing you into a certain path or getting preachy. You will want to protect this world and help these characters, not because you get an achievement for doing so or it unlocks a cool sidequest, but because you care about them.  With a beautifully evocative soundtrack and simple yet effective pixel art, Undertale is that rare deconstruction that doesn;t seem to hate what it deconstructs and it the very reason video games exist. if you still arent convinced it has a sexy robot and dogs you can pet (you cannot pet the sexy robot)

Moral choice systems have been vestigial in many games. Sure, you can be a jerk but you'd end up the hero anyhow. Undertale does it to the extreme. There have been a select few games in my life that have brought me to tears. Almost all of them required about one hundred hours of game play to do that. This game did that much sooner. This game, this is the first game I have ever paid full price for on steam (I'm a cheapskate, I wait for sales) and I would happily pay it again. This game is without a doubt one the most unique, heartfelt and humourous experiences I can get from my currently 210 strong steam library.  The graphics, although they feel a bit iffy at the start, fit the style of game perfectly. The music, amazing. I love digital music and this is no exception. The story, don't even get me started on that, it's fantastic, trying not to spoil anything, I was planning on playing differently on a reset after I finished but I really don't want to anymore, I like the characters too much to do that to them. The concept, I thought that an RPG with the possibility of killing nothing was odd to start with but is makes for such a more well thought out game, every battle is a clever puzzle that you can either solve with brains or brawn.  I hope my review is helpful, this is a lovely game at a fair price, I had about 9 hours of play time from it.

uh ok so in short this game is like. really good. you should play it  i should probably say some more stuff. theres gonna probably be some spoilers but i'll try to hide all of them  well as you probably could tell if you looked at like any of the pictures or videos undertale's an rpg thing where theres that thing where you can kill things or spare things and the enemy attacks are bullet hell things. so uh....if you dont like rpgs or bullet hell games maybe you wont like this very much??? i dunno even if you dont like those i still feel like you should play it because it has a really good story. it's uh, hard to talk about the story without spoiling  too much  but uh  basically there's a kid they fall in a hole there's a flower   (the flower is not nice)  then there's a goat then there's some skeletons then there's a fish and a lizard and a robot and another goat   and another goat  . that's. not a good description of this game i'm not sure where i'm going with this  but ok, so you probably could have guessed this but whether you spare or kill things influences what endings you get. spare everything   and also do some other stuff   and you get the pacifist ending, kill everything and you get the no mercy ending, kill some things and spare others and you'll get a neutral ending (there's a few neutral endings depending on what exactly you did! i would say that you should do different stuff everytime to see a few different endings but honestly i'm doing my third pacifist route in a row   (actually the 2nd one wasnt a true pacifist)   now i'm probably not someone who should say that)  the characters are all really good. the writing is good and the character design is good and overall it's just good. this game almost made me cry about a frog and the frog wasn't even a plot important character it just showed up and said one line (it was an important line though probably)  but enough about that one frog all the actual major characters are well-written and have a lot more to them than it seems at first.   like seriously i should not have mentioned the third goat    the soundtrack is really good but this uh. isnt a review of the soundtrack so i wont talk about it for too long. the first few tracks are pretty simple-ish chiptune-y stuff but i feel like they get a lot better by the time you reach the second area. This game is absolutely incredible. To briefly summarize, it’s an RPG that rifs off of old 2D RPGs, with all that awesome pixel art going on. If you don’t dig that art style tho, still give it a shot! It’s got a lot of other awesome stuff going for it!!! It’s got a killer soundtrack, great humor, and an awesome narrative with multiple endings and memorable characters. It dumps you on your head a couple times and has at least a few surprises you weren’t expecting, or if you /were/ expecting the surprise, you weren’t expecting the surprise you received. It's only $10, and it'll only take you about 6 hours to play through it, so give it a chance!  Explore an rich underground world! Kill the monsters! Or spare them! Your choice. Date a skeleton! Solve puzzles! Eat pie! Appear on live TV! Listen to music with a dapper ghost! PUNS. Chat with your best friend Flowey the flower! Be brave, and stay determined. At the end of your journey, and standing between you and the way home, is the king of monsters, ASGORE. Just remember, this is the friendly RPG where no one has to die!  (but that doesn't mean that no one will)

Undertale is a quirky RPG in the vein of the SNES game EarthBound. You never gain any other party members, and the RPG elements aren't that heavy (you only get two inventory slots, and there is no magic.) The game has two central gameplay mechanics.  1. Defense. Rather than just a text box saying the enemy attacks you and deals X damage, you control a small red heart inside a box and must avoid projectiles and other things, making it possible to not get hit at all. 2. Pacifism. It's possible to complete the game without hitting anyone (except Asgore, and Mettaton, but only in defense). After you complete the main game and get the Neutral ending, you can play again for a Pacifist run, extending the game beyond the normal final boss. Or you can just go for the Genocide ending.  The game is short, but sweet, longer if you go for the multiple endings. It's full of memorable characters and unique enemies. The soundtrack is amazing (like Waterfall, and the battle theme of Mettaton and Asgore). I do highly recommend this, and it's one of the best games of the year.
So many endings, so little time. Great combat, simple graphics, great comedy. It's a win-win-win-win-win game!

After seeing and reading up on this game due to recent incidents on the net, i decided to fork over the money and try it. Keeping an open mind, albeit a bit skeptical due to the hype behind it, I must say I was surprised! The game is fairly simple yet strangely complex...almost everything you do has some impact on the story in some way, shape or form. The story is nice and simple, easy to follow without any 'fluff' per se. The combat is nice and different, a combination of timed attacks and bullet-hell dodging, with a mix of something I wont spoil. Music, it was nice. It fitted the atmosphere of the stages and battles, and the sound effects were pretty well done as well. Graphics, they reminded me of those from the NES days, and that's not a bad thing! I really like how the characters seem alive, even the weakest of the badies to the strongest of bosses. All in all, for $10 it's a game worth trying. Is it the best thing since *insert whatever here*, maybe not, but is it a good game, yes. I personally give it a 9/10. Now to stay determined and make friends with everyone...or just gain some EXP and LOVE

In my opinion, Undertales greatest strength is also it's greatest weakness; it's an unapologetic indie game.  The fact that it is an indie game allows it to break the mold a bit, have an interesting and unique take on the turn based RPG such as the schmup style combat that changes with bosses to mix up the gameplay, a pure pacifist route option, deserved shaming for any non pacifist route (As compared to the defining scene in spec ops the line), and all the gameplay elements that break the fourth wall and alter the game experience in interesting way.  On the other hand, it suffers a lot because it is an indie game with little funding when compared to AAA games. The art direction (while good in style) is too low fidelity, the writing is sloppy and is very hit and miss, and many features are half present in the game (such as hard mode, the gaster storyline, and the arguable missed opportunity by only having 3 ending types). The biggest injury that being an indie game delivered to Undertale is the game length. Even for an indie game, RPG's are the genre that have the least trouble in extending gameplay through a variety of elements, and even though Undertale uses quite a few of them (random battles, a pure grind playthrough, and a playthrough where you cannot get stronger to fight enemies easier) the game is unbelievably short. Even if one looks for secrets, the first playthrough of the entire story should take no more than 3-4 hours, and if the pacifist run was done on that first playthrough, then the second true ending comes within 30-50 minutes later. Beyond that, the game is also suffers in it's presentation as many 'controversial' elements are presented without much tact or subtlety, once again due to it's indie origin, which serves to be extremely off putting if one is either uncomfortable with the subject matter it handles, the way it handles it, or the people the subject matter panders too.  As a player, I highly favour gameplay as the most important element of a game, which Undertale delivers on in a unique and engaging way, and I enjoy the style of humour it presents as well. While I did no like some of the overly dramatic and cliche moments at the end, nor the games short length, I did thoroughly enjoy what I did get, and would highly recommend this game to anyone willing to try it.

This game is perfect. Every single aspect of Undertale is enjoyable. The writing and humor is gold. The battle system is fun and unique. Every character, which includes every enemy, is lovable. The retro graphic style is charming. And the music! It's so incredible! Every track is memorable and you will just want to keep listening to it. It's the perfected JRPG formula. If you liked Earthbound, then you will definitely love this game. I actually think that this game is better than Earthbound. I didn't grow up with that game so I can give my opinion without nostalgia googles. Basically in this game, you can choose to fight or befriend anything that you engage a battle with. Fighting will increase your level; which will increase your HP, ATK, and DEF making it easier to beat the game. And your other choice is sparing your foes. You do this by choosing the 'act' option in a battle. There are several 'act' options to choose from and they vary depending on your enemy. It's usually a very silly sequence of actions you must fulfill to befriend and spare your foes. Your enemies are so charming and cute that you would feel bad killing them! They don't just get knocked out. They die! So choose wisely! There are plenty of puzzles in this game to keep the overworld interesting. And these are not tedious puzzles. I had fun with them. The most enjoyable part for me was the humor. This game made me laugh and smile throughout my whole playthrough. And right after I finished it, I went for a second playthrough so I could get the true ending. This game only took me 8 or 9 hours to beat, but it is truly worth it. $10 is a really good price. I would have bought it for $30. The story starts out all fun and silly, but you soon will realize how dark it really is. It's going to make you emotional. Toby Fox wrote this game, designed it, and composed the music. He really is a genius. And I really look forward to what ever else he will create. Hopefully another video game! 10 out of 10!!!

Undertale acknowledges all the tropes of the classic RPG genre and turns them on their head. I couldn't stop playing until the end (of which there are actually quite a few possibilities). Not only is it truly laugh out loud funny in a way that few games are -- it has the sharp humor and lovable characters of something like a Tim Schafer adventure game -- it's FUN. It actually has one of the BEST JRPG-style battle systems I've ever seen. It's actually fairly action-oriented, and it keeps things fresh up until the very end. No two fights are really the same. The music is out of this world good, and there's so much of it. And you might think the graphics are a bit bland looking at a selection of screenshots. They're anything but. This game has some of the LEAST repetitive graphics in a 2D game - there's always, always something new around the corner TLDR: I bought it this evening, and I got to an ending at 4:50 A.M., and I loved it so much I had to review it straight away.
The characters are so likeable and your decisions matter.

Undertale's uniqueness is one of its biggest strengths (out of many huge strengths.) It is a very story driven rpg that changes up the genre enough to make it fresh again. Each character you encounter has a very distinct personality, from basic enemies to full-on bosses. Some are humorous, some are very goal driven, the list goes on. The game's atmosphere is quite rich with distinct locals that feel alive for being an 8-16 bit styled game. The music, although unsure of what types it wants to stick with, is very catchy and very worth owning with the game soundtrack. Overall, it has very few flaws that can come to mind (being just one flaw) and is easily one of the best indie, if not general, releases seen this year. Check it out and feel ready to be determined.

A fantastic RPG in the same vein as Earthbound:All about its world,characters,and charm and less about its gameplay. However,for a game like this that puts more emphasis on story and atmosphere it's still no slouch in the gameplay department either.  The game is presented as a turn-based RPG,and for the player's actions it appears like such,but when it comes to enemy attacks it has the player move a heart (which represents their Soul) around to avoid the attacks of the enemy. Each enemy in the game has their own attack patterns and even enemies of similar types feel different enough that it never gets to feeling stale. Bosses even take things one step further by altering the mechanics in ways you'll never see when encountering normal enemies,such as limiting the Heart's movement to three lines or making it so you jump by pressing up instead of simply moving up or down.   Player attacks are pretty simple,after selecting 'fight' you must press the confirm button with appropriate timing to deal more damage (mistiming can either lead to less damage or even the attack missing altogether). However,while fighting is an option,the biggest part of the game is the 'act' menu and the ability to offer mercy to your enemies instead of killing them. Every enemy has their own set of options,ranging anywhere from petting them to simply flexing your muscles and just about anything in between. If you perform the right actions you're then given the option to Spare them,removing them from the battle at hand without having to kill them. This feature is key to a large amount of the game's charm and as such it's highly recommended that players do this for their first playthrough.  Of course,killing everything is very much an option and the difference between doing that and not killing anything is like night and day. Going Genocide over Pacifist takes you through the same areas,but the actual story events unfold in much different ways and leads to a completely different final boss and ending. When doing a Genocide run you must kill a certain amount of enemies in each area you go through (the number remaining is told to you at save points) until eventually they just stop appearing ('encounters' will still happen,but they will only contain the message 'But nobody came...'). Honestly this gets to be pretty dull,as the closer you are to your kill quota the longer it seems to take to get an encounter. In addition,none of the encounters in a Genocide run prove to be much of a challenge save for two particular boss battles. Personally I'd only recommend a Genocide run after you've already completed a Pacifist run as the personalities of the characters are very downplayed and it doesn't really represent what makes the game great.  Like I mentioned at the beginning of this review,the characters are a HUGE part of this game and going the Pacifist route really makes them all shine. Just about all of the major characters are surprisngly deep despite many of them seeming pretty one-dimensional when you first meet them. Hell,even a large amount of the minor characters in the game are memorable due to how silly and full of personality they are during the brief time you encounter them!  As for the game's soundtrack it's chock-full of chiptunes that perfectly reflect the areas and characters you encounter throughout the game and are prone to getting stuck in your head.   My only real gripe with the game is that it's fairly short for an RPG,lasting anywhere between 6-12 hours for a single playthrough,but considering you'll likely be laughing the entire way through it's a thoroughly enjoyable 6-12 hours and is well worth the $10 price if you're a fan of this kind of game.  (Reading this far into the review fills you with DETERMINATION!)

* One of the best games I've played in recent years. The story is so gripping and heartwrenching, unlike any other game I've seen in a long time.  * I love the mechanics behind the games' direction; for example, the game offers drastically different dialogue/gameplay based on a set of actions taken (or not taken.) This is based on whether you choose not to harm anybody in your way (for the True Pacifist ending), killing a few, but not all enemies (Neutral Route), or slaughtering everyone, mercilessly (for a Genocide Run)  * (but why would you kill helpless creatures, you monster...)  * Mechanics aside, the story/characters/etc. are a surprising mix of hilarious, lovable, innocence, seriousness, and sadness that combine to form the most twisted emotional rollercoaster that I've endured in a very, VERY long time.  * Seriously, do yourself a favor and play already. Be sure to both avoid spoilers at ALL COSTS, and collect all the Friendliness Pellets you can find along your way. =)

There are few games that I find myself personally invested in any of the decisions one would make while progressing from beginning to end. From the start Undertale empowered the value of ones choices, and then, maintained it through the game all the way to the last moment.  The writing was both clever and informative. The game is not shy when showing the results, and later, the consequences to your actions. Any piece of text, in dialog or observation, would provide more depth to the world and the characters that exist within it.  Undertale game play made two changes to the mechanics common in role playing game. First) You have the option to spare your opponents in combat. Second) You can maneuver your character during your opponent action to dodge incoming attacks. These changes make both random encounters and boss battles more unique.  Undertale is a well crafted gem that has been a rich experience to play.  With the hope you may one day enjoy this game, you are fill with determination.

Just.... wow. This game.  *'Undertale is a story about you, a young child falling into the world of monsters.' *... *But then it happens. *You play through it, and, obviously, the story grows into something bigger than it originally seemed. *You play through again and get a different ending. *Suddenly, the LORE of the UNDERGROUND expands a fair bit. *You play again, hungry for more information. *It works. The [chara]cters and world expand even more, and you go from the main character, the star of the show, to just a piece in the puzzle.  Undertale has great gameplay and visuals, along with an OUTSTANDING soundtrack but thats not the point. The points are the characters, the story, and the mechanic of MERCY. It may seem like a gimmick at first, but MERCY heavily affects the story and characters around you. Whether it's just a handful of enemies, a mini-boss, or a big boss main character, whether or not you give them MERCY, or FIGHT them and kill them, can completely change everything about the game and its world. It's amazing how the story goes from just a kid trying to get home, to a story of love and hate, a story of HOPE and DETERMINATION.  And that is why Undertale earns a 10/10 from me.

Undertale is a wonderfully polished and subversive experience. Beyond being a profoundly emotional and effective experience, Undertale also uses its setting and lore to its advantage by creating a commentary on morality as it applies to video games, and commenting on elements which we as players commonly take for granted.  -Memorable, lovable cast of characters, all of whom have more layers to them than you might think at first. -Combat system makes up for its rather simplified JRPG style by incoporating real time dodging mechanics, ala classic bullet hell style. Excellent use is made of a plethora of dodging mechanics to keep the game engaging, and in some cases, quite difficult. -Excellent, involving story which, much like all of the characters, has much more to it than you might think. -Great writing. The text in this game is contemporary, charming, and often downright hilarious. -Expansive meta-commentary. Besides the rather fourth wall breaking style to begin with, Undertale changes with each playthrough, showing evidence of your involvment in between saves and resets.  A unique take on the JRPG that takes themes from old masterpieces like Earthbound and turns them on their head, Undertale is an experience that is incredibly deep and complex, but at the same time refrains from over-complicating itself. One of my top five of 2015, in no particular order.   10/10

This game is more than a game. It's a game about a game, making a game while playing the game. This game is the game of life, the game of chances, the game of truth.   This game was forced upon me, and now I am forever stuck.

Years of playing RPGs have engrained so many habits into us. When we start playing an RPG we immediately think that we know how to procede. Fight monsters, gain EXP, level up, get the best stats and equipment, and get to the end boss.   Undertale takes those expectations and twists them. It allows you to take those expectations and run with them and then pull the rug out from under you and change your perception on their world.  That's all I can say about Undertale without spoilers. Any more information about this game will completely ruin it for you. Do yourself a favor and go into it cold.

I picked up Undertale in the Christmas Steam sale, so I got aboard the Untertale train pretty late. I had managed to avoid spoilers, so I was playing through it blind, but most of the way through my first playthrough of this game, I have to say I thought the game was kind of overhyped.  Sure, the writing was pretty funny at times, and the music was good, and the schtick of an RPG where you could talk your way through everything instead of killing was different. But I didnt get the story, and some of the boss fights were just tedious, to the point where I was pretty close to just quitting instead of continuing to slog through dying over and over and over on the final boss. When I finally got past him to the end of the game, it was with more of a sense of a grand FINALLY! than a grand finale.   But then, without putting spoilers in this review, lets just say that at that point, the pieces of the story that I had been missing finally clicked into place, and my appreciation of the narrative blossomed exponentially.   I no longer think this game is overhyped; in fact, I don't think it has gotten nearly as much attention as it deserves.  Since then, I have played through the entire thing, start to finish, two more times (something I have never wanted to do for any other RPG, at least without a couple years in between, and certainly not back-to-back-to-back playthroughs). Each time, I have gleaned more hidden gems of absolutely marvelous storytelling (there is a metric buttload of secrets all over the place.) The dialog and events are by turns charmingly funny and incredibly, heart-wrenchingly sad; no game has ever made me laugh OR cry as much as this one has. I can't recommend it highly enough.

Think out of the box, this is a fairly puzzle heavy game. 5. Pay attention to what people and objects say, it really actually helps and makes the story clearer. 6. Take whatever you think when you play games and through that away, that's what the game wants you to do.

At this time, you are likely reading this review because the hype you heard: friends saying to buy and play it, or you saw some videos or neat music on Youtube.  Don't let aparent overexcited hype dissuade you from the game. $10US is cheap for what it offers, easilly enough to make your own judgment. If your friends feel as strongly they might have offered to buy the game for you.   As a retro style game it makes good use out of the graphics of the age. The music while sounding much like the 16-bit music it's trying to emulate is very catchy and has already spawned many remixes of the themes on Youtube. The box 'Combat' system is interesting and often enough surprising to keep you on your toes. There are many Easter eggs and side bits are numerous and often require different playthroughs to see them. Battles change on depending on your playstle; you might fight one monster one way, or another by a different path.  The characters are interesting, often endearing. They react to how you play the game; even the random NPCs you meet have different reactions based on how the game progresses. The humor is goofy at times, but still quite amusing. The story is well written and easilly captures people's heartstrings depending on your emotional investment in the game.  I highly recommend taking the chance and play without any spoilers or guides just for the fun of it on your first playthrough. My hat is off to Toby Fox on the depth placed into this game. I hope to see more from him.

For the price, you really can't beat Undertale. It's a simple game, battles aren't fancy, but have theme and charm to them. Lots of people say to play a pacifist run first, but I say kill a couple of things, and follow the game's instructions at the end of your first play through. The replay value on this game is amazing, with the story changing depending on your actions in the current playthrough, and past ones. The writing is great, I'm strugling to do a Genocide playthrough simply from the writing and not the difficulty of the game itself. Soundtrack is catchy & fun. You can spare £6.99 on this game that will easily beat £1 per hour of gameplay, even if you play it through once!

It takes a great deal for me to write a review about a game, as I generally don't feel it necessary to do it. However, Undertale, a game by Toby Fox, has proved to be an amazing game. From the story that has a great deal of lore, to the characters big and small, to all of those tear jerker moments (I'm not one to get to emotional for a game, but this one surely gets to me) The price for this game is fair, as it takes maybe around 6 hours to beat, but the replayability to this game is HUGE. The different runs you can do where you don't kill anyone or you kill everyone or a mix of the two, makes a LOT of different dialogue options, and lets you get tastes of more of the story, which still isn't 100% clear, but what you do get is an amazing game.  Also, thank you Toby Fox for making a game that has caused me to rage really hard on one boss (Those that see this and have played will probably get it).

When I first heard about undertale I though 'oh another crappy rpg with crappy graphics.' The gameplay introduces a new gameplay style that is both easy and hard to understand and use. The characters are more interesting and developed than some of the people I know in real life. They made me want to help them. The soundtrack is huge with some amazing songs that get you hyped, sad, happy, or scared. The bossbattles are excited as well as hard. They make you want to keep trying and want to over come any obsticle that comes in your path. UnderTale is the best game of the year if not the best game ever made. The overall experience of the game makes you want to keep coming back for more and when you do you just get over excited with all the energy and amazingness that comes along the way. If you haven't played this game you are missing out on something great.

It's good It's great It's awesome Best game ever? meh, not really, still awesome  Heavily inspired by Earthbound, you play a kid who is trapped in the underground world where monsters live. Almost none of them are bad but they all seem to want something from you or are afraid of you so you get the choice to ACT things out peacfully like a puzzle or FIGHT with very basic combat. There's a special ending for pacifism and a gamebreaking ending for genocide. I recommend kill one person, spare another and just play as you like on the neutral route for your first run. Characters are great in case you haven't seen the fans gushing over them, story gets real deep at times, combat is a lot more interesting. Offensivly it ranges from figuring out each enemy with actions and just bashing them over the head. The real kick is in the defense where you have to move your 'soul' around to avoid bullets. In most fights I didn't think it was too difficult but then again I've lost so many times to Ran from Perfect Cherry Blossom. Regardless Undyne will be the first real challenge in combat and in Genocide route certain enemies really mean business. If you haven't been spoiled to what happens in this game I highly recommend playing it and locking yourself away until you've done a neutral route (it's okay, you can beat it in about 4 hours). I can understand the fans get annoying but for a few hours just ignore them, get this game, and never use Tumblr in the first place.

(review gets long and wordy, you were warned) When I first saw Undertale released on Steam, I kinda glanced over it.... and I liked it. It was nice, not too stylized, but unique all the same. The music sounded great, the concept looked solid, and I thought the no-kill feature was pretty neato. It just looked awesome all around.  Pros and Cons (As always, P&Cs are based off of my own personal experiences. Opinions are all different.) Pros: -Humorous (Or should I say Humerus :P) -Solid storytelling -Great soundtrack -Memorable cast -High replayability -Easily navigatable  Cons: -Repetitive jokes -You must be somewhat invested in the cast to thoroughly enjoy it -Somewhat unforgiving -Controls can be a hassle depending on your keyboard -Encounters can become boringly simple -Time battling in boss battles is directly proportional to amount of dialogue the boss has.  Note: If you aren't thoroughly aquianted with your arrow keys, well, you will be in a few minutes, because your movement in the game relies on these keys, both in battle and out. If you're normally aquainted with WASD, you may have a little trouble, but it shouldn't be too hard.  And so here we go. Undertale starts simply enough, with story and a tutorial. But as it moves on and as you make choices and interact with characters, it becomes a simply memorable experience. The music ranges from warm and energetic to haunting and slow, and that's not giving it much credit either. If you can, I definitely recommend you buy this game along with its soundtrack because HOLY HELL it is gold.  Undertale, though simple, is surprisingly deep, pretty solid with its story, and at times completely meta (or should I say Metta?). The characters are complex, ridiculously entertaining, and extremely memorable (and you can date a skeleton. Who can say no to that?). There is little, if any, of the fourth wall left by the time the game is over, which makes it that much more of a delightful experience. Not to mention you're subjected to puns and jokes hand over fist.  Undertale does come with its downs as well, and when I talk about downs, I'm talking about what the cool kidz these days refer to as 'The feels'. And this game has the feels. Oh, does it have 'em. Never have I restarted a game for feeling  guilty . And this game guilt trips you like you promised your daughter you would see her dance recital and totally missed it. Every action you make has an outcome. Every. Single. One. And it is glorious.  The game is also mildly self aware. So if you think you can kill everything with no consequence... Well, I'll let you be the judge of your own playthrough. But let me tell you. The choices you make define the outcome of the game. If you kill everything, the game remembers. If you spare everything, the game remembers. You can feel like a saint or a monster (which, in respect to the game, is offensive to the monsters) and if you think you can reset, NO WAY. This game knows. Every one of your transgressions, it knows. There are multiple endings and multiple dialogue options, and each of your actions effects these (present and future playthroughs included).  However, a few elements of the game may become tedious at times, especially encounters. Each encounter usually relies on a specific action in order to sate/destroy the monster, which can become tedious in a single area, encountering the same monster, choosing the same choices, time after time. Another mildly-tedious element is boss battles. Time battling in boss battles is directly proportional to amount of dialogue the boss has, meaning the amount of hits/times you stall usually don't matter- only the dialogue of the character matters. If you want EXP, you're going to have to kill something. Depending on your desired outcomes, this may not be so bad. But should you desire an outcome without violence, there's a bit of a curve as it becomes more difficult to find patterns and dodge higher attacks. Combine that with a low health bar and shoddy armor in a high-level area and you just might have a bad time.  At any rate, Undertale doesn't take itself too seriously (that's your job) and it's a delightfully refreshing twist on most of the games out there today- the story isn't the newest, the graphics aren't the most magnificent, but it makes all of it worthwhile. It's witty and different and I like that.  TL;DR If you want to date a skeleton, get dunked on with pun after pun, meet a variety of dogs, eat a variety of strange foods, make friends/foes with a bunch of cool people, have a flexing contest, fight a suspiciously Dr. Frank N. Furter-esque robot or  swear violently  talk to a flower, Undertale is  the  game for you. It's quirky. Its funny. Its creative. Even those words don't do it justice. But it may be exactly what you're looking for.    Absolutely perfect. Spaghetti/100. Get Undertale. You will not regret it.

Undertale, GOTY 2015?  A true contender, that's for sure!  Sure, it doesn't have MSG V's depth nor Fallout 4's/Witcher 3's longevity but it sure has heart.  This is a game where your choices actually matter and, believe me, the game is actually alive. The story is very rich, filled with humorous remarks, with interesting and instant-classic characters, replay value and it's pretty cheap.  This is a retro-style RPG that reminds you of Earthbound (SNES) with some pretty solid soundtrack and interesting puzzles. Oh, you can also date a skeleton.  Recommended!

[NO SPOILERS IN THIS REVIEW]  No game is perfect. However some games get so close to perfection that they shouldn't even be called games anymore.  Undertale is not a game; it is an experience.  I don't think I've ever had such an experience that brought out every single emotion I had, and with excellent execution. And I'm not usually a very emotional person. That being said:  Undertale made me laugh. Undertale made me cry. Undertale surprised me. Undertale scared me. Undertale angered me. Undertale astonished me. Undertale frustrated me. Undertale tempted me. Undertale questioned me. Undertale gave me hope. Undertale made me experience true joy and accomplishment.  And most importantly, Undertale filled me with DETERMINATION.  How many other RPGs can do that?

Undertale is a terrific game. A tribute to classic JRPGs from the SNES era, particularly Earthbound, which manages to transcend being a mere tribute to become a memorable experience that deserves to be mentioned alongside those games. Add in what's easily the best soundtrack of 2015, and you get an incredible game, well worth your time.

This game is everything I love in an RPG:  It's quirky The characters are lovable It's original The 'battle' system is engaging  and it also includes something I never thought I'd see. It has actual choice. You, the player, have the power to befriend or kill each boss and enemy. These all matter and affect your gameplay throughout the story and the ending drastically.  And the characters are phenomenal. You will love each and every character after knowing their whole story. Speaking of which, depending on whether you want to, you can play through the game and acheive multiple endings to patch together the plot, backstory, character development, and your role.  This game will make you feel guilt, feel disgust, feel empathy, feel happiness, and, yes, even cry. This game is far more than your typical indie game and it is far more than an Earthbound 'clone'. This game has it's own identity.  I heartily reccommend this game that has made it into my Top 10 games of all time.  Most of all, Stay DETERMINED!

Highly creative and inspiring! Undertale is game that progresses based off of the choises you make as the player. The first route you should do is Pacifist, in which you do not hurt a single thing. Each fight you encounter can be escaped in various ways, but you can beat the game without hurting anyone. This is very uncommon in an RPG. There is the Genocide route as well, in which you kill everyone and everything in the game. And then there's many different neutral routes and a ton of different endings you can trigger.  Obviously, you can do whatever you like, don't just take my word. But whatever routes you choose to do, I guarentee you will fall in love with the characters, from the main ones to the supporting ones. All the dialouge, no matter how small, adds something to the game. In fact, much of the dialouge is highly comedic!   Also, the game doesn't really have a fourth wall, an aspect I've always enjoyed in games. Whatever you do, the game will remember and sometimes it prompts dialouge and conversations that some players have not experienced because they haven't played the game exactly like you have.  I know there has been a LOT of hype about this game, but it is not undeserved. I apologize for the fans; they make it hard to want to play this game if you're unfamiliar with it. But if you are looking for a story rich game with multiple layers and angles you can get from it, then please. Play this game.

It's got amazing soundtracks (megalovania, SAVE the world, undertale), loveable characters (Sans, Papyrus, Toriel), and a critical storyline (pacifist, genocide, mutual). The different modes you play in the game can effect you and your game depending on the order you play them in. It's amazing how uneccesarily complex Toby made the game and programming in it. Ranging from discovering a hidden room from dodging all of the credits in true pacifist to the genocide ending effecting the true pacifist ending. It's nclear the more you look in to this game, the more you see messages relating to reality in it, wether it was Toby Fox's intentions in the first place. So what can I honestly say about this games that hasn't been said before?

This game was very sad, and also, very happy. I went on the genocide run first, without thinking about what I was doing, and I thought that that's how the game had to go, you kill, gain LV and stats, and things like that, but you don't think about what you're doing. You're going through the game, as if it is another rpg where you kill everything, and level up, but when you realize at the end, that your actions have consequences, it hits the sweet spot with moral and ethical values. The Frog at the very beginning of the game even pleads for mercy for himself, and all monsters alike, and when you go out and kill a monster, you slowly become a monster yourself by the end of the game, and not metaphorically, I mean, literally. So I went on a pacifist run, where I usually talked my way out of battle, or fled, or spared monsters, and needless to say, my efforts were rewarded in a very satisfying happy, yet bittersweet ending. I have been told though that there are lots of other secrets to be discovered, so if you like games that have mystery, or adventure, this one is for you.  I also found a whole lot of the music very calming, and peaceful, for instance, I was traveling through Snowdin, and the town was magical, the characters, given little dialogue and narration, seemed fleshed out among the other Snowdin villagers, and they just 'belonged.' It was like walking through a fantasy for most of the game, walking through the puzzles and braving the stronger opponents in the game. It was as if all of my literal dreams were being visualized, and, I will admit I used to dream and fantasize about things like that when I was a kid. From wacky characters such as Papyrus, to the bold and peaceful king at the ending of the game, every character had It's place in this big world, and I was so frustrated to find some of the choices very hard to choose. Even in the little things, like deciding which is better, crossword, or word jumble? Every single dialogue choice, big or little, has an amazing impact on things like, how Papyrus acted, or if I stayed friends with Sans, and weather I would have to fight Undyne.  And the soundtrack just added to the mystical tone of Undertale, as I fought Toriel, or battled Papyrus, or heard one of Sans jokes, all of the music just fit in somehow, to a game this small, yet so big. The sound effects were not the best, and neither was the music, but the way that they utilized what they had to make the game, and build it into what it is now, is amazing. I wish the music was more cinematic, or theatrical, but when I think about what the game might be if the music were like that, then that would ruin the art style, or at least just seem out of place, next to it. It is like an old NES game, or an old nintendo game, in that it has simplistic graphics, and movements, but it's not like it had to be completely realistic.  The fights are my personal favorite parts of the game, because it has some fast parts, and some slow parts, and some really just confusing moments, but it's not to fast for the style of the game, and not too slow either. I found a lot of what the monsters said really funny, and really inspiring, and that filled me with determination(no pun intended).  All in all, this game is not perfect, but for me, it certainly is, and I enjoyed every minute playing this game. I recommend it for an adolescent audience, or a young adult audience, because there are some things that kids should not play through.

pros  met a talking flower made a goat mum made friends with 2 funny skeletons based off of fonts found Toby to be a trap in the game realised it was just a dog which was lazy MANY MANY dank meme and weired stuff that we cant talk about amazing story plot  cons you havn't bought it yet.  if you didn't like my review then heres a recipe for some kickass brownies   Cut 185g unsalted butter into smallish cubes and tip into a medium bowl. Break 185g best dark chocolate into small pieces and drop into the bowl. Fill a small saucepan about a quarter full with hot water, then sit the bowl on top so it rests on the rim of the pan, not touching the water. Put over a low heat until the butter and chocolate have melted, stirring occasionally to mix them. Now remove the bowl from the pan. Alternatively, cover the bowl loosely with cling film and put in the microwave for 2 minutes on High. Leave the melted mixture to cool to room temperature. While you wait for the chocolate to cool, position a shelf in the middle of your oven and turn the oven on to fan 160C/conventional 180C/gas 4 (most ovens take 10-15 minutes to heat up). Using a shallow 20cm square tin, cut out a square of non-stick baking parchment to line the base. Now tip 85g plain flour and 40g cocoa powder into a sieve held over a medium bowl, and tap and shake the sieve so they run through together and you get rid of any lumps. With a large sharp knife, chop 50g white chocolate and 50g milk chocolate into chunks on a board. The slabs of chocolate will be quite hard, so the safest way to do this is to hold the knife over the chocolate and press the tip down on the board, then bring the rest of the blade down across the chocolate. Keep on doing this, moving the knife across the chocolate to chop it into pieces, then turn the board round 90 degrees and again work across the chocolate so you end up with rough squares. Break 3 large eggs into a large bowl and tip in 275g golden caster sugar. With an electric mixer on maximum speed, whisk the eggs and sugar until they look thick and creamy, like a milk shake. This can take 3-8 minutes, depending on how powerful your mixer is, so don’t lose heart. You’ll know it’s ready when the mixture becomes really pale and about double its original volume. Another check is to turn off the mixer, lift out the beaters and wiggle them from side to side. If the mixture that runs off the beaters leaves a trail on the surface of the mixture in the bowl for a second or two, you’re there. Pour the cooled chocolate mixture over the eggy mousse, then gently fold together with a rubber spatula. Plunge the spatula in at one side, take it underneath and bring it up the opposite side and in again at the middle. Continue going under and over in a figure of eight, moving the bowl round after each folding so you can get at it from all sides, until the two mixtures are one and the colour is a mottled dark brown. The idea is to marry them without knocking out the air, so be as gentle and slow as you like – you don’t want to undo all the work you did in step 4. Hold the sieve over the bowl of eggy chocolate mixture and resift the cocoa and flour mixture, shaking the sieve from side to side, to cover the top evenly. Gently fold in this powder using the same figure of eight action as before. The mixture will look dry and dusty at first, and a bit unpromising, but if you keep going very gently and patiently, it will end up looking gungy and fudgy. Stop just before you feel you should, as you don’t want to overdo this mixing. Finally, stir in the white and milk chocolate chunks until they’re dotted throughout. Now your mixing is done and the oven can take over. Pour the mixture into the prepared tin, scraping every bit out of the bowl with the spatula. Gently ease the mixture into the corners of the tin and paddle the spatula from side to side across the top to level it. Put in the oven and set your timer for 25 minutes. When the buzzer goes, open the oven, pull the shelf out a bit and gently shake the tin. If the brownie wobbles in the middle, it’s not quite done, so slide it back in and bake for another 5 minutes until the top has a shiny, papery crust and the sides are just beginning to come away from the tin. Take out of the oven. Leave the whole thing in the tin until completely cold, then, if you’re using the brownie tin, lift up the protruding rim slightly and slide the uncut brownie out on its base. If you’re using a normal tin, lift out the brownie with the foil. Cut into quarters, then cut each quarter into four squares and finally into triangles. These brownies are so addictive you’ll want to make a second batch before the first is finished, but if you want to make some to hide away for a special occasion, it’s useful to know that they’ll keep in an airtight container for a good two weeks and in the freezer for up to a month.

This game was a very nice refreshment in the RPG genre, giving a compelling story, fun gameplay, although a bit repetitive at times, it has a great soundtrack, and it has a nice, smooth difficulty curve. Bosses are creative, and every action you take has an impact on the game. I am NOT saying this is the perfect game for everyone, and especially not better than the alleged best games of all time. I AM saying however, that this game, with the time, effort, and determination put into it is definitely worth the 10 bucks needed to buy the game, and if you try out every path, you will have a great time. Some jokes do get old, and none are enough to get a full laugh out of me- only chuckles, it is definitely a great game if you are looking on a refreshing spin on the genre, especially since 'no one has to die'.  Just know: if you buy the game, you either go Pacifist for the story, or Genocide for the battles.  Overall: 9.5/10
