TL;DR  Pros:  - Great soundtrack - Unique game mechanics - Nostalgic - Non-linear experience - Unique characters  Cons: - Outdated graphics - Limited character itemization - Shallow storyline - Replayability   Like most people, if you ever came across this page for the first time, you would never think to try out this game because of graphical limitations. However, if you are look past the graphics, most people who played this game will tell you that this game is a unique experience.   Unlike most RPGs, Undertale does not focus on grinding from level 1 to 25 to eventually beat a dungeon boss. The creators of Undertale wants the player to feel immersed around the environment and characters in the game. Every character you meet in the game is likable in their own way, even the bad guys. Additionally, each character has their own theme song, and makes you feel 'OH SHI-', or in wrestling terms 'mark out' to a degree. Even with all the positives with the characters in Undertale, these characters do not add much depth to the story. However, these do not retract to what makes Undertale special.  For each enemy interaction in Undertale, you have the choice to either kill or not kill each enemy. Although, killing does not penalize you, it makes a difference in where the story ends. Not killing every enemy is rewarding at the end.   If you are turned off in how Undertale looks, do not let that deter you from playing this one of a kind game.

This game is a masterpiece!   The fighting mechanics are unique, the characters are well made with background stories and motivations, and the music is truly amazing. I have not been so invested in a game for a very long time. The game is kind of short, but there are several different endings, so it has a fair bit of re-play value.   Easily worth its price.

I was hoping the game would be ported to Wii U at some point, but it didn't happen.   I just finished the True Pacifist Route, and I can definitely say that Undertale is my favorite RPG. The game may not be perfect in some areas, and I don't like how it punshies you when you finish Genoicde (which is one of the reasons why I'm not doing it), but I still found it enjoyable overall. Lord of the Frisk or Undertale  This indie game has become a legend of sorts. With a dedicated fanbase to match, and packed with enough content, lore, addictiveness and all the bits that assemble an extraordinary video game, Undertale will be remembered throughout the ages.  Now, before we begin, what is Undertale? Well simply, it’s the story of a lost human child, who finds herself trapped in an underground world, and she must find a way out. Kind of sets up the basis for a fairly modern RPG setting, right? But it accomplishes so much more than a simple “Enter da dungeon, kill da mobs, acquire increasingly powerful loot, encounter even stronger bosses, and save the day” game. Your avatar is a little girl. She’s not some badass knight in spiked armour, wielding a sword/axe/spear/staff, but if she gets violent, which the game allows you to do, things go down a dark, spiralling path that may be discomforting at its most. In short, Undertale is a colossal triumph, because not only is it brilliant, funny, and engaging, but it also demonstrates how unique and amazing indie games can be. That’s not to say that the bigger game companies today aren’t talented enough to make their own heavy-hitters (here’s looking at you, Bethesda and Telltale Games).   Anyway, let’s get down to business: Story-wise, Undertale stars the human girl, trapped in the underworld, trying to find a way to the surface. As her journey progresses, we come across and entire ensemble of colorful, funny and memorable characters. There’s the mommy-goat figure, named Toriel, who wishes to take in the human child as her own, there’s the hilarious skeleton brothers, Sans and Papyrus, with their cartoony hijnks and skeleton-related puns that ought to tickle your funny bone, there’s the cool Undyne, with her grand plans of capturing a human, and many more. The main antagonistic force opposing the human child is a small flower named Flowey, who attempts to kill her from the very start! This is achieved with little “love pellets”, which are in reality, bullets that narrow the player’s health to one! Luckily, Toriel saves us in the nick of time and shoots a fireball right into the aforementioned flower’s face, effectively sending him flying away.  You’ll notice that it’s not just the aforementioned batch of characters, but also every single foe in the game, each with their own ambitions and personalities. In a way, they are no different from us humans; they just want to live and enjoy life. This further encourages the option to spare the monsters, which evokes positive reactions from other NPCs.  Now, gameplay is essentially a giant bullet-hell fest. During most sequences, you are enclosed in a small box, where your avatar is turned into a heart, which represents your soul. In order to win, you must dodge every projectile sent your way. This isn’t necessarily easy, and living up to its name as a bullet hell title, that small box is filled with deadly objects that will chip away at your health if you are not careful to dodge them. There are certain patterns to each attack, and you must memorise them carefully. Once you get the hang of it, the gameplay is extremely addictive and fast-paced The graphics of Undertale retain a pixilated format, equivalent to those of old Nintendo games. Some will point out that the graphics aren’t up to par with the rest of the game, but I digress. The pixilated graphics perfectly suit Undertale, making it stand out from other games that use the same art style.  The soundtrack…oh god, the soundtrack...it’s beyond anything you’ve heard before. Whether you are walking through the woods, or a monster village, or a field of snow poffs, or a cave illuminated with glowing mushrooms, the soundtrack sets the mood and adds an atmosphere of beauty to an already enthralling adventure. During the comedic events of the game, the music becomes silly and flamboyant, to the point where you have little else to do but chuckle. The music is a key feature of Undertale, and makes you want to stand up and cheer, because it is THAT damn good, and sets an example of how amazing game soundtracks can be.  One more thing about Undertale is its ability to be funny. The humor often dabbles in the realms of the internet, and twists long-dead memes into fresh and original jokes, one-liners, and puns. Especially bone-related puns, and there are a ton of funny bones within Undertale’s body, packed with comedic calcium. From an annoying mutt that prevents you from acquiring a legendary fruit by taking up your inventory space, to the mischievous antics of the skeleton twins Papyrus and Sans, you will find few other games that will make you spit out your spaghetti with laughter then this game.  To wrap up this review, would I recommend this game? Well, would a mouse patiently wait for a slice of cheese that has become incrusted within a purple crystal? Would a sea-dwelling onion beg you to notice him? Would that dog playing poker lose, even when it’s playing by itself?! If all of those fill you up with determination, than yes! I highly recommend this game! Anyway, I can sit here and talk about this game’s greatness, but that’s absolutely nothing compared to when you, yourself, play it. You will simply have to buy it and taste the epicness that is Undertale.  And remember, no matter how you look at it…  Or whatever you make of it…  It’s still a snow poff. ---Dr.M

Undertale 's creator was once known mostly for his  Earthbound  mods, and that background shines through in this game's tone and aesthetic.  Undertale  is a dreamlike, postmodern take on the classic RPG formula that regularly engages in genre critique and fourth-wall breaking and oscillates between scenes of sweetness and light and scenes that are, at times, geniunely disturbing. Fans of  Earthbound  will find themselves in familiar territory in this respect.  The central concept that sets  Undertale  apart is not the bullet-time feature that differentiates its combat from other RPGs, nor is it the clever way the battle system mechanizes the effort to end fights peacefully, though both are welcome additions. The more interesting feature, rather, is the game's awareness of the save file. Going back and loading your save will not quite reset everything you've done in the interim, and a few of the game's NPCs know what you've done and will hold you accountable down the line. The main quest takes about six to ten hours to complete, but the secret endings built on the concept of 'recreating' the world by starting over constitute the real meat of the game's story. It takes several playthroughs to experience every ending, and completionist players will occasionally be pointed out as such by NPCs.  While it's now easier than ever before to make a retro RPG at home and distribute it online, the resulting sea of sprite games takes a special effort to stand out from, and  Undertale  does so with clever mechanics and an interactive meta-story that provides stark tonal contrasts without feeling arbitrary or disorienting (or at least not more disorienting than feels appropriate given the nature of the story). If you liked  Earthbound , if the idea of an RPG revolving around the choice to kill or befriend appeals to you, or if you're just a fan of turn-based RPGs in general, I recommend  Undertale .

TL;DR : If you have emotions, buy it; it's worth so much more than $10.  A lot has already been said about this game in the year it's been released (at the time of this review). A lot of people comment on the heart of the game, the soundtrack, the characters... There's a lot to comment on. There is just truly so much about this game that makes it great. Forget all the memes of the annoying dog, how great a song 'Megalovania' is, how weird some of the fanart is. Forget all that. If you haven't played this game, spend the $10 and do so.   The characters are unbelievably fully-realized. Papyrus, Sans, Alphys, Toriel, even the late-game characters are so rich and deep. The human understanding it takes to create such completely well-developed characters you feel for, no matter what path you take, be it Pacifism or Genocide or some strange middle ground, the actual heart it takes to create these characters is astounding. A great deal of personal struggle had to of been experienced by the creator in some way, whether it be directly or vicariously. That struggle is omnipresent in every character, a struggle of genuine connection or unrequited love, of child abandonment or unjustifiable hatred. That struggle that a lot of people deal with resonates within these characters and what they do, the motivations they have, and the histories they possess.  Another notable facet is the soundtrack. You can create tone through anything in the story: the environment, the way characters speak, the way they dress, things that happen to the characters. It takes a notable appreciation of not only music, but of emotional drive of the relationship of character and world to have it become the driving force in how the game feels. Anybody can listen to 'Megalovania' and say that's a great song. However, with songs like 'Hopes and Dreams/SAVE the World' and 'Battle Against a True Hero' that show a different kind of emotional connection, a kind of worried, tense, ultimately sad atmosphere that tells the player that there's something much more significant, much more poignant happening than simply fighting a battle without using any words, those songs establish the tone far better than any number of big, passionately spoken words could ever hope to accomplish.  I talk about emotion a lot throughout this review because that's where this game truly shines brightest: the emotion it has, the true beating heart it always has. As much as I hate to sound like a 'le wrong generation' fedora-asshat, a lot of games these days just don't have emotion, or at least the kind of emotion that seems to evoke others to share in that emotion. Undertale just... does. It's kind of like a child, in that it seems so perfectly innocent in its own feelings until the concept of choice is introduced. A child can be taught to love rather than hate and vice versa. A child can be taught to defy expectation, meet it, or simply be disappointing. Undertale reacts like a child would to your choices: if you react nicely and positively to characters, the game points into a nicer, kinder direction of story, while growing in maturity as everything progresses,   eventually coming to a peak with an emotionally devastating battle with an old friend at the end.   If you react cruelly and negatively, however, the game grows darker and darker, a bleakness forms within the world and yourself. Characters become afraid of you and the once-imposing idea of death becomes something so completely casual, like a child learning about the constant death happening around him. The numbness grows.  It's very difficult to accurately describe this game in simple words because it necessitates emotional investment or detachment in order to truly understand and appreciate it. It doesn't look the best, but that's incredibly irrelevant when you actually get into the story itself. The gameplay is fun and different (I'll avoid innovative because I doubt this is the first game to utilize that certain system of battle and communication) and it's deep and immersive. The story and the heart of the game is the true star here, however.   10/10:

Alright here goes my diddly darn review of Undertale folks.  (This will most likely be rambly and inaccurate, please do not buy this game based off my opinion, or do, I'm powerless to stop you.)  Alright let's start with the diddly darn gameplay, your SOUL, the culmination of your being is represented as a little red cartoon heart inside a black background, white border box. To survive, you must use the arrows to avoid white 'bullets' that are created from the Monster you are fighting. The attacks can range from flames scircling you with small gaps to escape through each ring of fire, to small flies coming close, stoping, and shooting for your SOUL. Every attack is unique and has challenge to it. Frogs that jump for your soul, dogs that run at you, blue attacks that won't hurt if you don't move, orange attacks that won't hurt if you move through them, I'm never bored fighting an enemy in this game.  Now the freakin' story. It's touching, it makes you feel, no matter what ending you get, unless you're SOULless of course . . . but let's steer away from that. You make your own ending due to how you acted while Underground. The current state of the Underground is told to you througha phone call from one of the characters at the end of the game. Everyone could be alive and happy with you, or they could want you dead, it depends on what kind of person you are. This is why the game would be best played without story spoilers, as it may influence your choices.  THE MUSIC. The music in this game is exciting, mysterious, saddening, it fills you with DETERMINATION from time to time, no matter what, the chosen music seems to always fit the situation you are in. Battling agianst a true hero of the Monsters? Let's get some hot tambourine in there, some shakers and bells, feel like you're in an intense fight. On a date with a handsome skeleton friend? Let's keep it light hearted and fun, exciting and interesting. Beating the game? How about an adventureous, mysterious song playing for you, luring you back to the game?  GRAFIX. In my own, personal experience, I have not played a game with a similar art style to Undertale. I recently began watching a blind playthrough of the game Earthbound, which did look similar, but I've not   played   a game similar to this. Over (or should I say Under) world sprites gave me a good idea of all the colors and a general look of the character to get ready for the impending and unavoidable battle with the character, where, while they will not be colored for the most part, you will of course see more detail on them, which is where it all comes together for me. For example, let's say we meet a character in a purple dress. We can't exactly make out details of said article of clothing yet, but we know the coloration. And we can't seem to call out an eye color. In the impending battle with said character, we can see the detail of the dress clothing, and can now see an eye color due to the eyes being bigger and clearer. The two forms of the characters, in the Overworld and in battle both help you form an idea of what the character looks like, even if both are missing some major or minor details.  tHE cOMEDY. If you decide you want to have a good time with this game, I think it will crack you up a lot, I know made me. Before I got the game, I watched one video of the game where a scene where quite a good time was had was shown. And I could NOT stop laughing, the comedy was non stop there, and even when I played that part myself I had a similar reactions, noticing things I didn't before. Anything from a potted plant, a small chair, a 'water sausage', or a bed can produce humorus text for your reading pleasure by your generic narration text. I have a good amount of faith this game will make you laugh and have fun. Yes, it will make you cry, it will make you angry, and it will make you confused, but it will do all of those right too, and handle its comedy well when it uses it.  In conclusion, Undertale is a fun experience that I think a lot of people will enjoy, and you should certainly get it. But don't take my word for it, I was gifted the game for absolutely NO REASON from someone I just met! So I didn't spend any money and would not be aware of the fact of it being a waste of money if it was!  (Wait, this game came out in like september, I'm sure thre are like a million better reviews . . . what am I doing? Whatever. WHATEVER. WHATEVER!! This will still be good!)

So after owning Undertale for over six months I think it’s time I explained why this game is a must for gamers.   First of all a bit of backstory, when I first discovered Undertale it was though the steam queue, in what I believe was September 2015. The second I saw it, I hit “Not interested” To put simply this review will be why I regret making that decision. Over the next 3 months I would hear how Undertale is an amazing game that is worthwhile, it was special, it was different. This caused me to be cynical about it, but never the less I was interested in the idea of not having to kill anyone. After getting a few recommendations from friends as well as youtubers I watched, I got the game on the 26 of December during the steam winter sale. Undertale would then join the list of games I wish I’d bought at full price.  You may notice a lot of reviews don’t exactly give a lot of details about the game, chances are you’re like me (or what I was) thinking just how much of this, “you need to know as little as possible to truly enjoy the game” is legit. I have to say this is accurate. You will on most accounts enjoy the game more.   The characters are funny and lovable; you will likely become invested in them despite how little time is spent with them. Even those “enemies” you get a sense of personality, and who they are. To do a comparison with other games, when you came across bandit archer number 3750961 and as you fought them did you get any sense of personality, of who they are and what they want to be. No of course not, but Undertale you get exactly that.   There is a lot of thought put into this game; simple things even have a meaning. Things you would never expect, but when you do think on them you get a real sense of how much effort was put in. The website TVtropes can give you an idea, but obviously I’d say do that after finishing the game. (or done all the playthroughs)  If you are a person that gets emotional then prepare for feels, this game does get emotional. The reason Undertale has reached such high marks for me is not only cause it’s one of the few games I wish I’d got at full price, it’s one of only 5 fives, that in my current 22 year life span has ever caused me to cry. Towards the end of my own first playthrough, characters I’d have fought over the course of the game revealed a backstory story that had been slowly made aware to me over the course of the game. It hit hard, I am getting emotional remembering the whole thing, it was just that powerful, the music at the time also helped.   Of course that depends how you play the game, you might get something completely different. The game has 3 endings which are known as Pacifist, Neutral and Genocide and are based on what you’ve done throughout the game.   The music is amazing and really suites the game, with its retro style. It also helps with certain battles as you play along to the rhythm.  As for the mechanics, I’m not entirely sure how I’d describe it but the closest I would say it comes to is bullet hell, with a mix of the impossible game for some battles. Each one is different and suites those you are battling. It’s one thing to say they are easy to learn but boy can it be hard to master them. In fact the mechanics are one of the few legitimate complaints I see people making about the game (they didn’t like it cause of the battle mechanics) so a bit of a warning there for people.  Hopefully my review has helped you make a decision on if to get this game, I definitely recommend it (duh). There is more I could say but that would be revealing possibly too much.

Wow, where do I begin? This game is the most fantastic thing I have ever been able to experience. Once you have gotten into it you can feel the love that was put into it. The music is phenomenal. Absolutely immersing and emotionally driving. The characters are extremely lovable, and all are quirky in their own ways; when I 'finished' the game I felt like these guys were my family. The gameplay is really engaging and unique, a huge step up from games like Earthbound. The combat system never grew old as the further the game progressed the more unique elements were. The story was heart wrenching, and I cried quite a few times. The humor was a nice layer on top of the deep story and lore and i constantly cracked up when I played this. This is more than just a videogame. This is a story. An experience. One that I hope anyone would pay for just to enjoy. Please, buy this game, you won't regret it. And if you do... Well than I guess you didn't have enough.... DETERMINATION!

I played this a while back but I figure I'll leave a postive review because I do think highly of the game. The thing is, Toby Fox is right. He made a game that's probably a 7 or 8. The reason it has the popularity it does isn't because of particularly well-written characters or a highly compelling story, or even a few experimental ideas. No, UNDERTALE is great because of what it is compared to everything else around it. The ideas it has are pretty small, the GAME is pretty small, and yet those flourishes stand out amongst the frankly grey and brown world of the games that surround it.  Most people write reviews like this for the game and that should be telling. It's a mediocre niche-RPG with more heart than any game you've ever played and it might just challenge not just how you look at games, but the world around you. Personally I came to regret the monsters I killed as I realized it's less a world of monsters attacking me and more a case of me invading their homes. I wanted those deaths to disappear from my record, but they never did. And I completed the game with an interesting feeling: guilt. I didn't know! It wasn't on purpose! Yet, why should anyone forgive me? Some did, others did not. What an interesting, interesting, interesting game.  That's why people recommend it, that's what makes it fun and if nothing else, when you finish UNDERTALE you will have thoughts on it and that's why it deserves a recommendation.

Let me explain my experience of this game  My cousin told me about it, and I decided to buy it because I was looking for an rpg to play anyway. As I played it, I was purposely trying to make it seem like every other rpg (puzzles, dungeons, boss fights, etc). However, part way through the game, I realized that this isn't just 'another rpg', and that it is truly unique. people may complain about the nes-style graphics, but combined with the witty humor, loveable characters, and mind-blowing chiptune, you get; Undertale.   Pros: -Engaging storyline -Loveable/Relatable characters -FRIGGIN AWESOME MUSIC -Say goodbye to that fourth wall folks -Skeleton/Fish/Dinosaur dating simulator  Cons: -From what I can tell, was made in Gamemaker -Killing people may make you feel bad (is that actually a bad thing though?) -Current state of fandom: Desperate Cancer  Misc: -ALL OF THE DECISIONS COUNT DON'T SAY I DIDN'T WARN YA ABOUT THE FOURTH WALL NOT EXISTING.  10/10 would date a skeleton again  p.s, this review was written sept. 14th, and the 15th is Undertale's first anniversary. Congratulations for making and breaking people for an entire year.

Absolutely incredible! My favourite video game! My favourite aspect of the game is the soundtrack. It is so well thought out and I find myself humming tracks such as Heartache, Megalovania and Battle against a true hero on a regular basis. The battling style is rare, entertaining and at the same time challenging. Each character has their own unique style that is relevant to their character traits. The designs of the monsters of the underground are so varied and beautiful and each one gives the story a little special something. For example the Skelebros Sans and Papyrus give the game a light-hearted and comedic feel where as characters such as Asgore add drama and emotions to the story. Even less important characters such as Naptablook, Mad Dummy and my personal favourite, Muffet add things to the gameand it just wouldn't feel the same without them. Another thing I love about the game is how the ending is different based on the choices you make throughout the run. Overall I must say that Undertale can give you a challenge, make you laugh and tug at your heart strings all at the same time. The playthrough time can be around 4-8 hours long depending on how long the player spends in each key location. This allows the player to try out different options and endings. I would strongly recommend it to everyone of all ages and genders. I thoroughly enjoyed playing Undertale and despite the fact it was mostly spoiled for me by the internet, I felt multiple emotions whilst playing.

At first, I was weary of this game. Thought it was gonna be another overhyped indie title like Five Nights at Freddy's where I found the game to be not as great as others made it out to be. However, I sat down and played it after hearing about it many times and even having friends telling me to check it out. Thoughts in the end? I tried to resist raving about the game but I just couldn't because I ended up loving this game so much. I am with the hype!  The first few moments alone gave me that nostalgic feel to a game that I haven't quite felt since the PS1 days. As much as other games out there try to capture that retro vibe, Undertale went an extra mile and I would say it's all how it plays out at the start. A gameplay style that you wouldn't see everyday, an engaging storyline, lovable and memorable characters and one hell of a soundtrack which all together make this a game you simply cannot ignore. Months after I played through the whole of this game, I am still buzzing about it and even still listen to the soundtrack loads.  Whether you love it or hate it, one has to admit that Undertale has established itself as a game and made itself stood out of the crowd. This to me is the game the industry needs. For those that have yet to play it, I say go for it and see for yourself what the fuss is all about.

When I first saw Undertale, I looked at the store page and wasn't interested. Months later, I'd heard the odd mention of Undertale and had no idea what it was. When I checked it out on Steam, I was surprised to see the little game I had previously ignored. It was cheap so I bought it. I then thoroughly enjoyed the game. Another draw was that there are few system requirements so I can play it on my old netbook and my new PC.  I find Undertale to be an excellent game but it won't be for everyone. If you have the money, then I suggest buying it and simply trying it out. If you don't want to keep it after the first hour of play, then get a refund. If you're willing to try it though I don't think you'll refund it. The only real suggestion I have is to play it on your own without spoilers or a walkthrough. I decided to use a walkthrough on my first run and regret it. I missed out on a lot of excitement and the ability to immerse myself in the game. Mind you, I still love Undertale, but I realize that I would've gotten more out of it if I'd worked through it. So please try to play without help if you can, you won't regret it.    Music:  The music is very good and works to enhance the atmosphere of the game. Some of the music uses a similar melody but with very different takes on it. It reminded me of Yoshi's Story since did something similar. Since I loved Yoshi's Story I'll admit my opinion is biased, it keeps the main theme from becoming monotonous when it plays.   Graphics:  The pixel art is simple, but quickly grows on you. It also serves a purpose. It's easier to look at the pixel art characters and see little pieces of yourself or others in them, especially in a game with an in-depth story and plenty of character development.   Story:  The story is written well and offers many options. Actions may or may not have consequences and you may not see them right away. Even little things can affect the ending, things you may have forgotten that you said or did. What I'm trying to say is that a lot of thought and work was put into the game's story, so you don't mind that it's story-driven. Mind you, if you want to use a shoot and loot mentaltality, there's an option for that too. In the end no one is left out.    Overall:  I really enjoyed Undertale. While not my favourite game it's certainly up there. It's a game I can and do come back to once in a while. In my opinion, it earned the success it currently enjoys. It's a game that breaks the mold and isn't afraid to do something different. It may be a while before we see something similar happen. Especially since you could say Undertale created a new genre. It's difficult to say all the interesting things about this game since saying much of anything could spoil it. So all I can do is suggest again that you try it.

It is incredibly hard to go into what exactly it is about this game that makes it so special, without giving too much away, which is one of the reasons why one should go into this game completely blind.  Synopsis: The game takes place in a world inhabited by humans and monsters, the latter of whom were sealed underground, or more specifically, underneath a mountain, after a war to see who would rule the surface. Years later, in the year 201X, a young human climbs the mountain, called Mt. Ebott, and falls down a hole into the Underground.  The reason it is so hard to review this game is largely because, if you go into it blind, your first experience will likely be one unique to you and only you. This game gives almost all control to the player, and only occasionally interrupts for brief moments when something scripted needs to happen. You have control over just about everything, including how fights go. The game is heavily dependent on the choices you make as the player, and as such, gives you two options that are unique to this title: ACT, in which you are able to choose how you react to a fight, and MERCY, which allows you to spare an enemy once certain conditions are met, or, in some cases, just straight up run away.  You do still have the typical RPG option of fighting, but the game discourages you, dare I say even calls you out for, fighting and killing enemies. This game treats enemy deaths uniquely compared to just about every other RPG I've played: when an enemy is dead, they stay dead. For keeps. Sure, you can always reset, but the game isn't going to let you forget that easily, and will constantly bring back your sins to haunt you in one way or another.  This game also understands the concept of Karma fairly well, as while the bosses and enemies are difficult even in a run in which you don't kill a single thing, they are absolutely nothing in comparison to what's waiting for you if you decide to kill everything.  In addition to ACT and MERCY, this game's mechanics are highly unique to an RPG of it's kind: battles are fought in a bullet-hell type of scenario, in which you control your 'soul' within a small window box and are forced to avoid enemy attacks. This allows for gameplay in which you absolutely NEED to be involved, you can't just press 'Attack' or 'Guard' and expect to just sit back as the game does it for you.  Game mechanics aside, this is probably one of the most beautifully-written stories to have come out in the last decade, dare I say in gaming history. It isn't as simple as 'save a princess', and it's not nearly as complex as 'a demon god from the future wants to destroy the past because backstory'. It leaves a lot to inference and imagination, without ever sacrificing detail or necessary information, and, depending on the path you take, could either be heart-wrenchingly bittersweet, or an emotionally-destructive rollercoaster of numbness.  The characters, too, are some of the most well-written, three-dimensional, emotionally-invested characters I have ever seen in a game. They can be either friend or foe, depending on your choices, but no matter which one they are, they will elicit some kind of emotional response from you.  The music is absolutely stunning, written and composed by Toby Fox, the creator of the game, as well as the creator of the Earthbound Halloween Hack, which this game appears to borrow some ideas from. It consists largely of leitmotifs, and each track is played at just the right moment to elicit a desired response. Probably my favorite track in terms of timing is 'Undertale', a song that plays towards the end of a 'neutral' run. By this point, there is no turning back, and all you can do is march forward to face the final boss of the main game, and the song fits the moment perfectly as realization after realization strikes you right in the face and doesn't let up for even a second, leading up to one of the best and most-well-built-up-to scenes in the entire game, dare I say in the history of games.  Undertale is, at it's a core, a deconstruction of Role-Playing Games, if not games in general, and by the time you have finished it, or at least, finished it as far as you are willing to, it will have reshaped how games appear in your eyes. It will make you question not only how games will learn and improve from this title, but it will force you to look at yourself and do some serious personal reflecting.  That being said, nothing is without it's flaws, and while I can personally look past them, I should at least mention that they are present. The characters, as well-written as they are, may get a little grating to certain people. The music as well ranges from brilliant to good, and the good tracks may not be everyone's cup of tea. This game is also one that is mainly for fans of retro JRPGs, such as Earthbound or Final Fantasy, and people who don't like RPGs (or bullet-hells, for that matter) may not find as much value in it as someone who does.  Undertale, to me, is perfect, not in the sense that it has no flaws, but more in the same sense that Tetris is perfect: There are very few ways in which it screws up, and when it does screw up, it is mostly based around the player's personal opinion.  9.9/10

Undertale is definitely one of my top 5 rated games. I've replayed it twice (both times on the True Pacifist route), and it hasn't failed to make me cry happy happy tears. The characters are cute and have relatively well-rounded personalities - even the random encounter monsters have evident feelings and goals - which really makes you question how you should play through the game. The soundtrack is different and very well made. The fight mechanic is very unique, however, exposition - particularly when in a battle with boss monsters - can drag the fight out for far too long, which becomes very frustrating, escpecially if you're having difficulty. The pixel style is cute - I love the fight scene pixel characters, but more detail could have been put into the environment in some areas. Overall, this game will punch you in the feelings whichever route you choose to take.

I would highly recommend Undertale. At first I thought it looked super-ghetto, and I mean, it does, but it's actually an amazing game and it's very funny if you play it right. It's one of my favorites and I'm sure it'll become a classic.  The characters are really likable, so much so that I played without killing anyone and I haven't had the heart yet to play a neutral route because I still don't want to kill any of them. The plot is enjoyable (and varies depending on how you play; there's replay value) and it's interesting to speculate what the mysteries unsolved in the game are all about.   In a way this game makes you think a little bit too, since it's about the choices that you make and how you have to live with the consequences thereof. Particularly, the idea of mercy even in the face of opposition; this being the best way to play. This is true in real life as well. And it makes you think: Do I really have to try every possible decision just to see what happens, if it means I have to kill? Even if the characters are not real, but I like them, will I still kill them? What do my choices say about me?

Everyne claims that this game has 'rememberable characters', but they all have a counterpart in mother or earthbound.The only things that even make them rememborable is the fact that the characters arent even human, and that there are so few to actually make you your 'friend'. All of the other characters in Snowdin are barely rememberable, again, only being slightly rememborable is their appearence. Unlike in other good rpgs, is that Undertale dosen't give you that mych time wih the characters, onky giving you time once you beat the final boss. Another point about this game that's 'so rememberable and good' is the fact that the point of the game is to make friends and spare every moster, and if you don't play it the way the game wants you to, you will get bashed. If Iwanted to make friends, I wouldn't make NPC's from an RPG them for sure.all of the areas are quite unrememberable, and like the characters, they all have a counterpart in mother or earthbound. The fighting is probably the most redeeming quality of the whole thing. The whole gist of the 'fighting' minigames' where you have to withstand a certain amount of time to get back to the menue, and spare the monster, and each boss fight puts their own little twist on it. Another one of the very few good thing about the game is the muic, being some of the best i've heard in an indie game. One last note, something that really isnt about the game, but the communiy is utter garbage. Constant shippings, NSFW art, and just overall nasty art of some of your favorite 'characters'. Overall, if you want a good RPG, just get Earthbound or one of the Mother games.

When I first saw this game on the market, I thought it was some dumb cutesy game that cared more about sending a message about how violence isn't the answer and blah blah. Immediately marked it as not interested. Month or so later, I pick it up because my friends are all talking about how great it is and telling me I should play it.  My first impression could not have been farther from the reality. While yes, Undertale does have somewhat of an underlying message about how violence isn't the answer, it manages to be a deep, engaging, funny RPG with great gameplay that deviates from the standard RPG formula in ways that actually make your skill matter more than the amount of time you've invested in the game. The characters are very well thought out, the story is well realized. I really have nothing bad to say about Undertale. It's one of the best games I've ever played, I just wish I could experience it blindly again.   shame the true reset doesn't reset the player's memories of the game

Undertale is an RPG which- Okay you all know the ♥♥♥♥ing plot of the game by now.  Undertale is an okay game, with a nice plot that joins in together. It isn't as extreme as everyone says it is, but hey, it's better than the FNaF plot. If you're willing to play an RPG based around the Mother series with bullet hell fighting mechanics, then go and buy the game. Just don't expect the game to be too long, though. It's actually pretty short.  Notice how in the first paragraph that I said it's okay and I didn't say I love it with all my will and might and want to marry it. This is because the game can sometimes go at it's own pace, which is usually very slow. For example, in the 'final level', you're greeted with a bunch of monsters that don't attack you, they just say stuff that goes more into detail about the Undertale plot. This is all good and swell but you can't skip this. So you're just gonna be walking up to the castle when a bunch of monsters show up and make you want to die.  All in all, Undertale is an okay game and I recommend it.

If you caught this review with your eye, please don't scroll anymore further. I need you to read this. I regret not creating a review earlier when Undertale was one of the hottest games on Steam. It still is a hot game to this day, and this review will convince you that the fact is true. Undertale is your classic 16-Bit RPG that every gamer knows about whether they are young/old or inexperienced/experienced in gaming. When I say that it's a game that every gamer knows about, I mean that the game has the same aspects a classic RPG would have such as having to choose a decision during a conversation with an NPC. The fighting style is also similar to all classic RPGs. You have numerous boxes that say 'FIGHT.' 'ACT,' and what not. I'm not going any further into those aspects as it would drive the topic of this review astray. Now what if I told you that although Undertale seems like another one of those RPGs where you grind and move on, it will be one of the most unique games you have ever played. Now look at the store page of the game, and read the description of the game. It says, 'UNDERTALE! The RPG game where you DON'T have to destroy anyone.' Don't take that description lightly because every single choice you make in the game will drastically affect the future of your progression route. Every monster that you kill, every monster that you don't kill, and everything you say to NPCs. Those are the three main choices you'll make throughout the game that I can remember. Anyway, all those choices will decide the fate of the Underground, which is the place you're trying to get out of. It will even decide the fate of your character and the whole world. You're probably wondering how that's possible. You'll see soon enough... Now let's conclude the review with this: Undertale is a game that takes you on an emotional/comedic rollercoaster. Your ultimate goal is to escape the underground, but the real question is: how will you do it? Let me give you a little hint: think of these monsters as actual people with feelings. Don't want to do that? Well then, you're going to have a bad time.

Oh my gosh, the amount of praise I could give this game... When i first saw this game pop up, I was skeptical at first. I didn't know what to think about it. The graphics were crappy, it looked really simplistic... i just didn't want to play it. After buying it and playing it, im pretty sure all of that has changed. This game is a ton of fun to play and is kind of artisitic in the fact that nobody has to die. Although that battles can get frequent, the battles were still fun.There are a ton of secrets and jokes lying around for you to discover, including a library of just plain terrible puns. All the characters you encounter you will remember for some time, each with a distinct personality. And the music... OH THE MUSIC... Although that plenty of it is 16 bit, its still a delight to listen to. In fact, while i was writing this, i was listening to the soundtrack through the Steam Browser. I have nothing but positives for this game, aside from the fandom... oh dear god did something go wrong there. Careful, this game is easily spoiled... But aside from that, GET THIS GAME. It WILL be the most well spent 10$ USD on the steam market.

As for my final words here, don't tread near the fanbase that indulge themselves in this game and praise it to the high heavens if you ever feel like giving this game a try. Undertale at its core is a pretty simple game. You play a human child who has fallen into the underground monster realm and must make your way out. The puzzles and game mechanics are fairly simple, there are some but not many dialogue choices, the graphics and art are nothing to write home about...  What makes it great are the details. A unique and very fun fighting system, quirky characters, great music, silly monsters, sometimes scary monsters! Makes for a fun and vibrant world that's easy to get attached to. But the real tipping point is the pacifist run. It's not only viable, but in my opinion lots of fun and makes for the best in game experiences.  If you like quirky, sometimes silly games with an edge of seriousness I definitely recommend

Well, I was getting a bit sick of all the artificially emotional and wannabe artsy games even back when they were free and ran on Flash... And I was a bit afraid that Undertale would be like those. Well it isn't, and I'm glad.  Its combination of weird and heartwarming reminds me of Adventure Time. The game design itself (both in quality and quantity) is up to par with A-list SNES titles back in the day.  Pros: It has references to Kikiyama's obscure game Yume Nikki. It features dogs petting humans. There is a (usable and arguably useful) item called 'dog residue' in it. There's a boat with Doge / Shibe head and legs.  Cons: You won't like it if you don't like old JRPGs. The Steam community forum is worse than /b/.

This game is amazing.   It close resembles the Mother games. This game has one of the best soundtracks in video game history. It is similar to Earthbound/Mother2 except this game is more emotional. The game is goofy and funny with a charming humor like Earthbound had. Undertale has an interesting mechanic that you use while acting. When the enemy is attacking, you have to physically avoid the attack. Along the journey of the game you make new friends and when it comes to the genocide ending you don't really want to kill them. If you feel like this game is too expensive, with the different endings this game has to offer and all of its replay value I think its well worth the price. If you like RPG's or just love story and character driven games, check this out.

I fully expected not to enjoy this game.  Firstly, I wasn't a fan of the art style. The main character wasn't very detailed, the battle screen looked boring. But then I'm exploring a dark area that's lit up by glowing blue crystals and flowers, or I'm walking as a silhouette against a overlook of a faraway fortress that I think, 'oh that's clever.' The simple battle screen begins to crumble or change depending on the character I'm up against, and again I'm thinking, 'oh, that's clever.'  Secondly, I didn't think the battle system would be fun. I thought it was another turn based battle system. Nope, you control a little heart and avoid all kinds of ridiculous objects being thrown at you from every direction. It's always something new, and often correlates to that character or the current story. So again I'm thinking, 'oh, that's clever.'  The game starts out with some simple puzzles, but eventually they get much more clever.  Eventually, I realize I've seen so many clever things in the game, that Undertale really is a clever, well designed game; an experience worth having. No single concept is entirely new, but all of the concepts are put together so perfectly that it weaves together a great game.  So, the gameplay is worth it after all, but that's not really what it's lauded for. The story is a focal point, or so I hear.  Sure, the story is well written. You get some choices along the way as you discover yet another tale about humans versus monsters. But I don't think that is what really sets this game apart: it's the characters. They are mostly monsters, but they feel so very human-like, with their dialogue, their personalities, their faces, their mannerisms, their homes... that it puts weight to the story that makes it much more meaningful. You can hang out with a ghost who invites you into his home to just sit on the floor and imagine the stars in space... JUST BECAUSE. It doesn't affect the main story, but it affects your perception of the world of Undertale - it makes it more real. You feel a connection to the monster who tells you his latest pun-filled joke. You feel something for the monster who just wants to call to talk.  The game is not very long, although it warrants another playthrough or two. But it's an experience worth having. And it is oh so clever.

NOTE: The following has spoilers. if you wish to experience this game to it's fullest, do NOT read this review. you have been warned...  i bought this game just for kicks. i'm from the fnaf fandom, so i had lowered expectations. i never really liked these kinds of rpgs where you walk around, battle, etc. but undertale is DIFFERENT, a LOT different. the whole game is based around one question: to kill or not to kill? the game also has at least three different endings: pacifist: don't kill anyone neutral: i assume it's kill some, don't kill others and genocide: kill everything already it's unique. but it gets better. once you kill a character, they are DEAD. usually in games they just drop down and say that you've defeated them. in pokemon, for example, they just faint. but in undertale, they remain dead unless you reset your game. resetting also plays a big role, as the main antagonist (flowey) will call you out for it. now, i'm not going to get into the lore, that i'm leaving you to experience. then there's the humor, which is BY FAR the BEST i've seen. here's an example:  papyrus and sans: spin in circles until they face away from you papyrus: omg is that a human?! sans: no, i think that's a rock papyrus: oh sans: what's that in front of the rock? papyrus: O...M...G!!!!  i wish i could say more, but it's raining, so i'll have to leave it hear.  i give the game a 9.3/10   truly worth playing...

I don't even know what to say here. Words can't seem to describe how much I adore Undertale. The game begins like any other. You're given a bit of backstory, you wake up as your player character, and you begin exploring the world. But oh, god, this is not your everyday RPG. Undertale has stayed with me emotionally and mentally even after I have finished it. It's unlike any other game I've ever played. The characters are all so well-developed--you really, really get to know every part of these people. They might not be 'humans', but they feel human. The characters alone are more than enough to drive this game. Then there's the multiple endings facet. This game allows you to make choices about who you are, about what's going to happen to you. I'm a sucker for choice-driven games, but this one gets so meta that it feels like the characters themselves are watching you; like they know who you are and what you're doing. Some speak directly to the player. In this world, it's kill or be killed--or is it? You have to decide what's right here. You are the one who decides if you'll try to save everybody, or if you'll destroy everything in your path. And if you regret your decision and decide to reset and re-play? It doesn't matter. The game doesn't take kindly to forgetting what you've done, good or bad. Don't go into this game thinking it's going to be a lighthearted kiddie game. Depending on what you decide to do, it can get very dark, very quickly. It can be an RPG with a good, lighthearted ending, or it can become the stuff of nightmares. The soundtrack is phenomenal. I listen to the music almost every day! It does a fantastic job at setting the mood for the game, and the melodies are catchy and help you to get to know the characters and setting. I also happen to love the game's humor. The puns, the dry humor, the things that don't seem funny at first but are funny upon closer inspection...It's one of those rare games that delves into 'actually really f*cking funny' territory. But don't get caught up in the laughs--it's a serious game with a storyline that can be heartwarming or heartbreaking. It'll leave anybody filled with determination.  Rating: 10/10. Would recommend.

When I heard there was an RPG inspired by Earthbound I had to see what the excitement was all about. Earthbound is one of my favorite RPGs of all time, so to heard that someone made a game that rivals that level of quality was worth raising eyebrows. To my surprise, this game took a completely different turn than I expected. Here I was think this game would be a carbon-copy of an already well-known Nintendo title, but there's more to looks than meets the eye. Undertale is a story-driven RPG where a genderless child must travel through an underground world filled with monsters of all kinds in hopes of returning to their home back on the surface. Here the character encounters a goat lady, a talking flower, an a pair of goofy skeletons. One of this game's strongest assets is its characters and dialogue. Despite having a genderless character be the protagonist and a mute, the side characters are what steal the show. The moment that shorter skeleton, Sans, appear I knew this was going to be a very enjoyable game. This, however, is not all comedy-based as there are some very tender and heart-wrenching moments that makes makes the player feel all that more important to the story. The music is also really impressive. Some of it sports 8-bit synthesizers, rag-time jazz, and metal. This game has a lot of spirit when it come to intereacting with characters, which the game over screen telling you repeatedly to 'Stay Determined.' Oddly enough, the battle system is what intrigued me the most as the game gives you the opportinity to 'Fight' or 'Spare.' Unlike games such as The Walking Dead, where some events can change the story internally, this game goes above and beyond and makes the entire game effected by every decision made by the player in determining how many enemies you choose to fight. When the goat lady told me to 'strike up a friendly conversation' I was afraid that this will would be a trap and get me killed for now knowing better, but after I killed the first enemy the game made me feel bad for that decision, and believe me, this game will continue to torment you by giving reminders or your mistakes. Despite this game's somewhat disturbing message about humanity, it does well in providing you with enough information about the world you explore and intereact as you solve puzzles to return home. For some reason it says I've barely played for two hours, but nevermind that because I've played this game offline for far longer than it says so. This game's art style does show resemblence to that of Earthbound, and the battles always remind me of its predecessor, Earthbound Beginnings (NES). Overall, this game is one big emotional roller coaster that will keep you wondering. For a game that drew inspiration from a Super Nintendo RPG classic, it's no wonder this game got as much popularity as it does now.

Played for the first hour, I was wondering what’s so novel about this game. In the second hour, I started thinking: “I get it; I get what this game is aiming for.” Third hour, I started to dig the tunes. Fourth hour, I started to fall in love with the characters. Fifth hour, I looked past the simplistic look of the game and became wide-eyed about the world. Sixth hour, I had my big emotional moment. Seventh hour, I went: “I thought I got it, but this game keeps on surprising me.” Eighth hour, I couldn’t put it down and needed to get to the end. Ninth hour, I was like: “Oh ♥♥♥♥, what the ♥♥♥♥ is this that’s just happening? I don’t even…” I finished the game… … Tenth hour, I started over.

Don't look at my playing time, since about ~120 hours of my life were eaten away by this masterpiece... while I was offline. But. This is not 'just a game' for me. It's something bigger and heartwarming and something that set me onto being a better person. It's something that helped me a lot throughout my latest breakdown, and what really cheered me up when nothing else could. Undertale is a tale about LOVE, EXPeriences and DETERMINATION. What do you put into these words is your choice. It's also about you and who you are. About who you decide to be and deciding wether you want to be a player of the game – or a person. Do you seek all the choices that game shows you, or abandon this cause so you wouldn't do bad choices? Do you help everyone and with that help yourself, or you abandon all hope and choose NO MERCY? That's all on your conscience.  This masterpiece, unlike a giant portion of the fandom, is something that teaches us not about making FIGHTS, but about moments when we should ACT, and show MERCY, and how sometimes it's okay to FLEE and HEAL yourself.  I never gained LOVE, but I gained love. And I learned how to be better. That I am better than I think I am. And I am so happy that the people that made this game for me and MILLIONS of other people, and characters that were in Undertale, did everything in their power to show us a wonderful story and HELP all of us. I am grateful. I am alive.

Undertale is unique game with many twists. The art design is neat, the music is great, and the characters are rememorable. You do not have to kill every enemy you meet, vendors will not buy stuff from you (for their reasons), and you have to solve many interesting puzzles. If you want something different from traditional RPGs, this would be it since using a combination hybrid of bullet-hell/RPG elements while keep a great story to tell. Word of advice if you are late: the fanbase got very 'unstable' when the game became popular, so I recommend you keep away from most of it. Not all of it is bad, but just avoid the degradative materials      *A friend's review after dealing with the fanbase :^)* Undertale is the 2015 GOTY for autistic fur♥♥♥♥, replacing 2014's winner Five Nights at Freddy's. After it was funded by e-begging on Kickstarter, this mediocre indie role-playing game is well-loved for its gripping plot, amazing gameplay and the exceptional soundtrack that was composed in only the best software possible. The game doesn't offer a whole lot of selling points, other than the fact that you can date a skeleton and is also a ripe source for delicious furry Rule 34.

To explain what makes Undertale works so well would be to spoil it, but I'll do my best to avoid that. It gives the impression of being a standard RPG with an interesting bullet hell twist, but eventually, you come to realize that not all is as it seems. For anyone who plays video games with some regularity, especially RPGs, Undertale tackles subject matter which you might not actively think about, but is fascinating to think about. The core gameplay is surprisingly fun, and your interaction with the world leaves a far greater impact than anything that I've ever seen in a video game.  If you know nothing about Undertale, turn off the internet for a while (especially from the cancerous fanbase), sit down for a couple of afternoons, and enjoy the show.

Found Undertale to be strange, fascinating, funny, frustrating and brilliant in places. I went in blind in this game, and while I had to look up certain boss fights later on the web (just to be sure of my approach), played the rest of the game without consulting the interwebs.  No doubt, the game (the maker actually) is very smart and ingenious. The game levels and design are excellent. Despite the boss fights seemingly daunting, the game encourages and facilitates the player to win- that part's very well thought out.  And yet, I thought the game did have some major flaws, the primary one being the confusion for the player between killing and defeating. At one point, to my dismay, I killed a character I had definitely not been wanting to, and just the exploration and experimentation while grasping the cryptic nature of conversations led to it. Having gone in blind, there was no way for me to know if there were other endings possible to this particular chapter where the character does not die. Neither was the player offered a choice to spare or not, in this instance. At another point in the game, I was stuck for a while for just the opposite reason. When it turned out (courtesy interwebs) that fighting was the only way out.  The second minor quibble I have is I have no idea about dogs and items related to them. There are some more similar quirks in the game.  Third, the controller thumb stick did not feel reliably responsive during gameplay.  Four, poorly worded questions like 'will you take this item' from a certain setting. When playing a game where ethics matter, one won't just pick up stuff without asking, that could be valuable to them. But the game will punish player if (s)he doesn't.  TL:DR version: The game makers did not clearly differentiate between defeating and killing an adversary. For a game of such refined sensibility, I consider this a big oversight. A 9/10 from me otherwise. A charming, quirky, unusual game. It's heart is in the right place and it deserves applause for it.

You really won't be disappointed with Undertale, and at only $10 or less this game is a treasure.

There are games that you beat and be done with it, you write it down on a list of games that you beaten(if you do that) and move on. However, this is a game that truly sticks with you after you finish it. I have played through so many games and only a few really stuck out and showed me what gaming is like at it's best. Undertale is one of those games.  Battle system is fresh, characters are great, story flourishes, soundtrack is increadible.   I would say some 'negatives' are (because no game is perfect!): -Half of battles are experimental (Meaning minor trial and error in battles, especially for pacifist runs. Not a bad thing, especially for people that played RPG's back in the 90's) -The game is very short for an RPG. I would consider this game an experience before a full RPG. -You    might need to 'continue a new adventure' if you want the true ending, if you really care for another go.    -Stay out of the fandom, it's overwhelming.(nothing to do with the game, but a great tip LOL)  Other than that, totally recommend it. Worth every penny. A must have!

Writing a review for Undertale is nearly impossible. Undertale is a game which benefits most heavily if you know very, very little about it. The story is amazing. The gameplay seems simple, but uses that simple setup in ways that will keep surprising you until the very end.   If you don't know why you should play Undertale yet, you are EXACTLY the person who should play it most. I'd probably be happy if I paid 20 bucks for it, so 10 is a steal, and if you can get it on sale it's the best 5 dollars you'll spend all year.  Play Undertale.
NO. I'm not crying. Okay I am. This game pulls my heart strings way too much.

Simply put, this game raises the bar for what we can expect from the medium. The game pays homage to the best of the classics, and yet transgresses all medium conventions; it is cloying in its humor yet genuinely touching; and it is ostensibly simple yet deeply complex in a way no other game I've ever played is. I feel everyone gets at least one 'litmus test' game, movie, album, or book, where if someone you've met doesn't like it you know you won't ever understand them - this game is one of them for me. You are doing yourself a deep disservice as a fan of video games if you skip this one.

If you haven't watched any playthroughs, I highly recommend that you play it yourself. It's one of those games that I wish I could completely forget, just so I could relive it.  Get it on a discount if you can, and please, ignore the horrible fanbase.

Hey so im changing my review to be serious. I love this game. If you ignore some of the fanbase and look at the people who like the game for the game, its amazing. The story is pretty great, and it actually has some choice and speculation allowed. It also makes some of the best characters I've ever met, all of whom I have a deep connection with. Also look at the music. I love it, not just because it's great music, but because of the amazing stories it tells. Each song has its meaning, and it's part of what makes this game great, not to mention how the songs intertwine, showing the character connections and emotions, becoming part of the scenes and zones. People are talking about how it will die out and fade away, but I personally think that they just don't like what the game stands for or what they heard, because the game is so beautifully crafted that there is no possible way that the game's leaving public eye for a while. Try it. Might not be your cup of tea(or bowl of spaghetti) if you don't enjoy heavily story based work, but, who knows.  (its pretty great)

If you've somehow avoided this game and everything to do with it in the last year it's been out, all I can say is you've half missed out and half lucked out.  Put quite simply, this is one of those must-play games. Beautifully crafted characters, solid game mechanics and a storyline that makes you question the things we take for granted are all doused in a gorgeous soundtrack that perfectly manipultes your emotions.  It's equal parts homage to, invention on and interrogation of classic RPGs. Don't let the bullet-hell-esque gameplay put you off - it's challenging enough to be fun for everyone without being overly difficult (unless you choose to make it so) and is varied up enough to stay fresh without huge increases in difficulty.  I won't say much more about it, because Undertale really is best enjoyed blind. If you dig the Mother series, classic RPGs or, like me, have a penchant for subversive media in general, Undertale is a beautiful experience you won't soon forget.

I don't know how you haven't played this yet. If you haven't yet, it's likely you never will.  Essentially: Play the game. It does for RPGs what Spec Ops: The Line did for shooters. No manuals, no wikis, no playthrough watching if you can help it. The comparision to Spec Ops might seem a little weird if you've played neither, but essentially? Heartwrenching storytelling that doesn't forsake being an actual game, like a visual novel might (no those aren't games). Where Spec Ops has proper combat and ammo count and the like, while having a nice story, Undertale has proper bullet hell fights and resource management.  Also, a lot of care went into the games, with little details that I can't tell you because spoilers and it'll be better for you to experience it for yourself, anyways. Go play it.

Everyone praises this game for it's innovative story, that breaks conventions by making all the enemies actually have character. I'll keep this review quick, because saying absolutely anything about the content of this game could potentially spoil the experience of playing this game for this first time. This is a game that is best experienced going into it blind, with no expectations; I wouldn't even watch the trailer if I were you. What I will say is that Undertale is one of the most expertly crafted games I have ever played, and almost every aspect of the game features some of the most brilliant design choices I've ever seen in game. Don't let the community that has developed around this game online turn you off; Undertale does everything right and goes beyond.

UT things, like Urinary Tract Infection, are mostly bad (yes, I know it's a UTI thing, but shut up). Then a special man brought us a good UT thing. This man is called Toby Fox. Toby Fox began with a question, a question that ruptured the very fabric of RPGs. 'What if there was a RPG,' Toby thought, 'that allowed you not to hurt a soul?' Then it was built up, through code and thought. Think of it as a child, they could be innocent but also become vile, like a bully. This 'child' was Undertale. Undertale is a RPG where you don't have to be a hunter and a deer trying to live it's life. Like a hunter, they try to kill the deer, but maybe you thought the hunter would leave the deer alone. Think of yourself as a hunter, hunting different deer, and you're guided by Undertale. Undertale, as a child, would say that you should leave the deer alone. That is your choice, you may think, but it's a child. Let me ask you personally, would you kill the deer or will you listen to Undertale and give in to the innocent child's nature? I think I mostly hear you claiming to spare the deer, I mean, think of it's characteristics. It's peaceful, and you shouldn't bother it. That's just an example, and it's not over. In Undertale, you meet a variety of characters, and the first two you meet are clear definitions. You know who I'm talking about. Sans and Papyrus are skeletons, and they're brothers. Papyrus is a fun, spaghetti-loving fan favorite. Sans is a fan favorite too, and if you dare go bad but spare him, well, he prefers his Dunkin Donuts with a little sweet flavor. Although if you're going to bag the deer, you shouldn't forget how funny Sans is. Really, Sans seems to be a little COMICal, right?   (Nobody got that joke)  . Sans also has a knack for helping his brother out with puzzles, and he thinks his brother is cool. Whether or not he thinks Papyrus is cool, you can't forget how Papyrus constantly fails but constantly tries to get you captured from his puzzling traps. However, these characters can die if you decide to paint yourself red and get all HORN-y. Now, I believe I'm finished with characters, BUT we're just getting started on the book. So, to briefly describe the game's story without spoilers, I think this will be legit. So after a war between the locked-up monsters and the victorious hoomans, a child with a name falls and meets different characters from Flowey to the King. The child decides to go evil/good by sparing/killing monsters which is fun. Then after some funtime, the child makes it to the surface after facing some bosses. END!!! Now that you heard that, let me tell you Undertale's overall. Undertale is one of those games that will be remembered throughout time, and that's why I nominated it for the 'Most Heartwarming Game' Award during the Steam Award Nominations. What I ask of you, if you enjoyed the game, is to also nominate it for 'Most Heartwarming Game'. If you don't, then that's your choice. Think of this as a favor between fellow strangers on the internet united by god-like Undertale over here. Also, if you agree with this entire review, comment any Sans pun down below. I bet you, these puns will sure be a PUN-ch to the FUNNY BONE.   I bet I'm unfunny ;-;

A heavily-story based RPG with a plot that contains a surprising amount of depth. I will have to say that it was and still is my favourite game but perhaps you might want to play it on your own first before reading any of the analysis on this page since reading many of the negative votes for this game, most of them liked it but decided to downvote it due to it not being as good as other peoples' opinions led them to believe.  My recommendation is buy this game as you would any other RPG (or storybased, since it's more heavy on that side) and experience it for yourself with as little side-knowledge as you can to avoid spoilers. Only one slight problem I will explain, there's only one save slot and the three different routes for the game can easily be scratched out if you do something wrong so, if you don't want to screw up keep reading; if you want to experience this game entirely by yourself stop here.  ====================================================================================    For the neutral route you don't have to worry because you're most likely gonna get it naturally.       For the 'true ending' spare all characters and befriend all main characters.      For the 'bad ending' (and a whole different atmosphere throughout the whole game) kill every monster that pops up until the screen - But nobody came. - shows up.
omg now sale not cool i payed 10.99

Undertale is an amazing game. My favorite in fact. You can play it over and over, even if it is hard to take away an ending at some points. The gameplay is awesome, the characters are fun and have a real effect on the player. The music is to die for!  This game is the full package, feels, comical moments, great gameplay, and oh... did I forget to mention that there are 3 DIFFERENT WAYS TO PLAY THE GAME? And so many endings, it keeps making you go back for more!  The main paths are Neutral, True Pacifist, and the cold, dark, GENOCIDE.  Neutral is where you kill or don't kill, or do both. This path has the most endings and those endings depend on your actions throughout Neutral.  After you've done Neutral, you can play True Pacifist. To complete this path you must have Mercy on every enemy you encounter. And you have to befriend most of the main cast. There's lots of work to be done to have success on this playthrough but it's all worth it in the end.  Then, there's Genocide. You can play this at any time in the game, but I reccommend playing True Pacifist before this one. You must kill every enemy, not just the ones you accidentally run into, but you must search them out and destroy them until nobody is left.  Then there are secrets in the game, whether it be hidden rooms you must hack the game to find, secrets in the game's music tracks, or crazy new enemies, they will always be a thrill to find.  Undertale is a very unique game, I would reccommend to everybody who wants some challenge, fun, laughs, or tears. 10/10. Toby Fox made one hell of a game. :)

Undertale has a surprisingly deep metanarrative not just on RPG tropes, but video games in general. Learning more about it and pondering is quite the experience, but in order to even get to said experience, one must be able to enjoy Undertale's humor. Despite the game's darker elements, for the vast majority of the game, you are going to be spending your time interacting with the game's countless characters who are all nothing short of wacky and surreal. If this type of humor does not appeal to you, then it's really difficult to enjoy everything else Undertale's story has to offer, due to how prevalent the bizzare nature is. If you do enjoy it, or at least don't mind it, then you will more than likely enjoy Undertale's story.  Despite the game being a deconstruction of RPGs, this is not gameplay that I can consider to be that of an RPG. I'm not talking about the interaction with townspeople or item management. I'm talking about the core battle mechanics, which are clearly those of a bullet hell game instead of a role-playing game. Yes, you still have a menu with your typical RPG commands, but those don't really mean much when regardless of what you choose, the name of the game is to dodge obstacles. There will be bosses that put your skills to the test, but as the fight starts, the attacks that are used are rather slow, allowing the player to get used to how the fight works before it decides to speed things up. I think it's brilliant. There are very few attacks in the game that I would deem cheap, and the boss fights manage to spice things up so it does not feel like you're doing the same thing with every fight. I had 0 bullet hell experience prior to Undertale, but I still had a mostly comfortable ride. I did die several times on my first playthrough, but it was never frustrating.  All in all, fantastic game...assuming the style of humor appeals to you.

Wow.  Just wow.  (WARNING! MINOR SPOILERS AHEAD. JUST MINOR ONES)  PROS:  -AMAZING soundtrack that is worth the $9.99 alone.  -Character arcs so emmersive and developed that you cant help but get sucked into it.  -For the first time in forever, I actually gave a ♥♥♥♥ about a character. Not just one but several! I actually cared of what I said and did to them. I felt connected to these characters like no other character in any other video game ever.  -So meta it is down right creepy.  -Looks gorgeous for an 8 bit like game.  -Funny as hell and addicting.  CONS:  -The battle system is bland. You just press a button, and time it right to hit the target... thats it. Toby Fox most likely meant for you not to fight at all but ACTing still is pretty boring. The gameplay in general is pretty bland for an rpg.  -The locations just felt... random I suppose? These play just felt... dumb. The places you travel to are dumb I mean.  -Some of the 'fans' are pure and utter cancer. I don't understand how kids got into this kind of game. Aren't you kids suppose to be playing Call of Duty and saying you fondled my mother and screaming like a baby?  -The game has no problem telling you 'You are an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ for killing us' if you go down the Genocide route. I get it. Thats the point but I know that what I'm doing is wrong so I will pay the consequences later ok game? The game then says 'Oh yes you will. How about we delete your entire save file and prevent you from ever getting the other 2 endings?'. That is so dumb.  Overall a really good game. One I'll never forget and one I hope does the same for you.  7.5/10
